I decided to take a chance on this blower to replace a older 2 cycle one that I gifted to someone.  Upon unboxing the blower I could tell that it was built well with a lot of attention to detail.  I added regular motor oil to the crankcase and added gas.  Once the primer bulb was pumped and the choke was activated, the blower started on the first pull.  It is quiet as the other reviewers said and seems to blow just as well or better than my old blower.  The exhaust is clean which is nice when blowing leaves and dirt from my garage.  It has ALWAYS started on the first pull ever since.  Not having to mix the gas with oil is nice and saves an extra step.  Just a side note, Dolmar is owned by Makita and that is the brand that I have, it is identical to this one, just an red color, not blue.  You might be able to save some money with the Dolmar one as I did.

Update: Three years later, the blower would not run correctly.  It started fine, ran okay for a minute or two then would stop running.  I replaced the carburetor, but it still will not run.  Be advised, not many outdoor power equipment repair shops are familiar with this blower and most say they cannot get any parts to repair it.  So now I am stuck with a dead blower.  I only used the blower sparingly, put in gas stablilizer, changed the oil once a year, so I am not happy with this brand.

This little thing is fantastic! We used it to create a small water feature for our patio with a wide, shallow planter. At first, we suctioned it to a bowl, positioned under the water, and it worked fine. But I wanted to see how it would do floating freely and found that the water sprays up much nicer. I'd guess because the solar panel recieves better sunlight when it floats on top. The bowl we are using is wide enough to keep the water from shooting outside of it so no complaints there. But we experimented a little with a taller, more narrow container and it sprayed out. So I definitely see why there is so much discussion about that. My suggestion is to use the extra suction with the string to anchor it down under the water. That seemed to be the difference for us in how high the water sprayed! I hope that helps! We thoroughly enjoy this! So many options to make an easy to handle, very pretty water feature for little cost!
summary: This little thing is fantastic! We used it to create a small water ...

reviewText: This is a beautiful feeder. I live in the country, with high winds. I replaced a one sided feeder with this one. The birds love it. I have 5 or 6 birds at a time. Cardinals, and finches of all colors, and of course the doves still feed off the ground, for the wind drops a few seeds there for them. The feeder is sturdy, the mesh tight, but birds get the seeds out OK, and so easy to fill. I love the bright red color. The wind did blow the feeder off the sheppard hook, so all I did, was attach an old key ring on top, and it never blew off again.
This fixed our algae problem when the chemical company couldn't. Highly recommended.

Very disappointed. I questioned how this could cut tall weeds around plants and it can't. It just pushes over the top of taller weeds. I have to raise it and drop it down in the taller stuff to make any progress. It may work on shorter flimsy yard grasses but not on heavy growth in my garden. Also, the kit is adaptable to just about ever weed eater known to man. But adaptable and fitting are not the same. Because it does not fit tightly to the shaft diameter of my machine, it is slightly off center and has a vibration in it. It works but wears on your grip after a while. The vibration is bearable if it would just cut the talker weeds!

1. Of course you have to check your traps every day or you may find a dead mouse in one.  I had cleared the mice out of my house last spring and had retired the traps for the summer.  Last week, I was getting them out of storage and found one of the empty traps with a badly decomposed mouse in it.  Guess he/she had crawled into it even though there was no active bait in there -- I use a couple of peanuts, which they love, but perhaps the sent was still there.
2.  The smart mice have figured out that they can turn these things on their side and get out because the door will not stay closed behind them if the trap is on its side!!!  You must put something along side the trap to prevent if from being rolled on its side by a trapped mouse.  They seem to be able to move them around at will once they are trapped inside.  A moved trap may be your first clue that there is a mouse inside.
summary: Traps arenot fool proof -- can be turned on side by trapped mouse.

reviewText:
I'm really happy with my 2 shades. They arrived quickly, were well-packaged, and the color is pretty much as shown. Best of all, they really do keep the rooms significantly cooler.

My shades are 8 feet wide by 6 feet long, and I was able to mount them on stucco (real cement stucco not the foam stuff) by getting concrete anchors from Home Depot. After drilling the holes I filled them with outdoor caulk to keep water from getting in then put in the anchors.  They're holding up very well.

I did order longer cords because the ones that came with the shades were only about 3' long and the bottoms of my shades are 4' off the ground - meaning I had to get a step-stool to reach the original ones. The longer cords came within a few days and are just right.

My shades did come with anchors to keep them from blowing in the wind and those work very well, even in the high winds we get in the afternoon.

One tip for anyone else mounting on stucco: get a regular masonry bit (I burned the tips off the ones that came with the anchors), and use a powerful drill. My old cordless Makita was so slow, and would run down the battery before I got 2 holes drilled - not fun when I was working from a ladder 10' off the ground in hot sun, so I got a corded drill which went through the stucco like butter.

Oh, one other tip: if you want to change the side the pull is on, be aware that there are tiny gear wheels that will fall out when you take the cover off if you're not careful :-(. Fortunately, I had a second one to use as a guide or I'd still be trying to figure out how to get them back in.

reviewText:
These are pretty cool if you have a small area if packed down dirt that needs loosening and aerating so grass can grow. I received the Ohuhu Lawn Aerator Shoes at no cost in order to review and they are sturdier than I expected them to be. The green palstic is thick and strong as are the spikes.

These come unassembled but are easy to put together. A little wrench tool is included, but I found it faster and easier to use my needle nose pliers to tighten the nuts onto the spikes. There are three straps per shoe and a few different holes in the plastic shoes allow you to adjust the positioning of the straps to fit over your regular shoes. The straps each have a strong metal buckle.

These do a good job of breaking up the soil. Aerating is helpful for areas where dirt has gotten packed so tightly that grass can't seed in it and you get bare patches. When the soil is beated down and packed like that, nutrients and water have a tough time getting in as well. These are awesome if you have a smallish yard or a small area that needs some attention. We have way to much yard to walk all over in these, but I have been hitting some spots that have gotten beat down and packed and they have done good. I was surprised that these are actually pretty easy to walk around in. It's like wearing oversized sandals! I wear about a 7 1/2 to 8 in regular shoes and have had no trouble with these. The spikes are very sharp and poke into that solid packed dirt pretty easily. The only trouble I have had is that after about 30 minutes or so, the straps loosen a little, making my regular shoes slip out of place and I have to stop to adjust and tighten them. Thanks to the dogs and their infernal digging, we have some uneven ground around the backyard but these have done real good as I walked over those areas. They are strong and haven't flexed or broken. I look forward to using these around the garden this summer.
summary: Great For Breaking Up Compacted Soil

reviewText: This grass seed works extremely well PROVIDED that you follow the directions. It is important to plant it exactly as they recommend. Just follow the directions. Howevert is most important to follow the watering directions. The key is: water it to keep the soil moist but not flooded with water. I watered this 20 minutes at a time. That worked great. the grass popped up in about a week. Then you let it grow for 3 afters you planted it so that it is healthy before mowing. It is best to plant it in the Spring or Fall in cool weather as opposed to the hot summer months. The is best grass seed available for shady areas if you follow the instructions on the bag.
summary: Superb Results - Worked in an areas with little to no direct sunlight

Five SUCCESSFUL Stars! This is a lightweight, strong automatic "Rainbow" Plemo umbrella which has 8 different colored panels and opens and closes at the push of a button. The umbrella shaft length is about 11.5 inches long fully collapsed in its carry bag and 22 inches fully-extended from the tip of the strong handle up the aluminum shaft to the middle of the umbrella. The diameter of the fully extended umbrella spokes and fabric from side to side is 37 inches. The umbrella weighs 11.2 ounces

In testing, after the carry bag is taken off and the velcro strap is released to manually unfurl the collapsed umbrella fabric and spokes, pushing the "Up-Down" button automatically causes the umbrella to fully extend and then pop open in 1 second. Pushing the "Up-Down" button a second time causes the umbrella fabric and spokes to collapse back onto the shaft, only requiring the user to push on the umbrella top to collapse it back down the shaft, ready for using the velcro strap to secure the umbrella and placement back in the small carry bag for carrying or storage. There is also a carrying strap on the end of the handle.

After opening and closing the umbrella 100 times, the automatic opening and closing mechanism performed flawlessly and the umbrella fabric and spokes stayed firmly in place. My Highest Recommendation! Five DRY Stars! (Umbrella with carry strap. This item was provided for testing and an impartial review.)
summary: A GREAT COLORFUL PLEMO AUTOMATIC UMBRELLA: 100 FLAWLESS AUTOMATIC OPENINGS & CLOSINGS

I bought this as an extra measure against cockroach infestation in my house on top of the advion gel bait. Advion gel worked great against the cockroach infestation, but there were still few roaches left and we thought these pills will help in our extermination. So far from what we have been seeing these pills seems to be working.

After the Advion cockroach gel bait treatment, we saw more of baby roaches here and there and even one or two pregnant adult roaches. So, after placing these pills throughout the house, now we can hardly see any roaches. Thanks Harris for this great roach pills.

The only thing I didn't like one bit about this product is that these pills, which are not safe to pets or humans, not well packaged. I thought these pills would be inside a sealed plastic bag, but it wasn't. The only packaging these pills were in is the yellow box it came in. So, when we I took it out of manila envelope, I noticed whitish powder came streaming out of the box for a second. So, handle it with care. I would recommend those cheap face mask and/or cheap plastic gloves if you can. That's why I gave these pills 4 stars.

Other than that these pills arrived on time.

Absolutely love this filter pump.  Before we got this we would struggle each year to keep the pool water clean.  We had to leave the pump running almost constantly and it was like a science experiment to try and keep the chemicals adjusted correctly.  We also had to clean the filter 1-3 times a day.  Not so with this system.  The most difficult thing was trying to find the salt to put in to start with and that wasn't that hard.  I found out after searching for a pool store in our town that they have the pool salt at walmart.  This has been the most enjoyable swimming season yet.  I cannot say enough good things about this system.  If you are considering buying one, just do it, you won't regret it.  If you are wondering if the water is salty to the taste, it is very slightly but is so much less offensive than the chemical smell we had before.  We have two small dogs that get in the pool and they both drink this water, they never did that with pool water before. Just as a FYI we have a 16'x4' ultra frame intex pool.

I purchased a total of 12 of these for my 18ft round 52" deep, Bestway Pool. I installed them on top of my flat roofed garage. I arranged them in 3 parallel sets of 4 in series. I reversed the inlet/outlets of my pool first, because it seemed backwards. I now have one large intake to filter/pump and two 1.25" outlets back to pool. I routed one of the 1.25" outlets through my solar array. I also installed valves on both 1.25" outlet hoses and a tee to allow control of flow through the solar mats. I can force all supply water from pump, though solar mats and still get a 6* Fahrenheit temp rise on a 75* ambient day. I also purchased a solar blanket to retain that heat at night. I didn't have any problems with leaks due to factory connection, none of my seams leaked, and my water temp increased nicely. I try to read reviews of products through an idiot filter. Most problems with any product is a result from morons not following instructions, which seems to be a problem with these mats. I would, and probably will purchase more of these if they wear out in the future.

TIPS:

 LEAKING CONNECTIONS - all the connections rely on an "O-ring" making a seal. Wet, and carefully rotate and slide hoses onto fillings. Most leaks are probably due to people cramming the hoses on.

RIPPING/BURSTING SEAMS - I have the stock pump for my Bestway pool. I am not sure of the flow rate, however, there is NO way I would divert all the flow through a single line of mats. This is most likely why seams bust. Also multiple mats in a parallel configuration allows for some relief if the flow is restricted due to a kink, or someone standing on the mat, which is also a likely reason for seam bursting.

SIZING - If you do not purchase enough mats for your pool size it will never warm the pool due to basic physics. Also, purchase a solar mat to retain the heat! I  read that while it takes only one BTU of heat to raise the temperature of one pound of water, you can loose as much as 1100 BTUs per gallon of water through evaporation (or like 8 pounds of water).

EXTRA PIPING - I purchased 25ft lengths of 1.25" sump pump hose for my extra required piping for about $7/25ft at my local hardware store. Use steel hose clamps one extra piping connections, and use a drill/impact gun to tighten those extra clamps.

I have used Scotts products for years and by far this spreader is a huge disappointment. It's cheaply made but the real problem is it didn't spread or distribute their product consistently. I had the setting as recommended by Scotts, walked a proper pace, made my turns wide enough (5 feet according to Scotts) and what was supposed to be 4,000 sq ft. coverage was cut in half at 2,000 sq. ft. To cover my lawn I had to get another bag.

I called Scotts help line, waited a full 30 minutes on hold, discussed my problem with a Scotts representative for another 30 minutes. We went through all the entrapment questions to determine what I must have done wrong. Sorry, this was not my first rodeo with your products Scotts, you didn't get a first time amateur on the phone. In the end the kindly young man said he was sorry he couldn't help me and to have a nice day. Seriously, have a nice day, in his estimation it just had to be me as the problem, certainly not the product.

I went back to my hand held Scotts broadcast spreader with success.

-The inside hose must be thin because it broke already!- I only had it a few months and had to trash it.

There is nothing worse to me than trying to drag a heavy, long hose across the yard to water something, well not really but it sure feels like it at the time! If you are like me and find that a pain, you will love this hose.

I love this hose, it is so light and easy to maneuver. The length is great, I love that this hose is 100 feet instead of most of the hoses I've seen that are 50 feet.

The ends are very well made and there is a shut off valve right on the watering end, which I love because I do not have to walk all the way to the house valve if I need to shut of the water for a minute. The ends are well attached to the hose and also have rubber washers included inside the end. the material is nice and thick around the inner hose.

I would recommend when you use the hose to shut it off and wait a few minutes for the water to drain out, then it will be nice and light again and ready to roll back up.

reviewText: This was our 2nd purchase of a coop from the internet. It is relatively large (32 x 42" inside + the nest box) and appears to be made from Chinese fir, a relatively light and soft wood. Assembled easily with a series of pre-installed dowels guaranteeing the proper alignment of panels. Instructions were poor - a series of diagrams, but adequate if you take your time and dry fit (no glue) the panels first to make sure you're assembling them properly.  The coop needed some minor additions to exclude drafts and to keep rain from penetrating the hinged seam between the nesting box lid and sidewall of the coop. Anyone handy with a saw , wood glue and clamps can quickly add strips of wood to do this. The vent in the upper half of the front wall also needed some work on the unit we received to ensure rain could not blow in when it was closed. We added some thin ply to enlarge the panel the door slides over to fix this. Latex paint to protect the wood and this makes a nice coop for 5 large chickens. Very happy with it with mods described.

UPDATE :
Well its been over a year now with this Great White, and I must say that it is a HUGE let down. It never ran properly apparently. It never climbed the wall. It never ran the entire length of my pool. I wasted hours trying to figure out how to properly adjust the vrious settings to get the cleaner to work properly. This year we have done nothing but vacuum by hand due to the Great White simply not moving around whatsoever. I looked up how to repair this on youtube and saw how this SHOULD work. Mine NEVER moved that fast, or pivoted, or climbed walls, or shook that well.  I opened up the panel to make some repairs and saw that the gears which turn the machine did not work. I don't know if they ever worked since the youtube videos show this machine doing some incredible movement, while mine pretty much just vibrated a bit. I assumed that it was a "slow and steady" type machine, but apparently I was wrong. i threw my Great White in the trash. The gears won't turn properly and it looks like a entire section is busted or missing, so why bother. i'll buy something else.  if you buy one make sure you compare it to one that works -- since this never really sucked - it just sucked.
summary: Great is misleading... more of a Dead fish.

reviewText: Bought the Ex Officio shirt, hat. This stuff is way better and less costly.

The tube, tee connections, and mist nozzles are great. I have done a lot of drip irrigation and this is the same tube. I was used to how it goes together. I did not use any boiling water or hair dryers. I just pushed the tubes onto the fittings carefully and with significant force. I would probably have been a bit frustrated with it if I hadn't done so much with drip irrigation in the past. The tube itself feels like nice, high-quality tube. I have had zero issues with it kinking. The tee fittings and spray heads are similarly nice. They do not break, and I had no problems with any of them leaking.

There is one part that I did have a problem with. The faucet/hose connector on mine is terrible. It it very tight, and I cannot screw it down far enough to engage the o-ring seal. Due to this it leaks terribly. I've tried it on two different faucets and a hose, and I can't get it to seal on any of them. I glanced through the other reviews and didn't see much mention of this problem, so it's possible I got a bad one and all the rest seal fine.

This is a nice kit to set up a large mist-cooling system, but you may need to figure something else out for attaching it to a water supply. The tube is standard drip-irrigation tube, so there are lots of accessories readily available at your home improvement store. I will try to attach some pictures below. The water spray is very fine and doesn't show up well in pictures though. I got this kit for free to test and review. If my opinion changes I will update this review. Thanks for reading!
summary: Mine Leaks at the Faucet Connection

I noticed this is not longer available (Feb. 2016) but just in case if comes back:
First of all, this is a very attractive birdhouse...HOWEVER if you're planning to use it for actual birds, you'll need to make some modifications!
There are windows on each side (approx. 1.5 x 2.5 ") which have a metal screen stapled from the inside.  As I was getting ready to place it outside, I decided it would be too drafty for baby birds and was going to cover the windows when  I happened to feel the screen from the inside and ALL the edges were VERY SHARP and would certainly injure and/or blind the babies.  I managed to remove the screens and the staples that pulled loose and covered the windows with pieces of lath.
If it is available again, please check yours!
summary: 5 Stars for cute...1 Star for dangerous for birds!

They looked very green and healthy, but no change in size and I didn't expect them to...but in hindsight maybe I should have because as of today 8/22/13 the plants have doubled in size and I barely got them on 8/15/13!  I think they started to really grow after I put them in bigger pots and added the FoxFarm Happy Frog Potting Soil.  Last night the 5th banana plant arrived in the mail and I put all the plants side by side and sure enough, the first 4 were about twice as big as the 5th (check out the picture I posted).  I will have to go pot shopping this weekend.  At this rate these banana plants will outgrow the new pots in a few days.

reviewText: First off, I live in the woods of NH, and I've read the success of these machines will vary depending on where you live. I owned the Flowtron MT-275 for 3 yrs. It did work and caught maybe 200 mosquitoes a month. Being my first ever trap I thought this was good. The unit finally stopped working after 3 yrs. I replaced the fan according to their support with no success. Flowtron support was clearly guessing at the problem and I decided to throw this unit out before spending any additional money trying to fix it. What a great move this was!!  Advice to all....throw your Flowtron out if you own one regardless if it is working or not! I recently bought a Mosquito Magnet MM3000 Liberty and a Blue Rhino SV3100 SkeeterVac. One was put on each side of my 3 acres. Within 2 wk both of these units caught more mosquitoes than the Flowtron did in 3 yrs!! After 3 months now, the Magnet Liberty is by far superior at catching mosquitoes, but that is all it catches, and it does it well! I empty a full bag every wk, which must be 1000's. The SkeeterVac catches about 1/3 the mosquitos of the Magnet, however the TacTrap (sticky paper on the outside of unit) is excellent at catching other biting bugs, like the large black and green flies I have up here. After every 2 wks the TacTrap looks like a fully loaded pizza of bugs...very cool! The other nice thing about the SkeeterVac is that its cordless. However, the TacTrap and Fine Tune Biting (Octanol) will add to the monthly operational cost vs the Magnet. So far, following the advice of previous posters, I have not had any clogging problems. I replace the propane before it runs out so the units are not running on empty...which seems to be the main problem with these units. Bottom line, I like having both the Magnet and SkeeterVac units, and will never by a Flowtron again!
summary: Comparison of Flowtron, Skeetervac and Magnet traps

reviewText: Fits great and appears to be working fine. Ariens 42" Hydrostatic (93604200 model)

It's worrisome when I find myself transformed from an anti-kill proponent of "all creatures great and small" to a hardened, desensitized exterminator.  But the record speaks for itself: I clicked the "on" switch on 3 consecutive nights and netted one dead mouse per night.  However, I must register one troubling observation: on this third morning there was a chewed-out gap of almost 1/2" in diameter in the plastic at the backside of the trap.  I had been led to believe the trap was capable of "humane" (i.e. instant) kills of each victim, but this morning's evidence would suggest that the out-manned prey was desperately trying to escape before or during electrocution.  Worse, if the latter is true, it's possible a demobilized, half-paralyzed creature was yet capable of using its teeth in a project that was doomed from the outset.  Amazon shows a popular live-kill green plastic mouse trap that I had to abandon because within several nights the critters had chewed it to pieces, managing to escape.  In the case of the damaged Victor "electric chair" it appears the mice have once again scored an ultimate victory against their worst enemy (me).

I went ahead and used it the 4th night anyway.  This time there was no flashing green light indicating a kill because the shocked mouse fought hard enough to lift the latched cover and break the circuit.  So much for the claims about the trap being instant, or "humane."  All the same, I set the trap a 5th time, and the next morning the flashing green light indicated a kill.  Not wanting to bury the animal in my pajamas (I was still in my pajamas making coffee, not the mouse), I set it to the "off" position, planning to attend to the grave matter at hand in an hour or two.  However, upon returning I discovered an open door, an empty trap, a trap moreover showing not the least trace of the peanut butter I had lathered it with the night before).  You draw your conclusions. Either I'm harboring exceptionally resilient rodents or Victor's Electronic Trap is close to a "throwaway" (maybe the electronic circuitry is effective at giving the mice a pleasant, rejuvenating massage).

For several reasons, this trap can be recommended over Victor's Kill & Seal mouse trap, and my investment repaid itself to the extent of 3 consecutive kills.  Still, I say shame on Victor for the wastefulness and misleading (paranoia-inducing) promotion of the Kill & Seal trap and for the inferior component (plastic) of the electronic trap.  Were this trap made of metal or a similar indestructible (by mice) and conductible material, it would appear to be the mouse exterminator's best bet.  But now that I'm embarked on a career of rodent homicide, it looks like I'll have to move on to something that's not worthless after the first 1-3 fatalities.  From consumers' reviews, the "Nooski" looks like it just may be the best bet (but stay tuned).
summary: Victor Electronic Trap vs. Victor Kill & Seal (no easy solution)

This little meter helped me figure out that my "filter" was basically doing nothing for me. I purchased a filter hoping it would remove the minerals from my hard water. Tap water = 145ppm and filtered water = 140ppm! Needless to say, I got a reverse osmosis filter that now reads <10ppm!

As others have pointed out, there is no temperature compensation on this. For example, cold tap water = 145ppm but hot tap water = 225ppm. But for most of us, we don't need the fancy temperature compensation. I just let the water cool to room temp to get an accurate comparison.

I am so disappointed with this purchase! I have used these tubes for holding my pool cover for a long time.  I have ordered the single tubes and been very satisfied.  There was no reason to believe that I would not be just as pleased with this purchase.  The shipment arrived quickly and was perfectly packaged.  The address was from Robelle, so I was confident in the product.  It is made in China, but that's no biggie as long as it's well made.  I have received about 3 years of use from the old tubes and some were still in good shape, so I assumed these would do well.  The quality of the vinyl seems fine and the "welded" seams are good.  The tubes come individually wrapped.  I filled the first tube and tried to close it and that's when the problem showed up.  These normally fit snug and are sometimes difficult to open; but with a little urging, they usually close just fine.  Not this time. I have a pretty decent grip and it was a struggle for me to get the first tube closed.  It wasn't from weather either.  The temp is in the 60s today.  I had to work it around, keeping even pressure and push HARD in the middle to finally get it to close.  It was not the satisfying "snap" closure that all my other tubes exhibit.  I thought maybe it was a fluke, so I filled the second tube.  I have even more trouble with this one.  I had to squeeze and wiggle - and finally laid it on a flat surface and exerted a lot of pressure with the palm of my hand to get is closed.  I realized at that point, that I had made a mistake. These are normally a little tight when I try to open them in the spring and empty the water.  After closing the second tube, I realized that it was permanently closed.  It was too late to send them back, so I continued to the third tube.  I filled it and when I tried to close it, I realized that it was even harder than the first two. The opening had been put on the tube and was in an oval shape, but the closure plug is round.  They are slightly flexible, so I tried squeezing the shape, squeezing the plug - everything I could think of.  I got it close, with just about 45 degrees of the outside arch not closed and could get no further using every trick I knew.  I even tried stepping on it - about 200 lbs of pressure per square inch and it still wouldn't close.  Can't send them back and can't use them as they are.  I don't know if the one's I got were old and the openings were inflexible or if Robelle has changed Chinese manufacturers, but these are different from the ones I have received before.  A total waste on my part.  If I was evaluating the previous products, this would be a five star review.  Maybe your experience will be different from mine, but I would suggest a different brand or purchasing at the local pool store so you can see the product before you purchase.  I'm uploading a photo of the third tube so you can see the problem.  I hope this review is helpful.
summary: Wasted my money - not like the ones I received before.

This is a genuine Shindaiwa speed head. It replaces the older 375 model and has more line capacity than it's predecessor. I comfortably fit 16+ feet of .105 into new 400 model- but more on that  later.

I used this to save a pre-historic (by small engine standards)  Shindaiwa T250 whose original head went to head heaven after 18+ years of use. You gotta love the longevity of the older Shindaiwa motors. Mine still runs like a top after 1 or 2 pulls on the starter cord. I can only hope that tradition continues, now that they're part of ECHO, but that's a discussion for another day.

One of the included male by male adapters (the silver one with slotted end) instantly changed my gear drive connection to the correct male end that mounted the new speed head (original head is male- the speed head is female out of the box). There are many more adapters included, so you could probably hook up to the space shuttle- if were still flying. My only caveat is there still may not be enough adapters if you have trimmer from the big box guys-some of those have unobtanium trim heads.

 The web site said it would take .80, .95. or .105. ANYTHING bigger than .105 will not fit through the head (maybe the guides look big enough, but the internal passage is not). I threw out the supplied .95 string and used square cut .105 string. The included instructions do not mention .105 string. I can see why. The .105 is difficult to thread through the head(feels like it drags through the internal 'teeth'), and it 'bump feeds' unevenly. I can manually push on the dispenser and pull the measured amount of line by hand-but that could be a recipe for disaster with the engine running, and I don't recommend it.  I need the fatter line since my job has myriad stone walls, cement walks, and rocky soil. It just eats the smaller stuff. If you like the convenience of the bump however, stick to the smaller diameter lines.

Because your new head is probably a different weight and diameter than your old one, you may find the new trim head will not stop fully at idle. You will have to adjust your idle until the head just stops turning, otherwise you risk burning up the clutch. Please note you have been spared the full discussion on the moment of inertia or Newton's second law of motion.

Please resist the temptation for running without the string guard. When you increase the string 'orbit' past the 17-20" range you burn more fuel to keep the rotational speed up. With today's CARB compliant engines, the increased fuel you put into the combustion process will clog or carbon-up something.  Most likely you have a 2-stroke engine, and there are a lot of variables when you make up that 40-1 or 50-1 fuel mix. Whether it's a spark arrester or the engine cylinder, your wacker will need attention.

Overall, this saved me the better part of $300, as my trusty trimmer will wack another day.

Have had problems with these clamp style repair ends in the past, but they looked nice so thought I would give a try. The female end after fully clamped and tightened to hose bib still leaks. Not much better than the one I tried to replace. My guess is the male and joiner clamps probably work better. The female seems to be leaking because it is two parts and appears to rely on the plastic washer to seal the two parts together. Whatever the cause, just does not work well. So got some useless parts, probably a few good parts, and should have spent the money just buying a new hose. Meanwhile I trained the dribble leak down to a plant next to the hose bib. Not "premium" if it does not fix the leak. Should add that I tried the repair because I had a very high quality hose, where the female end also failed shortly after the warranty expired. Gave it a two star (rather than one) because it does look like brass to me.

Update: After sitting in the sun for a few days, (at 95 degrees +) both the hose and internal washer softened up enough to finally allow a very tight fit and no leaks. Read so much about these and watched videos about them, so ordered one for myself. Works great. Faster and better than the fan spray with my sun joe washer. "TIP", to make them last (all will fail after years of use) always apply pressure with the tip pointing down. There is a small steel ball inside the tip, that moves around to generate the cone spray pattern. Starting the spray tip down, starts will the ball in its working position. With tip up when starting, it forces the ball into position, slamming it into place, which will eventually damage it. This is a very good tip for pressure washers. I would buy again.

I've owned a battery powered trimmer before and this one beats it by a long shot.  However, this is still a compromise.  Of course, it doesn't compare with a gas powered trimmer for raw power but, it's lighter and less fatiguing to use.  And, with the long charge duration before recharging, I can get a lot of work done before having to switch battery packs.  With the fast charger and two batteries, I could probably work all day with no down time.  It's pretty easy to justify the purchase of the fast charger if you have two or more 20V tools and/or multiple batteries.  I have three 20V tools, two 2.0AH battery packs, one regular wall charger and one fast charger.  Suggestion for the manufacturer: The fast charger should be an option with the multi-tool combination kits or even with all 20V tools.  It's a shame to be stuck with a useless original charger if you decide to upgrade.  The net cost of the fast charger should be significantly less if purchased with the tool in place of the standard charger.  One negative I've encountered using the tool is that the string guard doesn't fully protect me from splatter when working in wet or muddy areas, especially in edger mode.  TIP: Always wear eye protection with all powered outdoor equipment.
summary: It's pretty easy to justify the purchase of the fast charger ...

reviewText: I've never ordered bare roots strawberries before, so I wasn't entirely sure what to expect.  The roots arrive dormant and require a good soaking to revive them.  They come in a small box - packaged well, but the bare roots look really brown and sad and the leaf sprouts are pale white from lack of sun.  This is totally normal and as intended.  They're just waiting for water and sun to revive them!  I planted the roots after soaking for an hour, and every one of them is thriving.  The pale sprouts turned dark green and unfurled within a day or two.  It'll be a while before they're ready to produce, but they're off to a great start!

reviewText:
Various hearty weeds grow thickly around my fence lines and need frequent trimming.  I need a tool that's lightweight, easily portable and effective for a variety of things.  My string trimmer works for the grasses, but not the sturdier weeds and the blade trimmer works for those, but not the grasses, plus it's heavy and tiring to use.  I decided to try this little tool and am so glad I did.  It's great.  It's sharp and slices off the poke weeds in a flash and can handle things with pretty stiff stems, plus tall grasses when I grab a sheath of them by the tops.  The curved blade makes the effort required minimal. I was so pleased with the ease with which I was able to clear around the paddock fence, I set out with my folding saw and this tool to cover one whole side of pasture fence and it looks terrific.  Only three more to go :)

The trimmers are great for specialized tasks, but when I am trying to trim a variety of things, they seem more trouble than help as I have to make multiple passes.  While this tool can't manage the harder saplings, my little folding saw makes short work of those and carrying both this tool and that one is easy since both are lightweight.

It also makes my trail clearing activities much more productive as I was carrying clippers, loppers and the folding saw, which was a bit cumbersome.  Since this tool handles a good variety of things, I only need to pull the saw out for the bigger saplings and cedars.  Of course I don't get as close to the ground as I would with a trimmer since I don't want to be bending down all the way, but it's quite reasonable and since I'm less tired after using it, I don't resist going back out there when needed as I did at the thought of fussing with the eccentricities of the trimmers.

All in all, I consider this purchase money very well spent.  The zippered case is good quality and even has a protective plastic trough for the blade edge.  This little machete will get a lot use around the farm.
This is absolutely adorable! I am keeping in indoors and filling it with potted pants and in front of a large window. There are hundreds of things you can do with this!

A lot of the B&S engines have switched over to using RTV rather than a valve cover gasket, including mine - you really cannot tell until you take it apart, as the parts diagrams list both the gasket and the RTV.  After cleaning off the old RTV, I installed this gasket with no RTV, and it is working fine.  If you decide to stick with the RTV, try Permatex 82180, which is better and cheaper than the official B&S RTV.

Overall a good purchase. The engine runs well, but not awesome. This is my first time with a 4-cycle so I can only compare against a 2-cycle. I love not having to mix oil & gas and keeping that around in a separate container. However, my only comment about the engine is, it seems to take a while (5 minutes) to warm up and stay running. Thankfully I purchased the JumpStart(er) .. which makes starting (restarting) a breeze. Because of the engine and long warm up (or whatever the issue is) , this takes away 1 star. The reason for dropping another 2 stars, is because of the bump head (trimmer line). After only 20 minutes of trimming (long) grass, the bump head melted and started wobbling .. yes melted. I wasn't too concerned at first because I assumed I would just replace the bump head with a replacement head (Gator 8010) .. however, the bump head is not replaceable (at least, I cannot remove the head from the curved shaft). I've Googled and searched .. and found no way of removing the bump head .. which in the end, makes half of this purchase a total waste of money. Thankfully, my old 12 year old weed whacker (yes 12 year old Home Depot special), trimmer attachment fits just fine on the Troy-Bilt. It needed a new trimmer head .. so I purchased the (Gator 8010 - w/ LoNoiz LN130MSP-2-professional .130 trim line) and (Gator 4680) and along with my other attachments .. can get back to my yard work. As a side note: I highly recommend the .130 trim line .. I've battled trimmer line for years with my metal fencing eating up the standard .095 line, feet at a time .. but with (slightly more expensive) .130 line, I finished off my fence line with only replacing 1 strand of 6" line.
summary: Overall a good purchase. The engine runs well

I did fairly extensive research and this is the best trap for rats I could find and within two weeks I have already caught a mouse and 2 adult Norway rats 1 juvenile rat.  The openings are small enough that it works for mice as well.
(Update: I have caught 2 more adult rats in this trap within a few days of writing this review. It has been weeks since I have had any sign of any rodents despite it being below freezing outside now.  So far, I have had zero problems with this trap.  I still highly recommend it.)

I bought the small version

I first bought traps from Home Depot: an electric one that was supposed to zap them and a Havahart 1025, but the rats had no problem eating the bait without triggering either one and neither has yet caught anything.

Then I decided to purchase this one. It triggers much more easily and I have yet to see the bait being eaten without it being triggered.

The trigger mechanism is a very good design and the main reason to buy this trap. I also like being able to use the raised loop over the door to lift up the cage without any worry of being bitten while carrying it (I still used heavy leather work gloves tho).

The bait tray can be a bit difficult to clean and one rat did try to bend the wires to get out, but did not succeed.  I was able to easily bend them back.

It arrived with instructions completely in Chinese, but it is not too difficult to figure it out without them.

My current bait is a combo of peanut butter and brownie filled Oreo cookie.
summary: Best trap there is for rats

After getting four standard "Kink Free" hoses from Ace Hardware, all of which kinked from their first use, I gave up on the standard type of hose, which is made of a pretty stiff material. I would always get into a situation where the hose would kink up upon itself and cut off the water flow. Then I would have to go back and manually unkink the hose, not always easy to do because of the stiffness of the standard hose material. Once the hose kinked in a spot, it was likely to kink again in the same spot, as a weakness had been permanently made at that spot, once kinked.

I did see some disappointing reviews here on the green Pocket Hose (15 metre), but when I saw that it was available, I decided to give it a try. After all, the Ace hoses were impossible. I bought one for the front yard and one for the back yard, and did my usual hand-watering.  I was initially delighted!

First of all, the weight of the hose is trivial compared to a standard hose, which can get a little tiring to lug around. As the product description indicates, the compacted hose filled with water to its full length. When I turned off the water, the hose contracted to a more compact form. True, it didn't compact back to the original compacted size, but to about a quarter of its full length, so that it could be stored easily below the water spigot.

The instructions indicate that in the summer the hose should be stored in the shade, and in the winter, inside, as in a garage. I don't know how important that really is. I'm just going to leave my Pocket Hoses outside under the spigot. But, then, I live in a mild climate. If you're regularly getting hot, direct sunlight or sub-freezing temperatures, the proper storage could markedly increase the life of the Pocket Hose.

One benefit that I did notice: the water flow was noticeably increased through the Pocket Hose as compared to the standard Ace hoses that I had previously used. I would attribute that probably to the fact that the standard hose is so stiff that it does not expand, whereas the Pocket Hose readily expands and contracts to reflect the actual water flow.

Unfortunately, my delight abated when, within weeks, I experienced two defective hoses.  One leaked badly after a few weeks' use, and another exploded like a balloon.  The junction of the hose material with the plastic on the faucet end is badly manufactured, and the hose comes apart there.

Since the 15-metre length was just a bit short for my use, I had been pulling the hose to reach.  Maybe this weakened an already-weak connector.  So I decided to try this hose, the blue Xhose (22.5 metres).  So far, this hose material seems more substantial.  We'll see whether the junction holds up.

12/02/13.  I have now had two of these hoses go out within weeks of purchase.  As opposed to the green (15 metre) type, which tear at the connector joint after several weeks, this blue (22.5 metre) type is defective in the inner tubing, which tears and makes the hose gush from the tube.  The most recent one I tried gave out in just two weeks.  It is too bad that the quality control on these hoses is so bad when their basic concept is so good.
Great price & quality

The out-of-production PSC2022 works correctly.  I thankfully happened to find one spare PSC2022 water temp sensor kit I had forgotten I was hoarding in my spares box and I installed it with immediate success.

I have a push lawn mower that was setup to mulch right from the store. I've never even put on the side shoot since mulching removes the need for yard cleanup (raking). I recently bought a new Poulan Pro riding mower but it was not setup for mulching. That's the reason I bought this kit. It was easy to install (Note: I've installed blades before). The installation instructions are clear to read, include pictures, are accurate and even include mowing tips. They also come in English, French and Spanish. The instructions specify how to replace the blades on a standard setup (Center Bolt) or if you have an EZ Blade Attachment System (Quick Release). It fits my Poulan Pro 42" model: 960460077. My model number was not listed on the box but it fit perfectly. Supposedly there's more models in a "Look-Up" guide in stores.

Blades:
You get two 21 inch blades in the kit which equal 42 inches total. They were exactly the same length of my OEM blades. The blades are of a good quality and match or exceed other aftermarket blades out there. The instructions nor the box state anywhere that the blades need to be sharpened, but they do seem dull to the touch. I have been told in the past that the paint that coats the blade to prevent corrosion covers the blade edge giving the illusion that it's dull. The paint then rubs off when mowing exposing the sharp edge. I have not found this to be true. I took them to my local hardware store to be sharpened and balanced and now they are sharp to the touch. I recommend everyone gets the blades sharpen before you install them.

Mulch Cover:
The mulch cover is plastic and is of the same quality and density of the OEM Poulan Pro side shoot. It attaches to the mower deck at the top via a metal tab underneath the side shoot and to the sides via rubber bungees. It fits the contours of my mower deck precisely and installation was easy. The only issue I had was if I started with the mulch cover in place I could not get the left bungee to stretch far enough to reach the mower deck mounting plate. When I attached the left side bungee first then stretched the mulch cover into place it installed with ease.

Normally with a side shoot on the right you can only trim around things like landscaping from the left side of the mower deck. I went one step further and removed my side shoot. You have to disassemble the spring mechanism though. If you remove the entire assembly you will lose the metal tab at the top that secures the mulch cover. If you leave the side shoot on it just hides the mulch cover when it's down making it look like no changes were made. It does not interfere with the mulch cover at all.

Update: 5/9/2016
Mulching:
No matter how fast or slow my mower is traveling, rows of cut grass deposit on the lawn leaving stripes I have to go over a second time. I believe this is due to clippings getting caught up somewhere under the deck causing the clippings to not distribute evenly. Also, the top of the deck collects a ton of clippings when mowing. This is the reason I dropped the review from 5 to 4 stars.

reviewText: I have have been waging battle with roaches for the last 2+ years in this apartment. Yes we have a bug guy that comes once a month but they come out to say hello very soon after he's paid a visit. Now I'm not saying it's like Joe's Apartment where the roaches are doing chorus lines in my kitchen but I'm from the north and once these southern roaches move in they're a HUGE pain to get rid of... Anyhow, I have had these traps set up in various locations around my home for about a week now. Thus far, I have caught 3 ants, 2 earwigs and only 1 roach. Once you get a bug to visit the trap they're not coming out again. I'm just not so sure if the attractant is super effective. I set 4 traps. only 2 of them caught anything at all. I will switch the location of the traps that didn't catch anything and see if there is an improvement but, thus far I can't offer anything better than 3 stars.

In central Maryland, you've got to break clay if you want to garden.  I hacked away with a mattock for a few hours, said 'forget that,' and bought this.

Assembled in a few minutes with no tools... make sure you have a heavy-gauge power cord... then off to the races.  I stripped all the grass off a 4x16' garden plot, put about 9 cu ft of hardwood shred mulch down on the clay surface, and then let the tiller work.  Fortunately the clay was moist from a recent rain, otherwise I wouldn't have gotten real far with hardpan.

Boy, it bucks on rocks and roots and solid clay deposits.  Not for the faint of heart.  Wear hard boots and prepare for bruises.  I weigh 125 and it got away from me a few times jumping off obstructions, but I didn't mind because once I got the rocks picked out, the thing chewed its way through my plot without further complaint.  Tilled the mulch in real nice, then the peat moss, then the compost and vermiculite, until that clay was thoroughly broken.

Got a nice raised bed now, with soil like potting mix.  Really couldn't have done it without a tiller.  This one did the job.
summary: Kicks like a mule in clay, so hang on!

reviewText: This bait absolutely works. As others have mentioned, it's very important to store the product in one or two plastic bags after opening if stored outside as mice or rats will try to get into the bottle. I keep a handful of dry dog food and the tube in two bags in an outside grill area and the rodents don't go near. Between this bait and the Rat Zapper, I've killed field mice and rats nearly every night for the past month or so. Highly effective.

I live in AZ so the warm weather period is lengthy. I have had a bat problem for 10 years. They love my vestibule area. They huddle in the corners. At one time the bats did migrate south so I would have maybe a 2-3 month respite. Then many started to stay all year. Now I have nothing against bats. They do a good job and I appreciate that. BUT, they make a mess with droppings near my paver front door area. Every night. And when I'm away, I come home to a big mess. Now I've tried many suggested remedies to keep them away. None worked. I was skeptical of product like this one...and there are several. Still, I was desperate. I set the switches for "bat control". There is a "variable" and "constant" mode. That's the high pitch that the bats (hopefully) don't like. I tried both. Constant worked better. Okay, the results. At first I continued to have a problem. I have a "L" shaped entry area so I tried various locations for coverage. After about 2 weeks I started to see a change. Fewer visitors. I did experiment with location and direction control. I have found that a location on the outside corner of my "L" area worked best. I also have adopted an upward slant to the box. Now that I've had several months to test, including a month away, I have had no nightly visitors. What a relief. This product has worked wonders for me. I highly recommend you give it a try. I'm not sure of the real coverage area when walls or other obstacles are in the path. But I also have a covered patio on the back of the house and in the past the bats used that as their base of operations. No longer. You need a power outlet for this product. It has continued to work flawlessly regardless of weather conditions. For me that means hot sun, high temps, cold (20-30 degrees) nights. No problems.
Arrived the next day and was just what I wanted.

Anybody who does outdoor cooking can tell you there are three specific things they need in a set of grill tools. First, it has to be heavy duty enough to handle a big piece of meat without bending. Second, it can't rust if you forget it outside overnight. Third, no plastic trim that is going to melt in the fire. Right there, 90% of the sets marketed as Father's Day bargains fall short.

I expected much more from Weber as a three-time owner (Genesis, bullet smoker and Smoky Joe). And these tools are a big disappointment. The design overpowers the function. They're great if you are a collector of Danish Modern but otherwise they are awkward to use and not really thought out. The tines of the fork can be bent with your fingers... not good. The tongs lack a clasp to keep them shut when they're not in use. Worst of all, the overall balance is off. They don't have that comfortable heft when you are using them and when you hang them on the pegs on the side of your Genesis the slightest jostle knocks them to the ground.

The day after I first used these I was in a big box store and saw a set from K*ngsford at half the price. Wish I'd bought those instead.

Wolf-Garten makes a number of different size cultivators that have similar shapes, making it hard sometimes to tell how they differ from just looking at the pictures. This is a medium large cultivator, about 4 inches across, with thick, heavy tines. It's about the same size as WOLF-Garten Classic Soil Cultivator 1315004, but it adds the weeder on the other side. That comes in handy for cultivating around individual plants etc. However, for weeding large areas, you will still want the WOLF-Garten 3226004 Push-Pull Weeder.

The tree arrived ALMOST exactly as pictured, but the packaging was a problem - it was fit inside a box (standard for most trees), the pot was covered (again, standard for most trees), but the entire thing was filled with packaging peanuts, in between the branches, in the pot, everywhere.  It's easy enough to shake them out, but lime trees have thorns, and the foam peanuts get stuck on them.  Additionally, foam peanuts suck up the moisture in the air - something citrus absolutely despises.  So, an hour of picking out peanuts, several pricks from thorns, then a thorough watering, The tree perked up a bit, and most of the leaves rehydrated.  The bottom branches are a little sparse, because those leaves could not recover, but the tree looks like it will recover nicely and grow.  It's only a 18" tree, but it is a good price and aside from it's trip, it appears to have been well cared for.  Hint to the seller:  Don't use foam peanuts for packaging on trees that love humidity.  Also note that I ordered late August, via standard shipping. The tree was in the box for several days.
summary: Small Healthy Tree for a Good Price; Shame about the Shipping.

Update: I decided to find out why the oil system quit working. I first drained the chain oil from the reservoir. I then removed the chain sprocket cover by loosening the large black knob and discovered the entire area stuffed with debris I had cut. I removed the chain and the guide bracket and cleaned out the cover and the sprocket. I refilled the chain oil reservoir and the oil flowed freely. So now I need to come up with a prevention to keep out the cutting debris.

Working well so far.  Would be five stars except for customer service and data formatting.  I had a technical question and called them.  When you get in the queue it is always 10 or 12 people ahead of you.  Takes about one half hour to get down to you.  I called three times because I got cut off twice when someone finally came on.  The third time the person could not answer my question and transferred me to another department...you guessed it...another queue with 12 people.  However, finally, that person knew the answer.
The .csv file header format requires some work to be presentable and the format illustration on the package has been massaged .  The problem is there is way too much data so it requires more work to get an average or mean for data plotting.  I am working on a spreadsheet to do this for me.  I purchased this unit from Costco (02064c), very reasonable.

Update:  Three months later.  The CSV file is more than "requires some work,"  The data is totally honked up.  The temperature data is 12 hours out of sync with the time (the high temp is at midnight and the low temp is at noon, and the clock is correct).  The Date/Time column is in reverse.  In order to make it correct you have to sort the Date/Time column bottom to top.  Rain has its own Date/Time column which is in the correct order but the rain data is confusing as it lists countless entries with the same data.  Why another Date/Time column?  Just list the amount of rain that accumulates.
I called tech support on this issue.  They related that, yes, the CSV file has difficulties and are working on the problem and will inform the user when a corrected version is available.  When is TBD.  The problem is not with the raw data from the console unit but the AcuRite Connect software.
Solution:  I deleted the AcuRite Connect software and loaded the older AcuLink software.  Works great!  Rain data is cumulative and uses the same Date/Time column.  The temperature curves are right on.  Aculink also displays real time data that AcuRite does not.
Bottom line:  Do not install AcuRite Connect.  Install AcuLink.  Reducing one star in review due to these problems and another star for the fact that they let us spend our resources on this defective software.

The block alone is easier to use.  It can wear quickly if you force the block into the grates - a light touch works better and cleans just as well.  You will need a v shaped wire brush to get in between the grates anyway since this just cleans the top portion of your grates. I have a very small, raised bed, vegetable garden and I also have bugs that want to eat my veggies before I do. I use natural insect control as much as possible but I'm growing my veg to eat it and that means protecting it from insects.

This Flower, Fruit and Vegetable Insect Killer from Ortho just works. This year I have tomatoes, cucumbers and beans and this has taken care of the caterpillars I've had so far.

I mix this 1.5 oz to 1 gallon of water in a hand held spray bottle. I just spray enough to wet the leaves and that's it. As with most insect killers, it's best to use this on a calm day and avoid contact with your body. I always shower after using any pesticides.

You want to be sure to spray at least 7 days before harvesting and if repeat applications are needed, wait 7 days between applications.

With my small garden, I expect this bottle to last several seasons and I'm happy to have it.

Just replaced a 10+ year old Hayward DE4800 with this newer model. The photo isn't the smaller 48 sqft model its the larger model. The actual filter housing is a much better and slightly thicker material. My old filter housing was more like a PVC than fiber resin. The clamp on my old filter had a single hinge and the new model has two hinges on the metal clamp making it easier to install or remove. The coating on the metal clamp is better than my old clamp and the clamp bolt no longer uses a tension spring. The clamp has a sheathed copper insert where you tighten the bolt. The rubber o-ring is not round its square and feels like it has silicon material added. The gauge is better in my opinion, has low/hi setting adjustments and although the valve is still plastic as was the old system its a better design. I only wish there was a over pressure  release valve option that would open if pressure exceeded 30+ psi. My old Hayward back-flush valve was a direct fit with no modification needed to fit this newer model. I had just bought new filter grids for my old DE4800 but they are the exact same grids that came with this newer model, so I have a spare set. The interior guts look to be the same. To me its just a DE filter but with the better housing material, better clamp, better gauge and compatibility with the older grids I feel makes this a great product. reviewText:
I enlisted my son, who lives in a small apartment in upper Manhattan, NYC, to help with this review. In Upper East Side Manhattan, even the nice places have some level of mouse and cockroach activity. The goal is to manage this as opposed to eradicate. My son had presumed there would be cockroaches and mice in the property since this is A) common, and B) there were traps for both in the apartment when he rented it.

To his surprise and pleasure, he has found no vermin using these sticky traps in the last three weeks of use. He has placed them under the sink and in various other locations looking for vermin and has found none. Further, he has seen no alternate evidence, either (e.g. fecal material). Thus, these traps are fulfilling at least part of their value, which is to show the absence of vermin as well as the presence.

I am only giving this product three stars for now, because it seems like a good idea, it is conveniently packaged and it does not carry the difficulties of some loose bait poisons or spring traps. On the other hand, it is also unclear why it has attracted NOTHING. After having seen his apartment, I can't believe that there is not any kind of ant, bug or whatever that would end up in this sticky stuff. Perhaps it is actually UN-attractive to them? In any case, we will revise it up a star or two if and when something gets caught. Additionally, he is taking one to work to check and see if the office mouse can be deleted (there is one, apparently.).
summary: even the nice places have some level of mouse and cockroach activity

reviewText: Good

I love the Power Pressure Washer.  Very easy to assemble out of the box with excellent storage of everything you need other than the water hose tp provide water to the unit.  The first time I used it for several hours and finished I discovered that the soap container had come loose.  Upon closer inspection I found that under the lower front orange plastic piece that runs from side to side there is a plastic projection hanging down through which the soap container is screwed.  The rear of the soap container is supported via a groove in it's back which fits 180 degrees around the wheel axel.  The screw had ripped out of the bottom of the plastic handing section for it on the lower front.  I had to remove the entire lower orange plastic piece on the front (family easy and straight forward) and then reposition the soap container to the other side of the unit, replace the lower orange plastic piece and then screw it through another hanging screw hold on the underside of the lower front orange plastic piece.  I also taped the back of the soap container so it could not slide around on the axel as it apparently had during my use of the machine.  This is a major design flaw and needs to be fixed by the manufacturer.  Thankfully there was a second hole I could use to secure the soap holder.  They also need to put retainers on each side of the rear of the soap container where it connects to the axel to keep it from moving around so much and causing the single screw holding it in place to rip out of plastic!  Were it not for this I would have given it 5 stars as the machine does clean easily, is easy to operate, starts on first one or two pulls and runs flawlessly!

Another problem was I copied the Serial Number from the box label and then I found it "engraved" on the lower right side of the motor and they matched.  When I attempted to register it on line it refused to accept it.  I called and the operator at Generac said it wasn't the serial number and might be the motor number.  Now I'm a 74 year old man and don't get down very well.  I went back to the shop and crawled on my stomach and finally found a sticker on the lower right side of the machine but because of the steep angle of the surface it was pasted onto I couldn't read the necessary numbers.  So I removed the spray wand and machine hose, then lifted it up onto my work bench.  Then I had to get an old milk crate to sit on and using a flashlight was finally able to record the proper serial number.  About the only thing they could have done to make it harder to find would have been to put it on the bottom of the machine!  Then I had to take it back down and put the wand and hose back on their very good carriers.  Of course as a result, having a bad back for which have to take narcotics to control the pain, I had to take an extra dose of pain meds to regain pain control!

I then attempted to register the machine on line again but when I entered the "Date Ordered" from the "Packing List" from Amazon their screen refused to accept it stating it was prior to their invoice!  So I ended up having to call them again and a nice lady registered it for me, but told me she couldn't take any comments about the machine and the problems I incurred!  Another reason for 4 stars.  Actually I was going to give it 2 stars after that but I waited awhile to calm down and gave it an honest 4 stars!
summary: Great Machine but needs additional engineering on simply things!

reviewText:
This was an interesting item to try.

It seems to get us (humans) more wet than any creature that comes in the yard.

While we were setting this up, the top kept popping off.  We turned down the water pressure as much as possible and that seemed to help to keep the top on.

It seems to be cheaply made, lots of plastic.  But, I guess if it was more sturdy the price would even be higher.  You need soft dirt to get this thing in the ground.  But, wait!  It better not be too soft as this thing is a bit top heavy and it will tilt!  If you have hard dirt, just forget it.  You'll never get the stake into the ground.  As it is, we got it in the ground, but it doesn't sit in the ground well.

We have had some fun playing with the sensitivity.  If it's not sensitive enough, it won't go off even when we walk in front of it.  If it's too sensitive, it will go off when people walk by on the sidewalk (we have it in the front yard).  But, we can work with the sensitivity settings.

The biggest problem/concern for us: no on/off switch!  How much could a switch have cost to be added to this?  When we do yard work, have the gardener come, or the kids come over, we have to turn the water off to it and then we need to trip it (walk in front of it) for it to release the water pressure it has in it.  Also, even though the water is not flowing to it, the thing still senses movement in front of it and will go off.  No water will spray but it's a darn waste of batteries.  Yes, I could set the sensitivity to low, but the sensitivity is so hard to get right, I don't want to mess with it!

We are using this but it's been very difficult getting it to work for us.  I suppose it's better than nothing.
summary: Havahart Spray Away Motion Activated Sprinkler Repellent

reviewText:
My kids were so excited when we ordered this kit. The thought of growing their own mushrooms was a novel idea to them. I had done a button mushroom kit long before they were born and had been meaning to order one of those, but then I saw this. Way cooler than white button mushrooms.
The kids did most of the prep, cutting it open, soaking it, and misting it daily. We started seeing growth in only about 3 days. After seven days, we had 1/2 a pound growing out the side of the box. It was really quite amazing seeing this shelf of mushrooms sticking out from the box. I went to get the camera, but by the time I came back it had been cut off, cut up, and sent to the pan for some stir-fry daddy was whipping up. It was delicious and the kids loved eating it because they grew it.
Now we get to flip it around to the other side and grow some more. Yay!
Definitely a neat, easy project for the whole family. It's pretty cost effective too. If I had been around for the cutting, I would have tried just cutting off the big mushrooms - not the whole "shelf" and letting the smaller ones grow larger. That would have increased our yield, I bet - something to think about at least.
Keeps the ribbon (Garter) snakes at bay. Haven't had any issues with poisonous species so unsure as to the affect on them. Good enough for me.
I Love it.
Looks beautiful this year.
summary: Got 2 of these. Love them, very full...

reviewText:
It arrived slightly dented and scratched. The materials are exceedingly flimsy. Rest assured, before assembly is complete you would have added more dents and scratches, it is unavoidable..

Assembly: Despite my scepticism, once assembled it was pretty sturdy. Assembly requires placing numbered parts together. The problem is all the parts are not numbered, so there had to be some guess work. Assembly definitely requires two people and takes about six hours. (Be sure to use the small plastic washers on every screw to create a water-tight seal and prevent rust.) Take careful note of the door track installation -- you dare not get it wrong. Despite contradictory video on their web site the floor assembly is done last and is placed inside the structure after it is assembled. To install the plywood floor you need to slide it in and put the narrow end in first (on the left side when facing the shed), then lower the right side. Do not attempt to put the rear end in first, you will damage the unit. On completion i had a bag full of screws, nuts and bolts left over. (My guess is they supply enough also to cover a larger shed.) It is not ideal for placement flush against a fence. The unit was assembled and then needed to be moved. (Not a big deal.) Despite all precautions, the door does not slide easily and the door handle does not align with the corresponding fixture on the door jam. (I've probably done something wrong but cannot figure it out.)

Value for money: Depending on how long it lasts, it is excellent value for money. The floor frame kit, by comparison, is hopelessly overpriced.

Overall: It is proving to be very useful and has a good appearance. I do not like the dark roof which makes it absorb heat. I would much have preferred it had the roof been white. I am almost tempted to paint the entire unit immediately to prevent rust. The walls are so thin that rust would immediately imply a hole and it already has several scratch marks where rust could set in. A paint job would be bound to improve its longevity. reviewText: Perfect!

We have just recently received and assembled this composter.  We ordered two as we intend to have one "cooking" as we load the second one.

First the bad news.  Shipment of the product was less than idea as both boxes appeared to have been to hell and back.  Parts were actually sticking out of one box and as we carried the box inside, additional parts fell out of the box.  Surprisingly and to our benefit, no parts were actually missing..  This may be more of an issue with the shipping facility.  The major negative issue is the assembly.  There are a significant number of holes that need to be drilled (approximately 80).  While the manufacturer did provide "dimples" as to where the drilling should occur, how difficult would it have been for the manufacturer to have pre-drilled all the required holes?  Another issue is that steps #2.8 and #2.9 are in the wrong sequence.  It makes much more sense to perform these two steps between 2.22 and 2.23.  This would eliminate step 2.10.  Another issue is that at times this is a two person job, specifically when assembling parts to the side panels.  The instructions should make this clear.  As mentioned before we purchased two of these products.  It required over four hours to assemble the first, and about three hours to assemble the second.  We are not inexperienced in assembling items.

The good news:  Once assembled the product seems to be very stable and solid.  Assuming we use it properly it will completely satisfy our requirements.  The large (and removable) hinged door will work quite well as we can position our little trailer underneath and dump out all the compost in one fell swoop.

The quality of this product is a five.  The assembly is a two at best.  I lowered the rating to a four as the assembly is a one time thing.
summary: Great product but hard to assemble

reviewText:
My Peppermint Willow, which I planted in April, began to show signs of stress 2 weeks after planting.  I live in San Francisco, near Ocean Beach where there is no soil but sand, sand everywhere. My neighbor mentioned that water just drain straight through the sand and won't spread around the base of the tree.  Even watering the tree twice a week about 25 gallons each time (with a water bag) didn't seem to help the stressed tree. It was time to try something different.

I've began to use the wetting agent a week ago by putting 3 tablespoons in the 25 gallon water bag.  After 2 weeks, the tree is showing signs of improvements.  New leaves are visible and the remainder leaves are not as dry and brown looking.  The directions indicate using more wetting agent but I am being conservative as this stuff is expensive.
summary: It works - Helped revive a peppermint willow tree planted in a sandy area near the ocean

I really want to give perennial rye grass five stars, but I just can't. Perennial rye will germinate very quickly in most situations, and will grow more vigorously than most other types of grass (please note that I am located in the upper midwest), but it has it's drawbacks. This type of grass tends to grow much faster than fescue or bluegrass. Unless your lawn is all ryegrass, any patching done with perennial rye will need to be mowed more often. You often hear the recommendation that you should never remove more than 1/3 of the length of the grass when mowing; well with perennial rye, you would need to mow every other day if that's your criteria (no, I am not kidding). By mid-summer, this rye will go completely dormant, or even die if temperatures are too high for too long.

After many years, I've come to the conclusion that fine fescue is probably the best choice for lawns in my area. Fescue doesn't need to be mown as often, and seems to survive sun, shade, and warm weather better than rye. Yes, fescue takes longer to get established, but once it is, it's lower maintenance. Your mileage may vary; depending on where you live, other varieties may be better for you.
summary: Try in a small area before planting large areas with perennial rye.

I needed something to lay in some firewood for my wood stove in my motorhome. (Yes, I actually have a cast iron stove installed.) It doesn't take a lot of wood to heat up the inside of the motorhome, but the labor involved using a handsaw and axe was more than I was accustomed to.

I did not want to purchase a gas chainsaw for a number of reasons. I don't like to store gas in the trailer I pull behind my motorhome, and I have found that gas powered chain saws are notorious for not wanting to crank. Trying to keep the motor tuned and running on a gas saw can be a real challenge.

Until I came across this electric saw on Amazon I did not know that battery powered saws had advanced to such a degree. The reviews impressed me, and this saw was less than half the cost of the similar 40 volt chain saw sold by Oregon.

Having used the saw to cut up a large section of oak tree, I can say that I am extremely impressed. The power was significant, and I truly did not discern that this saw was in any way less capable than a similar size gas chainsaw. It cut through the hard oak wood quickly. The chain tensions extremely easily, and is self oiling. The saw has a nice solid feel to it. The weight of the battery is similar to the weight one might have from a small gas engine, and the 40 volt battery has plenty of juice to lay in a good supply of firewood.

After running the battery down, I found that it fully recharged in 90 minutes, which is far quicker than many similar products. I am very happy with this saw. It appears to be a great product, and I am delighted to not have to purchase or store gasoline, or tinker with small engines to keep them running.
