reviewText:
UPDATE:  3/31/15

So for those of you that are late to this party, it originally started out as a 1 star review.  The bridge kept disconnecting and even a replacement did the same.  So what made it go to a 5 star??  Read on.

My review immediately caught the attention of AcuRite/Chaney Instruments Consumer Operations Manager, who reached out to me via email about my experience with this product.  He wanted me to call him back and give him a time where we could actually visit about the problem I was having.  Seriously...what company does this nowadays?  Only the best companies do this.  AcuRite and Chaney DO THIS.  To make it even more astonishing, this cat gives me his PERSONAL CELL PHONE number to call him on.  Which I promptly do and catch him on his way home from a long day at work.  Yet he answers my call (this was after 7:00pm I believe) while driving home and we visit about how to fix this problem.  He tells me that his best tech will be in touch...just give him a time to call.  So I did.  And guess what?  The best tech ACTUALLY calls me at the time I said.  This guy wastes no time and within 2 minutes says, "Yep.  I'm sending out a new unit, I will personally test it for a couple of days, and then will ship overnight."  How awesome is that.  None of this check this, did you do that, what about this...nope.  Just a sure fire answer that a new one is on the way.  Well guess what?  The new one shows up like he promised!  I go through the setup procedures and unfortunately it disconnects again.  Now I'm feeling a little bad...like, there is NO WAY I get 2 defective units.  This problem has got to be on my end.  I reach out to the manager and indicate that something is still not working, he's not happy and the first tech is out sick today, but they have backup experts...oh yes they do :)  In the meantime, I send them my router info, internet connection company info etc...and on the same day I hear from the other expert.  "Mr. Couse, I took the liberty of calling the manufacturer of your router and talking to their tech support and I think we have a solution".  What?  Are you serious??  You called the other company instead of making me do it?  "According to Belkin, you need to reset your router to factory defaults and that should do it."  Now honestly, at this point,I'm like sure...that's like the IT department calling and saying reboot all the time :)  But hey, if this individual took the time to call and wait for Belkin's support team, then I'm all for it.  So she warns me that I'll have do the whole song and dance of setting up my router after the restore, but hey, that's no big deal.  So I do that and BINGO! this bridge has not missed a beat since.

Totally and utterly ridiculous customer service!  I won't put their names here, but I know they pay attention to these reviews...so a big KUDOS TO YOU J, M and V!

Original review posted below:

The only reason one buys this device is to be able to track your "backyard" weather remotely.  Whether it be via their app, or uploading data to wunderground and looking at all of the cool data at that website.

Initially, setup was a breeze.  I followed the directions to a tee and it was up and reporting data to their web based software in no time.  After registering my location with wunderground, I was able to have the station start reporting my data!  Albeit, in 15 minute intervals and not "flash updates" like pricier stations from Davis that send updates every 2 seconds or set intervals that the user chooses.  15 minutes is just fine for my needs however.

After about day 3 of flawless performance, I check my station at work on wundergound and it said "not reporting".  Odd I thought, so when I got home I checked out the bridge and noticed that the 2 blue lights were steady (not blinking) meaning only one of 2 things...it was either downloading another firmware update (it does this when you first register it) or it was rebooting...turns out it was rebooting.  Went to bed a little frustrated, woke up and the unit had started reporting again.

Now tonight, the unit is again not reporting and is apparently stuck in a reboot cycle as I see 2 steady lights for a few minutes, then they blink again, then they go steady and then they blink.

So for now, I'm not sure if I should reboot the bridge which may or may not require me to re-register the device and may cause problems.  Since it sends data to Acu-Rite servers, which are then pushed to wunderground servers, I don't know if the problems lie within the Acu-Rite servers being down or not.  There is some chatter about Acu-Rite servers having issues, which is why they limit the data blast to every 15 minutes rather than seconds or minutes like other companies.

I'm actually more disappointed in this device now after writing the review and "seeing" my words come to life rather than just my head with the experience I am having.

Also be aware that you MUST have an open port on your router for this device to plug into.  It is not wireless connection capable.  So if you've got your smart TV, blu-ray, Xbox, network drive, or others hardwired in, just know you're going to have to make some concessions.

I may give it a few more days to see if it either gets better, or if the servers are the problem.  I've not had any internet issues so I'm a little snarky with Acu-Rite right now.

UPDATE:  3/20/15

The device continues to fail to connect and update data.  The lights stay solid...then flash...then solid...then flash.  For whatever reason, this device worked great for 3 days and then has crashed and burned.  I've reset the modem, the router and this device to no avail.  I'm convinced it is the device or their servers that are causing the problems as none of my other internet connected devices (whether it be cabled to the router or wireless) are having any issues except this device.

You'll see the WU site indicating that "this PWS is not reporting"...it should actually read "this POS is not reporting"
summary: Unfreaking-believable customer service!  READ THE ENTIRE REVIEW TO UNDERSTAND the context.

What did I do before I found this product for my gardening?  I live in an area with hot, dry summers and the whole watering thing was such a burden, I did little gardening.  Once I found these granules that absorb water and gradually release it into the soil, the watering has been reduced to a manageable level.  A good watering will plump the granules up so they can do their job over time and relieve me from having to hold the hose endlessly.

You do have to be careful not to add too much of the product and to work it well into the soil.  An over-eager addition in a new vegetable garden once, followed immediately by an abundant rain, left a layer of gel on the surface, which didn't help my plantings.  I learned my lesson however, and follow package directions now.  This is a great product and really helps keep a lovely and fruitful garden in dry conditions.  It's also super when planting new shrubs, as they will get a better start because of the gradually released moisture.  The granules in the soil last quite a long time.  I haven't had to add more to my garden in three years.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: We used this product when taking safari tours in Negril, Jamaica. Not one bug bite the whole week. As a matter of fact, my sister-in-law came into our resort room just after we applied it and were about to leave. She asked what kind of good smelling room deodorizer we were using. Bug Spray ! You're Kidding !

Outstanding!!!  Yes, it is that good of a method for controlling Jap Beetles.  I have an orchard of 22 fruit trees.  The Jap Beetles seem to LOVE Cherry and Plum trees foremost, and they like apple and peach somewhat less.  They also LOVE grapes.  I've used insecticides with limited success.  Having too much ground to cover with a ground/grub based insecticide, spraying the trees was what I though was the next best option since the trees are too big to capture the ravenous bugs by hand.  But again, spray only worked so well and usually only for a short time.  Trees were still being eaten alive.  So I bought 6 of these traps and put them on the fence line on the north side (wind is predominately from the southwest).  BINGO!!!  I've been dumping the captured bugs in soapy water by the 10's of thousands.  And there are only stragglers left on the tree which are not a problem.  I plan to buy even more of these now that I've implemented this wonderful solution.  Note:  the accordion bottom detaches easily from  the upper part and you can dump the bugs into soapy water and then reattach.  EASY EASY EASY!!!  The bad models might work but if you don't dump them daily then the dead bugs will start stinking and defeat the lure.  Try this product and you'll see how well they work.  I can't say enough good about this trap.  I wish they were a bit less expensive but I am planning to buy several more anyway!
summary: These traps absolutely are saving my fruit tree orchard and my grapes too!!!  OUTSTANDING PRODUCT!

reviewText:
Nobody likes to admit that they have a rat problem.  My neighbor on one side calls rats "those really BIG mice".  Hmmm.  I think you mean "rats".  My neighbor on the other side says "I saw *your* rat walking on *my* wall again last night".  Good grief.  C'mon man, that structure between our homes is "our" wall (yours and mine!).  And unless you see a collar with my phone number on it, the rats walking on *our* wall must be *our* rats.

So yeah, rats happen.

I've tried lots of different solutions.  Poison bait is probably the most effective for controlling them in the yard, but that's really risky when there are pets in the yard.  So non-poison bated traps are the safest solution for us, as long as we keep the traps away from areas where the pets can get to them.  I don't like traditional traps though, because they're risky to set, tricky to bait, and not especially effective.  Many times I've found the bait missing and the trap still set--or even the trap sprung but no dead rat.

I really like this trap though.  It's very easy to bait the trap BEFORE you arm it.  There's a hole in the top jaw that lets you fill the bait cup.  Once the bait is in place, just push down on the arming lever to latch the spring down.  Make sure the trap is where you want it first, because it's too dangerous to move it once it's set.

I've experimented with different baits.  I first tried creamy peanut butter.  That was OK, but it dries out after a few days and isn't as effective.  Then on a lark I tried a spoon full of gunk from my barbecue's drip pan.  It looks pretty gross, but I know that rodents are really interested in the grill.  This works great.  I've had very good luck reloading the trap with BBQ drippings and reusing it.

I've also had mixed success with lemon wedges.  The biggest attraction for rodents in our yard is our lemon tree.  They love the vitamins from the lemon peels.  I don't think the lemons put out the same smell as the food drippings though.

Anyway, this trap is really effective.  I've never seen the bait taken without the trap catching its prey.  And the trap's jaws are wickedly strong. It's a quick (but messy) end to Mr. Rat.

Killing the rats one at a time like this is slow business, but I've definitely seen their numbers decrease.

We also used zip ties to secure the shelving to the structure.  It doesn't take up a lot of space but provides plenty of room for about 8 dozen or more seed pots.

I waited to give this review. We had ants, termites and fleas we needed to deal with. We got the Hb and the Sc verities. The Hb is listed as good for termite queens, ants, and adult fleas as well as many others. Hb stands for Heterorhabditis bacteriophora.

I applied as soon as we received the nematodes and used them in a bit more concentrated then then was directed. The termites we had in an old tree and one wall haven't been seen since. The cat didn't have any fleas to speak of for ages despite this being a major flea area.

The ants have been our major pest. Since we moved here we had been feeding them borax and sugar or Aspartame. Despite continually poisoning them they just kept coming. Found out we have Argentine Ants that have multiple queens making it next to impossible to wipe them out.  Long story short the ants disappeared for months. Not a single ant for months. We couldn't believe it hardly. Talked to the neighbors who all have ants and have been poisoning and or trapping them with no end of the battle in sight. They all wanted to know about the beneficial nematodes. At least two neighbors are planning on getting some after hearing about us not having them for almost a full year.

We applied it in the middle of May and only now next January are we finally seeing ants again. We will be buying more in a month or two as the weather gets a bit warmer. Worked incredibly well.

UPDATE 2018: Still loving these things. I have been getting more every 1 to 1 1/2 years and have always had them arrive alive and healthy judging by how quickly the bugs disappear. I really recommend these if your having issues with the pests these are listed as attacking.
summary: WOW. Sold for life. Got rid of our ants, fleas, and termites.

I used one of these in each of two separate grills to make a sort of poor man's smoker. I filled the baskets with unlit charcoal, placed them on one side of my grill's charcoal grate, then put about seven well lit coals on top of each basket. The result was a slow burn that never got too hot and stayed in the 225-350 degree range for a couple hours - could have gone longer if I had not been opening the lid frequently after the first 30 minutes or so. I use the Old Smokey 22" grills. Granted, I could have achieved mostly the same effect without the basket, but the basket makes for easy concentration, containment, and placement of the coals, with very easy cleanup. Also, I believe putting the two baskets together (long sides joined) and filling both with lit coals would give you a very high heat area directly above for searing, yet still give you room to the sides for indirect heat (at least on a 22" grill). Hopefully these last as well as my Weber charcoal chimney, which is going on six years with no real signs of wearing out.

Update 10.16.2016: Killed 3 mice in the last 3 weeks, 1 mouse per week for 3 weeks in a row. During the summer months there is not much of a mouse problem, and also the rat snakes take out any nest or mice anyway. But temps have fell off. This trap is sitting there forgotten, no bait, but still plugged in. When i walked into my dark shop, I seen the blue light flashing and heard the buzzer signalling a kill. I was hurrying so just dumped the dead mouse and reset. It killed two more with no bait. Bumping to five stars.
My thinking is that when they come the factory, there must be a oil residue to protect from rust or was on the metal used to build. Once that wears off with humidity or wear,this trap becomes far more lethal.
_______________________________________
update:October 2016. Went into my shop and the blue light was blinking. I checked and sure enough, a mouse is in there dead.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Killed one mouse March 21, 2016 update changed from 1 star to three stars
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
UPDATE December 29 2015: The company contacted me and sent me a 99% off coupon to try the trap again. Once it is here. I will update again.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
UPDATE: February 15, 2016: The company did send me a new trap with a 99% discount. So once again I placed it in my garage with bait around the trap as well as  inside the trap leading to the bait tray, and once again all bait is eaten except for what it is in the trap's bait tray. This indicates that the trap does shock, but does not kill the mouse. So to further the experiment, I bought brand new , yet old fashioned snap traps and placed around the garage including one right beside this $70 zapper. Every snap trap has a mouse in it, yet the Zapper is still empty with the bait still inside. I place bait inside the trap but before the bait cup and that bait is gone. I wish this trap would work, but it just will not kill mice.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
First day the bait was gone in less than an hour. No mouse. Just dusty mouse foot prints.
Two hours later, bait gone again and no mouse killed. Mouse foot prints.
Read the reviews here trying to find a tip, and did stating to clean the trap well incase of oil residue. Another tip said to place a wet paper towel in front of it. So, I placed more bait in the trap and put the wet paper towel in front of the trap so the mouse has to walk over the wet paper towel to walk into trap but bait was gone,and dirtier foot prints in trap.
Next I switched to peanut butter so the mouse would take longer and be touching moist peanut butter that may conduct electricity better. Still no mouse. At $69.00 this is the worse purchase I have made. I returned it today for a refund. I am going back to the standard 50 cent snap trap which I hate. But it works and this trap does not.
summary: Killing mice regularly now. Bumping to five stars

Ola Gjeilo's Stone Rose [Hybrid SACD] Offers Blissful Piano Music Deeply Rooted in Nature, Cities and People. The album contains poignant pieces that resonate with purity, complemented by flugelhorn, violin and cello. Even the song titles are as fresh and unpretentious as the music itself. Available as an award-winning Hybrid from Grammy-winning Norwegian producers, 2L. Stone Rose heralds the arrival of a remarkable new talent in the new age piano music world. Cuddling up to watch a peaceful snowfall, reveling in the sanctuary of an empty church, taking respite in the quiet of a city park; these are the soothing gifts Gjeilo gives with his solo piano debut, Stone Rose, which entered the New Age music market in 2008. Stone Rose is like a musical garden, an empathic glimpse into Gjeilo's heart. In the years during his early success as a composer and concert performer, Gjeilo internalized and processed memorable landscapes, cities and people, finally channeling them into musical expressions. Inspiring, passionate, sensitive, these many forms of love provided the groundwork for the intuitive compositions he presents in Stone Rose. Recorded by GRAMMY-nominated Norwegian label 2L in an old church in Oslo, Norway, one senses the soulful resonance of the old wood, hushed tones, and smooth cool stone floors beneath the recordings. Gjeilo's works seem to float freely in their own time, sometimes playful, other times introspective, always unhurried. His composition style for Stone Rose was improvisational, composing by ear and fitting music to subject, whether it was his mother or New York's Hudson River; in fact, in "The Hudson," they were one and the same. Through his publicist, Beth Ann Hilton of The B Company, Gjeilo explains, "Fort Tryon Park by the Hudson River in New York is where I sometimes go to rest and rejuvenate; the water there has a very flowing quality that reminds me of my mother and our shared love of the water. I remember there was a glimmer on the water that day, which you might hear in the music." His gentle, sincere style has matured from a musical pedigree that includes London's Royal College of Music and The Juilliard School of Music, following an early education in jazz and classical piano at the Norwegian Academy of Music in Oslo, Norway. Entertaining and relaxing, this warm and reflective piano music is subtly accented by flugelhorn, cello and violin played, respectively, by Tom Barber, David Coucheron and Johannes Martens. Listeners having "one of those days" will find solace in the same place as those looking for a unique love song, in the musical garden of the Stone Rose. "In Norway, I grew up in appreciation of nature," Gjeilo explains, adding "`Snow in New York' reflects the magical quiet I felt upon waking to the snow falling like a hush in New York City; `Roxbury Park' captures the tranquility I felt in this little park I'd go to relax near my place in L.A." The quicker, lighter "Michelle" is quite playful, capturing the romantic love he felt for his girlfriend, he adds, and "Madison" is a tribute to a beautiful Christmas holiday spent near Madison, Wisconsin. Distributed in the United States by Naxos, the album is a Hybrid Super Audio CD (SACD), presenting 15 tracks in spectacular Stereo and 5.1 Surround Sound; of course, it also plays as a normal CD. Of the high-tech recording process, 2L founder Morten Lindberg says, "Recording music is an art of illusion. As recording engineers we need to do exactly the same as any good musician; interpret the music and the composer's intentions and adapt to the media where we perform." Suzanne Doucet of Only New Age Music, Inc. predicted, "Ola's beautiful music will be embraced by a variety of audiences, and especially those who enjoyed George Winston in the early days of Windham Hill." Upon early review, Capt. Christopher of WTUL Radio noted "Pianist Ola Gjeilo connects with listeners at many levels...all of them at the peak of perfection. His sensitive and tender keyboard stylings are the ideal accompaniment for an evening of romance, relaxation or fine dining..." Gjeilo is excited by the prospect of playing to small audiences in his beloved new home, New York City. Performances are announced [...]. "I love New York with all my heart. It's almost like a person to me, it has a very strong identity and soul," says Gjeilo.
summary: Stone Rose...by Any Other Name?  Unique Must-Have Music

So far only the violet shades have flowered(several Bi-color) , but i can tell by leaf shape i have 100s of mixes coming. Seeds ARE viable, I have ordered this mix several times and give away 100s of seedlings so many germinate. I will attach a photo of a first year bloom picture taken today 8/2/2016 from seeds sown indoors the 3rd week of may and planted outdoors the second week in June.  I do not top first year and i have several over 6 feet tall 1 plant is 7. The plant pictured is about 5 feet tall with several branches, and the bloom isn't even finished.... anyone questioning their zone I live near Buffalo NY(you may have heard of our weather) and my butterfly bushes from these very seeds are monstrous. And for goodness sake on the bad reviews, these seeds are so easy. Here is a cheap way. If your water is bad, buy some, tiny seedlings don't like bad water. Buy a window greenhouse(brand who cares) expand the pellets as directed and lightly break up surface of peat with tooth pick, drop 5 seeds on top of each peat pellet spray with fine mist of good water. put lid on greenhouse, place under at least a 100watt comparable cfl or any florescent grow light. keep the temp btwn 70-80F (trust me ive gone hotter and things are ok, but keep it around 75) . leave the light on 24/7 and in 7-10 days ull see tiny seedlings sometimes they sprout faster sometimes slower. when you can easily see leaves remove humidity dome and keep peat moist, if it dries out you're done. Or better yet cut holes in humidity dome to allow a balance of humidity and ventilation. once they reach about an inch tall they should have several sets of leaves. trim the peat pellet down to 1-3 seedlings and from there its real easy. The apex bloom on this branch is 13 inches long and still not fully opened. This plant was grown from these seeds this spring, and i have plenty of pictures.
summary: Awesome germination ratio!... If you cant work with small seeds don't write a negative review. Learn how to handle the product.

I put most of the review in on the flooring kit but the shed itself is exactly as expected for it's cost and as based on the reviews of others.  What they do not tell you are small things that anyone who has built a metal shed before will know.  You'll want plenty of silicon sealant (the tube stuff you squueze out with the gun attachment).  We built the shed and sealed mostly as we went along but still need to do the roof venting area in a few spots.  Some of the venting is deliberate so as to keep the unit cool on a hot day but there were a few spots where rain may enter if not closed off a little bit more.

If you want an inexpensive yet nice looking small shed, this one is a winner.  Using a handyman (who had never built this brand metal shed before) and us to hand him tools or hold parts as directed, we finished in about 5 hours.  We had a cordless drill that also does the screws and that was a major timesaver as there are a lot of them as you can guess.  Our handyman said that now that he has done one unit of this manufacturer, it would take him about 3.5 hours to do another of the same class if he had owners who are able to hold parts in place and are tool savvy DIY types just unfamiliar with this particular project.  He said add 1 hour if he had to do it alone and add 2 hours if the owners were not experienced and got underfoot while 'trying to help' (grin).

What you will also want is a ramp if you intend to roll a lawnmower up into it as it will sit about 4.5 inches up if you use the proper flooring kit.  You can get them pre-made or if handy, I knocked one together with spare wood in about 45 mins.
Vibrant color weather proof
What I expected and I sized it right.

The Nitrogen test doesn't work at all for me, and that's what I really needed.  It showed "Depleted" (aka no nitrogen reaction).  I thought that was odd since I heavily fertilized last fall and now my lawn was the greenest in the neighborhood.  But I trusted it and fertilized with a high rate of 34-0-0.  Two weeks (and 2.3" rain) later I tested again and it showed "Depleted".  ??  Now I lost trust and added some of my 34-0-0 pellets to the soil solution and let them dissolve.  I tested again and still no Nitrogen!  I attached those pictures.  What gives?
Perhaps it's because of the color of my soil.  You will see in the pictures that even after I followed the directions and let my solution set 24 hours, yes 24 painful hours of muddy water in the kitchen, even then the water was very brown.  Maybe the tester fails to produce a strong enough color change to read.

Edit: I emailed LusterLeaf and they think it might take more time for Nitrites to convert to Nitrates.  They also say I should wait longer than 24 hours and see if the water clears up.
summary: Will not test Nitrogen for me.

Got the tank two days ago, opened the box, and saw a sturdy metal tank--like old school tanks.  I thought, WOW!, this is great.  BUT then I saw the CHEAP, FLIMSY, WOBBLY, PATHETIC 2.5 inch PLASTIC pump and reality set in.  The pump is as cheap and junky as anything I have ever seen.  I gave this TWO STARS for the tank, but the pump gets ZERO STARS.  I use pumps extensively and hate the plastic pumps in the Home Depot plastic pumps in their sprayers.  But this pump makes them look like winners.  Words fail me in describing how disappointing the cheap POS is.  When you try to pump, the shaft bends, flexes, deflects to the sides and only shoots a tiny bit of air into the tank with each pump.  Did I say JUNK?  If you are going to build a sturdy metal tank, why would you put such a worthless plastic pump in it?  Remember when the pumps were metal and you could replace the rubber grommet on the end of the pump?  That wouldn't have cost them much more and face it, we would pay another $5 to get a metal pump.  I know I am venting to the choir but why does cheap always win out?  The sprayer wand isn't much good either.  The long metal part of the wand comes loose from the metal nozzle near the handle unless you really crank it down.  I usually trust Stanley when I buy tools but from now on, I will check it out first.  Thing is, I know the pump is going to break.  It isn't "if" it is "how soon."  I am thinking about ordering a new one now for when it does break.  Stanley, you can do better.

THREE USES LATER: After using the sprayer three times this is what I have found.  The wand attaches to the spraying handle by screwing the wand onto a PLASTIC nut.  As other users have noted, no matter how careful you are, the wand loosens and when you screw it back on, it cross threads and won't stay on. IT should have been made with brass. The wand wobbles on the spray handle and sooner or later falls off.
ALSO: The brass spray tip has no way to lock it down so it can move from fine spray to single stream by itself.  It should have been made with a lock nut to hold it in one position.  It is only a matter of time until the shoddy plastic pump breaks off. Stay tuned.

Final solution.  Sent the sprayer back today.  The wand wouldn't stay attached to the sprayer trigger handle any more.  As talked about by several reviewers even though it is a brass wand, the other parts it ATTACHES TO are PLASTIC and not even good plastic.  Since I had read about the cheap plastic parts the wand fastened to I was exceedingly careful and it stripped anyway.  If they wanted to do this sprayer right, they would make the attachment points brass and that includes the spray nozzle which is brass but attaches to cheap plastic.  I will search for some other type of metal spray tank with a good sprayer but don't hold your breath.  Mr. Sprayer--out!

I received this clock from the manufacturer at no cost for evaluation, and here are my thoughts. I would have loved having this digital calendar clock for my mother before she passed away. The clock has big bright white letters and numbers against a black background that are large enough for a visually impaired person to read, and they clearly spell out the day of the week, time of day, month, day, and year so a person with memory issues can see them and get their sense of bearing. My mom suffered both visual impairment as well as memory issues before she passed away, and not knowing what day of the week it was or the time of day frustrated her to no end. It also made her more anxious and added to her sense of loss of control. If we would have had this clock we could have placed it on her dresser or hung it on the wall by her door so she could see it and it would have helped given her back that one aspect of control at least. This clock comes in a plain white box that doesn't say anything about memory loss or visual aid on it, but it really is perfect for both of those applications, and it's easy to set up. The instructions are well written, understandable, and easy to follow, and the clock is easy to program in mere moments. It comes with a USB power cord and adaptor, so it does need to be plugged in to operate, but it has an internal battery that maintains the time, date, and other settings in case there's a power outage. It can be programed to display the days in English, Spanish, French, Welsh, Danish, or German, the date in US or European mode, and with a simple push of a button it can be switched to display a message such as "This is Monday Morning" etc... The lettering is crisp, bright, and large enough to read with the letters of the week being about 1" tall, the numbers for time being 1.5" high, and the date being about 1/2" in size. The clock has been keeping excellent time, and the display even has an auto-dimming feature that dims the letters each evening around 7p.m. and then brightens them again at about 7a.m. It's a cool looking clock that looks good wherever you put it. It would look good in an office, or be used to help kids learn how to tell time. More importantly though, this digital clock is a terrific assistive device for the visually impaired, the psychologically disoriented, and those suffering from cognitive issues secondary to stroke, traumatic brain injury, NPH, Alzheimer's, or age related impairment.
summary: Excellent assistive device for the visually impaired or elderly

Clues for bug zappers! The grid develops nasty voltage that will feel like a gorilla tried to jerk your arm off it touched!

So when you let the button go, the resistors are designed to drain the voltage quickly so you don't inadvertently touch the screen and get zapped after the button is already released...... problem is.... this resistance drain does not start when button is released but is actually wired so its connected all the time.
So as long as the button is pressed, the resistor is attempting to drain the voltage from the screen but its being replenished by the battery till released..... moral of the story.......

If you want your zapper to last, DON'T KEEP THE BUTTON PRESSED FOR EXTENDED PERIODS! Don't walk around the house in hunt mode with the button pressed the whole time.....

I simply use the trigger like a gun and don't press it till I'm actually swiping at the fly then I release immediately. Not only does this preserve battery, it prevents internals from overheating and gives a fresh zap from the battery that's at peak voltage.

I've used mine for years now... occasionally I lightly steel wool the metal grids to keep pristine clean for max zapping but otherwise its a great tool.
If you get it wet, sling out the water and don't use it till the next day or you "will" short it out.

If a fly is on a surface, don't slam the swatter down on the surface like a conventional swatter or it won't last long, instead swipe "over" the fly a couple of inches as you know the fly will see you coming and attempt to escape then it will be in your path and "zap!"

Without some practice, a conventional swatter you slam down is more effective, but with a little practice you'll be able to nab them in flight as well as on surfaces.
Its quite entertaining in a morbid sort of way to see them vaporize and be sentenced to a fiery death for being such a pest that they are...

I also wanted to mention, this has "C" cell batteries vs the more common AA batteries with most other zappers..... much more amperage to deliver the higher punch and keep it coming without a battery voltage drop!

Another note, zappers with straight wire grids like this one work better than the criss-cross type..... this will come in contact with the bug much better for a clean zap. The wires are alternately charged positive and negative and when the bug bridges the connection he's toast. The criss-cross type is not so effective so this is a better design.

I purchased this mower in July 2009 and have been using it ever since. I affectionately call it my "mower-chopper-shredder" as it is the toughest little lawnmower I have ever had. I needed a mower light enough for a female senior citizen to handle.  This is it!  My grown son moved away and the gas propelled mowers (all 6) needed more muscle and know-how than I had.  The self propelled ones were too heavy to turn or manage on a slope.  I hope they found good homes after I put them on the curb.  This B&D lawnmower crunches tree roots, pine cones, cane shoots, vines of every description, and does a beautiful job on the lawn where it exists.  It is so light and maneuverable I can do the whole job myself.  Handling the cord is just a matter of know-how.  Even 100+ feet of extension cord adds little to the chore. I purchased a spare blade to put on, but haven't needed it yet.  Beyond that there is NO MAINTENANCE. It is still working perfectly, just waiting for the 2012 season, which will be long and hot and challenging.  This mower gets my highest recommendation.  I intend to replace it, when the time comes, with another just like it!

reviewText:
I HAD a "BAD" problem with mosquitos (West-Nile fever...!)! I web searched for a bug killer... that would work!
Top choices, for me-
1. Propane powered models/traps...- High-maintenance, bulky, heavy, expensive (about $300+... for "top-rated" models!), 5 gallon propane tank lasts only about 30 days ($OUCH!), fire danger..., then you end up with a messy net full of mosquitos (still alive?)!
Too much of a HASSLE...! NOT for me!

2. Electric bug zappers- I read SERVERAL web reviews saying that these types of low-maintenance "electric" bug zappers would not attract mosquitos (My old Flowtron did not!)?
a. I reviewed the Stinger UV40. THIS WORKS!!! (I recommend getting at least the 40w (1 acre)! Only $7 more than the puny  looking 15w. The 80w "looked" AWESOME?!-
It comes with a mosquito bait lure- "Octenol (a USDA tested mosquito lure) cartridge included".
They recommend replacing it every 30 days (I replace mine "when" it stops drawing mosquitos. $5 @ Wal-M).
The Stinger unit has a place DIRECTLY UNDER the light, to place the Octenol lure- The fumes rise up and draw the mosquitos in to the electric zapper grid. Was this just "sales hype"?
#1$Wal-M & Lowes have liberal return policies. I decided to "give it a try"?
Every morning there WERE "hundreds" of dead mosquitos on the patio, under the Stinger!!!
Some environmentalists claim bug zappers "may" also kill helpful insects?-
All I've ever found, are LOTS of dead mosquitos & moths!

Some helpful tips-
1. Do not mount near doors... (draws "swarms" of insects!). Hang it 7ft high (head room).

2. As a test to see when it stopped zapping (temperature)?- I left mine on all night, and checked it frequently (I'm a night person), to see when it stopped zapping? We "usually" have cool evenings- it stopped zapping at about 1am. Does nothing "before" dark!
I put mine on a timer (I will adjust settings, as temperatures...  change)!!!

3. For easy cleaning (only once in awhile)- Instructions say- you can blow it off with the exhaust side, of a vacuum cleaner?
I blow mine out with an inexpensive air compressor (if you don't have one, you should! Lots of uses!).
I would "not" recommend turning a water hose on it (electronic parts/shock hazard...!)!

4. They recommend that after a year- Even though UV bulb still glows, it loses its effectiveness, and stops drawing many insects. I will "then" "easily" replace the UV bulb ($12 @ Wal-M).
ENJOY!

I just bought my fourth Nelson 50503 High Pressure Sprayer in about 9 years.  The first one lasted about 6 years, and then I have gone through about one every year since.  They are heavily built, and feel very solid, but they fail way too often.  The reason I keep buying them is they are the only spray head that will deliver the water flow that I need with my hose setup.  I tapped in to the same water source that feeds my in-ground sprinkler system.  This tap is BEFORE the 75 PSI regulator that controls pressure to the house.  This makes a big difference in having a garden hose and sprayer that will actually get some work done.

I have 3/4 inch copper pipe that enters the house from the city.  I think pressure is 120 or 130 PSI.  From the 3/4 inch feeder I tapped in with 1" pipe, and use nothing but 1 inch pipe, with one inch fittings, including a 1 inch shut-off valve.  I did this since many of the 3/4 valves actually do not have a full 3/4 inch flow, so you never get the full use of the 3/4" pipe.  That is why I went with 1 Inch.  Then I use a very heavy 3/4 inch garden hose, and then the Nelson Spray head.  This is the only head that will handle the water flow, and it works like a champ.  The issue is the quality.  When it works, it works well, but I have had 3 failures in about 3 years, all of them different type of failures, including leaking, handle breaking and then the last one just fell apart all of a sudden.  Weird.

I would change brands, but this is the only one that actually works, and has about at 60 foot throw, with lots of water.

I feel bad giving it 2 stars, since I like the way it works.  If they did not fail so often it would be 5+.stars.
summary: Works like a champ, but should be more reliable.

reviewText:
The last fabric staples I bought were too thin, dull, and short to be effective.  The reviews on these anchor staples indicated that they might be what I was really looking for, so I took the plunge and ordered a pack to use with a commercial weed block/ground cover around our home in Southwest Florida.  Good decision on my part!

First off, these are a much heavier (11) gauge, the points are sharp enough to pierce commercial ground cloth, and they are long enough to anchor the weed barrier to the ground.  A smart and well-executed design.  Prior to using these, I made my own anchors by cutting pieces of old wire hangers into an "L" shape and pushed those through the fabric.  The anchor staples I just bought are far superior to my homemade product and are a good deal as far as price.

In order to get the best life and use out of your ground cloth, consider the following tips.  First off, make sure to NOT pull the ground cloth tight before anchoring it down.  Chances are that you are going to have to walk on it while doing future maintenance and leaving it loose will give your ground cloth flexibility to move and lessen your chances of tearing it.  This is especially true if you end up using landscape stones and step on them.  I also use a heavy duty stapler to fasten the ground cloth to the vertical sides of any wood timbers I might use for framing.  Just remember to keep the cloth somewhat loose.  This will keep weeds from sprouting up between the cloth and the wood.

The other thing I try to do is to not only minimize the number of staples I use, but to also fold a piece of the cloth over the staples before covering it with the stones or mulch.  ANY hole in your landscape cloth can let in seeds the either float in or are dropped by birds or other animals, so minimizing the points of intrusion will work in your favor.  If you can, or as much as you can, avoid walking on your landscaped areas to minimize tearing.  .

The 3rd year (2015) I started having problems opening and closing the umbrella (the tilt still worked fine).  I had to now assist the opening and closing by using one hand to crank and the other to get it started by pushing up or pulling down on where the umbrella slides up/down the shaft.  And the 4th year (2016), it requires that I not only help start it, but I must push the area that slides manually up and down while cranking it the whole time, otherwise it won't move and feels like the rope will snap or something will break if I don't help it along.  It's difficult to do this and it no longer opens/closes just by using the crank.

This is not a cheap umbrella, for it to only last 2 years is horrible.  I don't want to purchase a new umbrella every 2 years.  I would suggest you look for another umbrella.

reviewText:
I own and live on a rather large place in the middle of the woods and fields.  The four acres we maintain includes a large vegetable garden, numerous flower gardens and a modest orchard.  Over the years we have found that hoses we need...lots of hoses!  We have had and do have several Stanley hoses and have been delighted with each and every one of them.  The one being reviewed here is no different.

As a matter of fact, this heavy duty hose is one of the best we have and if you consider hoses in this price range it is by far THE BEST of the lot.

This is built from heavy duty material and there simply is no kinking.  The couplings, which are indeed one of the major problems with hoses in general, are very heavy duty on this one and if the washers are changed out seasonally I see no reason this hose will not last four quite a number of year.  As a matter of fact the last Stanley hose we owned lasted for six years and would still be working as it should had I not run the lawn tractor over it while mowing...sigh.

I would be hard pressed to find anything to complain about with this hose.

It should be noted that the price here is about five dollars less than what we can find at our local stores.
summary: Difficult to find anything to complain about with this hose

I had lower back disk fusion surgery 3 months ago. In my post-surgical state I have trouble bending and lifting heavy objects. But I can work the Toro Power Shovel! I bought it with low expectation, thinking that either it will not work well or that I will have trouble with it due to my current physical limitation. Surprisingly, neither concern materialized. Toro easily chopped through 10 inch snow bank left from 18 inches that fell a few days ago, and I was able to push it through the snow as well as move it up and down the stairs to the house. In some areas I was able to push it one handed which was an easier position on my back, and sometimes I needed the second hand to get through a tougher spot. The handle is adjustable so with the highest position I don't have to bend too much. Wet snow update: I am updating this review after the first wet snow. Toro power shovel handled it well! It was a little harder to push, but I found that I could brace the handle on my thigh and that allowed me to push with my leg rather than my injured back. Then it was easy! The hardest thing to deal was not the show shovel itself, but the 100 feet of electric cord, which was heavy, unwieldy and became almost unmanageable to coil back, especially when it became cold and covered with snow. The electric caddy was not much help, it was hard to control. Putting back the cord tired me out more than shoveling itself. I found that the Toro power shovel was stable without having to lean it against a wall when I put it a big plastic storage bin (see picture). This way when I bring the shovel in and the snow melts I will not have a puddle on the floor. The caddy with the electrical cord fit nicely on top of the shovel in the bucket (see picture). This product is build for a right-handed person. Update: I found a solution for an electric cord winding - it is called Green Leaf WW-1 Wonder Winder Hand Crank: Green Leaf WW-1 Wonder Winder Hand Crank Extension Cord Winder Ali Julia review
summary: Easy to operate even with a back problem

This is my 3rd one of these types of pools in 10years.  I usually get a few years out of each pool, had one season where I went to a hard plastic rim pool but it was a project to take down in the fall.  This one is as simple as it gets and you really want a 18-20 ft round pool.  It is imperative that your ground is level and you flatten out the bottom of the pool before filling.  While filling ensure the sides are out to the bottom seams, inflate the ring and let the hose do its job.  Fills up nicely, perfect height for my young kids, summer lasts for 3 months in the Northeast and when September comes we drain, dry, fold up and store in backyard in a tarp.  I should mention that I use the regular filter but use the salt water system and it eliminates all of the added expense of adding chlorine, well worth it.

For those who read the countless positive reviews, those reviewers have never used a high quality foamer, or they are coming from using a hose end sprayer, which can't produce the foam without the pressure.

Fact is, this thing costs so much less for a reason.  It's junk.  Sure you see the pictures of foamed up vehicles, but not only is that foam not thick at all, if you could see a video of it, you'd see it running down the side of the vehicle within a minute or two.

A quality foamer may use the same style bottle, but it won't leak or get clogged, and it will produce a very thick, clingy foam that doesn't run down the paint for at least 5-10 minutes, solidly.  Almost like it's sticking on the paint.  This item is basically spraying soapy water with a few extra bubbles.  By the time I got around the truck, the first side was pretty much just wet, no more foam.

And yes, I know how to use these.  I've been doing part-time detailing for man years, and even with the reservoir bottle filled with soap, and the dial set to max, it still didn't make a thick foam.
summary: Pay more money, get more quality.

reviewText: This cover is very well made and durable; the zippers which attach the sides to the front are heavy-duty and open and close with no effort.  It comes in three colors but I ordered the dark green one and it goes beautifully with the cushions on my triple-cushion swing with canopy.  The cover is very heavy so I recommend you keep it on the swing rather than taking it on and off each time you use it.  Instead of folding the front piece and securing it at the front of the canopy as per instructions, after I unzip the sides I pull the entire front piece over the top of the canopy.  I then bring the front edge of each side up to the top and clip each to the front piece--thus allowing free air circulation from each side and the front is completely open.  I position the side pieces to shade the swing from direct sun, so in the a.m. the side facing East is more shaded and in the p.m. the side facing West is more shaded with the cover.  The cover is about 6" too wide and 6" too long for my swing, but this isn't really a problem for me.  I use clips to raise the bottom edge off the ground or pavement.  It is well worth the money and I would recommend it to anyone with a swing--there are cheaper covers available, but in the long-run this is the best value for the money.  The cover makes it possible to use my swing year round and regardless of the weather---and keeps my cushions dry!  There is a ventilation mesh to allow for air circulation to prevent mold and mildew, but it is too low for me to use in this manner. I am able to insure air circulation inside the cover since the bottom is open to the pavement and I usually have the cover open each day unless it is raining hard.  This cover stops having to dry off water-resistent cushions, table top, etc.
summary: Best idea since sliced bread for your swing

reviewText: I saved a ton of money on this mandrel, and it's a quality part. I'm very pleased. The pre-threaded holes made it simple to install too. I recommend and would buy again for my craftsman mower.

Check around, this time of year there may be sales like the one I found at the bullseye place.

A couple tips on assembly:
1. All of the pieces go "right side outward facing" EXCEPT FOR THE BOTTOM, which has the finished side facing the INSIDE of the box. This will make things much easier for your assembly.
2. If you are having problems getting the pieces together, LOOK AGAIN at the instructions, I found it was easy to get mixed up. Once I got them in the right places and facing in the right direction, it snapped together pretty seamlessly and easily, except for the top.
3. For the top, you have to align the three "hinge" sections and then sitting on the top may help to seat at least some of them. Once you get 1-2 of them seated, the rest will pop together more easily, at least that was my experience. I sat on the two end hinge parts and they snapped right in. I sat on the middle one and it did nothing. I got up, pushed down on the middle hinge, and it popped right into place.
4. Remember that the right side has the little string of plastic that will connect to the right side of the top, this helps to keep the sides in the correct place when assembling.
5. I recommend that when you get done, check the corner seams on the inside to see if any of them need another thump/bump to get them into place. A rubber mallet came in handy for this when I finished my assembly.

All in all, I'd hate to bet my life on it, however the seat feels pretty firm. It held the two extra folding chairs that I had bought on sale very nicely on my porch, which was my reason for buying it. So I'm a happy camper....er...decker....er...porcher!
summary: Good for the price here's some assembly tips

reviewText: Overall, this is a pretty good device.  I'm going to tell you what I don't like first, because there's just a couple things I don't like.  Those things might be deal-breakers for some people.  The electronics on this smoker are sketchy, meaning the control panel would sometimes just blink out when I was adjusting the temperature or time settings.  I played with the controls for a while, plugged and unplugged the smoker, and then it started working.  The remote control sometimes turned the unit off when I pushed a button, too.  I sat with the smoker for about 3 of 4 hours while smoking a beef brisket, and the smoker controls never missed a beat thereafter.  The next thing I don't like is having to put pellets (preferred) or chips into the smoker tube every 45 minutes to an hour.  That's ridiculous.  I have a great solution -- use at your own risk -- to defeat this problem.  More on that later.  I also wish the temperature setting would go up to 300 deg F instead of 275 deg F.  The last thing is getting a smoker with glass in front is a waste of time and money and just another thing to worry about if the seal went bad or the glass got broken, in my opinion, of course.  The glass smokes and smudges up so badly so quickly that I wish I had just gotten a 40 inch smoker with no window.  Yes, I know I can clean the glass every time with some white vinegar.  Ok, now to the good.  I love the fact that this unit can be used with a cold smoker.  It has made some fantastic smoked cheese for me in about 2 hours.  I like the fact that the thermostat kicks the unit's heating element back on when the temperature falls 2-3 degrees below the target temperature.  I like all the drip pans and trays.  I like the built in meat probe, altho I bought a separate aftermarket wireless meat probe just to keep the Masterbuilt probe honest.  There is about 9 deg F difference between the 2 probes so far.  I like the fact that this unit is electric, so I don't have to worry (I hope) about it not continuing to heat (compared to running out of propane), unless the power goes out for some reason.  It is rated at 10A @ 120VAC, so be prepared to use some juice while this unit is heating up.  The cold smoke is rated at 1.5A @ 120VAC, as a side note, but you should not be running them both together at the same time UNLESS you want to try something I have done *at your own risk*:  I bought a 6 inch and a 12 inch smoking cube.  I don't care what brand you buy.  I bought what was cheapest while still earning good reviews.  So I don't have to babysit this smoker every 45 minutes to an hour and add pellets, I light up the 6 inch cube for 2 hours smoke, or I light up the 12 inch cube for about 4 hours smoke.  They work very well, and they are pretty consistent for the 2 and 4 hours durations.  I am even thinking about buying a couple more tubes to have them loaded up and ready to light for longer smoking projects.  The only problem I can see with using the cubes is I have to open the door to replace the cubes, and that lets some of the heat and smoke out, but these cubes produce their own heat (helps with the maintaining of internal temp) and smoke so quickly that it really doesn't matter.  The other thing I have done is to shoot smoke in from the cold smoker into the main body of the smoker and not use the chip/pellet tube at all.  The heating element in the smoker itself will heat up the insides, and the cold smoker outside produces the smoke up to about 6 hours has been my experience so far.  Again, do so at your own risk.  I did not have good results using the smoker outside in the wind in cold weather.  Again, do this at your own risk:  I put my smoker right inside the door of the garage so it's protected from the wind on 3 sides (I have machine shed type doors that slide side to side, not up and down), and I opened the door a bit to let the smoke out and some cold air in.  That helps quite a bit.  If I had to do it all over again, I would not buy the 40 incher with the glass front.  I would get the 40 inch with the simplest and most reliable controls as well.  I would also make sure the smoker allows for the addition of the cold smoker.  This is a must, in my opinion.  The cold smoker is soooo great for smoking cheese.
summary: A pretty good unit, but spend less money and buy a Masterbuilt 40 inch without the glass front - 4 stars

I've owned this shredder for about three years -- bought it to grind my weeds and clippings for compost.  The material fed in has to be dry or the outlet chute clogs.  This may be a safety feature, but is also a design flaw.  The chute makes a right angle bend from the shredder body and the output jams up in it.  I have found that the easiest way to grind almost anything is by feeding it into the "branches" port at the back, which seems to give it a better angle into the blades.  I use a 1/4" diameter wooden dowel to push the weeds and twigs into the port, and also to clean out the outlet chute.  Cleaning the chute constantly keeps the shredder from jamming.  Once it jams it has to be disassembled, which is a frustrating and time consuming process.

The best thing about the shredder is that it is electric but the downside to that is the relative lack of power and capacity.

Miracle-Gro Fertilizer Spikes for trees contain the correct amount of nitrogen, phosphate, potash and sulfur for trees. ( according to the University of Minnesota). The various plants and trees (fruit, evergreen, etc.) require differing amounts of those nutrients. I have used Miracle-Gro fertilizers for over 35 years and have complete faith in them. I just finished pounding the Tree and Shrub spikes in for this growing season. The Spikes for Trees is the third types of spikes I have used this spring.
They are easy to put into the ground. Position at the drip line, tap into the ground with a heavy hammer, gently, while holding the plastic tip tightly on the spike, remove the plastic tip to reuse and give the spike a couple more hits to sink it further into the ground and cover with a little soil. Make sure the soil is very soft or the spike will just break apart.
My father was a gardener and orchid grower. He taught me that to have success in growing things, three things are most important: water at the right times, prepare the soil correctly before planting and fertilize as needed. This is good advice and this is a good product.

I have 8 tomatoes in containers and this is an effortless way to provide fertilizer. As you know, the frequent (daily, here in Texas) watering of the containers can easily flush all of the nutrients from the soil but the Jobe's spikes keep up with it. I also supplement with Miracle-Gro for tomatoes and Epsom Salts but rely on the spikes (2 per container) to keep my plants fed.

As an aside, I have 4 containers with cucumbers (Park's Spacemaster 80, highly recommended btw). I put 1 spike per plant into 2 containers as an experiment to see what effect the Jobe's spikes would have. Wow, after only about two weeks the difference was dramatic and I immediately added spikes to the other two cucumbers! And, I also supplement these with Miracle-Gro so it's not like two were fed and two weren't.

If I had tomatoes planted "in the ground," I would probably use one spike per plant assuming that other fertilizer was going to be applied periodically.

Highly recommended!

The Terro's come in 2nd place.  They don't attract as many moths and the glue is the same strength as these it seems.

I put this up on a concrete slab over my BBQ, smoker, outdoor kitchen area. It went up in the spring of 2015. It lasted all summer through many storms. During storms I had to pay attention to it to prevent water from collecting on the roof area. But, for less than $100 I was very happy with the purchase. After the outdoor kitchen shut down for the year in the fall, a huge storm came through and ripped huge holes in the roof. I had reinforced each joint on the poles with white duct tape and secured the framing to a cyclone fence on two sides, and the back side of my garage on another side with plastic zip ties. The framing is still standing.

My neighbor has a collection of cars in expensive canvas outdoor garage tents. His canvas was likewise ripped in that big storm. I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for an inexpensive cover that you don't mind replacing every year.

I am now looking to buy a replacement tent to recover the framing. But am having no luck.
summary: for less than $100 I was very happy with the purchase

reviewText:
For curiosity and practical reasons, I set up a motion-detection wireless cam to watch the cage that I set up in my attic. For two weeks I watched the rat sniff around the cage entrance and almost....almost....almost go inside for the assortment of treats. Maybe the metal (or my human smell) made him suspicious.  He seemed to know something was up.  But finally temptation won over the rat; the trap worked perfectly.  I was somewhat entertained, along with my friends, of my rat vs. trap videos.

I prefer this humane method for a number of reasons.  1) I don't want to have a smelly dead poisoned rat in my attic or walls--a friend had to pay to tear a hole in her drywall to get a dead rat out.  2) I don't want a pet eating a poisoned rat.  3) I don't want to kill anything I don't have to.

Good design and great mechanisms.  It'll last forever, too.  I can see using the same cage for 20 years.  TIP: Save the shipping box from Amazon. It's the perfect size to fit the cage (at least my shipping box was).  I later used it to transport the cage with the rat inside, for cleanliness and to keep the poor rat from being traumatized. You can also set the cage up inside a box.
summary: Rats are Smart but Patience Pays Off

I'm a 60-something homeowner and have killed two other pole saws over time that were just two sections. I hesitated before buying this - would I really use it? Did I really need it? I finally decided that no matter what, I needed a new pole saw. 21 feet was a no brainer, I have a lot of oaks that have lots of little dead branches. I have pines that need limbing up and in the past, I used a ladder strapped to the tree.

No more ladders. Trimming has become fun! I can't say enough good about this saw. I'm rating this on the merits for a homeowner - it's certainly occcasional use compared to any tree professional. But at this it excels. I can use the sickle end to pull dead branches off. The cutting is easy - gravity helps make the downward cut. The length is superb. And to me, the quality shows.

There's no question about it - you have to know how to use it. A hard hat is a must if you are working things above you. Positioning yourself is really important as well as planning for the branch's landing zone. Anticipating what's going to happen when the saw makes it through the branch is the most important thing in terms of handling it and keeping it from being damaged. And at 21 foot extension, it's definitely a workout!

Given all of the above, I can't say enough good about this saw. Used correctly and carefully it's a real workhorse. It's enabled trimming that I never thought I would be able to do without someone climbing the trees. The downside is that I cut so much wood down that hauling it afterwards is the real chore. That's not a bad thing - the trees have never looked better around here!

I like the cover for the blade. I like the locking mechanisms. I like the oval shape. I like the wrapped handle. And lastly, I love the blade itself. It's just amazing compared to the consumer pole saws that I've owned and used. I like the blade so much that I got a Silky hand saw to carry too and it's similarly amazing. Great stuff.

It is too small to hold a wheelbarrow or lawnmower if you want to put anything else inside, but it has eliminated a lot of clutter from my back patio.  In my opinion, this shed is good value for your money.

Good Product. Good Value on Amazon. 18v might seem puny in this new wave of 36-40v cordless technology. This unit has good balance with an 18" scicle bar. Plenty of power in the 1.3 AH battery to run the unit for about 20 min. I have used it extensively on brush. If the stem, ca. 1/2" will fit in the cutter guards, it will cut with a snap. General hedge trimming is an ease and pleasure with this unit. 20-30 min of cutting is all you want to do. Definitely a homeowners tool. Battery takes 3+ hours to charge, with full charge indicator light. By then you will probably want to do something else, anyway. Front handle-grip is the safety trigger switch. When squeezed with trigger pulled on rear handle, the trimmer actuates. Let off trigger or handle-switch and the unit shuts down. Scicle bar can be rotated 45, 90, 180 degrees. Light weight and low vibration for hand fatigue. I would have given it 5 stars; but the unavailability of extra batteries is a negative for me. However, the Li-ion slide-in battery by Black & Decker has the same 3 pin configuration on the battery and tool. Looks like B&D may be the mfg. There is a plastic tab on the B&D that you will have to cut off to use on the charger and tool. And, the pins are barely misaligned, so you will need to carefully make some pin adjustments and shave/trim some plastic around the pins. I did it; works fine. A very nice product and well-designed. Someone will produce an after-market battery soon. If your tired of 2-cycle woes on infrequently used equipment, electric/cordless is the way to go.  And, don't think the 18v systems are puny. Plenty of power and reasonable price. I recommend this mfg, and unit. I don't think you'll be disappointed.

reviewText:
I bought this item as a bit of a lark.  I thought I'd check the temperature of my walls, floors, ceiling and a few hot water pipes, watch a few pans heat up, and then put it in a drawer.

I've now found the product to be indispensable and use it at least once a day.  I have a gas range.  I can check a pan that is heating and get just the right temperature for fried eggs (300 degrees or so) or pancakes (375 degrees.)  I'm no sure how would cook these items without it.  I heat  the cooking scrambled eggs to about 140 degrees at a high gas setting while stirring, and then cut the fire back to minimal to finish the eggs.

I built a new house in the past few years.  I've used the product to determine how well it is insulated and to find air leaks.  Fortunately I've found I don't have any problems.  I took the device to a friends house which is older and we found all sorts of issues including an uninsulated ceiling in one area.

To use the device one holds the trigger in.  There is a laser to help with selecting the target point.  When held an foot away from the target the temperature is sensed from a circle with a diameter of one inch.  The holding the device closer or further away changes the diameter of the sensing zone.  As long as the trigger is held the device continues to measure the temperature, even if it changes.  When the trigger is released the last temperature read is held until the device automatically turns off which is in a minute or so.  This operation is totally intuitive.

I thought of writing this review because I just changed the batteries in the device (September 2013).  I've owned it since February, 2012.  It took a minute tops, to change the two AAA batteries.  I consider this to be excellent battery life given how much I use the device.

Along with the Thermapen thermometer for measuring interior temperatures of food, this product is a must-have for cooking.  The Kintrex thermometer also has other valuable uses around the house.
summary: "I've become accustomed to her face...," an indispensable product

For the longest time, I had three brass hose nozzles.  One in my backyard, one in my front yard, and a floater that went camping, in the RV, etc.  One of those nozzles I purchased from Lee Valley (which I will call #1 for this review), and it was all brass, and I had it for at least 10 years.  The second, or #2, I am not sure where I bought it, and had it for at least 15 years - I am thinking Home Depot.  The third one (#3) was a semi-recent purchase from Home Depot (5 or so years old?) and it was brass with that blasted plastic / rubber coating over the nozzle.

Recently, I noticed that the Lee Valley nozzle (#1) and the HD nozzle (#3) were leaking / dripping no matter how much I tried to torque them down.  I even tried new O-Rings to no avail... they would leak no matter what.  However, the oldest nozzle (#2) still worked flawlessly, and did not leak or drip.  Plus, the #2 nozzle had the best / tightest spray pattern on the coarsest setting, and moreover, when turning the nozzle and cycling through the different flows, it transitioned smoothly from start to finish, and finished up with a fine mist and wide spray pattern.  The other nozzles were not as tight a pattern, and were not as smooth on adjustment.  It should be noted that the nozzle that worked the best was also the nozzle I used the most, and was 15 years old.

So, since my other two nozzles were drippy (which drove me nuts), it was time to replace them.  So I went to Home Depot.... well, some of you know what happened next, a lot has changed over the years.  NO ALL BRASS NOZZLES.  Same thing at Lowes.  Of course Amazon had brass nozzles, and a selection no less!!  Then, my goal was to find the one that has worked so well over the years - IF it was still available.  The problem this nozzle I had for 15 years had NO markings on it - no country of manufacture (though I assumed US), no product branding... nothing.  Just a finely crafted, well functioning nozzle with no identifying marks.

When I was not sure I would find it, I originally got "sucked in" by the "Worlds Best" brass nozzle, which is VERY similar to the Dramm nozzle also sold here on Amazon.  So I bought the Dramm.  Bottom line - fine nozzle - BUT it was too rough a pattern (not tight on the full stream spray), and did not transition well through the spray pattern.  The difference was the top was very wide, and the inside part of the nozzle was a markedly larger diameter than the one I had for the last 15 years... I just did not prefer the way it performed.

So I then tried harder to find the same one I had that worked so well - the one we call #2 - by looking at the pictures here on Amazon closely.  I found two nozzles here on Amazon that looked like the nozzle - one was a nozzle from Backyard Pros and this Gilmour nozzle.  So I bought the one from Backyard Pros hoping it was similar.  The biggest difference I saw in the Amazon pics was the Backyard Pros nozzle has "Made in USA" printed on the nozzle.  Bottom line - when the nozzle came in, it did not take long to discover it was not as refined or well functioning than the brass nozzle I had all these years.

FINALLY, I purchased this Gilmour nozzle.  And you guessed it - other than a couple of minor differences, it was identical to the nozzle I had all these years.  The Gilmour nozzle still has no identifying marks just like the one I own, no country of manufacture, no branding, etc.  (Even though the pic here on Amazon appears to have stamped printing on the base of the nozzle, the one I received does not have any markings).  The real test - I took the new Gilmour nozzle outside, hooked it up and tried it out - and it performed as well, if not better than the one I own.  FOUND IT!!!

I plan on purchasing another.  Am I picky and / or a little particular about my hose nozzle?  Maybe.  But I know I want solid brass, and after having one that has performed so well, lets just say I learned the difference, and got spoiled by what I perceived as better / cleaner performance.  NOTE the Gilmour nozzle is not as fat as other brass nozzles, and this means it probably does not have the throughput or gallons per minute rating.  BUT, it has a nice tight stream, and transitions through the spray pattern smoothly and cleanly.  It also sprays much further as a result if that matters. The other nozzles may put out more water, but I do not prefer them due to their performance.  The fatter nozzles like the Dramm, Worlds Best, etc have a sloppy full stream, and the spray pattern does not transition smoothly in volume, and at some point just instantly stops....

I would recommend the Gilmour nozzle to anyone who would ask....

Thanks for reading.
summary: I looked long and hard to find the brass hose nozzle like I bought years ago- and this is "The One"

This actually works!  We moved into our new home 2 years ago and the house was vacant for 3.  The birds had taken OVER!  We were able to deter many of them, but the Phoebes were a different story.  I know birds have mites etc...but this bird has more than its share! And the mites will come off of them and crawl all over YOU if you try to move the nest etc.  Our first experience with this bird was at the home we moved from.  They had made a nest under our deck, unbeknownst to us.  Our cat went out and laid on the deck above the nest.  Her eyes got wide and she started freaking OUT!  The mites were ALL over her! Then when we moved here we knocked the nest down over and over, but they build so fast, up it went and the babies were IN.  It was right above our door to come in and poo galore on our steps YUCK! So we moved the nest after the babies were bigger.  They flew out of course and we gathered them back to the nest, but not before being COVERED in mites!!!!!!!  So that was it! We had to fight these mitey birds!  So after a search i found these balloons.  They don't cost much, so why not try.  NO more Phoebes!!! You have to hang the balloon so it will move around and have the tail on the end with the shiny straps hanging.  Nothing on ours broke and we have ours whipping around in the wind.  So, long story short, this was a great buy!
summary: Not sure why others had issues? This works!

I've been an owner of three different gas snowblowers. Each worked in its own way, from the MTD two-stage to my personal favorite, the Craftsman one-stage.

Many people see one-stage snow throwers as junk, and I'll agree they have their limitations in heavy or wet snow. But if you get out there right when the snow falls and clear it before it hits ten inches, you'll have a fine time with this little wonder.

It does as good a job at snow removal as my Craftsman single did--the two-stage may be a bit more versatile but it's like handling a rototiller and you have to have a place to store it. This baby hangs on a pair of wall hooks in the garage, with the cord hanging next to it.

I was amazed at how well this little "off brand" thrower does its work. I got it to test the proposition that 99% of snow removal can be done with a little tool like this. But it bore me out last year. Neighbor has an Ariens that cost him almost $1400. When he saw my little blower he offered to clear my driveway for me.

After clearing my (two-car with turnout space) driveway and hanging up the machine and cord back in the garage, I looked next door. He was still trying to get the beast started.

UPDATE MARCH 2010:

Well, I had almost three seasons with Snow Joe, but he couldn't handle the double whammy snowstorms of February--gave up the ghost. So I bought the Toro version of the same thing. It handles very similarly to the Snow Joe, but the impeller and chute design is better. I wish the chute crank were easier to reach (liked that about the SJ) but the Toro gets more snow faster than the SJ.

I was very close to buying one of Toro's gas Power Curve models, but went with another electric. When the second snowstorm hit, this Toro went through it like butter. I made sure to get out there and clear the first batch before it hit ten inches. Second batch was actually deeper at probably about ten inches, and it was just as easy. The Toro took full-width bites out of the first pass. The deeper pass required me to bump it out 4 inches or so to account for the higher snow volume.

But it chewed through it like a champ. I continue to recommend electric snowblowers to homeowners who don't face a huge amount of snow in the winter and don't have more than a hundred feet between their outlet and the street. My 100-foot cord hits the end just as I get to the street. If my driveway were a foot longer I'd have to go with a longer cord.

But I am switching my recommendation from Snow Joe to Toro. The Toro throws better, stays clearer, is better put together, and is quieter than the Snow Joe, especially under load.

Spend the extra and get the Toro. You won't be sorry.

Daconil works great to keep tomatoes healthy all season long.  Tomatoes are very susceptible to fungal blight, where the bottom leaves turn yellow, then brown, followed by infestation of the rest of the plant.  Blight kills the tomato plant, so it is very important to treat the plants once weekly, even if there is no sign of blight.  After losing many crops to blight, I now treat the plants once a week, and I have healthy tomatoes all season.  Use an ortho sprayer or equivalent sprayer to apply to the plants.  Terrific product, also works on any fungal problem involving fruit trees, lawn fungus, roses, etc.

summary: Great to Use on Tomato Black Fungus (Blight)

Used this trimmer for about 8 months before finally busting it open on my driveway in a fit of rage after it tore into my shins one too many times. I swear I spent more time applying band aids and trying to get the line to feed properly than I did actually weed eating.

Not only is it poorly designed from a safety standpoint but even when it feeds line properly (infrequently) it uses the required .80 line like crazy.  Sure, it has plenty of power and can cut through nearly anything, but the strong motor doesn't make up for the poor design and safety deficiencies.  The best thing I can say about the "grass hog" is that as a string trimmer it's decent but extremely hard to control- it kept digging in and wanting to cut way more than I needed, resulting in mangled borders and lawn edges.  As an edger it's flat out terrible and leaves pieces of line all over my yard and street.

Poorly designed and borderline dangerous, especially for the more diminutive gardeners amongst us. I destroyed it rather than sell it on Craigs to some unsuspecting guy with weak shins.  AVOID THIS PRODUCT.

2014 Update: I still have the scars on my legs.
