I am impressed by this feeders build quality and design.  There are many cheap and flimsy feeders on the market, but not this one.  The feeder is HUGE compared to standard feeders, which is great for folks who do not want to fill feeders all the time.  The acrylic dome is thick and will probably last many years.

We have seasonal problems with larger birds, especially Starlings, cleaning out our feeders to the dismay of smaller birds.  The best part about this feeder is Starlings don't like it and won't use it much, which is great!  The Starlings and other bigger birds find the feeding pegs and the large dome a bit too difficult to navigate.  Woodpeckers of all sizes love the feeder because they hang upside down instead of landing on the pegs.  There are 6 silos within the feeder, so you can do taste tests with different types of foods.  For example, I filled one silo with suet balls and was shocked to see that feeding hole being frequented by titmice.  Who knew?  You can have fun with the freedom that multiple silos provide, but I ended up filling the feeder with one kind of food.

In all, I was a little shocked by how expensive this feeder is to the point where I probably wouldnt have purchased it without having used one first.  Now that Ive had it for a month, I am convinced I would buy it because you get what you pay for with bird feeders.  Ive purchased dozens of cheap feeders of the years and they always break after a season or two.  This feeder is a tank and will probably be around longer than me.  If you want a high-quality feeder with a huge food capacity, this really does fit the bill.  Recommend!
summary: Heavy-duty feeder  great for small birds.

Living in Texas, we use our gas grill daily.  As empty-nesters, we are finding our large Weber Genesis Grill is larger than we need.  The Cadac 98700-33-01 Stratos 3-Burner Stainless Steel 39,000 BTU Gas Grill is the ideal size for small families or those who may, like us, be empty-nesters.

ASSEMBLY:  A pictorial assembly guide is included in the box; there are no instructions in writing.  Assembly is not difficult and requires only a Phillips screwdriver.  Some screws are pre-positioned; you may need to remove them to complete assembly and then reposition those screws.  From the opening of the box through completed assembly, total time for having the grill up and operational was less than 90 minutes.

APPEARANCE and SIZE:  The Cadac Stratos is an attractive grill.  The powdered black-painted frame and powdered gray-painted sides and doors contrast nicely with the stainless steel hood.  The hood is double-walled, but is not especially heavy.  The grilling and griddle surfaces, as well as the hanging rack, are porcelain-enameled stainless steel.

The Cadac Stratos may be a good choice for those with limited outdoor space.  When the side shelves are folded down, the grill is approximately 30  wide X 20 deep, including the knob protrusion X 41  high when the lid is closed.  When the lid is opened, the grill is approximately 51 high; when the side shelves are both extended, the width of the Cadac Stratos is about 48.  The cooking grids of the actual grilling surface measure about 15 X 15; there is a non-removable 6 X 15 griddle on the right side of the cooking area.  A porcelain-enameled hanging rack, attached to the hood provides an area of about 5 wide X 22  long on which to heat bread or rolls that are no more than 4 high.

COOKING:  The real test of a grill is its cooking capability.  Preheated for four-minutes on high with all three burners ignited, the grill reached a temperature, measured on the thermometer built into the hood, of 410 F.  Lighting only 2-burners during preheating resulted in the temperature on the Cadac Stratos reaching only 325 F.  Meats cooked in the same amount of time as they did on our Weber; lamb, steak and bone-in pork chops were done to the desired stage and, even though the lamb and pork chops were not trimmed clean of fat, there was little flare-up.  There was no burning and the meat did not stick to the grills surface.  With regard to grilling, this product is very good.  Salmon cooked on the griddle was almost perfect - the skin was crisp and the filet flakey.  We sprayed the griddle's surface with a no-stick grill spray to prevent the fish from sticking.  After cooking, the griddle cleaned up easily, requiring only a little scrubbing with a non-metal, non-abrasive scrubby.

WARRANTY and COST:  Because we have always cooked on Weber grills, I decided to compare the Cadac Stratos to that companys comparably sized product.  The Weber Spirit Gas Grill is very close to the price of the Cadac Stratus - $399 vs. $379.  However, the warranty on the Weber unit is 10 years vs. a 5-year warranty on the Cadac Stratus with respect to the cook box.  The warranty on enameled parts for both is 5 years.  Stainless steel burner tubes are warranted for 10-years on Weber products, on the Cadac Stratos, 2-years. All remaining parts have a 2-year warranty on Weber products and a 1-year warranty, with the exception of plastic components, on the Cadac Stratos.  Thus, if you move your grill frequently, the plastic casters may wear out.  I recommend replacing them with more durable casters when you initially assemble the unit.  Because Cadac seems to be a new product offering in the United States, availability and cost of replacement parts in the future is unknown.

Because we use our grill twice daily, we have had to, in the past, make claims under a grill's warranty.  Based on all factors the Cadac 98700-33-01 Stratos 3-Burner Stainless Steel 39,000 BTU Gas Grill is a 4-star product.  Were the warranty periods increased to those of Weber products, the Cadac Stratos would have received 5 stars.

SHIPPING and DELIVERY NOTE: UPS delivered my grill both upside down and to the wrong address.  Damage to the grill was primarily cosmetic; my spouse was able to straighten the pieces that were slightly bent.  Had it not been for the excellent packing job by Amazon  boxing the box, lots of air cushions, and lots of cardboard corners to secure the grill packaging  it is likely the grill would have been more seriously damaged.  If I had purchased this item rather than receiving it from the Vine program for review, I would have returned it.  If you purchase a grill and have it shipped to you, be sure to check the packaging and the actual grill carefully for any damage.
summary: Excellent Choice for Small Families and Those With Limited Outdoor Space ...

Break a sweat using the Fiskars 6208 Push Reel Lawn Mower! Burn more calories! I have Kentucky blue grass that needs to be mowed at least once a week and at 6 days the Fiskars worked just as well as my 12 year old Black & Decker MM875 Lawn Hog 19-Inch 12 amp Electric Mulching Mower with Rear Bag. The blades spin after you have stopped walking, so you can slow down around corners. My first pass was vigorous, and the mower left many tuffs of grass sticking up and a blanket of 4" stems of grass (I had the mower at the highest setting of 3.5"). So, I raked the lawn and then mowed it again with the push reel to get rid of the tuffs. The second pass "erased" the lines of my first attempt and I can see lines just like when I mow with my Black & Decker. This might be obvious to you, but push reel mowers only cut when going forward. I caught myself a couple of times trying to mow backwards, it doesn't work. On the property there are three tucked away small pieces of grass and the Fiskars dealt with those admirably, but those areas don't grow vigorously and did not require raking. With the raking it took me 45 minutes to mow the lawn, and 15 minutes of that was raking. When I mow the vigorous part of the lawn twice with my black and decker, I still need to rake but less, since it mulches, and I don't need to rake in between mowings, I can mow back to back. With the Fiskers, if you don't rake up the tall grass, the level of effort is almost that same as the first pass, if not worse. So, I raked and the second pass was a breeze. Also, this push reel mower is so much easier to transport up and downstair when compared to a gasoline or electric mower. There is a handle by the blades (it probably exists for the June 2012 grass catcher, I can't wait!). This handle allows you to pick up the reel mower and balance it with the larger handle, just make sure that the blades have stopped before you pick it up. In conclusion, if you have small patches of lawn (20' X 20') that do not grow vigorously, like under trees, or shaded by a building, or a fence, than this mower is more convenient than a gas or electric one. If you have larger areas (50' x 50') that grow fast and thick, then you are going to rake less with a mulching mower than with the Fiskars push reel. Also, grass does like some thatch, so raking every time is not healthy for your lawn. I will still wheel out the mulching mower, sigh, but I would rather not have to do so. UPDATE: 4/29/2012 --> I mowed again after 5 days and it worked great, I did two passes, criss cross and the lines came out beautifully and I did not need to rake in between and the second pass actually mulched what was leave on my vigorously growing lawn. I would still like the grass catcher for the perimeter. The push mower has the tendency to throw grass to the left, so if you keep the mulch edge to your right, then less grass will fall on your mulch, if you go around left you get a lot more cut grass in your garden/mulch area.
summary: Bag Catcher Needed, but oh so easy

Note that there are many reviews from people who received this unit for free (amazon vine).  I paid the full purchase price from a large hardware store.  My review is based on spending my hard-earned money on a hedge trimmer.  Also note that I wrote a very negative reviw on the Dewalt string trimmer.  This put a wrench in my plans, as I wanted to standardize on a battery platform and I thought that the Dewalt Hedge Trimmer and the Dewalt String Trimmer would be the products that I invest in the batteries.  Though I love this hedge trimmer, I might return it because I really want a common battery platform for my power tools.

In doing my review, I am basing it on my 3 years of experience in using my Echo HC- 150 Hedge Trimmer.  My initial impression is that the Dewalt is a much better tool, and that it does deliver gas performance based on this comparison.

- Power - Plenty of cutting power, it surpasses the Echo 150 that it is replacing.  It cuts thick holly branches with ease, I am able to "scuplt" my hedges, not just trim them.  The Echo's clutch would slip on the larger branches, the Dewalt has the power to cut them.

- Build Quality - Comapred to the $289 Echo HC 150 that this replaces, I feel that the Dewalt blades are of higher quality of construction, but I do not belive that the casing is better.  Like another reveiwer reports, the screws are too simplistic and seems that it will break.

- Weight - The Echo and Dewalt are comparable within an ounce of each other.  But I feel that the Dewalt, with the 4 AH battery has better balance than the Echo.  The balance places less stress on my wrist and arms.  However, compared to a Stihl 45, the dewalt is over 2 pounds heavier.  Weight is a critical feature for hedge trimmers.

- Battery life - the battery last at least as long as a tank of gas on the echo.

When comparing the Dewalt 40V Hedge Trimmer to an Echo 150 Hedge Trimmer (which is a gas model); I feel that the dewalt matches and perhaps out performs the Echo.  When compared to a gas-powered Stihl (which is also the same price as the Dewalt), the Stihl is more powerful, lighter, and better constructed.

Though this is an improvement over my Echo, I think I might return it and buy the stihl.  The main reason is that I am very disappointed in the Dewalt string trimmer, and I do not want to invest in an inventory of $200 batteries for a single tool.

Update***********
I decided to return this hedge trimmer.  For the price, I can purchase a gas-powered hedge trimmer that is 2.6 pounds lighter and more power.  The reduced weight is a significant benefit for the gas model, because the lower weight reduces the fatique and stress on my wrist.  I am also not pleased that the Dewalt string trimmer was such a disappointment.  I do not want to invest in these expensive batteries when the product line only has one model that I like.
summary: Dewalt 40V Hedge Trimmer delivers gas-powered performance

reviewText: met expectations

Yes it works but compared to the Fiskars Root and Weed Remover... They just aren't worth the money.  I did a head to head test on 20 deep root weeds and this product does a lot of damage to the ground.  Yes it will get the whole root out but only 60% of the time.  Which may work for Bryan Fantana but in my yard that means these will grow back.  The Fiskars removed the weed and its entire root nearly 85% of the time.  The biggest difference is on the 2nd attempt to remove the weed & roots the Garden Weasel really ripped up the ground making 2.5" deep holes ripping up existing grass roots and tearing up the yard with limited results on actually removing the root left behind.  The Fiskars root remover clams around the root and removes it with accuracy and does very little damage to the surrounding grass which means you can repair the hole very easily too.  With the Weasel you have to do a good bit of work to try to replant the chunk of earth it removes and leaves a VERY noticeable mark on every root you try to pull.

Top it all off with saftey.  The weasel requires you to stand on one foot and use the other to step on the tool to uproot the weed.  Which sounds easy but if you are old you may fall.  The Fiskars can be used with one hand and both feet planted firmly on the ground.  You just place it over the weed and press it into the ground using your foot if needed to really go deep then pull back.  No dangerous balancing act.  Simple and safe for older or less balanced people.

Top it all of with the metal it is made with bends if you pull back on it.  Disappointed it bent on my first 8 times using it.  It just isn't as good a Fiskars
summary: Works 60% of the time: Weasel Vs. Fiskars

I have been using this grill for a couple of months and have been satisfied with this product. Shopping for a gas grill can be hectic. There are many different models on the market. You need to figure out what is going to be right for you. I felt that a four burner gas grill was going to be completely unnecessary and this two-burner caught my eye.

Assembling this grill was rather easy. It's going to be a little time consuming, but you do not need to be a master of assembly to put this thing together.

When using the grill the towel hooks are a convenience, you need to make sure your cooking tools are going to work, but if so it comes in very handy. The grates seem to be very good material and are easy to clean. However, the burner covers and other pieces can be a little more difficult to clean up.

*Update: Everything is thriving.  We did plant the tomatoes a little too close because we didn't expect them to grow so much.

I already have a AeroGarden Ultra, so was excited to receive this smaller version for review. It fits better in my kitchen, and is simpler to operate (not as many options) for what I use it for. However, if the plants you're growing do better with less than 16 hours of light, the Ultra (or other model that's programmable) would be a better choice. Also, although the description stated that this new Sprout has LEDs - it doesn't, so these lights take more energy and will need to be replaced more often than the LEDs on the Ultra.

I don't recommend the Sprout, Ultra, or any other model, for growing tomatoes to harvest. The tomatoes taste watered down - a little better than store-bought, but not even close to garden-grown. I *do* recommend that you start your tomatoes with this (much faster growth than in soil) until they start flowering and producing fruit, then transfer them to pots for ripening. I did this (two plants lived, the other didn't survive the transfer), and the tomatoes tasted amazing. So much better than when ripened in the AeroGarden. When you transfer, make sure you soak the soil with water for the first week so they'll transition to a soil-based system more easily.

When using the AeroGarden (any model), read through the instructions. It's important to know how often to fertilize (and how much), when/how to prune, when to raise the light, etc. If you don't read the instructions, your plants won't grow well, won't flower, and will be thin instead of robust. So read the instructions, and watch the videos at the AeroGarden website. If you don't like to read instructions, don't purchase this - you'll be wasting your time and money.

I recommend the Sprout (or the Ultra if you want to "incubate" more plants at one time and/or need less than 16 hours of light for what you're growing) to start your plants very quickly and get them flowering and fruiting. But I don't recommend it for harvesting tasteful fruit. Instead, transfer them to soil. You'll *love* the difference in taste.
summary: Recommended for starting plants quickly, but not through to harvest

reviewText:
Birds are fascinating creatures. I love watching them and having them around our house so I was excited to review this Acrylic Window Bird Feeder from Yellow Beaks. It brings the birds up close for you to see!
We get a wide variety of wildlife in our area and I always find it fascinating to observe. This bird feeder allows you to see birds close up, right in your window.
I love that the size allows several to gather at once. Little birds just hop right inside! It is strong enough for the bigger cardinals to land on it as well. We have had some really strong storms since I hung it up and I was worried it would disappear in the high wind, but it didn't budge and the three large suction cups have kept it stuck firm to the glass!
I like that I can provide a place for our birds to eat without serving them up as a snack for our kitties! Where I put mine, on a second story window, I don't have to worry about squirrels or other critters getting into it, but the slick angled roof would prevent them from getting into the feeder. We have had only one storm where the birdseed got wet and that was only because the rain came from an unusual direction and the strong winds were blowing the rain completely horizontal. The days that we have had normal rain, the bird house has worked great at protecting the seed and keeping it dry.
The bird feeder holds a good amount of seed so you don't have to constantly keep filling it and the birds have plenty to peck at. It is so funny to watch them pick and choose which things they want to eat! I use a fruit and nut blend that they seem to really like.
The feeder is super easy to use. It is a solid piece that doesn't need any assembly and you only have to place the suction cups. Since my window is so high off the ground, I put the suction cups into the holes on the back of the feeder and pressed them onto the glass. It has stayed solidly in place without any problem.
I can't stop taking pictures of the birds that are visiting now! It started with one little one and now there are several that come and jockey for position. The number seems to increase every day!
The bird feeder is a great way for kids to safely see birds up close and learn about them. It would also bring enjoyment to an elderly or home bound person. This makes a great gift for any birdwatchers on your holiday list!.
summary: Sit Back And Watch Birds Right In Your Window!

I ordered this next day air delivered December 1st 2011. It arrived. MISSING THE PROPANE REGULATOR!!! I live in an area where these aren't sold or found. Very upset with this purchase. I needed it for a 80 lbs crawfish boil party the next day. Too late to order in time for next day air again. What the %$!@ do I do now? BAYOU CLASSIC SUCKS!!!!!!!!!!!

Just called my friend in Wisconsin to tell him. He referred me to this product. Said a couple of guys in his area bought one in the last month for family seafood boils, canning and beer making. Incoming threads on the burner itself are defective. Sent theirs back to Amazon. The regulator won't screw in. My box was factory sealed with clear tape. I thought it was a previous return to Amazon and someone forgot to put it back in the box. "Bayou Classic" has NO quality control checks. Brought the unit in to my local hardware store (they deal in a lot of Coleman and numerous other grills) to fit a new regulator. Guess what? NO REGULATOR ON EARTH FITS A BAYOU CLASSIC PROPANE STOVE!

I cannot tell you how angry I am. No store carries these. Not Home Depot. Not Lowes. Not Dick's Sporting Goods. Not REI. Not ACE. Not WalMart. Not Target. Not Northern Tool. Not Menards. Not Mall of America. It's all online dealers that REFUSE to ship overnight. I know none of them stock anything listed on their websites. Otherwise they would make the sale for next day air. You can call UPS and FEDEX to do a late pick up. But I was calling at 1:30pm-2:30pm CST.

UPDATE: I didn't want the word out that I didn't have a burner. A friend was going to rig his 20 year old trusty burner with a 100 gal propane tank, but luckily someone stopped by with their CAMP CHEF burner. It worked beautifully. Stay away from aluminum stock pots in cold weather. Aluminum radiates heat away from your boiling point. Takes 25 minutes to boil water with a half full 60 quart aluminum stock pot even with high psi and high btu burners.

If you want to build and run a successful business, learn how to STOCK INVENTORY and ship LATE LATE LATE in the day. I run a small business and we ship up until 7:00PM via UPS and FEDEX hubs. 70% of our sales are last minute buyers after 3:00PM looking to receive their item next day air... even Saturday Delivery. We've saved thousands of people and companies from disaster.

Roll the dice on Bayou Classic CHINESE made products.
summary: Did NOT come with the Regulator. Regulator is custom built and sold only by Bayou Classic!!!

reviewText: in 60 days

Forget the harsh chemicals that both you and kids don't need to be exposed to.  Havahart has a better solution to keep those pesky night critters away from your garden and trash.  The Spray Away Elite II uses a long, wide, hard blast of water to keep the night creatures out of your plants and vegetables.  It's motion sensor activated and you can adjust the sensitivity.  Even at the lowest setting I've found the blast of water to be quite effective.  The base holds a large amount of water so you are not filling it up all the time.  There is a warning light to tell you when it's low and another to tell you when the solar power is running out.  The sprinkler is not too heavy so it's easy to move around.  The material is high quality plastic and stays looking good even after the harshest storms. My garden has gone untouched this year with little effort by me and all the effort by the Spray Away Elite II.  Just remember to walk around the rear of it when it's on or you're going to get a nice little blast yourself.
it wasn't as great as it was made out to be

Works well, just like a mulching blade should. It has 3 holes, unlike the picture but my mower only used one. The blade is heavy and painted black (which won't last long). The edge so far has been good. If you want any blade to work, especially a mulching blade, make sure you mow your yard when the grass is very dry. Any dampness will cause your mower to clog with grass and then conk out. One more tip, make sure when you sharpen the blade disconnect the spark plug wire and tilt the lawn mower with the carburetor facing up. Good price on the blade over my box store prices. Highly recommended.

Let me say first off . . . make sure you get the right kit . . . or the air filter won't fit.  This kit is for any mower with a Briggs & Stratton 3.5 to 6.5 QUANTUM Series engine.  The Quantum engines have a vertically mounted air filter unit on the forward right side of the engine, which utilizes a paper air filter element with an integral blue foam gasket, overall dimension 4.4" x 5" (B&S part number 491588S, which is printed on the side of the paper filter media).

OK, if you've got the right mower match, let me comment that this is a very nicely put together kit.  It all comes enclosed in a plastic container and contains everything you need for basic annual maintenance and storage.  Price is very competitive, especially if you add a little extra value considering the top of the container converts to a re-usable funnel and the body to a used oil catch can (or for me, a handy parts bin for new and old mower parts, or nuts & bolts, etc.).  The contents are name brand parts/products, not a collection of cheap compatibles.

Included in the kit:  1. 20 oz bottle of SAE 30 Champion brand 4-cycle lawn mower motor oil.  2. Briggs & Stratton air filter for the Quantum engine. 3. Champion Copper Plus spark plug.  4. 2.5 oz bottle of Champion Fuel Stabilizer, enough to treat over 5 gallons of gasoline (in your storage can) and the fuel in your mower's tank.  As I mentioned, the container also provides a funnel and small parts bin.

A good idea and a decent deal.

I've never had a pool that I thought I needed a bunch of chemicals for.  This summer I purchased a 12' x 30" Intex frame pool.  I did quite a bit of reading & everything I read pretty much said I needed a bunch of chemicals.  I purchased this kit, but it doesn't come with instructions for first time chemical users.  When I used the shock I figured out on my own that I needed to dissolve it in a bucket of water before adding to the pool.  But still, a lot of the granules just sunk to the floor of the pool.  I didn't have much luck with this kit as my pool liner was usually slimy even though I measured all the chemicals just as instructed and added them in the order I understood them to be added.  The water was also discolored & smelled funny.  I remember reading about a mom using plain old house strength bleach in her pool.  She said it worked great.  So I did the same, and wah lah!  It actually stopped my liner from being slimy, stopped the discoloration of the water, and the smell is now gone!!  I imagine that in the pool world they would probably frown upon me for using bleach for one reason or another, but it works for me so I'm gonna continue using it.  It's also WAY cheaper than all those confusing chemicals.  I added 4 cups initially to clear up all the gunk then 2 cups in the evening after swimming when running the pump.  Thanks:)

24 hours after application:  I put in about 40 ounces in my pond.  Its a little over half an acre in size.  Applied it via a 1 gallon sprayer.  Filled the sprayer with water almost half way and then added the pond booster.  Pumped it up and then started  spraying in various locations on one side of the pond. I cant get to the opposite side because of the brush.  Anyway initially it turned half of the pond a dark blue color, along with the weeds.  Panicked some of the fish and the turtles avoided the blue initially.  Watched it slowly spread for a while then left.  Next day it looked alot different.  Was more green then before but expected that because of how cloudy the water in my pond has been.  It has spread all through the pond though its still alot darker on the side where I sprayed it.  Waiting to see how it looks next week.  Will edit this and put in how its doing then.  The fish and turtles seem to have settled in.  Fed them and they fed normally.  As in the turtles trying to hog the food.  Greedy things.  Got a few of the Florida Softshell in here.  Big ones.  A couple with  shells reaching 16 inches.
The water today is still cloudy. No settling out yet.  But expect it to take a week before its noticeable.  As I said.  Will report back here in a week.  Add some photos then as well.

This trap is genius in its simplicity and design!  It's been 100% effective for me. This device has cleared out a family of mice in short order - from babies to the Mommy.  The opening is large enough to lure timid mice inside who refused to go into smaller traps.  There's enough space once captured that there is less likelihood of death by confinement. Purchase tip: I purchased an identical trap for half the price at an auction site - but it took 3 weeks to arrive from China.  Bait tip; SUET!  I've had mice ignore the peanut butter and go straight for a small chunk of suet.  Get a cake of suet (with seeds) meant for a bird feeder - under a dollar and will last you for years.

I have a Big yard with lots of fruit trees and a bunch bird feeders, with lots of seed scattered all over the ground by the birds, so it's not surprising that I have lots of other wildlife (welcome & unwelcome) that frequent my yard, including tons of roof rats, but with the Raticator S-Plus Rodent Zapper I'm starting to pick them off.

When the sun goes down, I start seeing movement in the trees as the rats come running over the roof into my yard, it's horrifying!  I don't like using poison because they die here & there and we can smell it and following the smell is an not a fun game, I prefer seeing the flashing red light on the Raticator S-Plus Rodent Zapper and dumping the kill straight into the trashcan, then rebating and resetting the Zapper.

Because of another review, I've been using Ritz crackers topped with nutty peanut butter and it works really well, it seems to be a favored last supper for the awful Rats.

The Raticator S-Plus Rodent Zapper itself is really well built, it appears to be ready and able to serve me a long time, it's well made, not a piece of foreign cheap crap.  I'm happy to say this, the Raticator S-Plus is designed and made in the USA by Americans for our American Rats!

This really does a great job of ridding our pests without hurting the animals that we Love,  No Poison!!!

I think people are being a little bit hard on this product.  I bought one when our sprinkler system broke, and I had to water the front yard with one of those sprinklers that you hook up to a hose.  I didn't want to leave a hose lying across the front walk all the time for people to trip on, but I also didn't relish the idea of uncoiling and coiling a heavy hose every day.  The Pocket Hose was perfect for that.  It's very lightweight and you don't have to coil it.  It was easy to attach to my portable sprinkler, and when I was done watering, I could just gather it up and dump it in a clay pot in my flower bed.

I'm actually thinking about ordering a 2nd one in a longer length for my back yard.  I have an extensive container garden back there that I have to water daily.  My big black 100' rubber hose is a hassle to drag around and coil back up.  And on hot summer days, I have to spend several minutes bleeding the hot water from it.  I'm hoping maybe the pocket hose won't heat up like that, and I won't have to waste so much water.

A few caveats, though:

First of all, it's true that the connectors on each end are just plastic, and the little plastic nozzle thing broke the first time I tried to screw it on tight.  But I discovered that part is not really necessary, especially if you're connecting it to a trigger or sprayer mechanism, or some other hose accessory.  You do need to be reasonably gentle with the plastic parts, though.

Secondly, some people have complained that the hose doesn't instantly retract into a little ball as small as the original packaging.  That's true.  It basically just goes limp, and the material is lightweight and thin enough that you can then scrunch it into a ball and drop it into a bucket, flower pot, or one of those fancy ceramic things for hoses.  I find that very convenient, but if you're looking for it to scrunch itself up into a tiny ball when you turn the water off, it doesn't do that.

A few people have complained that the hose develops leaks.  I haven't found that to be the case yet, but I'm not really subjecting it to a lot of brutal use - dragging it across rocks or leaving it out in the sun for long periods of time, for example.  I'm just connecting it to a sprinkler or hose trigger to water the lawn and shrubs, and so far (about 3 months), I've not had any leaking problems.

Bottom line, this is a cleverly designed product that is unfortunately not made with very high quality materials.  But if you're the kind of person who hates lugging around, coiling, and storing a regular garden hose, you still might find it worth buying.  Just be gentle with it.

Update:  Hose ended up exploding violently when the lining failed.  This was a spot about a foot from the spigot, on a part of the hose that doesn't touch the ground or come into contact with anything sharp.  It just couldn't withstand the water pressure coming out of the tap, even though I had nothing attached to the other end of the hose (trigger, sprinkler, etc).  It's too bad, because the general concept and design of the hose is great.  It just needs to be made of much stronger material.
summary: Not the best quality, but works for my purposes

I called the customer support which took forever and they said the problem was the battery and they would send a replacement which would take 7-10 businss days. I should have know there would be a problem becuase their website has a specific section on their homepage dealing with battery problems. I purchased two of these items.  I specifically purchased them because of their depth.  Plants like tomatoes need depth to accommodate their root system.  I was also intrigued by the fact that you can combine two planters into one long, deep planter, to accommodate the rambling vines of squash and pumpkin, which is what I ultimately decided to do.  Overall, I am okay with the product.  It serves the purpose for which I purchased it.  However I only gave it three stars because the wood was not finished very well.  Instead of the corner posts being smooth inside, they were frayed as if they needed to be sanded which is what I did by hand.  I sanded it so that the boards would more smoothly glide in.  Even so, installing the boards is not an easy task. Take care to line each board up properly and use force to snugly push them down.  With respect to the "decorative" tops, they too are rough and are simply a square with slanted edges.  The picture makes them look rather smooth.  They are not smooth.  Also, you will need a power drill to secure them to the posts since the pre-drilled holes are not completely drilled through.  If you are not concerned with depth or flexibility of size, go for Suncast WGB48 48-inch cedar wood raised garden kit.  Smoothly manufactured and the smell of cedar is evident the minute you take it out of the box.  No tools are required.  However, the stake that you secure the boards and drive into the ground makes the structure somewhat permanent to where you place it.

I am keen on these plants. I live out in the desert and so very far from the produce that is so prominent in my Vietnamese cuisine.

I am no expert - just started gardening in January, but we started everything from seed and we do pretty well sprouting in coconut coir, but these seeds were not fans. We had one type of squash - the longer one/Calabash - and the two greens sprout (Choy sum & Kai Lan).

I've been using these spikes for years and have been very pleased with their performance. While their instructions tell us to use these in spring and fall, I tend to use them in spring only as I don't want to interrupt the trees' fall dormancy cycle with a burst of new growth. A couple of things I've learned:

1. When I first tried these, I would put them right next to the base of the tree or shrub so the fertilizer would drip into the roots. I ended up partially killing a small tree this way.... follow the directions and put them in the dripline of the tree and let the trees' roots reach them. If it's a new planting, suggest you use a liquid fertilizer or a granular release surface fertilizer instead of pounding these into a small root ball... learn from my mistake.

2. To pound them in, I wet the soil and if it's tightly compacted I stab it a few times with a small shovel or garden spade.

I was curious why these are banned in Pinellas County (St. Petersburg, FL) and did some research... they are concerned about phosphate-based fertilizers and their impact on Florida's dwindling water supply, so they have banned them. I used to live on a lake in Florida and the whole thing was covered in an algae bloom due to all the fertilizer running off from the bright green lawns that ringed the lake.

Very effective, highly recommended. I would very much like to see MIracle Gro develop some organic versions of all my favorites....these spikes and the "blue crystals" that go in the feeders.

Hope this helps.
summary: These work well, but don't put them too close to the base / trunk of your tree

reviewText:
I've have had a Briggs and Stratton Gas Power Washer for about 5 years. I lent it out in the cold weather and it came back with a frozen pump manifold. With that in mind, I ordered this unit, which is very close to the same machine that I have been using. The changes made on this machine in comparison to my old one, are only for the better. It does have a slightly lower hose pressure and HP engine, but this seems to not make any difference.
This unit has a slightly more flexible hose, which is great. It will actually hang on the hose holder. It comes with three spray ends: one is a single hard stream, another is a hard pressure fan shape and the other is a fan which is not high pressure. This one is low pressure for rinsing, etc.
This machine as well as my old one always starts on 2-3 pulls. Though it says it can use gas with up to 10% ethanol, at the advice of a small engine repair guy, I only use straight gas with no ethanol.  There is no gas/oil mixing.
This unit is easy to move around, and for storage, the handle, and hose come off. The extra hose ends have an easy on/off ring on the wand. You can change the type of pressure stream easily. The extra wand ends are stored on the handle.
I have found that when you remove the pressure hose, make sure that you let out the pressure with engine and water supply off, at the trigger. This makes it very easy to turn the hose connection off of the pump pipe. You can easily do it by hand.  I found out the hard way on my old unit, that by forcing the hose off of the pump connection, it is easy to strip the hose threads. This was a $125. lesson. I was also told by the repair guy that it is unwise to leave the power washer engine running without the water going through the wand for more than a very short time. The engine is cooled by the water going through it.
Incidentally...I ordered a pump manifold on Amazon for my old washer, put it on myself, and it now works as well. Parts are available for these units. I have been very happy with the quality of the Briggs. It has good pressure, always starts and it has been reliable.

3. Easy to put up and take down, much easier than my 10 year old EZ-Up. One person could put this up without too much trouble.
CONS:
1. The knob that latches and secures the legs in place got dislodge on one of the legs. Had to remove the bottom portion of the leg and maneuver it back into place.
2. The bags is already starting to show signs of wear and developing holes. This bag does not appear to be as durable as my EZ-Up bag which is still in pretty good shap after 10 years of use.

To sum it all up, this is a nice looking, easy to use shade. The overall durability is what I question and only time will tell on that. I suspect I will have to purchase a replacement bag sometime next year.

I moved into a new-to-me house 18 months ago.  At my previous house I had landscaping done about 13 years before I sold it, but only had deep root fertilizing done, professionally, the last two years.  I believe it helped sell the house.  Everything in the landscaping finally popped in the Spring of 2011. We sold the house, ourselves, in 6 weeks.  Needless to say, I was determined to have it done here, with extensive landscaping already in place. I photographed the sequence of the plants blooming last year, mostly to identify them, but did not do any fertilization last year.  I finally got around to addressing the landscaping this year, and had the time to concentrate on it because the weather remained very cool throughout the Spring.  I have even done some transplanting into late May this year.  I bought the Ross Deep Root Feeder device and several types of fertilizer refills, in time to make the rounds with it at the end of April.  I was very surprised to see the results a month later.  I used this particular product on the trees and non-flowering shrubs, the acid-loving refills on the evergreens, and the flowering shrub refills on all the flowering plants, including the azaleas and rhododendrons.  The blossoms on the rhododendrons are now larger than on any I have previously owned; and the azaleas look like they are straining to stretch their flowers open beyond their normal capabilities.  And the bees are going insane on the sea roses.  One bee was literally rolling around in one of those flowers, as if it was in a state of absolute euphoria. And the Weigela look fabulous, even though I cut them back severely just before I fertilized them.  I will be fertilizing again in the fall, but only using the acid loving and this fertilizer, so the plants will go back to building energy for their infrastructure. I can hardly wait to see the Montauk Daisies this year.  Those were fertilized with flowering fertilizer first, then get general fertilizer monthly until they bloom, because they get severely cut back early on and need energy to regrow.  And then there will be next year...
summary: Made a very noticeable and quick difference

Works extremely well for a vole problem we had by placing six units around areas of activity around my property. Combined this with the Tomcat All Weather Bait Chunx and the combination worked extremely well. Very easy to reload with poison and keeps dogs, children, cats, etc out of harms way so there is no collateral damage. Only reason for not getting five stars was that the retaining ring at the bottom of the metal rod holding the poison bait is practically welded on.  I have yet to find a way to remove it even when using special pliers and a vice. I have had to reload by unscrewing the rod each time from the top cap which makes reload the bait more messy and difficult. Tried to reach out to the company via e-mail, as I had purchased a set of six, for replacement rods/retaining rings but they offered no help and told me I needed to purchase new units if I needed to fix this problem. Regardless of the poor customer service I still think it is a quality product but don't expect any assistance from the manufacturer.

Addendum: the input I received from the other buyers of this product was right on. The retaining ring on the metal rod is easily removed but will require that you use a vise grip.
summary: Very easy to reload with poison and keeps dogs and kids safe!

reviewText: I bought this as a replacement for an almost identical Toro that was 15-20 years old. After I bought the original some ratings service rated this blower as one of the best on the market especially considering the price. I could have just bought the blower for about $20 less but I misplaced the vacuum bag and this packed contained the vacuum attachment as well. I believe the current price was about $20 less than I paid for my original purchase and the new one is almost identical. The only change that I noticed is that Toro has added an additional grip on the handle and replaced the male plug in the base for a corded plug in. My original went bad because of an internal short at the plug-in and perhaps this design change was aimed at preventing that from happening. There are lots of leaf blowers out there but this one has been on the market for a long time and still gets great reviews. Toro has a great reputation for producing high quality products at reasonable prices and this leaf blower is an outstanding example.

I've used this three times and have finally figured it out. I do follow the instructions, but find that I have to add charcoal after 2 to 3 hours and also add water and chips. I also have an electric smoker, but prefer the taste from the traditional Weber. It's a bit expensive, but should last a long time.

Final Update - Spring of 2013 (back to 3 stars)
I use thed mower several more times before giving it to my son for his flat lawn (he's delighted).  I will say that lack of power I mentioned in my original review is the major flaw.  The good news is that (a) The mower always started on two or less pulls.  One pull after winter storage with Sta-Bil in the fuel. (b) Emptying the bag is manageable if you don't let it get more than 2/3 full.  That's a PITA with a small bag and lots of grass or leaves, but it does work fine that way. (c) I found the wheels easy to adjust with the mower on a paved surface.
NOTE - While shopping for a new mower this spring I notice that the successor to this model now has an even weaker B&S motor.  See my comments on the 10632.

Update - Fall of 2012 (downgraded from 3 to 2 stars)
I kept the mower against my better judgement, so as to have one handy for "quick mows."  What a mistake.
I just mowed our small front lawn.  I had to push the mower up the modest slope with a  a lot of effort with the bag even half full.  It could not have been any harder to push with a manual mower.  To make it worse, the mower filled its tiny bag quickly with only a modest amount of grass and leaves and then spit out half-mulched leaf fragments.  The opening to the bag is so small that it clogs easily, making the leaf-spitting problem worse.  After a summer's use, I really can't say much good about this mower other than it still starts on the first or second pull and cuts grass.
I am giving it away to my son who has a flat and treeless postage stamp lawn.
Buy something else, it can't be worse.

ORIGINAL REVIEW - June 2012 - "Not Your Father's Lawn Boy - Low on Muscle"
A nice mower, but sorely lacking on power.  Fine if you have a flat clean lawn.  Poorly suited for anything else.

I have owned a self-propelled 2-cycle lawn Boy Silver Series mower for the past 13 years.  It is lightweight, maneuverable, powerful, cuts well, and has proven simple to maintain.  I have periodically serviced the carburetor and replace the magneto coil once.  I thought I'd try one of the new Lawn Boy models when my current one failed to start last week.  The 10604 seemed a good choice.

The mower came thoughtfully packaged for removal and with the required oil.  It was "on the air" in ten minutes.  Unlike some others, I found the mow height adjustment easy to make.  I set both front and back to 3" in my first cutting.

My mowing experience with the Lawn Boy 10604 is based on cutting my 2,000 sq ft back yard and 1,200ft front yard once each.  The mower always started both cold and hot on the first pull and quickly settled into smooth running.  The bag is smaller that the one on my older Lawn Boy, but adequate.  The safety door makes taking it off and on more of a pain than the "less safe" older bag.  The bag is held by two pins in an adequate but rather cheesy bracket. This mower IS indeed variable speed.  You just need to develop a feel for the control.  It was the same on my old Lawn Boy.

Here's the deal-breaker disappointment for me.  I found myself having to push on a moderate slope in the yard.  The mower acted more like power-assist than self-propelled.  It would not have moved forward without help.  It was fine on level ground.  This lack of power was also reflected in the poor grass lifting capacity.  My old 6.5HP mower easily moved up the slope and, when set at 3" cut, lifted up long grass and cut it.  The new Lawn Boy did a poor job of pulling the long grass to cutting height, nor did it pick up even the smallest bits of branch debris.

I had been a bit worried about power judging from a few of the reviews, but assured myself it would be fine since I don't rally have a hill, just a gentle slope.  I was wrong.  As an aside, the Kohler motor has a big "6.5" printed on the cover.  Smaller lettering says it is torque, not horsepower.  I saw the mower only on a high shelf at the HD before buying it and missed the torque part of the label.  Simply put, the 149cc motor is inadequate for anything deviating more than a few degrees from flat.

I'll be taking the 10604 Back.  Unfortunately I can't find a Lawn Boy with a more powerful motor.  I will be looking at other brands.  And yes, I'll be fixing my old LB too :-)

Overall it's a nice little mower, but not good for anywhere but flat terrain.
summary: Not Your Father's Lawn Boy - Final UPDATE

Okay I used a lot of this kind of stuff over the last 40 years of gardening and this is the first one along with the Hy-brix molasses that actually worked. I had moved 2 years ago to a house where the soil is actually almost sterile. I have put so much organic admendments to the ground and the plants were still struggling here. I had a Kishu  Mandarin tree that was planted wrong by a landscaper and it looked completely dead.i really had no hope for it and really thought I lost the tree. I found a little green above the graph line and applied this along with high Brix molasses and within 3 weeks period of time, this stuff brought my poor little kishu tree back to life. It now has about three feet of lush Healthy Growth all around it, I was totally shocked on how well this tree is now doing. I also saw a huge difference in the other newly planted trees, they all seem to be growing quicker and not stressing from the heat. My potted hibiscus plants which are all root bound with the old soil in it, every one of them after applying this ended up being very green and the new growth is three times bigger than before and the flowers on the hibiscus plants are almost saucer size. They look like they do came from the florist. My geraniums that were struggling are now Lush and very green and so many flowers on them they look like they came from a magazine. I also use this on my root bound fig trees, the new growth on them are huge. The leafs are the size of my head instead of my palm on my hands and they're producing figs way before they should. There fig is already bigger then the ripe ones last year. I also use this on a very tired old orange tree and was shocked to see the tree go from crappie looking to a very dense lush green orange tree and the massive amount of fruit on it is just incredible. My lime tree that was showing deficiency in micronutrients in the leafs. I had applied everything that it needed but the trees still was deficient. After I applied recharge about 7 Days Later all of my leaves are very Lush green and no longer showed any deficiency sign and the tree is just putting out a massive amount of new growth and now the tree is bearing an unbelievable amount of fruit. All of my potted plants also are showing great signs of being absolutely healthy and lush, they are all full of huge flowers or fruit. My boysenberry Vine the leaves are so big on them now compared to the older growth and already producing a lot of fruit, I just planted them. They were bare root. This stuff actually really does work, it is amazing.  It is hard to grow stuff here in Arizona with our Heat and it seems the plants are not stressing as much. There is comments about the stuff getting everywhere and it is real fine like baby powder but it is very easy to use. I just used it in a tree well in case any spilled it blown away the plant would get extra. You can put it in a Ziploc bag and use it from to thier. I used about a heaping teaspoon in a gallon of water, a teaspoon of molasses and a teaspoon of fish emulsion to ensure to activate and feed the enzymes when I applied this to the plants. I use this formula on all of the potted plants and just saturated the soil and the gallon container fed several pots depending on the size. For the plants or trees in the ground, I used a heaping teaspoon and applied it in my gallon container of water and then applied it to each of the tree wells. For the orange tree which is about 15 ft tall by 15 ft wide I used 3 heaping tablespoons completely around the tree well and drip line. I would put the little bag in the tree well and scoop out what I needed and if any would spill the tree would get extra. This size bag will go a long way and I've made a tea out of it to expand the use of it also. The product works really well and works really fast and does unlock any of the nutrients in the ground to release it to the plant to use. This has saved a lot of my poor plants that were dying and not doing well or not doing much. I cannot wait to see how Lush and beautiful everything will be in a few months. I will be buying this in a bigger bag. But this is something great to add life to any yard or potted plants. You can also use this for indoor plants and medical plants also. I highly recommend this for absolutely everybody. Love love this stuff.
summary: This really works like magic, brought back life to almost dead trees.

reviewText:
In outdoor furniture the challenge is always balancing "look" and "maintenance."  Assuming that this Highwood recliner lives up to expectations, the product certainly comes down on the side of maintenance.  Not to be overly critical, but I find it hard to imagine that anybody could mistake this chair for wood, unless they wore both blind and tactily deficient.  Perhaps at a significant distance (in bad light), but within five feet you know you are looking at something made of plastic and by touch that becomes still more clear. That can of course be okay. There's nothing wrong with plastic in outdoor furniture, but the effort to imitate wood failing badly seems to me a strike against this product. Further, I suspect that this problem is made worse in "Weathered Acorn."  Likely in other options -- the white especially -- this will not be such an issue.

In terms of assembly, I found the process a bit challenging.  Thirty years and three kids into assembling different types of furniture, this certainly falls on the more difficult end.  More than anything my issues resulted from the poor quality of the instructions.  The pictures included in the  instructions were photographs each taken scant inches from the point where I was inserting a screw.  Time and again I found myself referring back to the larger picture to better orient myself with regards to the whole chair. Moreover, while someone could probably put it together as they direct, I suspect many will be reaching for a flashlight (the guide holes are hard to find, especially when trying to attach three pieces on one bolt) and dropping the wrench in favorite of a socket wrench (some of the angles are challenging).  Is it really so difficult to write good directions with easy to comprehend images?  That said, the whole assembly took a little less than an hour.

Comfort remains, of course, the highest priority.  In this the chair succeeds and one can easily imagine lazying away afternoons reading or listening to music reclining in one of its three settings (though at $360, a cushion seems in order).

While I rarely think it proper to critique other folks reviews, I do have to disagree on one point when it comes to this item.  Some have described it as heavy, but I found the opposite to be the case.  A wood chair would be  heavier and feel more substantive.

As you should be able to guess, I'm pretty ambivalent about this product. If you value low maintenance above all and don't care that it looks more like plastic wood than real wood, than this may be the chair for you. I've gone through more than my share of wooden deck furniture that made it two seasons before self junking.  At $360,  perhaps more than anything you are purchasing this chairs warranty (12 years for residential use and 8 years for commercial).  Even so, $360 feels like a lot of money for what you are getting. I'd likely have felt somewhat different if they either had done a better job making the chair "feel" like wood, or hadn't tried quite so hard and plainly failed.
summary: Okay, but expensive for what you get

I've had this grill for a couple of years - $268 at Wal Mart.  It's well built, a bit thicker than most grills in this price range, but not thick enough.  I am constantly having to repaint spots.  And the cooking space in simply not adequate for large meals.  Welcome to the new millennium!!!  There simply isn't a good backyard grill out there at a decent price anymore.  I advise taking expanded metal and making briquette baskets to keep the heat as far away from the metal as possible and finding charcoal that burns well with minimal charcoal lighter fluid.  (Kindle, available at "Save a Bunch!")  Also, keeping DRY ashes in the bottom of the grill will help insulate the metal, but I must emphasize DRY ASHES.  Ashes have lye that is activated by water, ergo rust!  And be prepared to repaint occasionally.  Closing on a positive note, I always have briquettes that fully burn left over, so apparently it seals adequately.  Not a bad grill for the money.
summary: There simply isn't a good backyard grill out there at a decent price anymore

reviewText:
Great improvement over their previous unit. Here in Georgia the sun takes a terrible toll on almost everything that's exposed outside. The sun just cooked the previous units after about a year. What's nice about the new units is thepoo control is all in the house with air conditioning. The control unit and the valve in my home is approximately 70 feet apart and down one floor. The unit still works fine, gives feedback to the control unit, and you can turn the valves on and off from inside the house if you choose to be on manual control. Another nice feature is that you can control the unit from anywhere in the world that has access to the internet. That way if it starts raining I can shut all the valves off without having to go outside and get wet. The app that controls the unit is extremely easy to program and use. Well worth the money.

7/27/17 - After a month of having this unit I'm not as optimistic as I was. The moisture accessory is not as reliable as it was in the older unit. In fact, it's rather hairy-fairy. There also seems to be a belligerence to switch from auto to manual and has an annoying habit of dropping out of sync with the control unit. At the present, I'll say it's inclined to be frustrating. Unfortunately, there isn't another unit on the market to replace it. In addition, they don't have an app that will run on a PC.

3/1/18 Well, it's now been about eight months. I found out that this unit has a definite weakness in that the control unit has a hard time staying online. I go into it with my notepad and find it's offline and therefore I doubt if any of the functions would work. I've had the control unit replaced once and I still get the same results. Keep in mind that I've been in electronics all my life and bought my first IBM computer in 1982 and was the data specialist for AT&T before I retired. I've been working with computer problems for the better part of 30 years. Frankly I think this unit is flaky I wish the heck a new competitor would come out with all the features that the Melnor has.

3/10/18
At this point I'm so totally frustrated I'm going to bunch the whole thing and return to my Orbit irrigation timers that have no wireless. Melnor replaced the control unit and the valves and I still get the same results. Maybe the control program just doesn't like Samsung tablets or phones. Strange, because I have Nest thermostats, Alexa units, two stationary computers, a tablet and a phone, Roku and a Sony blue ray player all working on the same 60 megabyte internet line. All without any problems whatsoever. So Melnor goes into the useless junk box. Good luck if you want to try one. Hope you have more success than I did. Google rates the software at 2.7. That in itself ought to tell you a lot.

6/28/18 after countless failures to get this machine up and working consistently I've decided the best place for it is in the garbage can. At this point it's impossible to determine if it's the Android software, the Spectrum Wi-Fi or the Melnor unit. I'm not going to buy a new tablet or switch over to one of the crummier internet providers on the off-chance that they are causing the problem so the best thing to do is garbage can the unit and forget it. If you decide to buy one, good luck don't say you haven't been warned. If I get a review this product with 0 Stars I would have done it. This is the most disappointing product I've ever purchased from Amazon and I've been with them for a long time.

I'm sure you've heard Nat King Cole sing the song Unforgettable. Well, just plug in unreliable for unforgettable and you'll have the whole story of this unit.
summary: Great improvement over previous units that they have had.but still has some problems.

I love hummingbirds.  They are wonderful acrobats, as anyone who as seen one will attest.  And I've gotten buzzed a few times myself.

This is my basic, all-purpose hummingbird feeder.  It's glass with a plastic feeder bottom.  It holds about a cup of sugar water.  No dye is necessary, and the hummers thrive on a pure sugar diet.

It cleans nicely (I use a small bottle brush), it holds enough for a week's worth of food, and it goes up easily.  It includes what are billed as bee guards.  I don't have a problem with bees, so sometimes I just leave them off.  And the bee guards are the only thing that I consider a problem with this product; the guards are very hard to clean.  If mildew gets on them, it the devil's business in cleaning them off.  So I just don't often use them.

Highly recommended.  Perky Pet has a winner here!  Four-and-a-half stars for the Pinch Waist Hummingbird feeder.
summary: My Second One; They Last 10 Years or More!

reviewText:
Mine was a 2014 Q320(0). Wonderful grill, outstanding heat uniformity. Cooks better than any grill I've ever owned, HUGE heat output contained tightly within the porcelain top means great searing. The LED light is a gimmick and should simply be dropped; the heat quickly kills the battery and renders the light useless (idea: make it solar-powered rechargeable; do you really need six hours per night of light to grill especially considering that the light only illuminates when the lid is open?). The 2014 ignition is an exercise in patience as it took up to ten tries to ignite, including playing games like shutting down and opening the lid and trying again; I see the igniter looks different on the new version and perhaps they have fixed that.

Left it unattended with both burners on medium. Came back half an hour later and the grill had melted its way down through the plastic and the lid had embedded itself into the U-tube underneath. I mean it melted more than an inch down. Cracked the lid trying to work its way free of the plastic. The grill not only destroyed itself but it could have been an actual fire/explosion hazard - I see reviews of the grill catching fire and I can see how that have happened very easily. Most frustrating, the stand is absolutely undamaged and I can't seem to find the grill (either old or new) by itself to use with the old stand and save some money. I'm ordering a new one and hoping these problems have been fixed, because it genuinely is a great grill.

Except, that is, when it melts!

EDIT: Cancelled the order (actually refused delivery per Amazon customer service instructions) as Weber came through at the last moment and confirmed it was in-warranty (five years, and they had the serial number on file so I didn't have to come up with a receipt - that's worth a star back and I'll jump it to four stars if and when I get the replacement and confirm it works).

Although I could not convince the not-very-technical customer support person to let me speak with one of the design engineers ("sir, I am sure they know all about this and these problems are always caused by grease" - uh, no, radiant heat decreases by the inverse square of distance and radiated energy increases by the fourth power of the absolute temperate and by the way I'm a physicist and a grease flareup is not why your cookbox MELTED the cradle), I have a suspicion I know what actually caused this. At the time, the lid was down but slightly open to allow the handles of some kebab baskets to poke out. As anyone who has ever worked with a long-flue furnace (like a coke furnace or a smelting furnace) knows, the temperature goes up tremendously when you get a draft blowing through. A fire is never hottest when it is completely exposed, too much air cools the fire more than the additional oxygen heats it. Your hottest temperature is when air has partial, but not complete, access to the outside so it creates a partial vacuum and sucks high-speed air in through venturi effect. In one place, the instructions say to cook with the lid "closed" but in most places it says to cook with the lid "lowered." I'll bet that the lid is really supposed to be completely closed and if it is cracked open just the right amount and the gas output is set just right, this grill turns into a furnace. I didn't think to look at the thermometer readout but it must have been fantastically high, two years' worth of charcoal buildup inside the lid was completely gone (the inside of the lid looks like it just came out of the box) and I see on Wikipedia that's at least 660 degrees F (the built in thermometer PEGS at 600) and can go as high as >1,000< degrees...that's no grease flareup!

FOLLOW UP: I eventually received all the replacement parts (when Weber said they would replace the "cookbox" I thought they meant the entire cooker, but that turned out to be just the bottom, so I had to subsequently request a lid, cradle, and igniter switch - the light was also melted but I didn't bother with that). Oddly the lid is jet black, I thought they only came in gray and red. Anyway, back in business and back up to four stars. By the way, the new cradle sits higher than the old one (I can clearly see the drip pan between the cooker and the cradle, whereas before I could not) and upon inspection I found that they have added ceramic discs to the feet of the cooker, no doubt to insulate the plastic from heat and prevent exactly the kind of meltdowns that I experienced. Also, the new design has limited airflow intakes on either side that greatly boost cooking temperature - with both burners set to medium (and remember, the burners weren't replaced, so these are the originals) temperature climbs to over 500 degrees. On medium! So while it is annoying that I'm burning burgers while learning to adapt to the improved heating (I'll start cooking stuff at low, or using only one burner and save gas), that tells me that they have made tremendous overall improvements. Oh and even though the igniter element is original, with the new igniter activator installed I'm now getting lights at the first or at most second try.

Two and a half stars for the one I originally bought; four and a half stars for the current model.

I got this, along with a Miller Manufacturing Double Wall Fount to get through a snowstorm and below freezing temps this winter. It's Oregon, so we aren't talking -40 degrees or the like. But it was in the high teens and low 20's for several days. Frozen water was a big problem. I was changing water every hour or so to keep the ice at bay.

I placed this in a sheltered corner of the girls run, and put the water on top. Presto. No more ice. Water stayed at a nice temp. Not too warm, and not cold. So the girls not only didn't have to deal with ice, the water was not cold either.

I just bought my fourth Nelson 50503 High Pressure Sprayer in about 9 years.  The first one lasted about 6 years, and then I have gone through about one every year since.  They are heavily built, and feel very solid, but they fail way too often.  The reason I keep buying them is they are the only spray head that will deliver the water flow that I need with my hose setup.  I tapped in to the same water source that feeds my in-ground sprinkler system.  This tap is BEFORE the 75 PSI regulator that controls pressure to the house.  This makes a big difference in having a garden hose and sprayer that will actually get some work done.

I have 3/4 inch copper pipe that enters the house from the city.  I think pressure is 120 or 130 PSI.  From the 3/4 inch feeder I tapped in with 1" pipe, and use nothing but 1 inch pipe, with one inch fittings, including a 1 inch shut-off valve.  I did this since many of the 3/4 valves actually do not have a full 3/4 inch flow, so you never get the full use of the 3/4" pipe.  That is why I went with 1 Inch.  Then I use a very heavy 3/4 inch garden hose, and then the Nelson Spray head.  This is the only head that will handle the water flow, and it works like a champ.  The issue is the quality.  When it works, it works well, but I have had 3 failures in about 3 years, all of them different type of failures, including leaking, handle breaking and then the last one just fell apart all of a sudden.  Weird.

I would change brands, but this is the only one that actually works, and has about at 60 foot throw, with lots of water.

I feel bad giving it 2 stars, since I like the way it works.  If they did not fail so often it would be 5+.stars.
summary: Works like a champ, but should be more reliable.

This sprayer has made my gardening sooo much easier! Mind you, I have never had a pump sprayer before, so I am not an expert. But after trying for two years to spray organic pesticide with recycled Windex or Method bottles, I got tired of hand cramps, and small, spotty, coverage, and the pump sprayer seems wonderful.

The pump mechanism is also the top. It is easy to open and locks securely. It is also easy to pump up the pressure ; the piston moves smoothly, although it squeaks. When open, the mouth of the bottle is fairly large, with a wide collar around it to catch spills and direct them into the bottle. The collar can help balance a strainer if, like me, you mix DIY fungicide/pest repellent* and want to strain it into the bottle. The hose inside the bottle does have a fine-mesh, built-in strainer, but I didn't want to gunk it up. The plastic bottle is lightweight, which makes it easy to carry, and hold while spraying. I have knocked it over many times without damage. I have been using it a few times a week for 2 months. The spray is steady, not a firehose by any means, but distributes enough liquid to really wet the plants after one pass above and below.

I enthusiastically recommend this product for weekend gardener who grows vegetables and wants to give up on expensive, toxic sprays.

*2 cloves garlic, 1/4 cup cedar chips, 1 tbsp tea tree oil, 1 tbsp Sals Suds, 2 gals water. (I battled fungus, cabbage moths and aphids for two years. Now I just spray this everywhere after it rains. Tea tree oil is harmless to us and our pets; it's in dandruff shampoo. You can also use neem oil instead of tea tree.) Unfortunately, it did not work agaist vine borers. If you grow squash, you know what I mean.
summary: Give up toxic sprays. Make your own and spray them with this efficient sprayer.

reviewText:
I bought this to replace an 11-year old Rain Bird ESP-8Si that was no longer working.  Being another Rain Bird product, I was relieved to find that my old wiring would plug directly into the new controller without any changes.  This made installation mindless and simple.  I labeled the zone controller wires for my 8 zones, unplugged them from the ESP-8Si, removed it, mounted the Smart Station, and then reattached the 8 zone wires.  Everything worked perfectly from there.

Once I had swapped in the controller, the only extra installation work I had to do was mount the remote weather sensor unit to my fence and run the line into the controller.  Once plugged in, I started seeing humidity readings on the controller.  When it rains, the sensor seems to detect this within 2-3 hours.  It will then stay in "rain detect" state for up to a few days until the sensor dries out.  Until the rain detection expires, it will not water your lawn.  I love this feature!

We've had some sub-40 degree (F) weather recently and, as advertised, the smart station did not water my yard when the temps dropped below 40.

The humidity readings are consistently too low for my area.  I live in Houston, Texas and we often have high humidity (as high as 100%).  The highest I've seen on the Smart Station is a reading of 63% (when the weather channel was reporting 100% humidity AND it was pouring rain).  When not raining, the highest humidity reading I've seen is 58% (when weather channel was reporting 100% humidity).

It took me a bit to rethink my lawn's schedule in the context of the new "smart" adaptive functionality of the new Rain Bird, but once done, I'm confident it will work better than my old unit.  I love the seasonal adjustment that reduces watering in the winter.  I used to "manually" do this in the past.  Now I can just forget about it and let the Rain Bird smart station do all the thinking.

Overall, this is a nice and easy upgrade.  If you are somewhat careful with the wires, even someone with little technical skill can remove an old rain bird unit and hook up this one.

Considering that this auger was not terribly expensive, I am not terribly concerned with the relatively weak metal used in its construction. Fortunately, the weak-ish metal has not led to any breaks in the auger/twist portion of this bit. However, if you are not extremely careful, you will inevitably strip the metal away that is inside the drill chuck to the point that it breaks off or needs to be broken off. Fortunately, I rarely drill much deeper than the twisted section goes anyway, so I just break off the stripped metal and put the bit back in my drill. After that, I just have to bend over ever-so-slightly more to use the auger. Another thing to watch out for is if the auger hits a rock or something else hard and binds on you. If it does that, be prepared for the drill to try to rip your wrist off. I find keeping the drill handle near my near saves my wrist, but leads to huge bruises on my thigh. Pick your poison.
summary: Better than expected, but not amazing.

reviewText: I purchased this for the first time in July 2015, and just returned to purchase another one. It truly does its job--protecting my Landmann 26364 23-1/2-Inch Savannah Garden Light Fire Pit. I keep it outdoors year-round with this cover on it, through our North Texas thunderstorms, searing heat and below-freezing temps. The only time I bring it in the garage is if we're expecting an ice storm or very high winds. This cover has kept the fire pit looking like new. The cover was recently torn by workers who replaced our roof, otherwise I'm sure it would have lasted through the next summer. Now, it has faded in the sun to a gray color., but this is after 18+ months outside in the Texas sun. This cover has not cracked or peeled, and no birds or squirrels have been able to damage it. Birds do perch on the top of the firepit quite frequently and leave evidence of their visit, but I just hit it with the garden hose and it cleans right off. All in all, if you're looking for a strong, durable, weatherproof cover that will protect your firepit, this is the one.
summary: Durable, weatherproof, cover will protect your firepit for years!

reviewText: Killed VERY LARGE bee hive in siding in two days.  Over 100 bees a minute were entering and exiting a hole in my siding created by the heat pump piping so I went out at night wearing large gloves and bee netting and filled bellows half way with power as recommended.  I sprayed three puffs inside and ran away.  The next morning about 15 bees a minute were staggering out and were afraid to enter the hole.  The second night I took my time and sprayed a puff in each direction, up, down, left and right.  The length of the nozzle really helped.  By the second morning there were no bees anywhere.  I will wait a week and then fill the hole with expandable sealer.  This produce worked much better than the wasp spray because the bees track through it until the entire hive gets exposure.  I couldn't see hive until I could put a remote camera in there, and it was huge.
summary: Kills all bees in hidden (under siding) hive in two days.  Excellent product.

We have lots of house finches, song sparrows and seasonal goldfinches in Eastern Iowa. Keeping them fed with thistle in the Spring and Summer can be a challenge. The sock feeders get torn apart on feeding frenzies and the traditional slot feeders just don't have enough statios which leads to more fighting and less feeding.
The 17" Bird Quest Spiral Thistle Bird Feeder has alleviated the fighting problem as the birds can go from ne port to the other by simply sliding down the spiral. In fact, they seem to derive a certain amount of enjoyment from sliding from port to port. I forget exactly how many ports are on this feeder but there are plenty. As someone who has gone through many disappointing thistle feeders I can recommend the Bird Quest 17" Spiral Thistle Bird Feeder without reservation.

I purchased HeatTrak in the fall of 2015 and used it all last winter. It did not work as fast as I expected but it did work. So I just pulled it out to get ready for this winter. Here is what I learned based on my last year experience. The mat works slowly, so it is best to turn it on before the storm prior to any snow fall. I normally keep the mat unplugged and plug in only when the storm is predicted. I am using it on a wood deck. The mat did not cause discoloration under the mat. I see no signs that the wood stain under the mat has aged faster compared to other parts of the deck. The mat never felt hot to touch, only somewhat warm. Note that it only gets warm when the temperature is cold, keep that in mind if you are trying to test in the fall when it is not cold enough. The mat is less than 1/2" thick but has a thicker bump where the cord is connected to the mat. The size of the map is 24" x 36" and feels quite heavy. It does not get lifted even by heavy winds. The "carpeted" side should face up, the smooth side should face down. I also used the mat to melt icy patches on the deck. It took a long time to do the entire deck by moving the mat from spot to spot, but it was easier and caused less damage to the deck compared to trying to chip the ice off. I am using a 30 foot cord outdoor power cord and water-tight cord lock from Farm Innovators to protect the connection between the extension cord and the mat cord Farm Innovators Model CC-2 Cord Connect Water-Tight Cord Lock I wish it was a bit larger and a bit cheaper, but overall satisfied with how it worked last winter. Ali Julia review

I get a lot of spiders and bugs in general inside my detached garage - and a lot of the spiders are black or brown widows.  I've tried many different compressed "bug bomb" type of products.  This one seems to work the best.  Typically after (as long as a day) deploying these I'll walk out and see dead spiders outside the entrance door or garage door - they must have been fleeing but damage was already done.  I take both cars out of the garage when using these.  I've seen a lot of questions about using it in places like this with a freezer.  No worries - it doesn't bug bomb the freezer.  I keep buying these and will continue to buy them.
