reviewText:

When I discovered that my downspout drains were clogged and water was running down next to my foundation, I knew I had to act quickly.  I installed 10' sections of 4" PVC drain pipe with these drainage emitters at ground level.  They worked exactly as I'd hoped... the water is now draining away from my home.  The emitters remain closed when not in use, opening only when necessary.  We mow our lawns at a 1-3/4" height with a power mower, and I've not had any problem with these.  I did actually change out the elbow... rather than using 4" PVC Sewer and Drain pipe (which is the type of pipe the elbow is designed to work with,) I used Schedule 40 PVC drain pipe which is slightly larger and much heavier.  Using this pipe means that the pipe is far less likely to break and can certainly be cleaned out as necessary later on.  I had to pick up an adapter that I placed into the Schedule 40 elbow, then used only the green emitter portion from this part.  Some might say that's overkill, but it really didn't cost that much more to do it and I'm happy in the knowledge that I can clean this later as necessary, and that I won't have to replace the drain lines in the foreseeable future.
Got this in 2 days, super service. Used it today to clean my boats, dock and lawnmower, works perfectly. More power than I expected

Love it.

I really like these Gorilla hoses.  There are still a few quality issues.  I have had to return 2 of the 4 I ordered.  I had a 75 ft. and 100ft. hose that the end blew off of it.  The captive brass fitting was loose and I peeked under it and noticed the outer sheath of the hose (fabric part) was not well captivated under the clamp.  Well it lasted a day or so.  When the hose blows off, the rubber internal hose shrinks without collapsing the outer sheath. I spent an hour feeding it back through and putting a generic clamp on the hose to fix it until I could return it.

The expanding hose is a different animal. You should take it off the hose reel before turning the water on or it will be a pain to get it off as it will tangle (mine is a simple wall hung hook type).  It works best if you let it fill before starting to use it.  I had two hooked together and if you run it wide open too long the hose shrinks, making it too short if using it at full length.  it takes a minute to shrink back down too before putting it away.

Last issue is to please use thread locker on the screw holding the ball valve handle. I have had every one of them fall off, the screw head is not standard so you cannot just replace it if it's lost in the grass.  I had to grind down a socket head screw to replace it.

On the plus side, this hose is awesome.  I have hooked 200 ft of hose to fertilize my lawn and trees and it pulls across the grass like a dream.  I can wind 200 ft of hose on my reel and it looks like 75 ft of standard hose volume wise.  Easy storage, you won't believe the tiny box it comes in.
As Promised.

This was not at all the same quality of the first cover I bought at my hardware store, my first one will outlive this cheaply made crap by a few years I bet. Not sure if this is really made by Weber or a knock off somehow but shame on Weber if they are just making these cheaper now!

We have had one of these for several years and while it never worked what one would call "smoothly", it did work OK.

Until now. Something has gone "funny" with the hose feed mechanism and the hose does not reel in being guided so that it loads evenly on the spool. It just stacks up at one spot on the spool, so, of course it jams.

The cause is plastic being used where metal should be and the resulting wear on the plastic making it fail.

Actually, it is a miracle that this lasted as long as it did with "OK" performance.

I wish these hose reel manufacturers would design for 10 year lifetimes before failure instead of 3 years.

I am very impressed with this product. Assembly was very easy once I figured out the proper way to do it. Lubricate both near corners of each of the 2 steps with silicone spray. Place the far corners of each of the 2 steps into the appropriate spots on the 2 side supports. Slide the tongues into the grooves as far as they will easily go where the side edges of the steps meet the supports. Stand on the steps to snap the near corners of the steps into place on the side supports. This method bypasses the use of a rubber hammer which I found did not work very well. The steps do flex somewhat when I place my 225lbs. on them but it is minimal and no problem. These are great steps at a great price.

Once the chair has reclined it is easier to make adjustments but it is a major effort to go from sitting upright to the recline position.

This is a lot of line, but all things considered, better than running to the store every month or so to get a little 25' piece at a lot higher cost per foot. I have a lot of trimming to do and expect this will probably last for 2-3 years anyway!

This series of emails speaks for itself. The word, "b--ch" was edited per Amazon instructions. It was spelled out in the e mail. Amazon, sent an apologetic letter and a free replacement the next day. Here are the emails from General Hydroponics:

General Hydroponic

From: Jesse Pennington [mailto:jesse@genhydro.com]
Sent: Wednesday, September 04, 2013 1:17 PM
To: Matthew Durst
Subject: FW: GENERAL HDROPONICS 50 POD STARTER TRAY : DEFECTIVE

What should we do if anything for this whinny little b--ch?

From: Marc Berrenson [mailto:marcberrenson5@gmail.com]
Sent: Thursday, August 29, 2013 7:17 PM
To: info@genhydro.com
Subject: GENERAL HDROPONICS 50 POD STARTER TRAY : DEFECTIVE

WELL, I WAITED SEVERAL WEEKS UNTIL I HAD MY LIGHT AND SEEDS AND WARMING MAT, ETC. THEN I EXCITEDLY FILLED MY GENERAL HYDROPONICS STARTER TRAY WITH WATER AND PLACED THE FIFTY POD UNIT INSIDE AND STARTED TO SET MY SEEDS. I FELT REALLY EXCITED, SINCE I'M JUST STARTING OUT IN HYDROPONIC GARDENING. THAT DIDN'T LAST TOO LONG SINCE ABOUT AN HOUR LATER WHEN I WENT OUTSIDE TO CHECK, I NOTICED A POOL OF WATER AROUND MY OUTER TRAY. THE OUTER TRAY, UPON CLOSER INSPECTION HAD HOLES AND CRACKS ON THE BOTTOM, THUS MAKING IT TOTALLY USELESS FOR ITS INTENDED PURPOSE. NOT ONLY WAS I OUT THE COST OF THE TRAY (AMAZON, BUT I CANNOT RETURN IT IN ITS PRESENT CONDITION AND I'M STILL TRYING TO SAVE THE SEED PODS BY PLACING IT IN A LARGE, CUMBERSOME, PLASTIC BOX UNDER MY FLUORESCENT LIGHTS), BUT I HAD PROBABLY WASTED THE SEED, AND IN THE PROCESS SOME OF THE PLUGS FELL OUT AND WERE UNDOUBTEDLY PUT BACK IN THE WRONG HOLES.  BUT EVEN THAT DIDN'T REALLY BOTHER ME. I WAS JUST EXCEEDINGLY DISAPPOINTED IN THE RATHER FLIMSY PLASTIC TRAY, WHICH, NO DOUBT WAS CRACKED DURING SHIPPING.BEFORE WRITING A REVIEW ON AMAZON, I THOUGHT I'D CONTACT YOU DIRECTLY. YOUR REVIEWS ON AMAZON ARE VERY GOOD. I THOUGHT I'D GIVE YOU THE CHANCE TO MAKE THIS RIGHT.

I LOOK FORWARD TO HEARING FROM YOU. HOPEFULLY, MY CURRENT SET UP WILL AT LEAST GIVE ME A FEW SPROUTS. GOD KNOWS, IT WILL SET BACK THE ENTIRE PROCESS AT LEAST A COUPLE OF WEEKS.

Sincerely,
MARC BERRENSON

This is FAR better than Warfarin based poison since many rats, (like Norway Rats) have become immune to that poison.
At minimum, make sure you are using a Bromadiolone based poison and check the amount that is in it. One star off for price. Too expensive.

This is the best stuff to use in ponds in Florida.  Nothing works better!  It's not cheap but your pond will be happy.
These are very sturdy.. will hang heavy objects if you need. I bought them for extra hummingbird hangers.

Quite a few things wrong with this unit, so here's a list...

Soil needs to be perfectly smooth - Rocks, weeds, compost will all collect in front of the seed chute and stop it dead.
It's not enough to disc your plot.  You need screened topsoil... or sand.

Does not cover seeds - the chain device is useless.  You have to go back over each row or the birds will get your seed.

You have to push down HARD to make the front wheel roll, and it still slips - It really should be made with a big heavy front wheel for momentum.  Think of a bicycle wheel.

Seeds pop out of the hopper - The motion of the disk in the hopper makes seeds pop out of the top.  When this happens, the hopper looks like a pop corn popper.  It's so ridiculous that I was SURE I lost the hopper cover somewhere.  Surely they would have thought of a hopper cover, right?  They didn't.  No cover.

The row marker is useless. Trying to use it just adds more drag to your already difficult forward momentum.  Forget this feature.

Sometimes it gets the spacing right, sometimes it doesn't get any seeds, sometimes it gets 3.

The only way I can see this working is in a DEEP, well defined furrow and then cover over it manually.  That will reduce this thing to just dropping seeds and poorly spaced at that, which I'm sure I can match with a little aim.
summary: Your soil needs to be the consistency flour - or forget it.

reviewText: good

Every spring for the past couple of years, I've bought a cardboard version of this plastic chute at a big-box hardware store for around five bucks a pop. Each one lasted about a year (I used those chutes for both grass cuttings and leaf collection, so they got a fairly good workout). Being cardboard, those chutes warped and bent over time due to moisture and cracked at the hinges from folding and unfolding. This plastic chute solves the durability problem and has a handy funnel-like top that the plain models don't.

This chute is more expensive than the basic cardboard model, but if it lasts longer than three seasons it will have served its purpose; even if it lasts only two years, I think it's worth it due to the funnel-thing on top. This doesn't look like your everyday garden trowel at all, and probably had I not had the opportunity to review this product at a reduced price, I wouldn't have given it a second thought. What I really loved about it is that it did not put the strain on my wrist that other hand tools do simply because the motion to use this tool is completely different. I purchased this cart from Tractor Supply on sale for $99, regularly $119.  I had both tire blow out within the first month but was given free replacements because it was under 90 days.  The tires are the weak link.  I had some trouble with the dump lever re-engaging in the beginning but it is working perfectly now.  I do not over load this trailer.  The recommended max load is highly inflated.  I have been using my trailer for moving rock/dirt and it is great.  With a heavy load you can see the sidewalls of the tires flex a great deal when backing up over uneven terrain which is what I have been doing on a hill.  The tail gate is no problem to lift straight up and the dump works well.  I put the trailer over the area I want the rocks to go, remove the tailgate, engage the dump and drive forward.  The entire load empties out.  The hitch is OK but noisy when pulling.  The tailgate also rattles a bunch adding to the noise.  I place the tailgate in the back of my rig to lessen the noise.  Keeps the neighbors happy.  I will be converting the hitch to a ball soon.  By the way, I using a golf cart to move this rock and it works great.  If you can get this cart at a reasonable price it can do the job.

I now have 2 of these sets, and an additional 4 sensors.  I use them to monitor the temperatures in my 12-V / solar powered freezer and my propane refrigerator in the cabin, as well as my product cooler on the water.  The system works well, but the readings are inconsistent (not great uniformity between sensors in the same location).  That said, if you do the ice-slush calibration, then mark each with the error that sen=sor has, there is no big problem, since the individual sensors appear to be accurate once that error is taken into account.  Also, for the freezer units, make sure you get Lithium batteries.  That can be a problem in a lot of areas, but the sensors in the colder compartments stop working when their batteries get below 0 or so.  Changing batteries and then re-setting the unit is a bit of a hassle, so do it as infrequently as you can.
summary: OK, but could be more accurate

This is a real Haws watering can made from quality copper nicely fitted and carefully soldered together.  Because solder melts at relatively low temperatures this is not the can to use to heat water in.  It is not a multi-tasker.  It is beautiful and useful.  The copper is not lacquered so it can be polished using a good copper polish or jewelers cloth and it will need to be polished periodically to keep its 'out of the box' appearance.  I find the 2-pint/1 Liter size is the 'right' balance between useful capacity and comfortable carrying/pouring weight when full.  The classic Haws design with a copper tube supporting the long, flowing spout is stable and sturdy.  Water flows at a good rate and the long nose of the spout works well for placing water into the middle of a plant.  The brass rose is also well-made and provides a gentle spray that doesn't stray too far from the edge of the pot or planter.  As the manufacturer suggests, the rose is not best used on indoor pots and plants because there will be some over spray.  The rose slips on and off easily.  Good gardening tools give me extra pleasure every time I use them so I see value for the price in this item.  The packaging in the picture is also 'a step above' in quality, being fitted to accept the can.  A little gift wrap and you have the presentation that will please any avid gardener.
summary: I've Always Wanted One Of These

reviewText:
When compared to other brands of tube feeders, the price of this feeder may seem a bit high. But after you see one you'll know why. There is no other tube feeder on the market that is designed and built as well as the Droll Yankees "B" series. I have accumulated about six of these various lenghs over the past several years, and all of them are still going strong. The 30", 12 port executive model is my personal favorite.

The Lexan plastic is heavier and far stronger.

The entire feeder disassembles easily for cleaning.

It has a very attractive design.

The birds love it!

Although they have to work at it, bears are about the only north american critter that can break this feeder. But even then you can still order new parts and rebuild your feeder at a fraction of the cost of a new one.

Customer service at Droll Yankees is exemplary. The people there the best at what they do!

Update 9/17/2013: If you have lots of squirrels at your feeders, sooner or later they will gnaw through anything. Such was the case with two of the polycarbonate tubes of two of my oldest feeders. After about 5-8 years, they were able to gnaw around some of the ports. I just got off the phone with Droll Yankee customer service. My intention was to purchase two new tubes. They would not hear of it! The lifetime warranty is real! They needed no pictures, only a verbal description over the phone of the squirrel damage. Two new tubes are on the way with free shipping! I love this company!

I couldn't tell the difference between Scotts 31005A Moss Control Granules (most expensive) and Scotts Moss Control Granules 31005 (least expensive) by the description.  Last year I applied this product, the more expensive one, and was very satisfied because it killed the moss quickly with only 1 application.  When it came time to order this year, I wondered why would I pay more  for what appears to be the same product so I ordered the least expensive one.
After application this year I see that the 2 products are very different.

The Scotts 31005A Moss Control Granules (most expensive) is very effective at killing moss with only 1 application.  I use it in flower beds as well as grass.  It has rust granules.
Whereas the Scotts Moss Control Granules 31015 (least expensive) with gray granules isn't as effective at killing moss but add nutrients to lawns; this product is best used to keep moss at bay after the moss has been killed and, it has much less coverage than the 5000 sq ft claimed.  To be clear, this product does kill moss but much more product is needed.  I still had moss and had to order the 31005A rust granules to get the job done properly.  What initially appeared to been a saving was not in my case.

For my climate in the no snow wet coast with a lot of moss, I think it's best to apply the 31005A in early November and again in early spring to kill all the moss and use the 31005 to keep moss away and feed the grass during summer.

The names of the products are the same which is confusing but they are different products with a different purpose.
summary: Difference with this product and the less expensive Scotts 31015

reviewText: I have an Intex 52" by 24' above ground pool with a sand filter. This shock has been a lifesaver! We have been able to keep our pool crystal clear all summer with very little maintenance. This year we tried using liquid bleach along with the floater & adding a shock treatment every 2-3 weeks. It's worked wonderfully for us and saves me $150 a month on a pool guy to come out & maintain our pool. I will definitely be reordering this again! Our pool did cloud up once when we were too busy to check on it for over a week, I added 1 bag of shock in the evening, a second bag the next day because it looked blue but still a little cloudy & it cleared right up by the next morning.
summary: Great buy & has kept our pool clear all summer

Well I looked at my front walk from the driveway to the house today and it had about 30 inches of snow. I was going to shovel it and then I bulb went off - what if I use my little Toro as a "shovel" lifting it with the handle behind the blower shute and the other hand on the handle where the power bar is located. Well it worked great scooping off 6-8 inches of snow and again until I hit the concrete and in no time I had the sidewalk cleared.

Now maybe not everyone can use it that way - my wife probably could not but it worked for me. I doubt Toro would every recommend such and if you try just use proper precautions. For smaller snowfalls it works great!!  Doesn't hardly take up any room in the garage either.

reviewText:
I have been smoking meats for about a decade now and started with a charcoal grill, then on to 2 different propane grills and now my first experience with an electric smoker. The engineer part of me LOVES the fact that electric smokers can maintain a constant smoker heat without constant monitoring and with the internal temp probe on my 40" MES unit, I can get an accurate picture of how the is progressing. Best of both worlds? In a way - yes and in a way - no. Although I do get a reasonable smoke flavor infused into the meat using the standard chip feeder, it is much less pronounced than any of my previous grills. I ordered an A-Maze-N pellet smoke producer and my problem was solved. With the MES chip feeder removed and the vent open, the pellet smoke producer has provided between 10-15 hours of flavorful smoke. VERY convenient for anyone that does an all night "low & slow" cook. Smoke producers can also facilitate cold smoking of things like cheese, jerky and fish but I have never tried that so cannot comment on usefulness. (Seems logical though).

This unit is a breeze to clean, has plenty of room to smoke enough food for larger groups of people and (so far) has been a welcome and reliable part of my outdoor cooking experience.

If you want ease of operation - This is your unit! If you enjoy a stronger smoke flavoring - either plan to purchase a 3rd party smoke producer or stick with propane, wood chips or a pellet smoker.

reviewText: I've purchased five humidistats over the past five years; I've trashed five of them over the past five years. This is the first one that actually works as advertised. I love that it can be calibrated. Just use a 2:1 ratio by weight of table or sea salt (NaCl) to water solution in a sealable container, insert something for the AcuRite to sit on (out of the water, of course), seal the top, and give the container time to develop a stable 75% humidity. After the humidity reading settles down, note the discrepancy from 75 degrees, remove the AcuRite and let it adjust itself to the new humidity level outside the container. DON'T THROW AWAY THE SALT SOLUTION AND CONTAINER. Then follow the directions for calibrating the unit. Do the procedure all over again to make sure you calibrated it correctly. Repeat until the AcuRite reads 75% inside the sealed container with salt solution. It's a piece of cake.  And on top of that great little perk, the unit reads the humidity and reports it every 15 seconds. So you don't have to wait half an hour for it to give you a reading, like most other units on the market.
summary: This little item is a gem...read on

reviewText:
Over the years, we've had a variety of bird feeders. The squirrels always seem to find a way to make a feast out of all the bird seed. I was hopeful with this feeder as it's setup meant that the dispensing slots closed with the weight of the squirrel. Unfortunately for the smaller birds, it also means that it closes when the larger birds come to feed. While that doesn't sound like a bad thing, it is if the smaller bird is already feeding as it can cause harm to the smaller bird if they don't move before the closing mechanism is activated by the larger bird.

Like many other feeders, there is the issue of the squirrel chewing their way into the feeder. I thought the feeder was protected enough to avoid this issue, but I was wrong. I will say that it took them longer to chew their way through than with some of the other feeders that we've used.

The feeder itself is quite lovely to look at, and the idea behind it is good. Realistically, you would need to have a more durable plexiglass or glass to avoid the squirrel chewing issue. If you don't have a lot of squirrels, this feeder would probably last for quite some time.

Have been using this over my new Weber stainless grill for 8 months in North Florida. Good velcro straps to keep cover tightly contained around grill. This cover shows no sign of wear or substandard qualities. Fits well and easy on/off. I also put a heavy (thick) piece of PVC shower pan material (Lowe's 4 ft widths by about 6 ft will be pricey but worth it) over the top of this cover to also deflect the weather elements. The heavier PVC slides off easily and keeps this grill cover from dealing with the sun and storm elements. This cover provides total coverage and keeps grill from getting wet inside which can mix with the greasy aspects of the grill interior. Love the quality of Weber!! (We grill fish and chicken almost every night - clean grill every 6 - 8 weeks. A clean grill is a joy to use. This cover is an important part of keeping it in good, pleasant working condition. I figure that good grilling practices include keeping a grill clean . . . one free from pests and bacteria.) Happy Grilling!!

reviewText:
UPDATE Feb 12, 2015.
This inexpensive generator is doing well. No power outages but to be ready I have:
1. Tested it up to 1500 watts running (space heater). No problem.
2. Tested it with my Samlex battery charger. This is an expensive 50 amp charger and so draws 500 watts max. In the ecomode the generator had no problems supplying that amount of power.

I hope to run my furnace and sump pump off my deep cycle storage batteries with an inverter and so avoid having to run the generator all night or get out of bed at 2:00am during a hurricane to set up a generator. The issue is getting an inverter that can play nice with your house circuit wiring (bonded neutral), not simply running appliances directly plugged into it, which seems, so far, difficult for things like your furnace.

I really should give this thing 5 stars but I am still bummed I can't get 240 volts to backfeed the house with two running in parallel. They should make that clear. My son in law is an electrical engineer, and he also assumed that could be done (He bought the Honda, and paid 2 1/2 times what I did. "What's the 2nd one for Dad? Spare parts?" Bah. Snarky kids.).

 So, more accurate advertising, please.

Oh, about the noise. My original review stated they were noisier than I expected. It turned out I had the cover improperly attached (open at the base), and that defeated some of the insulation. With the case cover on properly, and in the ecomode, this is really not noisy at all.

So, one very pleased customer here.

===================End of Update=======================

Bought two when they were on sale. This is my first generator. I was planning on hooking two together and backfeeding into the house. That cannot be done because they produce only 120 volts. A big bummer.

However, they arrived promptly and are very nicely made machines. I have only run one machine for a short break in but here is my experience:

1. Customer support: Good. I called about changing the sparkplug, since the manual doesn't discuss their new style of changing the plug via the opening on top of the case. Got a human who was very helpful without waiting.

2. Filling the crank case is a nuisance. Pour the oil in slowly or it will back up. Put tinfoil under the oil filler opening on the floor, and put some paper towels on top of the tin foil to absorb the oil that spills. That will prevent a mess.

3. Being an amateur, I spent most of my time fiddling with the grounding rod. (How do you make one of those?) I finally got it done. I used a green metal fence post from which I ground off the paint  to make it conductive. A big nuisance. Then I lost, in the snow, the set screw for the ground connector as I hammered the post into the frozen ground. Good thing I had bought two ground wire connectors. It is now buried in 2 feet of snow under a collapsed bush. I'll find it when I need or next spring. In retrospect, rebar wold work fine. Lowe's sells the ground wire connector, the wire, and the rebar.

4. The generator started on the second pull in 24 degree weather. It powered a 1500 watt space heater without difficulty.

5. It is light enough to be easily carried.

6. It is a bit noisier than I was hoping for, but, not bad. Nowhere near the noise of other, albeit larger, generators.

Other advice for amateurs. Be sure you have a gasoline siphon. I was surprised to find after the snow began, that my lawnmower gasoline cans were almost empty.
summary: Nice generator but cannot backfeed into your house

reviewText: I bought my little Weber Q grill from Home Depot.  I should have just bought it from Amazon!  However, Home Depot only had the little cover for the grill itself.  It didn't come down to cover the stand at all.  When I was buying other things for this grill on Amazon, I found this full cover.  It is much better than the small cover.  I received the Amazon cover in just a few days and I took the Home Depot cover back.  Now, I'm not putting Home Depot down.  It's my favorite store for many things.  I'm surprised they didn't carry the larger grill cover, but they didn't. Thank goodness for AMAZON!!

I've had this for a year now, and have used it about 30 times. It still runs great, and does a fantastic job on my very large lawn. I have about 2400 sq. feet of lawn, and it takes me about 30 minutes to mow it. The mower has 6 settings for blade height. I use the highest setting in the summer to conserve water, and the lowest setting before I dethatch and aerate in the fall. The best part about this mower is the vacuum effect when using the included bag. My neighbors' trees drop tons of leaves on my lawn. Rather than blow them off before mowing, I just run right over the leaves. The mower sucks them right up, chops them, and spits them into the bag. It really saves garbage space to have the leaves chopped up. The machine is really light, and the handle folds up. This allows me to fold it up and store it on the side of the garage, without taking up too much space. See the attached video showing vacuum effect.
summary: Clean cuts, light weight, and excellent vacuum effect

As of today, I've owned this blanket for 1 year and 6 months, give or take a couple of days.  It largely does what it is supposed to - reduces evaporation and heat loss (which is what keeps your pool warmer).  However, it won't last.  My cover is carefully reeled up during each swim session and placed in the shade.  About a year after owning it, I noticed some of the bubbles started popping and taking on water.  Then  a few months later, the cover started ripping every time we went to stretch it back over the pool.  I actually don't even reel it out lately unless I know we won't be swimming for a couple of days because it's so fragile.  I contacted Blue Wave about their five year warranty.  Sent them pictures and a copy of my Amazon receipt.  Ms. Kim Buchanan generously offered to replace my pool cover for $86.63 plus $36.87 shipping....which is $6 over the price that I originally paid for the cover!  Given that I have yet to see anyone given a reasonable offer for replacement, I was a fool for purchasing it anyway (I actually believed the hype of the favorable reviews, but I now realize almost all of these people are reviewing after ownership of a few days or use their pool a few months of the year).  Buy at your own risk - Blue Wave will only honor the warranty at a huge hassle and cost to you.

I really like this v box smoker box.  I use a Weber gas grill. I have tried an assortment of other methods of getting that smokey flavor using chips including tin cans.

Here is how to get maximum performance out of your wood chips and gas barbecue.  Soak your chips for about an hour.  Put the chips into the v box.  Put into the v box into the wedge on the barbque one off from the flame, so it is not directly on the flame.  Then add water up to the lip of the v box.  This allows you to get maximum time from your chips, provides the smoke and smokey flavor to be absorbed by the meat.  Now your cookin!

reviewText: Excellent

With a creek in our backyard, enjoying the yard in the summer requires some intervention. This "lantern," when lit up, matches my outdoor decor of blue Mason Jars filled with tealights and isn't noticeable as a insect repellent. Other fans I have seen in stores are brightly colored, unattractive, and have huge brand-names written across them. The Cons: - Lantern is a misnomer. This lantern barely lights up, more of a dull glow, but this may not be the worst thing in the world. Light attracts bugs, the same thing the lantern is attempting to ward off. It is strange, however, that the lantern has two settings. One with the light and fan and a second setting for the light without the fan. Given the minimal light, the second setting seems pointless. It would make more sense to have a fan with light option and a second option that has fan with no light. - Refills are, at this time, tough to find. Amazon sells them but they currently won't ship for 2-4 weeks and the cost is insane compared to buying the lantern to begin with. Refills, for those interested, can be found here: Stinger Mosquito Repellent Refills (2 Pack) The Pros: - DEET Free! No nasty chemicals here. - Comes with batteries (always a huge plus in our family) - A fairly quiet fan. Nothing that guests will have to scream over. - It works and looks cute doing it. Mosquitoes are the only insects that fly in this part of California at night (besides the benign moths). It does a great job of keeping me bite free which is the only task I really expect it to do.

These were ordered to replace 4 units I purchased last year that were stolen from my yard by a couple of drunken fools living nearby. The Nightguard seems to be keeping the deer out of my yard as last year my veggie garden, apple tree, and my wife's flower garden were untouched by the deer for a change. In the warm months I do also use a "Scarecrow" motion sensitive sprinkler as backup for the veggie garden coverage. Two years ago the deer ate green tomatoes, tomato and pepper plants, and string beans but last year nothing was touched

As suggested I have mounted 1 Nightguard on each side of a 3' high 2 by 2 for 360 degree coverage. I put a lag bolt with the head removed in the base so I can move them around the yard as advised by the manufacturer. Apparently the deer get used to them if left in the same spot. I have a game camera monitoring deer activity and have seen only two instances where they were close enough to be photographed but they were not in the yard. The game camera did also take a picture of the two theives as they snuck into my back yard but when the police got to where they had my nightguards they had fled the scene taking my nightguard stick with them.

I ordered this cutting board set as a sample for review and evaluation and I love it! I use multiple cutting boards all day every day and these are a wonderful addition to my collection. Surprisingly I use the small paddle one most often (I cut up fresh fruit and veggies for my little one for each meal). I love that they are nonnlip and have a groove for juices, that is a problem with other cutting boards I use the juice ends up on the counter and I have to clean the board and the counter. So having that feature is very helpful. The boards are all very sturdy and easy to clean. I love the size variety because I do so much food prep I often use all three at once, especially if I am doing freezer meal prep. Overall I love them and have had no problems with them. The come in a box that is suitable for gifting if you are looking to gift these.

Hello, I am the QUEEN OF CHRISTMAS!!!!
Let me explain... we used this type of fire ring while camping at several parks, and my husband just loved them. So, I snuck and bought him one for Christmas. I had it shipped to a neighbor, because I figured the packaging would give it away. It would have, too, so good move on my part.
Come Christmas Eve, he got it and I was Queen of Christmas! He absolutely loved it! It's super easy to put together if you have any DIY genes in you at all. But, if you don't, it does not come with instructions, so you have to call the company. But, seriously, it's SO easy, I can't imagine needing them.
We sunk it in the ground just a bit, and were using it within an hour. The grill section flips out of the way easily. The grate on it is a perfect size to do a few burgers or steaks. So, we broke it in with burgers, and we made baked potatoes down in the fire itself. Later on we made s'mores. Did I mention it was WAY below freezing when we did this? Who cares, it was totally worth it!
For the price I paid, I cannot believe how big it is, and how wonderfully it works.
This one is a keeper, and we are planning to make a little courtyard around it this spring.
summary: Not only is it a GREAT fire ring, it made me a Queen!!!

I live in upstate NY where winters are quite harsh. Lake effect snow storms are a pretty regular occurrence and ice storms happen more often than I would like. Our family likes to use products that are safe for animals and the environment so when we came across Nature Safe Ice Melt by Green Valley Earth Products we were eager to try it. Finally, bad weather made it's way to us and I had an opportunity to use this product. We had a small ice storm with travel advisories. There was a layer of ice on my front steps thick enough to be a hazard. I applied a generous amount of this product to the steps and waited for it to do it's job. It didn't work. The green pellets were fully intact on top of the ice. After the temperature increased significantly 2 days the ice began to melt. All the water laying against these pellets created a situation where people were tracking in green water on their shoes. I've had to mop several times to contain the problem. Once it did dry up enough outside I was able to sweep up the pellets and finally take care of the issue. A disappointing experience to be sure.

I was provided this product at no cost to me in exchange for an honest unbiased evaluation.

Sooooo.... this does work as advertised but nowhere in their listing does it warn you about the nightmares that you will have after using this product. Let me paint you a picture, you grab one of those cute little chickens that you raised as a peep and shove it into this metal cone to Slit its throat so the blood drains out of its body. In a couple of minutes you better dunk it in scalding water so you can rip the feathers off of it and then gut it. Does this do it supposed to? Absolutely am I ever going to raise chickens again no. I'm going to buy it at the grocery store like a civilized human being. I'm not a Savage so I don't feel the need to raise and then kill animals in my yard for fun.

2nd time I have purchased these....they always give you more than you order, but some usually die off.  I am pretty sure I have at least 10 growing good now.  I will take some pictures and post them later.

Needs an S hook.  I avoided this type of feeder in the store because it doesnt have a hook.  I have a metal shepherd hook attached to my deck railing but the hole on the feeder is too small, so now I have to guess what hook fits this feeder.  How hard could it be to add an S hook to the package?  I live nowhere near a hardware store.  Perky Pet has a 12 inch hook on Amazon but thats way too long in my opinion.  I need one thats 2 to 4 inches in length.

Okay onto the product.  The flowers are a soft rubber material rather than hard, which I like a lot.  I always felt bad for the hummingbirds sticking their beaks into those hard plastic flowers which have no resemblance in feel to a regular flower at all, so these are better in that aspect.  I like the little perches in front of each flower because then the hummingbird will rest there while he drinks and you get a better chance to see him without his wings fluttering.  They are such marvelous little creatures to see up close.
The top is screw-on and you fill it from the top, which is another plus.  I have one thats bottom fill and its sometimes tricky getting it back together without spilling.

The body is hard plastic.  I prefer glass, but this is rather nice for plastic.  You can take the entire reservoir apart and clean it and the feeder has an ant moat on top but I wonder what would stop the ants from climbing up from the bottom.  I have a lot of ants yet none have tried to get in my other one.
like the dry pellets and not having to fool with liquid  my plants love this stuff.

I have done quite a bit of research on trying to get rid of bats.  It is my understanding that a system like this will not work when bats are hibernating or when they have young; however, right now is the best time! Bats in South Dakota will migrate and their young are now ready, so - yes - I am confident that this is going to get rid of the bats in our attic.  We have sealed up four holes that we found and have allowed one place for them to escape.  I do not want to kill any bats, but I also do not want them in my attic or in my house!  I believe this is a safe way to get rid of unwanted bats (August through September or early October.)  Our neighbors are buying one of these, too!
summary: It is my understanding that a system like this will not work when bats are hibernating or ...

reviewText:
This tube feeder has the same problem almost all tube feeders I have found have.  The tube is made out of clear plastic that turns yellow and becomes brittle over time and then breaks.  The finish on the metal also deteriorates fairly quickly.  It looked great the first season, but only so, so the second season.  I was hoping to get a third season out of it even though it was looking in pretty rough shape, unfortunately plastic tube broke when I was trying to clean it for the new season.

I'm giving it three stars because the durability of this feeder is on par with other finch feeders I've purchased over time.  None hold up because they are so cheaply made.  If it weren't for the fact that this is the standard quality one has to expect from bird feeders like this, I would have given it two stars.

I'd happily pay twice as much for a feeder with a glass tube of the same quality as canning jars, and better quality metal/finish that wouldn't need to be replace for several years.
summary: Lasted for two seasons then plastic tube broke.

This is the first Corona product I have tried because I needed to replace my lost Fiskars lopper with extendable handles that had a flip down catch.  My model looks the same as the FL3470, but is the FL3479 3X Titanium Series with a brass colored blade.

I had the Fiskars gear driven long lopper in my cart, but ran across this Corona model at Lowe's and decided it was close enough to Amazon's price to get it locally.

The Corona still has a problem with the handle extention twist locks coming loose like the Fiskars locks did (minus 1 star), but the Corona is heavier and stronger.  I bent the handles on the Fiskars lopper and that was annoying, but they were light enough to offset other weaknesses.  However, the Corona seems to have much stronger handles even it they come loose occassionally, and it is heavier.

Not sure why mine is a Titantium Series unless the blade is titantium, but I decided that the trade off in increased weight is more than made up for in the heavier duty construction.
summary: Excellent Lopper Replacement for Similar Fiskars Model

reviewText: I purchased two of these at Home Depot. Each package contained two traps. One of the four traps was broken and will be returned. The remaining three were used briefly to catch small field mice around our rear patio. The traps are not strong enough to kill a mouse, so it's more of a "catch and release" device. If you happen to catch a large mouse, you'll likely never get it out of the trap. If you forget to check the trap, the mouse will eventually die a very, very slow death. This is definitely not a "humane" friendly trap and I'd highly discourage anyone from purchasing it. A much more effective product is the d-CON 00027 Ultra Set Covered Mouse Trap. These traps quickly kill the trapped mouse and are easy to empty.

The following review is my opinion.  I rarely give poor reviews, because I try to research items as best I can before purchasing.  BARELY usable.  I'm a retired mechanical-technical-type, so I'll try to be precise.  Here's the two problems; one, it's true that they barely swivel, and once you tighten up one end the swivel is too tight to operate.  You wind up spinning your hose into this adapter instead of turning the swivel.  Second, the threads are not deep enough on one end.  Actually, the one end just isn't long enough.  Once you put the included washer in, the male end of your hose barely threads in two turns, and it leaks unless you use tools.  So this is why I rate it barely usable.  You will need a large wrench or pliers to tighten the one end, and as you tighten one end of course the other end unscrews.  So you really need two tools, one on each end of this adapter, to tighten it properly.  And then you need the tools to remove it.  I understand the need for it to tight at the swivel so it doesn't leak, but really?  They couldn't have made the swivel a little looser?  I even tried the thinner, red-colored "soft" rubber washers but they made no difference.  I put just the one in the "shorter" end.  The softer washer seem to bind the swivel even worse.  I consider this adapter a semi-permanent adapter not a casual one.  If I needed to use it more than once every few weeks I would send it back in a minute.  Aside from all this, it's solid brass and otherwise well-made.  It's just that it doesn't function as I think most people would think it's intended.

I went through "30M" Sf nematodes from a competitor in 3 weeks trying to reduce my fungus gnat problem. During that time, my infestation GREW at an alarming rate. When I used up the original "10M" nematodes I decided they may be too deep in the soil or to plentiful and I ordered the last "20M" and used them every five days until they were used up. By this time the nematodes were starting to do the job I bought them for. When the 1st "10M" did nothing, I ordered a handheld optical 60-120X microscope to inspect the next ones when they arrived.

I was unimpressed with small amount of activity I was looking at through. Only about half of the nematodes I saw were moving. I decided to be more careful in selecting a different supplier, BugSales' Soldier Bugs brand. The 1st thing I did was examine some again (in a drop of water). I couldn't believe my eyes! There were so many nematodes in my that it took me a minute to realize that there were probably a hundred of them in that drop of water and they all were moving. There were so many, I wouldn't have even cared if half of them were dead!

BugSales and their Soldier Bugs line of beneficial predators is my go to supplier from now on!
summary: Quality kills a competitor's product I used just before it

reviewText:
We have two of these "defending" our vegetable garden.  This morning I look out the window and there is a big grey squirrel digging up a seedling six feet away and directly in front of one of the Defenders.  And the Defender is doing nothing.

I've been trying to get these Defenders to work for months now.  I did manage to improve their performance somewhat by adding a pressure regulator to the hose that supplies water to them.  It seems that the battery powered solenoid valve is not strong enough to reliably open against standard water pressure.

But the primary problem is that there is no Sensitivity setting that will detect a squirrel and NOT result in the Defender triggering constantly in response to plants swaying in a breeze.

So:  Useless for small pest control.

However, depending on your sense of humor, you may find them well worth the purchase price as you watch the Defenders soak your spouse, friends, gardener,......
summary: For Amusement Only, Useless for Detering Pests

I have a big problem with fungus which turns my tomato plants, my ferns, and some of my best flower plants brown and crispy.  Spraying Daconil stops it cold!  I don't like the triple-threat sprays from the hardware stores because I don't want to kill insects too.  When I coddled the plants with appropriate water and fertilizer, and removed the affected plant matter, the fungus just kept progressing.  It was frustrating and so disappointing!  But adding Daconil spray (after testing it on a small part of each type of plant) has been effective on tomatoes, ferns and perennials, period.  It did affect one annual badly, but I can't remember which one, and I don't care because they die each fall anyway.  But I hated losing my tomato vines by July when they should produce till frost, and watching ferns, peonies, and monkshood dwindle year by year.  The fungus blight spreads so fast that playing "catch-up" isn't always a sure thing.  But if I jump at the first sign of the fungus and spray all the susceptible plants immediately, then again in a week or two, then a third time, I can pretty much stop worrying.  Daconil has increased my gardening pleasure marvelously.  .

Wow, works exactly as described and quickly! Anyone that lives in the Northwest can attest to how tough blackberry bushes can be to eradicate! I have tried salting, digging them up, cutting them down as well as other weed killers all with no luck - in fact I think the blackberry bushes just laughed at my paltry attempts! I sprayed them as instructed and within a few days noticed they were looking less than healthy, after a week they were all dead! Now whos laughing!! ;) I did cover the bushes up so that no birds/bees etc would attempt to feed off the plants which I recommend doing at least until they are dead and no longer look appetizing to creatures.

Its been a few months now and they are still dead, with only a few small vines making an attempt at a comeback. I just need to get rid of the dead vines now - OUCH!  I will be spraying them again! This stuff works great!
summary: HIGHLY recommend - especially for those invasive TOUGH Northwest Blackberry bushes!!!

reviewText:
I just put this up this morning. I had seen another review where the millet (the tiny white seeds in bird seed) fell through the holes. I could see they could, so I "think" I solved the problem. I cut a piece of landscape fabric to size, and placed it in the bottom, on top of the screen. That way water can still pass through, but the seeds won't. When there are too many hulls, I'll just lift the fabric out, shake the hulls off, and then replace it. I haven't had any experience yet, but it SHOULD work. I'll update my review later.

Well, this feeder has been up through a couple of rains and snows. I'm happy to report that the landscape fabric really works, so if you're concerned about small seeds falling through, try the landscape fabric!
summary: Love my feeder, have great idea for making it better

Plus when you have a good view of it, it has nice brightness and color contrast to it.  No complaints here.  Also, make sure you have both AA and AAA batteries for the unit and remote.  You don't have to have these since it plugs into the wall, but you can take advantage of some of the other features, such as the outdoor remote sensor, if you have batteries.

Better than a drop spreader by far.
This thing evenly spreads fertilizer and is quick and easy to use.  I did 2000 square feet of lawn in under 10 minutes.

It is small for easy storage.  It is designed so that it can spread evenly on hills.

It is best to buy this on line.  For some reason, the ones in the stores like Home Depot or Lowes are always dirty and beat up.  They always looked used.

There are some downsides to this:

-Some fertilizer gets spread into the inside of the wheels.  A good fix would be to turn the wheels around so that the smooth side is facing in.

-The little rotor on the inside is a little elevated.  When there is just a little fertilizer left, it is no longer agitated.  So you have to tilt the spreader so that the fertilizer goes down the hole.
summary: Don't let the name fool you.  It can handle pretty big lawns.

reviewText:
Being disabled makes it really difficult for me to garden but these hoses make a huge difference.  I love them.  When they don't blow up.  I've had several of these hoses now and have learned all the tricks for making them last as long as possible, but this is the shortest lived hose yet.  I bought it in Feb and it blew up yesterday for no apparent reason.  It seems to be about 50/50 as to whether it's the hose or the fittings that give out, and this time it was the hose.  Needless to say that in Northern Cal I'm not needing to use it often this time of year which makes it doubly disappointing.  I did, however, get a lifetime guarantee with this hose.  I'll update my rating based on how that goes.

***********************************************
I emailed the seller the same time I posted my review and heard back just a few hours later.  They're sending a replacement.  We'll see how the new hose does, they usually do last longer than this.  On another note, I would happily buy from this seller again knowing that they'll make it right if something I buy from them is defective.
as described and quick delivery

I love my new bird feeder. It's not only practical and easy to use, it's also stylish and graceful looking. You can see from the Amazon photo that it's design is quite elegant and it's made of sturdy, long-lasting brass. Being brass it will probably tarnish with weather, but that often gives it the antiquated look that is so popular with many people.

Only time will tell if it's a "keeper" for me--a lot depends on its stability on windy days--but for now the birdies like it and that's good enough for me. I enjoy sitting on my patio watching them fluttering around, taking turns feeding. The robins seem to be pretty smart; they never go to the feeder, but are content with what the smaller birds scatter on the ground. And who says birds are dumb with their teensy-weensy brains? Hmmm...

Highly recommended to all nature lovers.

Reviewed by Betty Dravis, June 25, 2011
Author of E-Book "1106 Grand Boulevard" and others
summary: Most attractive sip-and-seed feeder I've seen

I was finally able to get my hands really dirty with these gloves this morning. We had plenty of weeds to pick today, so these garden gloves got a good workout. I am actually not used to wearing garden gloves (because I never had any good ones) - I usually would use non-latex disposable gloves. I have tried to use garden gloves before but they were much too large to fit my very small hands, so it didn't work out.

First of all, if you have small hands, these will work! It helps that the part of the glove that goes over your wrist is a little long and tight but flexible around your wrist, because it keeps them in place really well. After hours of use, these gloves do not seem to be worn out at all. I have not had to wash them yet, and I will probably put them to the test and see how long I can go until they really seem like they need to be washed. I think that will also prolong their life.

I am very pleased with these garden gloves. It was very simple for me to pick weeds with these. They have a good rubber grip on the palm side and a lightweight, comfortable material on the rest of the glove. These gloves are hypoallergenic, which is great because my skin is very sensitive. That was one of the things that drew me to purchase them.

Also, this package comes with 4 sets of gloves!! What a deal. I can't complain about that.

Really happy with these gloves. Worth the money and would recommend and purchase again.

Update 9/1/16: I washed these gloves for the first time in a delicates/garment bag in the wash. Bad idea. One of the fingers came off like it was sliced off. To give these gloves credit, I should add that the garment bag was not the best one I have and has been known to come open in the wash. Moral of the story: hand wash only. I should have known this, but I guess I was just being lazy.
summary: Perfect garden gloves for small hands and/or sensitive skin!

I've have changed my opinion of this product after several years use in Southern California.  First, it looked as good erected on my as represented in the pictures shown on Amazon's site. If you live in Heaven, where there is no rain, no wind, and no beating sun, then the Regency Gazebo is for you.  Otherwise, keep shopping.  Save money and pay the price for a well made product. I feel the Regency II Gazebo is cheap, really cheap.  Let me count the ways. The fabric cover rotted out after only a couple of seasons. (Note this gazebo is my third or fourth over years of use.) The attachment points for the cover are pointed, if you can believe it, just aching to poke through their attachment pockets.  And these pockets are flimsy, unreinforced and lightly stitched. Flimsy!  The netting between the vent and the roof rotted off, again after only a couple of seasons' use.  The fabric cover quickly became bridle and faded. The steel frame is attractive but just as fragile as it looks. After only a short time, I had trouble keeping the gazebo square. Most of the time it looked like a drawing in a cartoon. And it is light. A few weeks ago a late santana (a seasonal high wind in the Los Angeles area) balled  the Regency up into a neighbor's tree. Yes, these winds are fierce, but keep in mind I have used one gazebo or another over the past fifteen or twenty years, and all of the Regency's predecessors, with some care, stood up under similar conditions. And, as other reviewers point out, it rusts - even in Southern California weather where rain is an event for celebration.  Yes it is powder coated, but that does not help at the weld points or, especially, where one part of the structure is inserted into another part. When I tried to dismantle the Regency after pulling it down from my neighbor's tree, I had trouble separating the various components due to rust.  I decided to buy the Regency II despite serious reservations after reading the reviews. My nervousness was not assuaged when I unpacked and erected it.  And my worst fears were confirmed when I looked out my kitchen window and saw it perched in my neighbor's tree.  The Regency irked me almost from day one.  Even before its mating with a tree, I had decided I would not waste my money on another flimsy replacement cover. My advice to you: If you want to use your gazebo for just one season, then the Regency II is for you.  Otherwise, pay the price for a good product.
summary: The Regency II is as flimsy as it looks

reviewText: Boy, do I like these! I have a Weber, and the family really digs a smoked bird. I've used bricks, wrapped in foil, in the past, to split out the coals and cook meats and poultry indirectly, and that worked sort of OK, but these- THESE really do the job! The airflow is 100% better, and the heat is more even. How can that be, you ask? Well, if you're using bricks, they take a lot longer to heat up than you'd think, and they choke off some of the airflow to your briquettes- with rails, this doesn't happen, so the grill heats evenly, quickly, and it's much easier to control the speed of the burn. Having done turkeys, chickens (both whole, and spatchcocked), large roasts, and potatoes, I can tell you without any reservations that the rails are far superior to the brick method- plus, you have more room for a better drip pan in the bottom, and that makes for some fiiiiiine gravy! I bought these in the off-season (although, if you're a grilling fanatic, there IS NO off-season for BBQ!), so I got a great price- but I would pay more, knowing now how well they work. These are a must-have, if you're even semi-serious about your BBQ, and indirect-grilling or hot-smoking meats. :)
summary: Just what I was looking for!

I have tried all manner of traps--gas, poison, flooding and nothing works.  I starting using the Black Box about three years ago and this device consistently works.  This is the procedure:
- probe the dirt mound with a long screw driver or similar
- when the tunnel is located remove the dirt to expose.  Create a space large enough to house the box.  The box doesn't have
to lie horizontally--it can be at an angle
- wash the Black Box with Dawn to remove any human scent.  Handle it with vinyl or latex gloves.
- arm the Box and insert into the hole.  Cover any exposed gaps between the box and the hole with loose dirt.
- flag the Box location so that you will remember where it is--believe me it's easy to miss after a few days
- check the Box periodically.  If it hasn't sprung take it out to see if the gopher didn't back fill with dirt(yes they are clever).  If
so remove dirt and reinsert trap.  Guaranteed to get the gopher the next day
- if there is no activity after three or four days the tunnel is abandoned--relocate trap
- after use wash Box with Dawn and handle with gloves
Happy hunting!

reviewText: I purchased this to fight the massive flea infestation that has taken over my house over the past month. When I first awoke in the morning I treated my cats, temporarily kicked them out of the house (to the porch) and thoroughly sprayed my living room, furniture, dining room and hallway.  At first it appeared to stop the fleas.  Me nor my children were getting attacked; however when we got home that evening not 30 seconds of walking in the door all of us were attacked by a lot of fleas.  I did this for a week straight and our flea problem doesn't seem to have been touched.  Same thing with my bathroom, I sprayed one night before bed, soaked the floor and under the cabinets, and through my bath mat in the dryer for an hour.  Next morning I went into the bathroom and got attacked by 15-20 fleas.  This $23 can of flea spray didn't even dent my problem, time to try something else.
summary: Doesn't help with fleas at all.

I purchased the Terro Permiter Bait, Terro Liquid Ant Killer, and Terro Outdoor Liquid Ant Bait Stations in an effort to launch a full assault on the sugar ants present at my house. I applied (and reapplied) as directed for a month long period. The visible ant population increased (as expected) dramatically and then failed to decrease (as the product claims it should). It just didn't work.

I ended up purchasing a 10 lb bag of Diatomaceous Earth and it worked wonderfully. I still occasionally see an ant or two, but by and large the problem has been solved. I wish I'd have went with the Diatomaceous Earth from the start and saved my time and money trying the Terro system.

We have used both the Spa Frog Spa Frog Mineral Sanitizer Filter Frog and the comparable Nature2 Spa Stick Zodiac W20750 Nature2 SPA Stick Mineral Sanitizer . We typically go with the Spa Frog or whichever one has the best sale price. They both claim to last ~ 4 months. Both products appear to work equally well and allow reduced Chlorine or Bromine usage to maintain sanitary hot tub/ spa conditions. We prefer the top inlet/flow feature of the Spa Frog, because that is the way the water flows into the floating weir in the skimmer basket (at the filter intake).
summary: Spa Frog is comparable to Nature2 Spa Stick, but Spa Frog top has prefered a flow-through design

reviewText:
Bought this for my second home / vacation rental in Hawaii.  My previous hammock had turned black with mold after a few months and nobody told me.  Ick!  (Yeah, what are property managers for anyway?)  So I got this one and it has been left outside in the rain and humidity for almost 2 years, and never looked dirty.  So that was great.

In June it was fine, but now in September we just showed back up and the wood slat is rotted away and broken in two.  We don't know what some renter may have done to it, but still it is clear the wood is rotted so it probably wasn't their fault.

I am still getting another one of these, because I don't know another better choice.  But since this is anti-mildewing rope, maybe the wood should be treated better, or metal used.
summary: Love it, doesn't mold.  Wood broke after 1.5 years, need to buy another

reviewText: This stuff is the bomb..!! I've got to point in age and health that it is a real effort to use a pump up sprayer. I just have a garden home size yard and thought this was worth the test.  It has a very heavy duty plastic tank - the problem is you can't see the level of water you've added.  It is a bugger to get that top off the tank for cleaning - super duper tight.  It's powered off 4 D size batteries - use alkaline as they are 1.5 volt - if you try rechargeable they are only 1.2 volt - 4 batteries you'd lose 1.2 volts before you got started. The unit will spray down for weeds and across for shrubs reasonably fair, but not up like you could with a pump sprayer.  The spray on/off is by a switch on the unit rather than handle so it is difficult to spot spray weeds with. The wand, nozzle and everything abt the unit is plastic. The unit is abt 4 lbs w/batteries and water is a tad over 8 lbs, so you tote abt 12 lbs.  I think this unit will probably do the weed killing spray job for the summer.  Regardless, I see the theory will work so I'll spend the buck for a better unit when the time comes.
summary: Testing a battery weed killer sprayer

Just purchased my 4th one of these. So I read the reviews before purchasing, and some of them are accurate. It is not the strongest structure - but I expected that after reading reviews, so I knew to reinforce it before I hung it up. I actually put these things through some rigorous jobs - I hung them on a bamboo wall with nails and have honeysuckle I am training to grow on there. Before I reinforced it - 2 or 3 of the pieces came looose.. so it isn't super well constructed - I think it would have done fine if I had, had it on the ground, but I am hanging them. They are worth reinforcing. They are pretty and unique and I have a Japanese garden with a pond and tons of bamboo and I am picky, but they look great. To reinforce - I used zip Ties in several places and double zipped so they basically cant fall apart in core areas. Then when I mounted them - I used U screws (for coax cable management). So it secured the Willow against the wall - again in strategic locations. This may sound like a lot, but it was really no big deal. Took like 15 mins each trellis? Worth it for the Willow look. Its unique and the item is priced right. Zip ties and cable management U screws were an additional $7 maybe. I do have 1 issue - I ordered 1, loved it so ordered 2 more.. then I had space on the wall for 1 more so I got a 4th and it came In a different color and thickness. Still beautiful - but wasn't uniform. Totally okay because its a trelllis and should be covered by plants - but when I went to order the next one I wasn't 100% sure what I would get. However - if I hadnt ordered the others, I would never have known the difference and would have been happy.
summary: Beautiful- needs to be reinforced if hanging, but worth it

I bought this for my husband who is a weather enthusiast but also we needed to monitor our pool temperature; Just a head's up, the title" Ambient Weather" is the company name, and is not a "feature". I of course took it to mean that it also included outdoor ambient temperatures, which it does NOT. You have to buy another (third) sensor piece for $20 (twenty dollars) to have the ambient outdoor weather work with the system. With the $40 (forty dollars) system, you only get pool temp and interior temperature where your second sensor is located. We plan to get the additional sensor, but just thought the product name was a little misleading if you didn't take time to really read the features (I just skimmed..).  We double checked the accuracy, and what it is reporting, is what the actual temperature is (we used another thermometer to check). Thanks!

Update: Dropping to 2 stars. The temperature  sensor that goes into the pool, has already fogged over and we can no longer read the temperature of the pool. Plus, there is no way to secure it, and it constantly get sucked into the pool filter box. We had to wrap a string around a rock and tie to thermometer to try to keep it in place. Doesn't look great, and clanks against the pool all day. Kind of annoying. I would not purchase this again. Maybe ours was defective.
summary: UProduct name misleading: "'Ambient Weather' WS-14 Wireless.." is a company name, and not a "feature". No outdoor weather temps.

"Wow", is all I can say. We received the first two and were pleasantly surprised at the quality. Amazon Prime had a special price on these and we bought at the right time (around $33/ea.). The other two arrived several days later (temporarily out of stock). The material is definitely made for either use, but I lean toward these being mostly for outdoor use.  The texture is definitely like other outdoor cushions that will resist water, but will not be completely waterproof.

Used in an aluminum dining outdoor set, they replaced seat cushions that were 19" x 20". With the backs, these things over-stuff the chairs, so actually a little give will be welcome. They extend out past the seat frame, but line up perfectly with the backs of the chairs and the ties are in the right spot. Still, I wanted something over-sized so that as time wore on, the cushions would still feel rich, classy and not disappear in the chair frame. These definitely do the trick. Also, we didn't have any problems with the tag removal at the top of the back section. After clipping in between seams, leaving only a very thin piece of the label, we mushed the cushion into itself and the back cushion basically absorbed the rest of the label, never to be seen again.

I would recommend these, and at the price we paid, they are well worth it. Stitching is absolutely great, sturdy construction, and the cushions are filled firmly to last for some time. Now, if we could just get our cats off of them so we could enjoy them too, all will be right in the world. *By the way, cat hair is so much easier to remove from this material*
summary: Classy design, sturdy construction, deisgned to last and looks like we paid a fortune!

reviewText:
Easy Gardener burlap stops the deer from eating our ornamentals every winter. As long as they can't see the bushes, they don't nibble on them. This particular burlap is very open mesh, and works well with shrubbery. It allows air and water to get through, and also allows sun penetration. We don't wrap the plants, but instead make a fence around foundation shrubbery. As a bonus, the winter birds enjoy the added seclusion this burlap makes.  After one season, the burlap is usually a little frayed but the ornamentals all look great. We save the burlap for future uses like seed germination or frost cover.

I used to be able to find Easy Gardener burlap at big box stores at cheap prices, but now Amazon's are often lower. Burlap seems expensive, but having to replace just one ornamental would be more costly than the 4-5 burlap rolls we use for winter protection.
summary: Keeps The Deer Away From Shrubbery

reviewText:
I agree with the average rating of 3.5 stars. The unit is heavy duty and well constructed, a bit heavy, but you can roll it where needed. One issue I had, sometimes, when I placed the wheel to start trimming it was turned in the wrong position and hard to get moving. Once moving it rolled decently. Trimming a larger area where you need to go back and forth, you need to hold your trimmer handle to guide it. This is fine, but for me with a bad back it causes some discomfort. The seller shows using the unit with a handlebar (not included) which I think would help in guiding the trimmer and reduce bending over which can cause back pain.

The big wheel on this unit is a good idea which aids in moving over lawn imperfections. Having two wheels as some have suggested, would would reduce maneuverability of the unit. The spring loaded shaft worked well for bumping my trimmer and advancing the line. Also, the angle adjustment nut which is also spring loaded is convenient.

We had a LOT of paper wasp nests all over the eaves of our house and were trying to figure out what to do. As we were painting the house, we had to get all the nests down. Once the painting was done, we put up Waspinator's - one on the front and back of the house and the same on our garage. I even put one up in the chicken coop area as some wasps were trying to build a nest there. It is now six weeks later and we do not have even one nest and I only rarely see a wasp at all, so this has been very successful for us.

A few notes: You do need to get all the current nests down for this to work. It stops them from rebuilding. Also, it really is an empty bag, we filled each Waspinator with plastic grocery bags and then put a rock in each one as well so they wouldn't blow around too much. A much nice alternative to spraying them and it really did work. Recommended!

reviewText: I think more than I should about "where my soil has been". Consequently, I always wonder when I buy "organic" animal compost if the original animals were fed antibiotics. It is pretty easy for me to assume that a company who produces organic compost would not use GMO methods, it is still pretty common for animal producers to use antibiotics like ivermectin. I am grateful for antibiotics, their usefulness in treating illnesses is unmeasurable in my opinion. However, to me, adding them (or their byproduct) to our diet when they are not indicated for sickness seems inappropriate. Hence, I was tickled pink to find Charlie's Compost. They actually thought about whether or not their customers cared to know. I added it to my raised bed soil and while I cannot claim huge production increases, I can say I am very happy with the fertilizers that will go into my family's tummies!
summary: Actually tells you what is NOT in it...no antibiotics

reviewText: No Comment

Just received the light last week. I was a little disappointed to see features not included that others do such as the ability to daisy chain. Not something ive ever had to make sure was an option before. Very disheartening.

The light states the lumens on height, but I would argue that the led (or at least mine) must be a bit closer to achieve similar results.

For a 600w light, I would expect a larger area of coverage.

Now then, the light itself is pretty good. Wide spectrum, low draw. After adjustments from the above qualms, plants are drinking it in. I have them about 30 inches above my plants without bleaching or any adverse effects. No idea if this is a good or bad thing since my 300 w will bleach the hell out of anything that close. Maybe the lenses are different.

I will most likely switch this to clones and find something with more bang like a cob with a daisy chain. Still can't believe there are lights made without a daisy chain option. These are lights for growing, not lighting up a room like a light bulb.

Update: my opinion on this light hasn't changed much, but I do like the reliability of the leds. Ive not had any go out on me yet and its been in use 18 hours a day so far. For the price of the unit, if daisy chaining the lights together isn't on your agenda, I would whole recommend this light. It has enough light for 4 or so smaller plants. If you plant on growing something large, you'll need supplemental lighting for the under canopy.

EDIT: A year later and the light is still going. Good quality!
summary: it will make your plants grow with adjustment

reviewText: I've been using the 'Stainless Steel Double Sieve' For a good many years to strain, mostly, pieces of wax from my honey prior to bottling. I do, however, then pour the honey through a nylon strainer for an absolutely clear product.

The only flaw can be easily fixed, as another reviewer noted, by drilling out the eight feeding holes at about a 45 degree angle with a 1/8 inch drill, so that the birds don't have to bend their necks in order to get their beaks vertical and feed. This type of gauge will never read properly, for what we want (a reliable indicator of when to change tanks).  Propane is a refrigerant (a refer that explodes), and like all refrigerants its pressure is dependent on its temperature through almost all conditions (technical:  as long as there is a bit of liquid refrigerant in the tank, the refrigerant occupies the flat area on the P/T curve).  As a result, you'll always "read green" on the gauge until it almost exhausts the tank (= vaporize the last of the liquid).  If you watch the gauge while cooking (a real trick), you'll see the needle drop in the last 5--10 minutes, but of course at this point you have food in mid-cook.  Watching the size of the flame jets is just as effective in getting a lead time (no jet = no gas!!).  I tried this gauge twice (I'm such a glutton for punishment), and both times when I changed tanks (after a "surprise outage" in the middle of a cook) the gauge then refused to pass gas; I surmise the tank change operation introduced a spec of dust (twice) that blocked an internal port.  When you're cooking (and the shrimps on the barbie are making fun of you), you're not going to sit down and clean out the ports (if they can be cleaned; at $13 I'm not investing anymore time).  Fortunately, these gauges are as easy to take out as they are to install, so the shrimps lost the game after all.  However:  "never again".  On the bright side:  we have Recycling here, so some lucky sorting facility gets some brass!!  I love happy endings.
Good

Pros - This thing really rips.  It was cutting through 6 inch branches like butter.  The saw seems well made and am very happy with it overall.

Cons - The bolt that holds the cover and chain tensioner down stripped out the first time I tried to tighten it down. It was an easy fix to re-tap the hole and put a new bolt in but I assume most people don't have these tools to do so.

The saw can get heavy when you have it extended to its max.  I am a fairly rugged guy and after an hour of using it, my arms were tired.  This is expected as the majority of the saws weight is at the cutting end.

Overall I am very happy with this purchase, especially for the price.  I hope it lasts for many years.

reviewText: came to late for 2017  , will be used in 2018

This would be really useful for any job where people are working out in the field. In my case working on a film set, on location. It always happens that we will be out in the middle of nowhere, and everyone has devices they must use that eventually run out of energy. Having this handy, with the ability to charge it with a solar panel is exceptionally valuable in those situations. Using this, I can keep my laptop charged and in use for over 24 hours when needed, and a cell phone even longer!

Devices seem to charge as fast from the battery as they do from the wall. I love that there is the LCD screen that shows how much energy is remaining in the battery. The entire kit is very user friendly.

Also great for long car trips. You can charge it in the car, and then recharge devices as they die along the way. Particularly useful when you have a bunch of kids in the car that will lose their marbles if their tablet stops working.

Most importantly though, this is an invaluable item to keep in a home safety kit. When the power goes out or there is an emergency, this battery is portable, reliable and charges in many different ways. This can turn a bad situation around. We lose power after storms and sometimes it can be out for as much as a week. Having the ability to plug in a lamp or a toaster, that makes life livable in an outage.

Some things to note- The Sherpa does not come with any sort of a storage pouch. It is very vulnerable to damage from liquid spills, so if you intend to port it around, I would invest in a waterproof container of some sort. The solar panel does have a mesh pouch which holds all the cord that come with this kit, but again, it isn't waterproof.

There is a metal wire on the top of the battery pack that you can use to attach a lock to keep people from walking off with your power source. This is a great feature for using away from home.

On the back there is a door you can unscrew to gain access to the fuse. There is an indicator on the small lcd screen when the fuse fails and it is easy to replace.

There is not a laptop charging adaptor made by goal zero for apple computers, but I was able to plug my apple charging cord directly into the ac outlet on the inverter and charge the laptop that way.

There is a 6 month warranty with the product.
summary: Exceptionally useful in many situations. Worth the money.
