I am a real purist normally about metal fittings. Problem is, they have gotten so junky as of late, that the metal ones leak horribly too. Having worked with a lot of indoor PEX plumbing lately, I've dealt with some indoor plumbing fittings called 'Sharkbites', that are expensive, but wonderful about no-leaks, and durable. I thought, 'man, that would be great to find something like those for hosepipe'. Well, they aren't metal, but these Nelson fittings are 'sharkbites' for hosepipe. They have fingers inside that bite and grip the hose, and the clamp down is solid and secure. I have three of them in operation, one is often under pressures approaching 70-psi, and it has held up for a year with no problems and constant pressure. I am a believer! Not a single drop of water leaked since I started using them. I can't say enough good about them. Once you cut and square your old hose pipe end with a knife or cutoff tool, you don't need tools to put these on, they just press-on, and hand tighten down, right there. No clamping, no wrenches, no screwdrivers, you just tighten them and you are like new again. You can get Male, Female and hose-to-hose joints. I picked up a bunch more, once I saw how good they worked. Can't afford not to have a few in your toolbox at all times!
summary: Greatest Hose Ends you'll ever buy. PERIOD!

"Cavy" (Guinea Pigs) website posters recommended Ivermectin for treating mites. Ivermectin mix for Guinea Pig is only available from vets. The posters recommended mixing the stronger (horse) Ivermectin with water then spread it over the infected area, a topical solution. It worked well for the areas where the animal had lost furs. It's more difficut to rub it into the infected area where there are furs. It's also difficult to get to mites that had burrowed deep under the skin. There's danger of poisoning where the pig lick the Ivermectin to clean itself. The solution works on "cavy" but it's better to take your cavy to a vet who knows how to treat them.
summary: Not just for Horse, it's for Cavy too

reviewText:
This is a very similar concept to a rain jacket in a pouch--it's a BBQ cover in a pouch, literally, when you open the package (see pic of pouch w handle), and is a mid to lighter weight plastic material, like a good shower curtain. The fabric is not exceptionally sturdy, but will probably last two or three seasons in the sun (granted, i live in a mild, coastal climate). This is a sewn plastic cover that fits your two extended side-arm-shaped grill. The bottom skirt has two sets of ties (you need to manually tie the two ends together) to go around two of your grill legs, and one pull cord that slightly tightens the circumference of the bottom of the skirt (see pics). I say slightly tightens, because the pull cord only comes out one side, and so it is not easy to tighten the skirt all the way around- you have to pull really hard. There is also a triangle vent on each side (see pic of my fingers showing through some of the holes on the inside) covered by outer plastic on two of the three triangle edges, so no water can get in.

Btw, the pouch the cover comes in, is actually sewn to the inner top of the cover, so it will be laying on top of your grill on the inside.  it's a bit weird, and causes a slight bump on the grill (but u can move it to the back, kinda). I guess this feature would be great if you plan to use the pouch to store your cover again, since this way you can't lose it, but this feature has limited use for me, since i don't tend to pack up my grill cover- i just set it on the side until the BBQ cools, and i put it back on the grill. i can't see folding it up and taking it with me anywhere w that handle, etc...

It's sewn well, overall, considering it's a single stitch construction without a waterproofing underseam like some tents have. so i can't speak to the waterproofing of the seams at this point, and it does not look like it would leak much, if at all under normal rainy conditions, but it might not be absolutely water tight at the seams if there was a deluge. Overall, the price is a tad high for this item, and i prefer the thicker fabric-type covers that are about about $5 more expensive.  One i've used for the past three years and is still holding up great and feels much more substantial, is the Classic Accessories 73902 Veranda Small Grill Cover For Weber Q-300 & Q-320 Grills--http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007XAKFRI?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_search_detailpage.

Still, this  green grill slicker is pleasant looking, and about 1/2 the weight of fabric covers, so that does have it's uses.  Overall, not a bad product.
summary: Like a Slicker for your BBQ

Originally bought one of these units a few months ago to target bats in my storage shed that I store many items useful for my rental houses. It is a metal shed [about 2000 Sq Ft] with only 1 small window. Perfect place for bats to shack up. I have a motion sensor alarm that alerts my house if ANY intruder moves & after no false alarms for 5 years suddenly it became obvious that bats had moved in. MANY people have bats without knowing it. Bats are almost helpless if anything interupts their sonar sound system & this unit stopped my false alarms almost instantly. After I saw how nice it worked I moved it under my house that I live in. Most houses in Kentucky have no basement but a crawl space to sevice plumbing,wiring ect. My crawl space is about 3-4 feet tall with plastic on the ground neat & clean. Suddenly had some rodent move in [maybe a squirrel] that started tearing up some insulation. After no success in trapping it I went to my shed & got my ET pest unit & the varmint moved out as suddenly as it had come in. This unit is so versital in repelling so MANY different kind of pests & uses NO harmful chemicals or poisons. I am ordering more of these units to put under my other rental houses because it is trouble free,not noticable,works 24-7 & I calculate electric cost at about 25 cents per month. To control almost all pests just set the pitch to "Variable" & it will drive em all out with it`s inconspicuous squalling sounds. It has a test button you can push to hear the sound at YOUR ear level & that will convince you that it will drive the pests crazy when they hear it at THEIR ear level. Nice product,easy & clean to use & a whole lot cheaper than an exterminator. Trapping gets only the dumb ones. This things cleans house.

Today I used this hoe to clear some very hard ground of well-established weeds.  I thought I'd be working at it for hours, but the weeds came away so easily I could hardly believe it.  I've had this silly looking hoe for over 30 years and it's still the one I reach for. The actual act of using it seems to sharpen it so I've never had to and it's received no special care in all that time.

It is not ideal for every job, but if you're trying to clear away weeds on hard packed ground or cut weeds away beneath the surface of garden soil, you just can't beat it.  When I'm trying for a more 'tilled' effect, I use a hoe with tines, but today I wanted to expose ground covered with weeds so I could hack into it with a pickaxe in order to plant a shrub.  Having the right tool for the job really makes a difference.  It was hot today and being able to finish the whole job in 15 minutes couldn't have been better.

Should this hoe ever break, which it shows no sign of doing, I'm glad I can replace it through Amazon. I also have the hand-held mini-version for weeding my raised vegetable garden and will be using it tomorrow. Very highly recommended.

I have wanted to buy this for some time, had it on my wishlist hoping it would come as a gift one day.  Finally I decided I was tired of waiting.  Now I am a bit disappointed.  The initial disappointment was due to the size, which was smaller than expected, though that does have its advantages as well.

Now the frustration is poor performance.  First it takes a bit of effort, the seeds need to be watered three times a day for best results.  This might not be a thing if I didn't have a job, but I do, so I am limited to twice a day effectively, and if life gets busy less.  That may be related to the next problem which is rot.  The sprouts I have been trying to grow seem to be rotting before they reach maturity. I have had some good batches, but my wife is getting upset at the smell from the not so good batches.

Finally I have had an issue with the drainage from tray to tray being plugged by the roots of some of the sprouts which leads back to the more maintenance problem.

That all said, the only reason I have not given it 1 star is that I have been using a different blend of seeds that may be to blame.  I have now ordered some straight alfalfa seeds to see if that resolves some of the issues.  The Radish, Broccoli and Alfalfa mix was tasty but the problems I am having are prohibitive.
summary: Now I am a bit disappointed. The initial disappointment was due to the size

reviewText:
Looking for a perfect Christmas gift for a spouse who has a green-ish thumb - and we like to cook with fresh herbs.

This is as simple as it gets!  There is no "dirt".  This is a full habitat for tiny seedlings - that will allow them to grow into nice edible (or just pretty) plants.

The kit comes in a big box - but don't be intimidated.  The whole thing snaps together in no time (wife had it assembled in 5 minutes - before we had picked up the wrapping paper...)  There's basically a "base", a beam, a lightbulb, and the dome.  Snap them together and you're ready to go.

You need to provide clean water (we used rainwater!).  Then they have prepared seed pods that you place into the holes in the base - and each seed pod gets a little plastic see-through cover snapped on top to keep things humid/moist until the seeds sprout.  Press the button and you hear an aeration pump turn on - and the sunlight bulb.  (There's a special timer built in that will cycle the bulb off at the appropriate time.)

Easy (pictures!) directions.  And a supporting website.  And - just Google the product and Tips/Tricks - you'll see some great ideas and reviews.

Update - it's just a few days after Christmas, and I see our little seedlings starting to peek out of the seed packs.  Very cool indeed!

My spouse was happy.  I am happy.  And the new little seedlings appear to be happy and growing.

JDMc
summary: Christmas gift - and we have sprouted seedlings by New Years!  Happy spouse, happy plants!  Easy to set up.

reviewText:
UPDATE Jan 21, 2017
The all new software is not as good as the old.  The worst part of it is that you can only go back 31 days to review data.  Before they "new improved" software was release, I could go all the way back to when I first setup the weather station.  Now if I want to review what the temps were three months ago, I have to go to weather.com or some other place that keeps records.

Jan 2016. I got my weather station for Christmas, and set it up that day.  I have always wanted to be able to look at what the temp was earlier in the day or over night, now I can.  I can look at charts of the different weather trackers.  One of the really cool features is the temp sensor has a solar powered fan to bring in outside air so you get a more accurate reading.  I have a regular sensor that feed a different temp display when the sun is on the east side of the house it is sunlight, and always showed a much higher temp then the one on the AcuRite (at night they show the same temp).

After about a month of use the solar fan stopped working.  I called tech support, they asked a few questions, and then sent out a replacement solar panel/fan unit.  Quick and easy.  Thank you.

UPDATE June 2016. It is now mid June, six months after first installing my weather station.  Once again the solar powered fan has gone out.  What this means that with the sun shinning on the unit it shows temperature of 100 degrees.  Other temp sensors I have that are in shade show a temp of 91.  Minor problem, but still have to get a replacement and install it.  Again

SEPTEMBER 20, 2016. Acurite has changed it's app for the WORST.  I have not been able to upload my past data.  Called their usually excellent tech support, and I was "called number 30" in the que.  After 20 minutes, I was caller number 29.  The help for this major change is terrible.  The online help is usuless.  Because of this terrible new app, I am changing my relating to one start, since it is not easy to access the data.  And I have a color tablet and the app is black and white, how 70s is that.
summary: Poor Software, Data Only Kept For 31 Days

I just picked up this little gem. I must say it cooks really nice! I a novice at this grilling/cooking stuff but I really enjoyed grilling steaks on this tonight. The charcoal Chimney I got made starting coals really easy. I'm normally the one wadding up news paper (about 20 sheets) to start my coals. But the chimney was impressive. But that's another review.
I originally purchased the smokey joe portable grill. But after reading the reviews, and rethinking the point that other reviews made about this grill. I returned the Smokey Joe and purchased this go-anywhere grill.

I like the fact that this grill is rectangular shaped rather than the round. I just feel that the coals are spread out better with this design. The heat is even from corner to corner.
The fact that the food sits closer to the coals is a big plus! With a nice bed of hot coals I cooked a 1.5" steak 4 minutes with the cover on and the vents fully open, then 1 minute with the cover off to seer the steak and give it a nice char. (did this on both sides) The steak was a perfect medium rare!
I also like that when done, if you close all the vents the grill cools down really fast.

I would highly recommend this grill to anyone who needs a good portable grill.

Oh? Some of the other reviews talk about the side vents being stainless steel?? They look like they could pass for stainless, but they are actually aluminum. Just FYI.

Update:
I've had this grill for over a year. The grills inside are fairly rusted but that's to be expected since the grill is left outside 24/7. But this is still my favorite grill to cook on!  Weber just got this design right! Food comes out perfect every time! It's portable size and great grill area is a must have for any tailgater! I'm definitely purchasing another one when this one falls apart! I just hope weber does try and change this design!

Putting this together was an abomination. When you get it, set aside a nice large area to set up the parts in, at least a one car garage. Those whose names should never be uttered that compiled the instruction manual are no doubt cackling in glee as each tortured soul makes the assembly attempt. I'm a pretty mechanical guy and even I had to break out a vintage primer on curse words so I could add a few to my vocabulary during assembly. I don't remember the exact part/bolt/screw but I remember it being around the wheel installation. Before you put them on, look long and hard at it, there is a part/bolt/screw that has to go on first, before the wheels that the manual instructs you to put on after. Unless you have the hands of a two year old with the strength of a bodybuilder and a wrench 2mm thick this will not be possible, forcing you to remove then reinstall the wheels..(which you just used 14 of your new swear words installing the first time).  A small 12v drill/driver with a nut driver set helps tremendously during assembly (have a nut driver set, you didn't think any of the fasteners would be the same size did you?) as you'll be holding two parts with one hand while trying to tighten with another.

It works, it'll save you countless hours of raking, it's held up nicely after many hours behind the tractor... but you'll be talking about putting this together for years.
summary: Works just fine, has held up well... assembly instructions written by demons with no soul.

This is a really perfect gas can for my 2 stroke lawn equipment. Flow control with the dispensing handle is clean and precise, and the parts of this can look to be made to last forever.

The flex spout fits into the tank opening of even my smallest chain saw, and is long and flexible. At the rate I use 2-stroke fuel, I only have to refill this can about 4 times a year, and even with the strong spring on the filler lid, it's not a problem at all. You just need to use two hands to get the gas station nozzle into the can. Then it holds itself.

Despite the high price, this gas can is so much better than ANY plastic junk out there that I am going to buy another one for plain gas for the mower and never store fuel in plastic containers again.

reviewText: perfect

We live on two acres next to a golf course. I have trapped several gophers but every now and then I come across one that keeps avoiding the trap. This happened about a month ago so I tried putting some Moletox in the gopher tunnel and gopher mounds quit showing up. I wasn't sure if the gopher died or just moved to a different area. Another too smart to be trapped gopher showed up last week so I opened up the tunnel by the gopher mound, put some Moletox back in the tunnel as far as I could with a small hand shovel and then just to be sure I set the trap a little closer to the opening than the Moletox. Two days later the gopher hadn't filled the hole in so I decided to dig further back down the tunnel. In the process I uncovered a dead gopher. I'm impressed, this stuff works and it is easer than setting a trap!

I have read a lot of people have a hard time setting this up - and I'm pretty surprised.  Unroll it in the sun, weigh the ends down and in 5 minutes on a good day it will lose the "memory" of being shipped rolled up.  The rest is cake - really, really easy.

Easy to use, easy to set up - the only reason it doesn't get more stars from me is that I've got a lot of critters in my neighborhood - squirrels, chipmunks, rabbits, skunks, groundhogs, deer, raccoons - and a couple of the more enterprising among them have chewed some holes in the outside.

Not huge ones, mind you, but enough that I quickly went to the Home Depot and got some 3'x25' 1/2" wire mesh, snipped and surrounded the still 99% intact unit.  Problem solved.

The fact is, I should have thought to do this first - I've seen what they did to my poor bird feeder, even to the airtight feed storage box, so part of the blame is on me.  What should I have expected when I kept putting delicious raw and cooked veggie scraps, old bread and other delectable items in a bin on the far side of my property, abutting a forest?  It may as well have been a written invitation.

Next year, I'll just remove the plastic and leave the wire mesh, but for a beginning composter, this is an easy, affordable solution that works WAY faster than even my new rotating composter.

But if you've got a set of wire snips, some fine mesh (1/2" is best) chicken wire, and a few 3.5' poles to thread through the holes, you can make one of these yourself.  If you don't ,you'll spend more money than this costs to do it from scratch, but not a world more.  And you'll have some chicken wire left over for parties and holiday dinners.
summary: Pros, cons - a good product but depends on your situation

reviewText: Thanks for this it looks very pretty leaving colors on the wall of the dining room! Just wish it came with string like the rest of them~!~ But came very promptly! Thanks again!~

There are a few aspects of this well-made set that should get some attention in a review, especially for a high-ticket item like this one.

ARRIVAL AND ASSEMBLY - at least as I received it, it comes in three big boxes on a pallet. As other reviews noted, it will take about about an hour to break everything down, take all the packing paper off, get it all out of the boxes THEN you can start to actually construct it.

Good news - while the paper is all taped around the chair's metal frames, it is easily ripped masking tape. So it wasn't difficult to get the packing paper off, just time consuming. And that's a good thing! The set should arrive without any dings or damage.

The fire pit comes assembled. It is a TWO person job to move it, and it it's in top box. So expect to need two people to do all this.

The chairs are easy to assemble with two people AND a socket wrench set. I tried to use the included wrench, but that would have taken forever! But using a socket wrench took maybe two minutes a chair - very easy. Again - two person job. I wouldn't even try to do it myself. The chairs are not light, and to line up and then screw in the bolts is not worth the hassle of doing it yourself. And to repeat - use a socket wrench.

You are going to be left with an enormous amount of packing material - again, not a bad thing. Just make some space before it all arrives so you don't huge cardboard boxes getting in your way after the fact.

QUALITY - this is really the most important thing anyway, and on this score, this set seems worth the money and very well-made.

The chairs are metal with welded slats to enable the rocking. While the metal is light, it's still heavy-duty enough to hold up against the sun and the rain (I hope, anyway). The rocking motion is nice and i think a neat switch from a standard unmoving chair.

The cushions are thick fabric - and you're going to pay at least $50 for a similar cushion anywhere I've seen. Maybe more, since this is a two cushion set. Again, the fabric seems good quality and should hold up.

If you paid $225 for the chair/cushion, you'd be looking at $900 for the set and I don't think that's unreasonable. Expensive, but not unreasonable or unexpected. The cushions would probably be included.

The fire pit is solid, and while I don't love the design on the sides, it's okay and you won't notice it that much. The pit itself is not that high and a few chairs around the edge will fill it in quite nicely. It certainly would cost $400 by itself - probably more. And with the chairs, that puts this at a fair price of $1300, which is what it's currently listed at.

As for the fire pit performance, I haven't used it yet, but I'll update that part of it later. I wanted to do all this now while it was fresh in my head! It's not like you'll be cooking on the flame, anyway. It's mostly for the ambience.

SIZE - I have a 20x11 deck, and that is the minimum amount of space you need - assuming you already have other deck furniture. I already had a table, a few chairs and a chaisse lounge. Obviously, these chairs replaced a few others - but even then, the space got filled quick. Ideally, you'd have a 20x16 space, and I think that would be perfect.

The chairs rock, so you can't push them up against a fence or railing - not a negative, just be aware. They take up space but they are big and comfortable. They are deep cushioned, so you'll end up sitting back from the table a little bit.

The fire pit measures 38x38, but again - it's more than that. You need space for the chairs to have space, and it's going to take up a lot, quick. So if you ALREADY have a table/umbrella like most decks do, be aware of all that.

None of this is a bad thing, and most buyers probably have a lot more space than me and it won't even be an issue.

To sum up - good quality that feels high-end and well-made. They're charging high-end price and they are delivering a product that seems to deserve it. The cushions and the rocking chair are fun. The fire pit ledge gives a good space to put drinks, but I don't think I'd try to use it as an eating surface.

It doesn't come with a cover, and I would get one. I don't like the idea of rainwater getting underneath the rocks...although since it doesn't have a base, the water won't collect in anything. Still, I would get a cover.

At $1300, it's pricey, but I think you'll get what you're paying for - I like these chairs, and the pit is a neat addition to the deck ambiance. I will update this review as I see the quality prove itself over the sun and rain of the summer months.
summary: By early impressions, well-made and rugged set

Great medium-duty 4500psi 50 footer.  Comes with 3/8 inch QC couplings, male on one end and female on the other.  Includes the o-ring, and it is installed on the female coupling.  Also has bend guards on each end, as shown in the picture.

Note, this is for higher-pressure machines.  This will not work out the box for mid- and lower-pressure machines, such as most every electric washer and most every 2500-3400psi gas washer.  It is not the products fault if you order the wrong hose/connectors.  You should order this if your setup uses 3/8 inch QC couplings, such as you would find in most every machine above 3500 or so psi.  Check your machines specs first before ordering.  This will not work out the box with 1/4 inch or 5/16 inch hose setups, unless you change the connectors on this or your system.

The hose itself is rated 4500psi.  My machine can do 4200psi/4.0gpm.  Always, always, always, lower the pressure on your machine when testing new hoses.  If the hose bursts or a connector comes undone, this can be a very dangerous situation.  Start low and check the entire length of the hose.  Gradually increase pressure and re-check the hose.  Keep raising it until you reach your desired working pressure and re-check the hose.  Use it for a short while and re-check the hose.  Really, you should be doing this every time you use your machine, and not just when the hose is new.  Its smart and safe.

The hoses themselves are high-quality, but I would not say pro quality.  These hoses are too flexible for day-to-day use and abuse.  These are the kind that will easily kink and ruin themselves if you are not careful.  Don't get me wrong.  I am not calling them cheap.  They are good hoses.  However, compared to other comparably-priced pro-level hoses I have had in the past, these are not the best.  As long as you can keep them from kinking, they should be fine for many years.

As for corrosion in the braiding.  First of all, make sure to roll up your hoses in such as way as to allow the water to drain out completely.  It takes practice, but you can get most of that water out.  Also realize that all hoses have this "problem."  Its just that you usually cannot see the braid.  These are translucent, and that's why now all of a sudden you can see it.  If this is really a problem for you, I would recommend you leave the pressure washing thing to the pro's.  Really, this is not a problem in itself.  Its normal.  Bubbling hoses are bad.  Rusted braid, eh, not a big deal.

I was able to use two of these plus the OEM 50 footer, for a total of 150 feet with my machine no problem.  Still had great pressure at the tip.  If you need a long reach, just buy more 50 footers.  Do not waste your time, effort and money with 100 footers.  50 footers are better in every way except price.  Well, price at least in the short term.  In the long run, 50 footers are cheaper.  Also, 50 footers allow for easily customized setups.  If you only need 50, then only use 50.  Add more as needed.  Also, if one bursts, its not the end of the show if you get my meaning.  When a 100 footer bursts, it hurts your feelings.  Also, 50 footers are easier to clean up at the end of the day.  I did this as a business for many years.  Trust me, stay away from the 100 footers.
summary: Great hose, though not quite pro quality

reviewText: Fit our fire pit perfectly and works very well to keep it dry and clean when not in use.

I am so excited to have this grill! I was able to unpacked it mostly by myself and made sure each part I needed was there, per the instructions. My drum was was not dented, and I only had one small scratch on the red top (about 1/2 to 3/4 inch long on the right side of the lower portion of the top). Given that the unit weighs over 120 lbs., and has to go through many different shippers to get to its final destination, I am very satisfied with the physical condition of my smoker. While I unpacked most of it myself, putting it together was different, and I did require my brother's assistance (well, mostly I assisted him) when it came time to assemble the smoker/grill. It took us about 45 minutes to get everything in working order.

We followed the instructions very carefully as far as using the smoker/grill for the first time, and I would recommend everyone do so (even if you are familiar with other smokers). Be aware, even after loading the unit with the pellets and getting everything ready to go, you need to run the grill for a good 45 minutes on 350 degrees without food in it, in order to season the grill. (So I suggest you attempt the assembly and the initial set-up on less than an empty stomach, because it does take some time.) Then, once the grill has cooled, you need to coat the grates with vegetable oil and allow them to cook on a low degree setting for 2 hours, and then cool the grates again, before using. (All of this is in the instruction manual, and I suggest you read the entire manual before starting.) Once that was done and the grate was completely seasoned, we cooked some of the best rib-eye steaks I have ever had.

The next day we cooked some marinated chicken pieces. Fantastic! We have basically used the grill function, but next weekend we are going to do some ribs, low and slow, and I can hardly wait. I can only review a product based on my own personal experience. And, for me, this MoJack 47101 Myron Mixon Pitmaster Q3 Grill/Smoker definitely deserves 5 stars, and I highly recommend it. I would definitely purchase one as a gift for a friend or a relative. Bon Appetit, everyone!

reviewText:
This multi-use steel container looks beautiful on my patio.  I am not currently using it as a hose holder.  The description for this product states that it can hold a 125' long hose.  I have a 100' long hose, but it would be way to much work to coil it back up in this container.  So I am using it to store a lot of my gardening supplies - tools, sprays, grass seed, etc.  It is a very light weight container, so trying to use it with such a long and heavy hose could be a struggle.
The stamped, textural design on this container looks great.  It is a dark green, almost copper patina look with different colors of paint used.  I have not had any issues w/ rusting.  I live in South Texas, where we get a lot of morning dew, but not usually a lot of rain.  It's definitely not Seattle!  There are drainage holes at the bottom of the container, plus the three hex-head type screws that secure the center post for keeping the hose reeled neatly.  I removed the center post and put the three screws back in to keep those holes covered.  Where I live I could encounter some nasty critters, might as well keep that chance to a minimum.
I recommend purchasing the lid, which is sold on Amazon separately.  I received this container and lid as a Vine Voice, and the lid really completes the look.

reviewText:
A very strong wind is produced and it lasts about 10 min.

It's noticeably-lighter than gas blowers, and much better than the other battery-powered ones I've tried. The charger is substantial, is the battery, but it's easy to use and turns off when charging is complete.

There is a toggle on/off switch that gives a beep to announce that it worked (the trigger is ready to be pulled). It remains on, until switched off (or until the battery is dead or removed).

There is a 2-3 second delay after pulling the trigger. This is somewhat annoying, but it has a variable-speed trigger, so it's possible to just slow down the flow at times, rather than let go completely. It's so powerful, that maybe the idea is to act as a sort of safety switch, so only a deliberate press sets it off. I would like it better without the delay before starting each time when pulling the trigger.

It's been maintenance-free and easy to use and charge. The battery pops in and out with ease, and slides into its charger intuitively. It has some heft, the main weight of the unit, but the quantity of wind makes clearing the driveway 3x faster than with our previous battery-powered units, and just as fast or faster than our gas-powered one.
AWESOME!

I have fed it limbs and grasses as well.  It's a solid performer.  Best of all, all the lawn and garden waste that I was sending the landfill is now being used around my garden beds. This is a review of the Vex Zapper Electric Bug Zapper Racket by Vez Zappers. This is like your normal electric fly swatter but on steroids. There are a lot of different fly swatters out there, but this one seemed to have more features than all others. -This one is rechargeable using your normal ac wall outlet. Others I have used always took those two heavy D batteries which once dead are expensive to replace. When the power winds down, I just need to unscrew the base and pop it into an outlet. (You should charge these four hours before you use and pop it in for recharge once every 30-60days when not using to keep your battery in the best shape.) -Nice and powerful at 3,000volts. -The base which you can unscrew has a built in flash light. -There is also a led light to illuminate the metal mesh end of the swatter and draw the prey in! -Has a ZAP button to press when you go to swat. -Well-built and does not feel flimsy at all. -If you are wondering, yes I have zapped myself to feel how strong the zap is and yes, it is a nice strong zap. We want to use this in our garden out back soon as that seems to be a meeting place for all the mosquitos and flying bugs in our neighborhood. Not sure why, but there is a great pleasure when you swing, see a little spark and hear the bbzzzzt! I know this is not a toy, but it certainly gives me a lot of fun and enjoyment using. Cons I have to reduce by 5 star rating down to 3 as there is a problem with my power button on the handle. (See video.) Something must be loose as it flickers and goes on and off when you touch the switch. If I mess with it, it does work though. But certainly something is not right. If the seller reads this and offers an exchange, I can update this review accordingly as if it would not be for the issue with the switch, this is certainly a 5 star item. I don't know about you, but I depend very heavily on reviews that are posted on Amazon. I also read what reviewers on Amazon have to say. I want to help others by providing my reviews that detail the product as well as the experience I have with the products that I get on Amazon. Please note I have no relationship with this seller and Im not compensated in any way for my review. I did receive this at a discounted price in exchange for an unbiased and honest review. I take my reviews serious and will only provide my true feedback. Thank you!
summary: Powerful and rechargeable using ac outlet.

I've had my ET 732 since January and used it at least 30 times since then.  The only problem I've had with it was that I let grease get on the oven temp probe and it caught on fire and stopped working.  I bought a new one from Maverick for $12 shipped and was back in business.  It was my fault it died since once the hamburger grease got on it I should have taken it off the grill and wiped it clean, but I didn't do that so I bear the responsibility.

This thing gets great reception between the remote unit and the base. I can go 200' easy and still get a good signal. The only negative I've found in this unit is that it is a big pain to set the temperature limits as you can only go one direction when scrolling to a new temp.  So say you have your max temperature alarm set to 195 and you want to move it to 190, you have to scroll upwards from 195 to the max temp setting where it will then start over at the bottom setting and start scrolling up from there.  If you go past your stopping point you are out of luck.

However, other than that minor problem, the unit has been rock solid and I use it every time I use my keg grill.

UPDATE: 5/15/2012 - I've owned the ET 732 for almost a year and a half and *when it works* it is awesome.  The caveat is that the probes just don't last.  I've already had to replace the food probe (was $12 shipped from Maverick) and now the original oven temp probe and the replacement food probe have both failed (the ET 732 reads HHH whenever either is inserted). I guess if you don't mind paying $24 each and every year to replace both probes, and my pricing data may be out of date, then this is a great thermometer. It is my understanding that the new replacement probes are longer at 6' but weren't redesigned to make them more durable.  I did not treat mine harshly and never got them wet however my Big Steel Keg, like many cookers of its type, is known for retaining moisture in the cooking chamber so perhaps that is what is killing my probes.  Frankly based on reading the large number of 1 star reviews with the same exact problem I doubt it though.
summary: Work(ed) great with my Big Steel Keg

reviewText: I've been growing herbs the old-fashioned way (indoors and out) for over 40 years and never had any problems. When I saw this Chia Herb Garden in one of our local stores, it sounded like it was an easier and quicker way to get results - at least according to the package instructions. Boy, what a disapointment! The only thing easier was to plop the wet sponges into the little pots. Well, it's actually just as simple to fill a pot with some dirt and add the seeds. Reading the instructions that were enclosed with the Chia Herb Garden were actually more involved than growing my herbs the regular way. Also, most of the seeds that came with it were either way their expiration date or just didn't take. I got a few spindly seedlings? even after keeping the sponges wet and covering them with plastic bags, as instructed. I talked to a few of my friends who bought different Chia Pets in the past and not one of them was satisfied with the results or would ever buy them again. Guess we stick to the old proven way instead of wasting our money on another useless invention.

Initially, I tried to clip the shade directly to the wire but realized it was uneven and strands of cloth were blocking the prongs of the clips making it difficult to close, even with pliers.

I put the sunshade on my floor and placed the prong side of the clip through the material at even intervals and worked past the strands of cloth easily.  I then put the sunscreen, with clips half-attached, against the cable and closed them BY HAND easily.  I hope this tip helps as these clips get the job done.
I can't wait to feel better as I have a lot to do.

Works like a champ. I installed a NDS catch basin drain to get water out of a low corner of my driveway and then under an adjacent sidewalk and into my yard to drain. Problem with the yard is that it is gently sloped and only slightly lower than the catch basin, so trying to cut in a horizontal PVC drain of any kind was out of the question. Instead I mounted this emitter on a 90-degree elbow and set it flush with the yard. Works perfectly and is unobtrusive when not being used.

Only downside that I can see is that right after install, if you have any good rains you're likely going to get a little bit of erosion around the base of the emitter if it's installed on a soft/dirt surface. This isn't a design flaw, just something to be aware of. So over time, as your grass grows back in, you'll probably have to add some dirt around this device to get it back flush with the surrounding surfaces. Not a big deal at all, just be aware you might have to re-grade a little to make it perfect over time.
summary: Works like a champ; elegantly simple solution

I am really amazed. I would never have bought this if it weren't for the reviews, and I am very glad that I did. When the UPS man arrived and pulled it out of his truck, he said "Cheryl, this won't work", like why did you buy this piece of junk with such a silly brand name?  I didn't think something this dinky looking could mulch up my finished garden debris, but it ate all of it up like a hungry monster. I had pulled tomatoe, corn, pepper and sunflower plants, but had to cover them with plastic because it was going to rain before the machine arrived. The tomatoe plants were already decomposing when I got out there this morning, so I probably should not have put them in the machine. Didn't even phase the machine. It gobbled them all up very quickly, despite the mold and moisture. Swallows large pepper plants whole, and it loves large sunflower stocks. I assumed that it would take days to complete the task, but I spent less than two hours. It only stopped once, but it reset right away. I had to clean it out three times when it got full of wet mulch,(you can tell that it is getting slow) but easy and quick to do so. Oh, and it is quiet. I am an extreme gardener with a huge garden so I bought this to mulch and compost and this tool will actually work for me. I didn't want to deal with a gas machine. This is very light and manageable. I can take the legs off and slip it under my potting bench during the winter, but I intend to keep it out by the garden next summer for daily use.

reviewText: I can't add much to the good reviews here. I have used these traps years with good results.

Before buying this gas can, I did not really understand how the environmentally responsible (CARB Compliant) spout actually worked, but here is the layman's version.  It is supposed to be a one-way valve.  The way you empty the gas can when inverted is to engage the hook on the side of the spout on the edge of your gas tank (lawnmower tank, snowblower tank, whatever) and then depress down (i.e. actually push down on the entire can, pressing it towards the ground with the 85053 cradled in your hands).  This compresses the spring-loaded spout and opens the one-way valve so the gas is allowed to empty out the spout and into your lawnmower (like depressing the nozzle on an aerosol can so something can come out).  Sounds good, right?

Well, there are several problems.  First of all, the tip of the spout has to extend fairly deeply into the tank of your lawnmower to enable you to engage the hook on the side of the spout to activate that whole spring-loaded compression process.  You really can't see the gas emptying out the end because it is already buried in gasoline in your shallow lawnmower tank.  Secondly, I found the whole process rather clumsy because the gas can handle is on top (perfect for carrying it away from the gas station) but you have to invert the tank virtually 180 degrees to position it to make this spring-loaded spout process work.  It is just clumsy trying the hold the inverted can, especially if full and heavy, without the assistance of any handles since the handle is now underneath the can in that position.

But, worst of all, when I depress the spout on my can, the gas does not just come out the end of the spout like it is supposed to.  It comes out everywhere.  There is a flood of gasoline that spews out from who knows where, through seals that are supposed to keep the gas from leaking out presumably.  I tried everything I could to fix it.  It was not an issue of the spout being improperly tightened down into the can.  The gas just gushed out through the side of the spout everytime the spring-loaded mechanism was depressed.  That is why my Briggs & Stratton 85053 is worthless.  I mean that literally.  It is unusable.  You just end up with a mess on the ground as maybe two-thirds of the gasoline makes it into the tank, and the rest of it is on your lawnmower deck, your shoes, and ground.

I now see as I post this review that I am not the only one who has had this problem.  For some people, it evidently works fine.  For me, I may has well have just burned a $20 bill.  It was wasted money.  My efforts at better environmental responsibility have ended up with one more piece of plastic in a landfill somewhere because there was nothing else I could do with this can.  It was simply unusable.  I bought this particular gas can primarily because it had the Briggs & Stratton name on it, which has been a name that I have associated with quality for over 40 years (ever since I was old enough to know about small gasoline engines).  I rather doubt that this spout was actually designed by Briggs & Stratton engineers.  I wonder whether you can really design and build a spout mechanism into a $20 piece of equipment without having a high failure rate.  I don't know.  It obviously doesn't fail for everybody, but it failed on my can.

reviewText:
This Weed Knife works best in the left hand. But I switch back and forth.
Joseph Bentley Traditional Garden Tools Stainless Steel Hand Held Weeding Knife is a life changing tool.
I edged the driveway and removed grass from cement cracks with this weed knife. Then removed AIR POTATOES from citrus.

I also bought a, Truper 32100 Tru Tough Rotary Lawn Edger with Dual Wheel and Ash Handle, 48-Inch
This Rotary Lawn Edger needs some practice and wearing in. I have not yet used my bench grinder on it sharpen the back angle of the shearing plate, yet have done two lawns without too much difficulty, though straight out the box is seemed I might shatter the stick shoving too hard.
The Joseph Bentley Weed Knife was essential to clearing out weeds and tall grass I got into it from my own yard. And has helped again.

The negative is that I look forward to wearing out this four foot handle. Currently you bend over and erase the edge with repeated strokes.
It needs a six foot Ash wood mopping stick to be bolted into it to save your back so that it feel more like raking gravel, than erasing roots.

I used my shovel to do clean up of the walk and drive way,
Bond 2060 7-Inch to 22-Inch Adjustable Steel Rake seem like a useful rake but I have not used it yet.
I bought it to use for grass clipping. But it became unneeded with a Troy-Bilt.com $19 price Xtreme Mulcher blade upgrade.
I look forward to seeing if a well made flex rake may change my preference for stiff landscaping rakes.
Joseph Bentley looking at your quality garden rake.
Had I known the grass clippings would be correct with an Xtreme blade from Troy-Bilt.com, I'd have bought their rake instead.
summary: Life Changing endless useful piece of metal and wood.

*** This IS the 2015 version of the Aquabot XLS. ***

Many other websites sell the older version of the Aquabot.  They look nearly identical.

New for 2015:
Swivel head (helps reduce tangled cable)
Jets (on the bottom to break up debris)
Fine Mesh Filters (captures stuff down to 2 micron.)

I have received the product and quickly opened it to make sure it was the 2015 version.  Many of the negative comments below are for older versions.  The new version corrects many of these issues.  As long as the version you are buying has the swivel head, it will be the 2015 version with the other changes included.

Aquabot was very helpful during the buying process to ensure I had the right cleaner for my pool.

I got this as a Christmas gift and I was so excited to open it and start it up.  (At this point, I've had it running for 4 months) The instructions and set up are easy.  Then I waited until the sprouts started, which didn't take long.

Strangely, in the dill seed pod, there was only ONE seed, which... needless to say, produced a very scrawny tuft of dill.  That died.

The cilantro seemed to have so much promise, seemed to be off to an amazing start.  It, too, died.

The parsely, which is still alive, is really a useless amount of parsley.  I feel guilty when I clip any of it for fear that the plant cannot survive off the tiny amount of leaves that remain.

The chives, well.... lets just say that they're lacking in length and girth, and thats never a good sign.

HOWEVER! the basil.  Oh the basil - both the regular green and the purple, they will NOT stop growing.  I am constantly cutting it back because the plants are growing up to the lightbulb and burning on the bulb.  I haven't figured out how to use enough of the basil to keep those plants under control.  But then again, basil grows like a weed under any circumstances, so it isn't because of the AeroGrow that they are exploding.

And the lights, don't even get me started on the lights!  They are so insanely bright that you don't need to use any other light source in any room that the AeroGrow is in.  I have mine in the kitchen and have resorted to using a curtain to block the glare at night.  I have it set to turn off at 10:00 pm, but until that time, its like the surface of the sun in my kitchen - blinding white light.

The pump is quite, unless it needs refilling, which is often.  I have mine near the sink so its easy to refill the reservoir when I hear the trickeling noise.  But that noise is actually a pleasant sound, so really, no complaints about that.

But you know what, for the price of running those lights for all those hours every day, and running that pump for 24 hours every day, I am starting to suspect I could just buy organic herbs and produce and still have money left over for a latte.

Yes, its a cute conversation piece and yes its nice to have basil on demand (nothing else really grew at all), but really.... it takes up a lot of counter space, its blindingly bright and it is an energy vampire 365 days out of the year.

So I give it a solid "Eh..." - 3 stars

This is table is very smartly designed, how one or both sides can fold down.  We live in the city with a very small deck and most outdoor patio furniture seems to be designed for huge houses out in far flung suburbs (why is that??).  Go to Home Depot and most of the furniture there would swallow our entire deck.  I have this table half open and plan to put flowers or a lantern on the top.  It is easy to quickly open up each side of the table, and I expect it to be painless to open the other half if we all want to eat lunch outside.  Also I like that this completely folds down to a fairly narrow profile and I plan to store it inside in the winter to keep it better maintained.  The quality is very nice... it is so nice I now I wish the wood on our deck was nicer!  Looking forward to using it this summer.  Even my husband had positive comments.  Honestly I would give it 5 stars but we haven't eaten on it yet.

reviewText: This sign is fairly brittle, so after a fair amount of use the staples connecting the plastic sign to the wooden stake came out. I purchased this assembly at a local hardware store (didn't check Amazon first or i would have probably ordered it here). The reason I got it was to safeguard my sewer line from backing up into the house in case the main floods and backs up. It seems to fit the bill but the main reason I'm writing a review is to praise the company's fine customer service. I ran my mower over the unit and, since the one I bought didn't have a spring, the suction from the mower pulled the pop-up valve into the blades. I contacted National Diversified (manufacturer) by email through their website and they not only replaced the insert (as a one-time courtesy, with no questions asked) but they sent me one with a spring so that I won't have to worry about the mower "sucking it up" anymore. I am now officially a fan! This kind of customer service is rare and any company deserves high praise when they "step up" and provide it.
summary: Top notch customer service from the manufacturer of this product.

reviewText:
These stakes are very satisfyingly sturdy and a confidence-inspiring 6" long.

I used them to tack down large-grid hardware cloth (technically vinyl-coated, wire fencing). So far it has kept the dog from digging the living daylights out of the bed right next to our pool. Soon I'll try re-planting elephant ear bulbs and hopefully they won't get dug up!

The "Strathwood Coco Fiber Closed Boxes" Doormat is well made and fairly attractive for what it is. We live in the county and need a good doormat to prevent dirt and mud from being tracked into the house, this mat should work nicely. Here are my observations:

* It is a good size (18" x 30"), but is a little bit on the light side for it's size.

* Made from recycled rubber and coco fibers, it has sturdy stitching and should hold up for a few years.

* The coco fibers are fairly high, with a good bit of channeling between them to provide a lot room for dirt, mud, and water to fall away from cleaning surface.

This doormat looks great on my porch and does a good job with cleaning thick dirt and mud off shoes and boots.

*** UPDATE 02/02/2011: Going on two years of daily use and this mat still looks and works great! Upgrading my review from 4 to 5 stars.

Recommended!

CFH

reviewText:
I bought this item as a bit of a lark.  I thought I'd check the temperature of my walls, floors, ceiling and a few hot water pipes, watch a few pans heat up, and then put it in a drawer.

I've now found the product to be indispensable and use it at least once a day.  I have a gas range.  I can check a pan that is heating and get just the right temperature for fried eggs (300 degrees or so) or pancakes (375 degrees.)  I'm no sure how would cook these items without it.  I heat  the cooking scrambled eggs to about 140 degrees at a high gas setting while stirring, and then cut the fire back to minimal to finish the eggs.

I built a new house in the past few years.  I've used the product to determine how well it is insulated and to find air leaks.  Fortunately I've found I don't have any problems.  I took the device to a friends house which is older and we found all sorts of issues including an uninsulated ceiling in one area.

To use the device one holds the trigger in.  There is a laser to help with selecting the target point.  When held an foot away from the target the temperature is sensed from a circle with a diameter of one inch.  The holding the device closer or further away changes the diameter of the sensing zone.  As long as the trigger is held the device continues to measure the temperature, even if it changes.  When the trigger is released the last temperature read is held until the device automatically turns off which is in a minute or so.  This operation is totally intuitive.

I thought of writing this review because I just changed the batteries in the device (September 2013).  I've owned it since February, 2012.  It took a minute tops, to change the two AAA batteries.  I consider this to be excellent battery life given how much I use the device.

Along with the Thermapen thermometer for measuring interior temperatures of food, this product is a must-have for cooking.  The Kintrex thermometer also has other valuable uses around the house.
summary: "I've become accustomed to her face...," an indispensable product

reviewText: Lay-Z spa designs these so that they fall apart quickly and you have to buy more.  A real hot tub would have a fabric filter, but the paper starts to disintegrate very quickly.  My advice is to take them out after a couple hours of filtration after use, so that they last longer.  I am surprised no one has tried to make filters for these spas that last longer (like the K-cup adapter that you can put your own coffee in), it is basically $10 every week/ 2 weeks to keep the filter running right, so that is a minimum of $260 a year on filters alone.  If I had 220V in my house, I would have purchased a less temporary hot tub.
summary: Designed to fall apart.  Very expensive.

reviewText:
Update: I wanna say it's been about two years now since I got this. I moved away from the house a couple months ago, to an apartment, and left the arbor in the yard as a gift to my friend and landlord for helping me move and giving me a nice deal on rent. When I left, the arbor still looked gorgeous and white, and the only thing that was a bit off about it was the footing/stakes. The yard has some major ground/soil issues and developed some hollow space on one side of the arbor, making it lean. Some longer stakes would have been nice, but I think these probably would've been fine if the soil hadn't been ridiculous and some of our furry little friends hadn't been digging tunnels everywhere.

It was absolute bedlam trying to put this thing together, but now that I've got a better idea, I think next time would be faster. You definitely want at least one other person to help you, but two is better. As someone who has a bad habit of doing two-person jobs on my own with some ingenuity, I can tell you not to bother; it will only waste your time and frustrate you. The good news is that once my neighbors and I got it together and the glue dried, it's stayed together. Now, it hasn't been through a hurricane yet, but since it's been anchored, it's been pretty sturdy. No discoloration whatsoever, no bending (though some of the strips -are- flexible), no mold or mildew, and it's hot and humid here.

It seems pretty sturdy for something that isn't wood or iron, so I'm growing my passiflora edulis on it. I expect it will support the vine and its fruit well. It also just plain looks nice, doesn't look 'cheap'. Very charming!
summary: Gorgeous, but get help putting it together!

I bought this hose repair because my lawn man accidental cut through my hose when trimming the bushes.  It was an older hose but I really liked it because it was short enough for the spot it was located in.  I spent a long time evaluating all of the other hose menders and decided to select this one.  The solid brass fittings are what made my mind up for me.  Brass will not rust and will not break like the plastic ones available for sale.  Also with the brass the clamps can be tightened much more securely than with plastic.  If you screw the clamps down tightly on plastic there is a good chance it is going to break.  I am glad I chose to purchase the brass set.  I had just moved into the house, had none of my tools available and  did not have time to take on every little project.  My dad lives just up the road so he doesn't mind helping me out with small repair jobs.  He came over to my house and asked me which hose I wanted repaired and where the parts were.  I handed him the hose repair kit and went back into the house.  Three minutes later he walked into the kitchen door and I asked what's wrong.  He answered, "Nothing. Should there be?"  I asked him what about the hose.  "Yeah, what about it?"  Is it fixed.  He answered yes.  I was shocked and couldn't believe that he finished repairing it within a few minutes because he is 78 years old and has extreme arthritis in his hands.  His hands swell so bad he can hardly move his fingers.  He took me outside to inspect his work.  When I turned on the hose it was not leaking one drop.  It was that easy to repair with this mending kit and the clamps secure the hose tightly.  Months later it still has not leaked one drop and I have my favorite hose back.  I would highly recommend this repair kit.
summary: Hose good as new or maybe better than new

I recently picked up this same Weber regulator.  Believe it or not, I had a squirrel eat through my supply hose.  It was old and covered with a "garnish" of drippings from meals gone by, and in his earnest he chomped all the way through the hose and drained the tank.  I will admit that at first I thought I could seal the hole with the great fixer upper, duct tape.  But it was a no go.  After refilling the tank, the instant smell of gas permeated the air.  (If this happens to you, or you get a hole in yours for any reason, forget the duct tape.  It will leak anyway and be dangerous).  This Weber assembly is pretty much the one that is found around here no matter where you go, so I picked it up.  My grill is a Charbroil, but I feel that this hose can be made to fit any grill.  The tank connector is a universal fit and will screw easily onto any tank.  Its the other end that where you may have to improvise.  Apparently the fitting at the end of the regulator on newer grills has been simplified to a screw on like the tank side, (took them long enough).  My old time dependable grill had a regulator that was not so accommodating.  I solved the problem by completely cutting the fittings off and twisting the end over the regulator valve.  Although its relatively easy to slip on, the regulator valve is thickly threaded and the hose stays tight and secure. Even so, when dealing with gas its best to make sure, so I installed a small worm clamp around the end and the job was done.  Safe and completely without leaks.

Its my opinion that if you are in the need for a new supply line on your gas grill, no matter what brand it is, this universal kit should fit it nicely.  If its a newer one the job becomes a simple matter of screwing to ends on.  If you have an older one, you can improvise as I did and be grilling before you know it.  Its an easy job.  And if you are an online shopper, I feel that ordering this kit here on Amazon will save you a lot of time running around wondering which one to get.  Recommended should you ever have an aggressive squirrel in your future...
summary: Can Be Made To Fit Any....Good Price

Most reviews of this type of temperature gauge or thermometer say they are not very accurate.  I can't help but think that this is due to people not understanding how the surrounding environment affects these products.

Firstly, it is not a scientific instrument so a couple of degrees off here or there is fine.  I placed mine inside next to one thermostate and two thermometers.  They all were within 1 1/2 degrees of one another, but this thermometer was two degrees higher than the average of the others.  To adjust it I simply took hold of the housing of the bimetal thermometer works on the back and turned it gently till it was "calibrated" with my other thermometers.  It now resides outside and is within 1 to 1 1/2 degrees of my electronic thermostats.  That's fine for what this product is.

The clock is accurate and so is the thermometer, within reasonable expectations as I noted.

A note to users of thermometers:  1, do not place it in the sun, it says this on the box;  2, if it is on a wall and the sun is beating on the wall below the thermometer it will affect the thermometer reading even though the thermometer itself is not in the sun - heat rises; 3. place it where there is a wide margin of shade around this item and it will work just fine; 4, remember that the walls of your house hold heat due to their mass, so when the air cools off at night, and your thermometer is hanging on the wall with its mechanism 1/2 from that wall, it will register higher than the ambient air temperature until everything equalizes.  For people that expect instant readings and total accuracy, you can buy an instant-read thermometer for over $100, so go do that and stop complaining. If you want an instrument that is decorative, inexpensive, and reasonably accurate then get this one.

I tested Mosquito Bits by sprinkling them in a container of water swarming with wriggling mosquito larvae. I came back a little later (maybe 1/2 hour? maybe an hour?) and the water was nearly clear of larvae. A few minutes later and the larvae were completely gone - water clear. Amazing. The active ingredient is BTi, a bacterium that, when eaten by insect larvae, kill the larvae.

The organic gardening guy, Mike McGrath, host of NPR's "You bet your garden" recommends setting out lots of containers with water + BTi. Mosquitoes lay their eggs in the treated water, but baby mosquitoes never emerge. (Read more at the www site  [...])
summary: This stuff clears mosquito larvae while you wait

It does what it's supposed to do, and it does it well. The variable speed vac assures that you won't be sucking up rocks, just the leaves on them. The vac is very good for picking up leaves between bedding plants. The only problem is that the zipper on the bag is not robust enough and is prone to sticking when clogged with fine debris. Use too much force to free up the zipper and it will fail. It's covered by a very good warranty, but that's a nuisance. Removing the bag for emptying requires some finesse, but it's not a big problem. The blower is excellent. Switching from blower to vac and back seems tricky at first and also requires some finesse, but it becomes faster and easier with practice. Four stars because it is a very good vac and excellent blower. Minus one star for the zipper and relative difficulty detaching parts and swapping functions.
summary: It does what it's supposed to do!

You will not be able to swat a fly against a hard surface, but you can just lay the racquet against the fly and it will get zapped.  Once you get the hang of it, you can zap flies in mid air, which saves the time of waiting until they land on something.  It can be tricky but I prefer it over a traditional swatter.  The fly guts don't get all over the object...the fly stays in tact.  Sometimes you have to zap it more than once or even take a napkin and finish the fly off yourself as it's recovering, which is why I didn't give it a 5 star.  I would think with that much voltage, the fly would be killed from one zap.  This may be the result of the batteries wearing down so there's less current zapping the fly.  It's also good for mosquitoes as they are flying through the air, but this netting has larger holes than some smaller racquets, so if you intend to use it on mosquitoes, I might buy another model with double netting or just smaller holes that won't allow the mosquito to fly through the netting holes.
summary: Works pretty well for flys - You don't have to wait for them to land

reviewText: These ant stakes really do the job, and you don't have to spread a lot of granules around where kids or pets can get to it. The poison is contained inside the plastic hub. The ants go inside and and take the poison back to the nest. They attract the ants within a few minutes (or hours), but it usually takes a few days to wipe out the colony. So these are best used ahead of time as a preventative measure. Used this way, you will solve your ant problem before it  gets to be a problem. I replace mine every 3 months, which is excellent duration for a pesticide.
summary: Bottom Line -- These Work for a Long Time

Haven't owned a gas saw for many years due to older models being difficult to either start, or keep running. As it was past time to invest in one, I chose this due to reviews and pricing at the time. It came assembled, however I followed the instructions and took it apart to be sure the assembly was done well, and it was done very well. After completing all of the quick start instructions, I to include adding bar and chain oil & fuel, I took the saw into our back area to test it and take down an old plumb tree which was 16 inches in diameter at the base. The starting sequence went without a hitch, and the saw cut through the trunk like a hot knife through butter. It cut so well, that I went ahead and cut a dead/diseased trunk from another tree, with the same results. As for mixing oil and fuel, I decided that since my use of the saw would be pretty infrequent, I went ahead and purchased (3) cans of premixed 40:1 at my local Lowe's. All in all, this is a very good saw, a great price, and yes, I would recommend and purchase again.
Arrived and worked as expected, an affordable option compared to local stores.

The first one I got was not threaded properly so when you pulled on the string, nothing came out and it got stuck.  The next one I got was threaded fine and the string works well in the garden.  The green does fade in the sun, but that is to be expected.

I bought this to replace an original Hedgehog, an HT1000, that died after many years of use (and probably over use).  Unfortunately, I had to buy it locally rather than from Amazon, which cost me an extra $25.  That's the price you pay for equipment failure in mid-job.  :-)

It weighs perhaps 2/3 of the old trimmer and vibrates perhaps 1/2 as much.  Still tiring to use for long periods, especially stretched out trying to reach the middle of a big bush, but far less tiring than the original.

The extra reach over the 16" trimmers is amazingly helpful.  For the first time at this house, I didn't need a ladder to trim.  The cord minder seems to work better than the original Hedgehog as well.  The cord never came out once.

After about 3 hours use, I'm very satisfied with the trimmer.  Worth what I paid for it locally; more than worth the Amazon price.

I'd like to address a couple of things I saw in other reviews.  First is a question about the handle being "too small to get leverage".  How much leverage do you need to put on a hedge trimmer?  Unless you're trying to force it through something you shouldn't, the handle is just fine.

The complaints that it won't cut through the 1/2" as advertised.  Yes, that's a legitimate beef, but you shouldn't be doing that anyway with an electric trimmer.  I'm pretty sure that's what killed my first trimmer.  Use loppers and pruning saws for stuff that big.  (You probably also ought to trim more often as well.)

Remember, this is not one of the big gas trimmers.  You want arms like a gorilla, feel free to buy one.  They do a tremendous job, but they get heavy for us occasional users.  Unless you own an estate, this unit should do the job nicely.

Should have known better.  Enough reviews complain about the flame and soot and smell and it not staying lit.  Well I figured they must have put something together wrong.  So I can assure you I did not put it together wrong.  Pretty straight forward.  Unit looks very nice.  doors do not line up properly on mine and one door scrapes on the top overhang so you have to yank the sh#% out of it to get it open and closed.  I can live with that but most important is it just doesn't light .  Followed the instructions , tried it 10 different ways.  pilot light goes on.  small flame.  won't ignite to full flame.  On about the 5 or 6th try it all of a sudden "blows" and the flame shoots up and it works.  Flame is nice.  But a lot of soot and smell that is not great.  Maybe all propane fires have this smell and soot. Flame works for about 10 minutes then "poof" it goes out.  Try to light it and it won't re light.  pilot goes on and that is it.  Messed around with it on 3 days ( one of which with a party of guests ) who now know not to buy this either.  Many reviews say you need to modify the burner air gap to reduce the soot and smell.  I moved it out as far as it will go without "modifying" the whole assembly and it still is not good.  And the tile work on top is "real tile/slate" and as such is not even or smooth.  I actually like this "hand made" look but others may not.  So keep that in mind if you want to roll the dice on this thing.

So I want to return it.  But I am not taking it apart ( which will take forever ) and I got rid of the huge amount of boxes and packing material that this came in.  So I hope amazon will just send a truck and take it "unboxed".  Not sure what they would do with these pieces of crap anyways that don't work so it really should not matter.  I'll let you know how Amazon comes thru with customer service on something like this.

It is to bad because the unit looks nice and would be great if it worked properly.  I refuse to give companies a "pass" on quality control issues like this on expensive items that are now made in china.  :(
summary: Stay away unless you soot and smell and a fire that won't light and goes out every 10 minutes.

I love fire pits and have purchased several over the years.  Usually they are made of thin sheet metal and eventually fall apart.  I don't think that this pit will suffer that fate, at least not for a long while.  The bowl is cast iron and bigger than I imagined it to be.  The legs are made of stainless steel and attached easily and securely.  The grate fits in nicely and the lid keeps sparks from drifting away and possibly causing a wild fire.

This brings up an important point.  When I was a young boy we used to go camping quite often.  One of the mainstays of our camping site was an open outdoor fire pit.  However, with much of the country suffering from drought it is important to keep fires controlled.  I could see using this fire pit on a camping trip instead of using an open pit since the embers are kept contained by the screen covered lid.  All in all a well made product that is worth it's price.
summary: A nice pit for the backyard or even for camping

This is a MORE concentrated version of Roundup 5005610 Weed and Grass Killer Plus Concentrate Bottle, 36.8-Ounce. I have used both over the past 10+ years, and they are both amazing. I started using it in Ohio, and moved to Arizona six years ago. It has consistently killed everything I've sprayed with it in both places. OCCASIONAL I may need to spray a second time a couple of days apart to completely kill some bigger or tougher weeds. But, most of the time a single application is all it takes... within 6-12 hours weeds start looking wilted, within 24 hours they start to brown, and within 48-72 hours they are completely brown and deed. The only word of caution is that it does not distinguish between the plants you do and don't want (so it also kills grass, etc. for example). So, you should not spray or let it get on any plants you don't want to kill. I've been using it for over 10 years, and am very satisfied with it.
summary: Kills everything from Ohio to Arizona -- From a 10 year satisfied customer

reviewText:
I hate dealing with mice and especially dislike having to dispose of them. But after trying several different mouse traps the Victor M140S has turned out to be a good choice for me.
The trap is easy to bait and set yet difficult to set off by mistake.
While I prefer not to look at the dead mouse, any decent trap will be too cost prohibitive for one-time use and this trap at least makes it easy to dispose of the mouse quickly without having to touch the carcass.
I did try the Kill and Seal trap, which touts easy removal of the mouse if you choose to reuse it. But those never worked properly for me and because it seals in the mouse, it was actually hard to tell sometimes if something had even been caught (I had a lot of false positives).
At least with the Victor M140S Quick Kill trap, whether it is working or not is obvious.
No one likes dealing with mice, especially dead ones, but the Victor M140S makes the process as painless as possible for both the hunter and the prey.
Expensive, but works great!
summary: Works great in my chain saw and snow blower.

Just can't tell if it works or not. I used this when living in a rental that was kept in poor condition as far as window and door seals go. We had an infestation of yellow sac spiders, which unfortunately hangout on the ceiling in corners and come inside during the fall. The first fall we were there I was seeing up to 5-15 a week, killing them myself. Sprayed this all around the perimeter inside and out of doors and windows every few months. I also caulked the Windows and sealed the doors. The second fall, I saw less of them but they were definitely still getting in. So I just can't tell if just this worked, or if it worked in combination with sealing entry points. The only problem is that they come in during the fall mostly, and you have to re-spray any exteriors that have moisture such as rain or snow.

First, I will give you a bit of background. I've raised and showed chickens for over 30 years, so I know just a bit about them. My husband and I live on a large dairy farm with various other animals, and I ordered this because, I had a broody hen who hatched out 4 eggs we put under her and her and her babies were getting way too big for the pet porter we had them in. I wanted a place to put her and her babies (now at 2 months old) in to integrate them back into the flock of 40, while she was teaching them how to go to roost, etc. My husband is so busy; I thought that this coop would be faster than having to build a small transitional coop.

First, one box arrived via UPS, and the next day a second box. So, just be aware that if you just get one box you will have to wait for the next box to arrive to complete your coop. The directions are not great either! Good thing, my husband put it together (ha-ha). Measurements are 68 inches by 30 by 41-Inches.

This coop looks nice. The finish is very nice. The hardware cloth looks to be fairly good quality. Though, this thing is smaller than it looks. Currently, we have the one momma chicken (a standard size Buff Orpington) and her 4 young (3 pullets and 1 cockerel) in there and it really is too small for all of them, but, since it is just transitional, it will work.

If I was ordering this for a permanent home for chickens, I would NEVER put more than 2 full sized chickens or 4 bantam chickens in this. If chickens are overcrowded you can have a ton of behavior and health problems, such as feather picking, due to boredom.  I added photo's to show how cramped it is with just my one hen and her 4 chicks. Of course, you can move this often to fresh grass and build another run to hook on to give more room.

Also, one thing I didn't like about this coop is that the ramp into the house is finished wood and it is too slick for chicken's feet. My chickens don't like to use it. I plan on gluing some shingles to it for added traction or adding more wooden slats between the slick wood.

Another thing, I thought could be improved was the quality of the latches and closures, particularly on the doors. I will probably replace the latches with a better quality latch, as raccoons could easily open up the doors.

I wish there was a sliding cover on the one window in the coop, as during winter at night this could be closed if there were a sliding cover.  When I use this coop in winter I will cover this up at night.

Though, I think this is the perfect coop (with a bit of tweaking and more winterizing) for a broody hen to hatch her brood and raise them if you want her separated from the rest of the flock. Also, this would be perfect for one hen and one rooster if you want to insure that you have purebred fertile eggs- which is what I plan to use it for once my hen and her chicks are integrated back into the big flock.

Overall, I would purchase it again, as it is quick to put up, looks nice, it's easy to get the eggs out, easy to clean and does the job I need it for. Though, if you can build fairly well, and want more than 2 full-sized chickens, we built an 8ftx8ft coop, complete with everything for just $50 more.
summary: Nice looking, but small and ramp is too slick for chickens feet
