So far so good.

I bought these to replace the "ceramic" style filters our hot tub came with; one of them cracked when I removed them for cleaning. I bought these for three reasons: 1) I could get the four filters needed for our tub for less than *half* the cost of four ceramic filters; 2) These are made in the USA; 3) I wanted to experiment with the "lesser" style of filters to see the cost/benefit compared to the (way) more expensive ceramic filters.

And then there was the free two day Amazon Prime shipping ...which greatly helped get our tub up and running ASAP.

Do not fear these filters. The Pleatco replacement filters fit our Hot Springs "Sovereign" Model II spa tub perfectly. In fact these filters are a bit larger overall than the ceramic filters that came with the tub; they are both a little taller and a bit wider in diameter. Whereas the original ceramic filters slipped on with lots of room to spare, these filters needed just a bit of careful alignment to get them on ...nothing heroic or potentially damaging ...just not as easily as the ceramics. And FYI ...I read a review of a person who bought these filters and complained about having to remove the band on the filters ...you don't remove the band. The band is glued in place and it'is there to help stabilize and keep separated the filter folds; leave it be.

If you want to make the change to the non-ceramic filters make sure you read up on their care in your owners manual or the Pleatco website; no, you can't toss these in the dishwasher. But keeping them clean isn't much more work than hosing them off regularly and occasionally using the filter cleaning spray solution. Like I said, so far so good.

The ET Pest Control from DNR Tech arrived safely, smoothly and on time.

This device is very easy to setup and comes with instructions. I live in Florida and we have all kind of bugs all year around.
I did not buy this unit for bats, rats or mice because we never had them in our houses. Snakes are probably taking care of rats and mice for us. I bought the Pest Control for roaches, ants, mosquitoes, spiders, silverfish and flies.

I plugged it in an outlet next to the kitchen and the lights came on. I pressed the test button and heard the terrible sound that is suppose to keep bugs out of the house. If you don`t press the test button you don`t hear anything and the device doesn`t bother you. It has a low and high setting and I put it on high because it is a two story home with more than 2500 square ft. The device is suppose to cover up to 5000 square ft.
It has a little night light at the bottom which I find a great idea. So far the device seems to work and we find less and less bugs in the house. If it continues working this will be a great money saver because I would have to pay more for a one time chemical spraying of my house with a pest control service than this device costs. Not only may it be cheaper it is definitely safer than chemicals.

For a little under $50, I rate this Pest Control device five out of five stars.
I am thrilled I received this product at a discounted price for my honest and unbiased review. Opinions are my own and I did not get paid for this review. This is a product I would recommend!
summary: CHEAPER AND SAFER ALTERNATIVE TO REGULAR PEST CONTROL WITH CHEMICALS

I purchased this light after a couple experiments with the smaller, older editions.You can find more details in my reviews of the other lights in the P series, but this panel is exquisite for the price and deserving of a special shout-out. There appears to be as much secret sauce in the refraction as there is in the diodes. The optical quality is obvious even when observed very casually from a point light source hitting the individual diodes' glass. The focus is fantastic and, along with the precisely targeted spectral options, makes the light possibly the most efficient I've seen on the market in terms of PAR on leaves per watt. The hardware would be worth it at most price points -- capital costs on LEDs barely factor into the equation given the extraordinary service life -- but the P1200 is silly cheap for what you get. I'm just a tinkerer, but it's loaded with other features that larger grow ops will appreciate too: very modular and rigorous engineering, the ability to daisy chain power, and a sales team that actually knows how sausage is made. Throughout the growth process, I ran into four primary unexpected issues: 1) Everything I had learned around nutrients, water, spacing, and so forth is now obsolete because the low heat signature and high PAR changes the equation so radically. I have specimens that are basically solid domes of vegetation about 8 weeks into life and it takes some digging to even see the stem... and it's already pretty wooden when you find it. 2) I didn't choose enough hungry varietals. This light permits aggressive use of basically everything else to get the most out of it because you have so much PAR to work with. 3) I'm gonna need to find some more species to grow. There is only so much fresh produce that one man can consume. 4) Commercial scale; probably overkill for almost all home gardens unless you want our own little slice of the Congo Rainforest. As of harvest time, the plant might have been dunked in Elmer's. Kinda surreal and makes working with it more difficult. A little seems to go a long way, though.

reviewText:
We came home from vacation. It had not rained for a week and every day was over 100 degrees. Out kitchen was filled with ants. (I learned that they come in looking for water during a drought). We cleaned out every cabinet and sprayed with bug spray until we couldn't see any.

THEN... I decided to do some research, and learned that all I did was chase them somewhere else. Unless you get to the queen in the nest, they will be back (or they will go somewhere else you don't want).

The reviews for the Terro PCO baits were fantastic, but they didn't have them at Lowes or Home Depot, so we bought Hot Shot Mini Ultra Liquid Ant Bait instead. I found some places outside and in my garage where there were trails of ants. I placed 4 Hot Shot baits in their trails. The ants mostly ignored 3 of the 4 baits. 1 of the 4 baits (one in the garage) did attract a lot of ants, and sure enough, 2 days later there were almost no ants in my garage.

After that, I ordered the higher-rated Terro PCO 6-pack from Amazon to compare.

The Terro baits came yesterday, and today I found 2 places where I saw some ants outside. I placed one and 15 minutes later, no ants. But an hour later, there was a long trail of ants coming across my driveway and were eating it up like fat kids eating donuts.

I placed a second Terro PCO bait in our front garden, where I saw some ants. Half an hour later it was so filled with ants it looked black. They were streaming from 2 different directions. This thing REALLY attracts the ants. (I recommend reading my Terro review at amazon for more details).

24 hours later, there were NO ants at either site.

BOTTOM  LINE:
The Hot Shot baits are OK.  They work, but only IF the ants go to them (and only 1 of the 4 baits I placed actually attracted ants).  I recommend the Hot Shot baits ONLY if you can't get the Terro baits.

I'm a believer in chimney starters. If you have trouble with our coals, or want them to be faster and more evenly lit then you need to try one. Yes you can do it without one but this makes it so much easier. When camping I sometimes use coals to cook food over when I need a real even temperature, like with fish or chicken and they can be a pain to light and start in a fire pit. Especially as temperatures drop. In the past Ive had to use a torch to get them going... a literal torch made by snow peak just to get them evenly warm and hot enough to catch. Instead on my most recent trip to crater lake where the temps were in 30's and oxygen was a little tougher to come by (altitude of about 6-7000FT) I used this bad boy. And life was easy. Nice hot even fast coals ready to cook in minutes. Golds down flat and is durable.
summary: Start using a chimney no matter where you are

My pressure cleaner arrived by FedEx upside down. Ok, In the excitement, I opened the slightly damaged box to find out that there was no damage. I assembled as instructed, added oil to the engine and toped up the Cat pump, all with the specified oils. I also added an hour meter, Pressure gauge  and an in line water filter. The time of truth was extremely disappointing. I had to pull on that sucker almost 10 times. Ok, I let the engine heat up while I tried cleaning a section of concrete. The pressure gauge runs up to 3000psi at idle, however as soon as the trigger is activated the pressure drops to 2500psi. I would have thought that it should maintain 3000psi as advertised. Next I turned off the unit to rest for 5 minutes and tried to start again, I still had to pull 4 times and that is holding the trigger open as to relieve the pressure in the system. I bought this unit as per recommendation of the reviews, saying that it started on the first pull, I am disappointed. I call Yamaha and they referred me to the closest dealer who is about 50 miles away. I called the dealer and was told that this is a normal condition for this small engine. My guess is that Yamaha wrote their own reviews. If I could return it, I would. Acme's return policy clearly states that once gas has been added to the unit, the problem has to be rectified by the dealer. I am going to try Amazon customer satisfaction policy. This unit is absolutely a piece of garbage. It is always hard to start even after bringing to the dealer for service. DO NOT BUY< YOU WILL REGRET> I had a Honda for 22 years prior to buying this garbage. I thought it would have been better, however it is an expensive piece of garbage. I am now going to Home Depot to buy a Honda equipped with a Cat pump. Yamaha customer service also is of no use.

Unbelievable value!  Sturdy and multi-functional, we were surprised at how easily assembled the Gorilla cart was upon its arrival here in Central Texas.  We put the new cart to hard work on its very first day!

We started by fetching full loads of heavy limestone chunks, hauling the stuff up a rocky, uneven slope with surprising ease.  Later in the day, the boys filled the cart with mulched cedar to replenish the bedding around various plantings and trees.  Finally, we lowered the cart's sides --- easy, peasy --- to heap batches of deadfall limbs and tree cuttings, then cart them away to the brush-pile for later mulching.

An important feature of this solidly-made cart is the extra-long pulling length and broad, comfortable-fitting handle.  We've had carts before with handles so short and tight-squeezed around fingers that adults had to hunch over and squinch their hands in order to pull it along.  Note that with the handle upright, it measures 45.5" from the ground.

This Gorilla Heavy-Duty Steel Utility Cart is most highly recommended..
summary: Best-built Utility Cart on the Market

I bought this feeder because we were having trouble with our old one as the squirrels were getting more food than the birds.  I researched bird feeders for weeks and the only one I found that sounded like it would cure our squirrel problem was the Brome 1024.  I was really hesitant about paying so much for a bird feeder, but went ahead and made the investment.  It has been worth the price in every way.

Now after about three months of having the Squirrel Buster feeder mounted on a post in the back yard the thing is working just as advertised.  The birds found it the first day I had it open for business and so far not a single squirrel has manged to steal seeds.  I have the feeder setup on an 18 inch long hanger bracket so that helps discourage squirrel attacks, but if one of the furry critters ever did manage to jump onto the feeder itself the clever feeding port closing system would slam shut.

The seed capacity of the Brome 1024 is huge and provides food for several weeks in our yard.  So far we have had mostly Juncos and Black Capped Chickadees visit our feeder.  The feeder is easy to fill and to clean.  It is made of nicely finished metal mostly, with the seed hopper being heavy transparent plastic.  This is a quality unit and will certainly last for years.

I think this bird feeder is the best one on the market.  You won't regret buying one.  The birds will thank you.  The squirrels won't.
summary: We like it and so do the birds

reviewText:
Just got these chaps today, and although I have not used it, I do have confidence that its something that will protect me since its made of Kevlar material and covers my lower part of my body. However, after trying it on, I found the pants will not stay on well even with a wide belt and wide buckle in the back, the belt slides out of the buckle while you are wearing it.  I tried a personal belt that I have and can use it over the pants and it will work, but the sad part is that I should not have to improvise to get this to work. If you make a product, make it so it works properly.

You can't have such an important body protection while using a chainsaw and have it fall from your hips while you are sawing, surely an accident waiting to happen. I can't give this product 5 stars because of the poor way they designed the belt that holds this heavy Kevlar chaps.

If you get this product, be ready to use your own personal belt over the chaps, it will certainly help keep the chaps from falling!

UPDATE Aug. 11, 2017
I found a large tool belt in my closet, very similar to the one that is fixed to the chaps, and it had a ring on the belt (see attached photo) to keep it from backing up while you are wearing it.  Tried it out, and the belt doesn't loosen when I bend.  The part, which I don't know what its called, probably costs 5 cents and if they add this to the chaps belt, the belt would be fall proof.

The pictures shown in the ad all show these chaps covering the crotch, but when you get the chaps, they are nothing at all like the picture. Other reviewers found the same MISREPRESENTATION of this item on Amazon.

this is my second hose of this model. Have one in the front and wanted another for the back. Tremendous water pressure, rolls itself up, doesn't destroy any flowers it runs into. With this hose I just set the sprayer to a gentle flow, place it at the base of the tree and walk away.

I gave away my traditional 75 foot hoses. They had just become so difficult to deal with, heavy, all of that coiling them up each time, and they would damage flowers.

I am sold on this hose

5-2-2013.  I have used this type of bird feeder for eight years and it has performed flawlessly. I now bought another for a family member. The feeder has two sides and can dispense a lot of feed, if you want.  I used a piece of plastic and aluminum tape to block off one side and a few of the feeding slots on the other side to reduce the flow of bird seed. Install the blocking  adpation on the insife of the feeder. I have the feeder mounted on a six foot pole in our yard so we can view the birds easily. The feeder has spring-loaded doors that will close if large birds or squirrels attempt to eat the food. The door is spring-loaded and has several pressure settings so it can be adjusted to the types of birds you want to feed from it. I adjusted it to exclude large birds (crows, blackbirds, etc.) but cardinals and blue jays are able to use it easily.

It comes with a 1" thin metal pole (four sections) and an adapter with screws that attach to the bottom of the feeder, if you want to use that. I found the steel pole so flimsy that I purchased a 1.5" diameter plastic water pipe 10' section from Home Depot and installed that in the ground after cutting the pipe to a 7' length (burying one foot deep into the ground). You can use the pipe adapter and shim it for instertion into the plastic pipe to create a very sturdy pole that will withstand any weather. For the new one I purchased the "Birds choice Mounting Flange For 1" Pole by Birds Choice" from amazon.com. It requires some shimming and drilling screw hole into the bottom of the feeder to mount, but it fits the plastic pipe better, especially if you use a 1.5" to 1.25" plastic water pipe reduction adapter fitting, also available at Home Depot.  My first pole setup has lasted perfectly for eight years, but I like the newer idea better.

I bought this monocrystalline solar panel for a solar generator to run my refrigerator in case of an extended power outage.  While I have not yet used it for my refrigerator, I have used it for a 150 Watt icemaker using a 400 watt inverter and in full sunlight, the panel output was 22 volts into my charge controller.  it provided enough power to charge the batteries while it was also running the icemaker.  Even on a heavily overcast day, the panel output was 18 volts.  The construction is solid. I took it with me on a recent camping trip and it returned with no evidence of all the bangs and bumps it took riding over rough roads with no special protection.  Even in a shaded area with very little direct sun, it produced enough power to charge the batteries while simultaneously charging several heavy duty 12-volt battery packs.  The price of this HQST was significantly lower than other brands and it proved to be an excellent value.
summary: Panel produced 22 volts in direct sun and 18.5 volts in overcast

Actually, streaky windows bug me.  Our house has some floor to ceiling windows facing the backyard and between the kids having squirt gun wars and the cat scratching at the windows trying to come in and eat dinner 6 times per day our windows are always kind of streaky.  Every once in awhile I would feel some inspirations and go at the windows with some Windex and paper towels but they never really looked that great when I was done (still streaky) and it was a lot of effort (and paper towels).

So I was more than willing to put this Karcher through the paces.  Plus the male side of me was kind of excited to add another motorized tool to my collection - the more the better.  So this little shop-vac for windows actually works.  I cleaned and squeegie vaccumed my big rear windows and they look way better than using Windex.  Pretty quick to use and very little streaking - a bit of runnage in the areas to the side of the squeegie.

So I like this product.  However, around the same time I also began using the "e-cloth" that I purchased on Amazon based upon rave reviews.  The e-cloth is low tech - it's just a microfiber cloth and it costs $15. The thing is the e-cloth gets my windows absolutely spotless streak-free with less effort than even this Karcher vac - plus cheaper, no recharging, less noise, etc.  My wife was impressed with the Karcher but she could absolutely not believe how well the little e-cloth worked.

So in summary, I definitely recommend this Karcher vac over the old chemical methods such as Windex.  I would be using this Karcher now except for my e-cloth discovery.  4-stars for the Karcher in consideration of price-value and if you are allergic to e-cloth.

After reading reviews on Amazon and other places I decided to purchase the Scotts 20-inch reel mower.  The quality of the mower is fine with no obvious flaws in design or assembly.  At first I questioned the cut quality however realized that this was due to the some weeds in my lawn being too high for the reel to cut instead of just push down.  I checked the blade adjustment and all was well.  If you have a thick lawn or one that is mixed (like mine) then this may not be the best mower for you.  If your lawn is pretty much free of weeds and not too thick then this will do just fine.  I must admit this is easier to push than using my self-propelled mower.  What a surprise!  I love being able to mow and hear the kids playing, or my wife calling out to me - and no risk of things being thrown and injuring my children.  They can actually play nearby while I mow!  Would I buy it again?  Probably so, although I'd wait until I had the weeds and non-grass stuff under better control.
summary: Nice mower but know your lawn before purchasing

I bought this last year and the first couple of times I used it it was ok. It threw the line out, but not so much that it wasn't usable. When I used it this spring, it would throw the line out within seconds of trimming. I put it away and used my little electric trimmer. Today I needed to do trimming around the garden and got it out along with a fist full of .130 size line pieces. I check to make sure they are seated and can't be pulled out, start the trimmer and I can rev it to full speed with no problems. As soon as it touches anything heavier than a blade of grass it throws both the lines at the same time. Problem can't be from wear, since it has only about a half hour total use, and I have tried the two alternate places on the hub with the same results. I bought line the next size down, thinking maybe that was the problem and it does the same thing. The really odd part is that it throws them both, every time it meets a weed.

Warranty is worthless, since you have to pay shipping and a return shipping fee. My advice is to stay far away from this product. I guess I'll head to Walmart and buy whatever they have on the shelf, it has to be better than this.
summary: Worst purchase in a long time

I have heard a rat in my attic for some time now.  I have tried Decon, glue traps, and traditional rat traps.  Nothing seems to work.  The rat seems to come and go over time. I can go for weeks without hearing him, and then I can hear him for a few days and then gone again.  I decided to give this trap a go.  After 3 weeks of use, still have not caught the pest.  So I can't review the item as to its ability to catch a rat, but I can discuss other things...

First off, very easy to use.  Probably the easiest mechanical rat trap I've ever used.  Just push down the back lever, wait for it to click and you're done.  Much less stressful than setting a traditional spring loaded rat trap.  I was disappointed that this trap does not come with bait.  The video on the product site showed a person pre-loading with a liquid bait, but noting like that came with this trap.  I did use peanut butter which isn't a big deal, just thought this should come with some sort of bait.

It's easy to handle and easy to place.  If I ever do catch that rat, I'll make sure to update my review with a success story!
summary: Very easy to set.  Does not come wth bait

reviewText: These brushes are great!  Unlike flat brushes, the more open pattern gets between the bars on the grates much better.  Additionally, while most brush manufacturers have gone to stainless steel, this is still brass.  Apart from the fact that stainless steel can damage some grate surfaces, stainless quickly begins loosing individual bristles which become stuck to the grate and are often quite hard to see.  I have been stuck in the roof of my mouth and tongue with them when they got on the grilled food.  Fortunately never in the throat.  BRASS BRUSHES DO NOT SHED BRISTLES LIKE STAINLESS, making them much safer to use.

reviewText:
I don't know about cardinals themselves, yet, but all the other songbirds feed in a frenzy from this thing, though we have a niger feeder, a suet feeder, and two other tube feeders.

I first filled it with black sunflower seeds and they were gone very quickly! Next, I used safflower seeds, which are supposedly more appropriate for cardinals than other birds, due to the cardinals' way of opening them. All I can say is, there is a feeding frenzy on this thing by juncos, goldfinches, chickadees, nuthatches, and tufted titmice. I believe a bluejay has discovered it, but so far the cardinals prefer to eat on the ground. That's ok.

This is very attractive. It's a little odd that you can't just sit the feeder on the ground, open the top, and fill it. It completely collapses, as advertised, so you have to hold it up with one hand and fill it with the other.

I'm hoping the cardinals discover it soon, but so far it is just a great attractant for all the other songbirds we love!
summary: Beautiful, sturdy, and attracts birds like crazy!

I replaced the cover of my Costco 10x20 with this item. It seemed of good quality when I opened. I did notice that the style of this cover is of the older generation of Costco canopy. It is supposed to attach to the upper bar with bungie's. It is to wide to attach securely to the upper rails and keep it tight enough to shed water. My solution was to run a cable below the rail and then attach the top to that cable. It provides a secure attachment and tightens the top enough to shed water. So be prepared to do some extra work and inovation to get this to work. The price is substantially less than what was offered by the company that imports the Costco canopy.

Crab grass is a very, very persistent tough plant to kill and not kill your lawn. Bermuda grass is not affected nearly as much as wide blade lawn grass. Crabgrass leaves are somewhat similar to St. Augustine grass, so I have seen some minor damage to my St. Augustine grass where I sprayed this product too much. But the St. Augustine grass grows back quickly with new runners. This has only happened in one spot about 6 inches in diameter.  It was the first place I experimented, so I'm sure it was my fault.

Every time it rains, you need to wait a day or two for the crabgrass to start growing fast again and that is when crabgrass is most susceptible to this week killer.  The directions say to wait another two days before mowing or cutting the crabgrass.  If you cut the crabgrass too soon, you cut away a large part of this crabgrass killer that was still on the leaves that are now lying on the ground disconnected from the roots.  The objective is to wait for at least two or more days for this weed killer to get into the roots to kill the plant from the roots - or it will just keep growing back from the roots below the ground. Do not expect to see instant results, so don't give up too soon. Think in terms of many weeks to kill crabgrass or most of a spring and summer growing season and hope the roots are dead and won't come back next year.

I gave this product 5 stars because it is the only weed killer that I have ever had any success at all with crabgrass.  Most all other products never mention crabgrass and those that do mention crabgrass, don't do anything to crabgrass.  It is a very tough weed to kill and not kill your lawn.  But if you really overdo it, you can kill St. Augustine with this product. It kills other weeds, too.  I am trying to get rid of crabgrass primarily. It's too expensive to use as a general weed killer over an entire yard. It is only available as a hand operated pump in Texas. And with a hand pump, you are not tempted to spray your entire yard with it - just spot applications directly to the plants you want to kill.  Usually, it will not affect St. Augustine grass unless you spray way too much on it.  There are a few different nozzle spray patterns from which to choose.  I have three clusters of crabgrass and I'm trying to keep them from spreading.  But with a vacant lot next door, that is next to impossible. It is loaded with crabgrass.  I have not been successful yet to kill the roots sufficiently to prevent the crabgrass from coming up the next year. But I can get it killed enough before about September that it decides to wait until next year to come up again. I'll probably have to dig up the roots to kill it permanently.

So remember not to expect instant results on Crabgrass.  Just keep spraying it at opportune moments until it finally starts to wilt. Read the instructions to learn more about the most effective way to use this product. The print is not so easy to read, but it is readable if you have good close up vision.

When you first see the leaves wilt, then you know it's going to work. However, you'll have to keep reapplying it for most of the summer.  This Ortho weed killer only works if the crabgrass is growing.  So if it has been dry for a while, intentionally water the crabgrass to make it grow in a couple of days.  Then spray it.  Wait at least two days before cutting the grass so that the Ortho spray has more time be absorbed into the roots.  The main objective is to kill the roots. Otherwise, next spring, the crabgrass will grow from the roots and you have to start all over again.  I may have to resort to digging up some of the worst ones by the roots up after this current rainfall over the past several days. The ground won't be so hard.
summary: Only Product That Can Actually Kill Crabgrass. But Requires Dedicated Persistance and Multiple Applications for Weeks.

Orbit is a great name (my opinion) in garden watering products. I have used their garden hose timer products for years and have found them to be very good on average. So when I had the chance to test this multi station smart timer, I was happy to do so. Additionally, since I already have a Rachio 16 station, wifi networked water system controller installed at my home, I knew I would be able to do a good comparison. In fact, most of this review is a comparison of the two.

Good points:
* the B-hyve has manual controls in addition to its networked phone/computer interface. So, you can just program it up or control the sprinklers in the same way you used to use your 20 year old electronic sprinter. It's a good back up. The Rachio has no manual controls. You must use your phone or PC/Mac.

* The casing is rugged, lockable and suitable for outdoor use. The Rachio is for indoor only. It has no water resistance at all.

* It has two sizes of knock-outs for the control wires. One is used for fewer and smaller wires, the other one for larger and more wires.

* Connection process to the wifi network at home worked well, and worked the first time. So did the Rachio.

* The app was easy to load and use. I have an iPhone. It is not, however, as good as the  Rachio app. It's not a disaster, but it's missing some refinement that the Rachio app has.
  - Rachio allows you to use a custom photo to represent each sprinter group. Seems like a small deal, but it is a big deal if you have 16 zone potential.
  - Seems like a lot of steps to do simple things when setting up the controller.

* Orbit just has 6 zones, but costs about as much as the 16 zone Rachio.

Overall, since my wires all come to our indoor garage, I prefer the 16 channels of the Rachio to the6 channel rugged, little unit.
Does the job and we really like the quality.

reviewText: This feeder is bigger than I realized, and heavier.  It's metal and although it has the metal hanger at the top, it seems too big to hang like that and would sway a lot in the Oklahoma wind.  I didn't want it directly on a fencepost on our fence perimeter, but did want to mount it. Also, since it's a metal feeder, I worried about accidental head hits if put in the wrong spot.  It comes with a little mount that you can screw to any wood surface.  I asked my husband to attach a small piece of wood to the top of a 2 x 2 piece of treated wood.  He then attached the mount to that, sunk the post in the ground at an appropriate level, and the feeder just slips right on.  You do have to be mindful of the direction you attach the mount to the post because it is beveled and will only sit one direction.  I set the tension to the heaviest weight it would take, and I have finally seen birds using this.  Yesterday a squirrel tried to figure it out, and after repeatedly having the door close on him, he switched to another feeder.  I think it works great.

It grows fast and big so you need a lot of room for it, I didn't expect it to take that much space but I had to move all my flowers in front of it because it was wrapping around them. I would give it at-least two feet in front of it if you plan on putting anything in front of it. Another thing, the flowers are very beautiful but they don't look like this picture, even with that I am still completely satisfied with the product.

First bought an Intex 24 X 12 pool in 2008.  Got the Innertube looking one and it was OK for the price, but after patching holes in the "innertube" for 4 years, it gave up the ghost and got big cracks.  Got a saltwater system at the time.  Can't remember if the salt water system outlasted the pool.  Bought another 24 X 12 pool, but I got smart and bought the rectangular ultra frame one.  It is defintely great and so far a 5 star.  But back to the Krystal Clear.  I just bought my 3rd one, so they've lasted an average of 3 years.  First one just quit and all the electronics are set in epoxy, so not fixable.  The 2nd one had a timer, which was cool, but it started showing "low salt" this spring and I added too much salt.  Then it showed the "service" light.  This should say the "buy a new one" light.  This new one has some more improvements.  If I had read the one star reviews, I would have saved some salt, but the price devided by 3  is definitely worth it, but that's why I only give it 4 stars.  Really works great  --  when it's working  --  Larry

This pump is a replacement for one exactly like it that has done me flawless service for over 10 yrs. It has run day and night 365 days a year and never a single problem. I have an approximately 1400 gal. in ground pond in Alabama, where the temperature makes circulation/ aeration a major importance for the fish to survive. This pump is not only able to keep the circulation for aeration and filtration up , it also powers a water feature/ waterfall as well.

  It did recently kick the ground fault and could not be reset. I took that as a sign that old faithful had gone as far as it could. I have bought another identical pump because the Little Giant Company has shown me that they deserve my loyalty. Having anything for more than 10 years without any problems or maintenance is a very rare thing in this day and age. Something to be commended and supported. I highly recommend this pump.
summary: Fantastic Pond Pump at a good price

I can't tell the difference between this pink and white filter and the blue and white filter, they both work about the same. Just got back from the gas station where the attendant groaned as he saw what can I had -- yep, the "sure to spill."

This is Oregon. No self-serve gasoline here. And the station specializes in no-ethanol gasoline for small engines. I thought it was only me, but nope, the attendant says, he fills some 40 gas cans per day and one of the worst is the No-Spill. It is extremely difficult to put the cap back on without cross-threading it. And, even with his experience, the attendant said that it usually takes him quite a bit of fussing to get the cap on right -- and if he doesn't, the can leaks on the patron's trip back home.

I will use this thing until I can't stand it anymore, but when I finally toss it aside, I am not ever going to buy this thing again.

reviewText:
I bought a half a cord of "seasoned" firewood in the fall. The stuff just would not light. So I started shopping around on Amazon for a traditional manual bellows. All the review were pretty room-temperature; seems like one of those products that you can't get quality out of even if you want to spend the money. Leather ripping, cracking, coming apart, whatever...

So the FiAir popped up with a bunch of stars so I said why the hell not? Hey, it works just fine! Three AAA's is all it takes to power this simple tool, and it works great. No more bending over and blowing on the coals for me! My friends think it's ridiculous but it was cheaper than a bellows and will probably last longer!

EDIT: Dropping down to three stars. The plastic bars at the bottom of the FiAir that act as feet are not wide enough. You have to put the thing down JUST SO or it'll roll onto its side. I learned this the hard way this weekend when I was trying to get a fire going. I placed the FiAir down on the end table without looking (was reaching for more newspaper) and it rolled onto its side and then off the table, smashing onto the hardwood floor. One of the plastic tabs that clips the "snout" onto the fan part broke off.
Just what I wanted

Trying to adjust the float angle to maintain the desired water level is an exercise in frustration. There's a tiny thumbscrew which must be tightened very hard to maintain the desired angle of the float to the valve arm. If you over-tighten, you can't loosen the thumbscrew by hand. If the valve is located in the pool's narrow  inlet well, there's not enough room to use a pliers, so you have to turn off the water main, remove the valve, readjust the float angle, re-install the valve, you get the picture. Once the thumbscrew corrodes, it won't budge and you have to replace the entire unit. If you finally manage to adjust it, there are too many loose-fitting moving parts which regularly jam or catch on each other, resulting in the constant flow problem mentioned by several other reviewers. Look for competitors' units that have a big wing nut that allows for easy adjustment and a simpler two-piece design that won't jam.
summary: Adjusting the float level is a major pain, literally

Okay, I wish I had found this years agoso does my back doctor. Here in the (rainy) Pacific Northwest, our sidewalks get overgrown with black moss (or is it mold?) in no time. I live on a corner with several hundred feet of concrete sidewalk and a wide (stamped) driveway. I own the neighborhood power washer and I dread having to gear up and hit the sidewalks. The last time it was done, I recruited some teens, but the result was...well, think zebras or prison bars.
Once the Yamaha showed up, I waited for the first dry day but had to settle for a brief break in the clouds. I had no problem at all attaching it to my power washerI just removed the "red" nozzle and plugged into the Yamaha. Once I got started, what took me by surprise is the lack of side-effect splashing. That is, when I powerwash, I usually catch <explitive deleted> from my wife about the flowers I've decapitated. With the Yamaha, the water stays under the dome. Yes, it took a bit of practice to figure out you can't "push" it over the sidewalkyou have to pull. And then I discovered if you let it hover over the surface, it works far more smoothly as when using a sweeping motion like a floor buffer. That's a little harder on my old back, but far easier than using the needle nozzles and having to meticulously overlap each stroke at just the right angle. The result was a virtually streakless sidewalk. One issue is the edgesthey're round while all of the sidewalk edges are square. I soon found that if I keep rolling over our (rounded) curbs, the Yamaha does just fine. Now I can get back to writing my new novel.

Product arrived in the original box about 30x30 without damage. We did extensive research on spreaders before deciding on the Agri-Fab 45-0462. The area to be covered by the spreader is between 10,000-15,000 sf of turf. The grass type is St. Augustine. We fertilize between 6-8 times per year as we are in Florida so durability of the spreader is important. The primary fertilizer we spread is Milorganite.

Initial impressions: Unit arrived quickly without damage. Opening the package the product is shipped in pieces and packed sufficiently to reduce damage. The parts are of a substantial quality and the finish appears durable. The hopper is fairly large for ease of filling and the amount of material it can hold. The tires and wheels are fairly heavy duty. The frame coating and painted surfaces appear to be a powder coated steel with substantial thickness for durability.

Assembly: Unit requires full assembly. You will need a socket set, small rubber mallet and needle nose pliers. Since the gear box is sent without grease you will need to take it apart to grease it. It is very easy to gain access to the inside of the gear box as it only involves 3 clips. I used synthetic grease for the gear box. It took me about 2 hours to assemble the unit and it was easy. You will want to spread all parts out first and review the diagram carefully. Follow instructions!

Use: Spreader feels balanced and smooth during use. The spreader rate is very easy to use and change as it involves a wing nut with a calibration scale. I set mine at about 3 for the Milorganite. The spreader stops material sufficiently when you move the lever to off with no leaks. A clip rotates material in the hopper to prevent clumping. Material appears to spread evenly and is dependent on speed of the operator and the opening size. Unit is very easy to clean after use as all parts have sufficient clearance to clean properly. I use a garden hose and blow the unit off with a blower that is used on the driveway.

Conclusion: The unit works extremely well and is well built for heavy use. It has no flimsy cable that either goes out of adjustment or break. Plan to take time to put it together. If you have basic hand tool skills this is a very easy task. If you don't take the time to construct the unit properly you will not have satisfactory results. Those of you looking for a well built mid grade spreader will be happy with this one. Remember to keep it clean. Take care of your tools they will take care of you.

As any suburban home owner who is incapable of growing hostas, azaleas or strawberries, due to their consumption by the bottomless pit stomachs of deer, I am always looking and testing for new tools.  The only guaranteed method is a high fence, but that is not always practical, economic or even aesthetic.  Therefore, we resort to chemical repellants, automated sprinklers and the like.  I am battling a herd of deer who live in the woods near my neighborhood whose gardens they use as a personal smorgasbord.  Because their direction of attack is varied, and there is no one specific deer path, it is difficult to use this Electronic Repellent to block all entries.  The set-up is very easy.  One does need to remember to periodically check the batteries, renew the scent, move the stakes if the location is not right.  And you can block certain avenues of attack.  However, this works better if there is a single main deer path, and your plant predation is relatively low.  Otherwise, be prepared to combine this with other weapons in your arsenal.
summary: Only one tool in the arsenal against the suburban menace

I waited the summer to write a review and I'm SOOO happy I did. SAVE YOUR MONEY!!! These things stretch, mold and rust and were only used a handful of times, by children and stored in a pool room when not in use.

I was expecting a sturdier product. This is made out of hard plastic that isn't as thick as I expected. I have already seen it bend slightly when I was leaning over while sitting on it to pull a weed that was almost out of reach.  I am trying to remember not to do that now, but Im pretty sure this isn't going to last long and that there will be sharp edges when it breaks. But while its working:

One of the reasons I wanted this is that it has handles to help you stand when you are kneeling to pull weeds, etc.  Unfortunately this is too narrow for that to work. I still have to get up the same way I do from my old kneeling pad. And my old kneeling pad has much better cushioning for my knees. There is a slight give to the kneeling pad on this, but not enough for my knees. They started hurting very quickly. Also, the bottom is pretty much flat on the ground so you can only use it where that doesnt matter. I had a metal gardening bench that raised the kneeling platform up a couple of inches which made it more versatile as to where you could place it to work from.

For sitting, the seat is at a very good height for me and I like that the top does not have raised handles making it very easy to swivel around on the seat. It has no padding at all though so sitting on it all day during major gardening efforts became rather painful. I kept trying to shift positions but it didn't help.

So yeah, Im using it for sitting work because its what I have, but Im a little worried about getting hurt when it breaks, and when I replace it I will try to get something more useful for kneeling work.
summary: I hope it doesnt hurt me when it breaks.

reviewText:
Just put oil in it and start sawing! I used this chainsaw to cut up a large dead limb that came down from an ash tree in our front yard after some thunderstorms rolled through town. Someone should have brought this up long before now.

I have had two or three Ortho products with this style of measuring cap. They all have leaked. Turn the bottle over or just tip it on its side and the product will leak. When you turn the bottle right side up, the product that has accumulated in the cap will run down the side of the bottle and over your hand.

This is not only dangerous for adults, it is very very dangerous for children. They could get it on their hands, which could spread to arms, legs, face, eyes, and even ingest it.

See the pictures. I tipped the bottle on its side for less than 5 seconds until a couple of drops appeared. I then set the bottle up and perhaps half a teaspoon that had accumulated in the cap ran down the bottle, over my hand and fingers, and some dripped off the bottom of the bottle. If I had left the bottle tipped over, I have little doubt that most of the product would have leaked out.

It doesnt seem to matter if the cap is snugly tight, or very tight as in this case. It leaks.

I live in AZ so the warm weather period is lengthy. I have had a bat problem for 10 years. They love my vestibule area. They huddle in the corners. At one time the bats did migrate south so I would have maybe a 2-3 month respite. Then many started to stay all year. Now I have nothing against bats. They do a good job and I appreciate that. BUT, they make a mess with droppings near my paver front door area. Every night. And when I'm away, I come home to a big mess. Now I've tried many suggested remedies to keep them away. None worked. I was skeptical of product like this one...and there are several. Still, I was desperate. I set the switches for "bat control". There is a "variable" and "constant" mode. That's the high pitch that the bats (hopefully) don't like. I tried both. Constant worked better. Okay, the results. At first I continued to have a problem. I have a "L" shaped entry area so I tried various locations for coverage. After about 2 weeks I started to see a change. Fewer visitors. I did experiment with location and direction control. I have found that a location on the outside corner of my "L" area worked best. I also have adopted an upward slant to the box. Now that I've had several months to test, including a month away, I have had no nightly visitors. What a relief. This product has worked wonders for me. I highly recommend you give it a try. I'm not sure of the real coverage area when walls or other obstacles are in the path. But I also have a covered patio on the back of the house and in the past the bats used that as their base of operations. No longer. You need a power outlet for this product. It has continued to work flawlessly regardless of weather conditions. For me that means hot sun, high temps, cold (20-30 degrees) nights. No problems.

UPDATE: SEPT 3, 2013-

Here in Florida rust is a major problem for Plumeria plants during the rainy/humid season.  Even the huge Plumerias in the Disney resorts are covered with orange powder this time of year.  But not mine - this stuff has kept me rust free this year.  I have 6 Plumeria plants that are about 6 feet tall, and I started using the immunox at the first sign of rust (about July 4).  It only takes about a half a gallon in a pump sprayer to treat them all (be sure to spray the bottoms of the leaves too), and I apply it about every two weeks.  All of my Plumeria trees are still growing and blooming while others in the neighborhood are losing all their leaves due to the rust.  This is good stuff.

Original Review:

I live in Florida, and I have several Plumeria plants that were covered in Plumeria rust this fall.  I had been using Orthenex as part of my standard insect/disease spray regimen, but it was not helping with the rust.  After some Internet research I found a few products that were reported to work, but could not find a suitably small quantity of any of them, so I decided to give this fungicide a try.  After a couple of applications, it seems to have cleared the rust and the plants are growing new leaves.
summary: Seems to be working on Plumeria rust

I started with one earth box (EB) last Spring. This spring I have 13 and plan for more. They pay for themselves in one season. For example, I got over 30 tomatoes from one box, and that was a low yield. I've met people who have EBs going strong after 15 years. The home made versions usually last a couple years or are <not> food grade. So if you value your time and money, invest in EB.

EBs are scientifically balanced thus following set up instructions precisely will produce the best yield. Their online forum at earthbox.com is a wonderful support. The members are wonderfully knowledgeable and giving. Some have PhDs in horticulture, yet give information freely and frequently. I usually get a response to my questions within hours, no later than a couple days.

EBs don't use "soil." They will yield more and have less disease problems when we follow manufacture instructions as to the type if potting mix is optimal. Read the forum before starting and you'll avoid common newbie errors.

I never had problems with the wheels as some reviews mentioned. With the box upside down, I insert and press firmly till I hear a snap. They never fall out. They roll easily and have a lock to keep stationary when needed. For transporting longer distances I use a mover's dolly which fits nicely between the wheels.

EBs keep the plants so healthy that they are less prone to disease, thus require less work to maintain. They have an automatic watering system option that minimizes the work further still.

I've spent most of my time as a new gardening learning about insects so I know which are good and which are harmful to the plant. I have so many good bugs in my yard that I rarely have to spray. My worst problem is squirrels playing in the new potting mix.

I had a problem with one of the boxes cracking; customer service at earthbox.com replaced it immediately and assured me the faulty mold producing the weak box had been replaced. When I bought mine, they provided a satisfaction guarantee for one year. So no risk.

Summary:
Earth Box is a great investment in one's health as the yield on home grown veggies provides optimal nutrition at minimal cost especially if we use our boxes for years to come. They are scientific, resourceful, and can be life changing. I started mine in memory of my deceased mother as it reflected her nurturing life and commitment to healthy habits. I've not been disappointed.

10/24/12
I now have 20+ Earth Boxes. ;-)

I purchased my first Hitachi RB24EAP leaf blower from Amazon almost 4 years ago on September 21, 2012.

I'm happy to say that my first Hitachi leaf blower is still working great and I've purchased three (3) more of these leaf blowers, one for our lake cottage, one for my sister and one as a father's day gift for my dad.

Before purchasing this leaf blower all my leaf blowers were electric.  This was my first gasoline powered leaf blower and I thought mixing gas and oil might be a hassle and more importantly I was concerned that the blower might be difficult to start, especially for my wife.  As it turns out mixing gas and oil is a very simple procedure and should not prevent you from buying this leaf blower.  Likewise this Hitachi leaf blower is very easy to start.  The best testimonial I can give about how easy to start this leaf blower is, My wife regularly starts and uses this leaf blower without my assistance.  My sister and my 78 year old father also love this leaf blower and both find this leaf blower easy to start.  My wife won't mix the gas and oil, she still gets me to do that for her but as far as starting goes, when she wants to use the leaf blower she just picks it up and a couple pulls and it's good to go for her.

Performance:  Yes this leaf blower is easy to start but it is equally impressive when it comes to performance.  My next door neighbour has a Echo gas leaf blower and my other neighbour across the street has a Sthil gas blower.  Both neighbours agree my Hitachi leaf blower is more powerful than either the Echo or Sthil mainly due to the tapered concentrator nozzle at the end of the blower tube.  As far as weight is concerned all three gas blowers are about the same weight and all are nicely balanced but as far as power goes the Hitachi has a more powerful air flow.

Cons:  While the Hitachi blower is easy to start, well balanced and powerful there is one feature that is missing on this blower that is included on some competitors and that is a 'Trigger Lock Button'.  I don't know why Hitachi didn't include a trigger lock on this blower, it certainly is not an expensive item to include and is certainly a useful and convenient feature.  If you have a large yard or you are a landscaping professional and will be using this leaf blower for hours a day you definitely miss the trigger lock, for the rest of us a trigger lock would be nice but shouldn't be a deal breaker.

Summer-Winter:  My wife and I have used this leaf blower year round, Spring, Summer, Winter and Fall.  In the spring, summer and fall we use the Hitachi leaf blower for grass clippings, leaves, cleaning the sidewalks, deck and driveway.  The most surprising use we get from this leaf blower is cleaning snow from the sidewalks and driveway in the winter time.  When buy this leaf blower we never anticipated using this blower in the winter to clear snow but it's awesome at clearing light skiffs of snow and much easier and faster than sweeping or shovelling.

Summary:
In my opinion this Hitachi RB24EAP is the BEST handheld gasoline powered leaf blower available.  It's compact, powerful and easy to start, even for my wife.  The blower works great in the spring, summer and fall for leaf and grass blowing and general deck, sidewalk and driveway cleaning.  This leaf blower works equally well in the winter time and works great for light snow removal.

I've purchased four of these leaf blowers and the oldest one is almost four years old.  They're all still working great and continue to be easy to start.
summary: Best Blower ...  from a repeat buyer, long time user

I've taken it down to clean it and refill and will try it in a different location.  I am wondering if it's just too close to the primary feeder.  I will report back after a few days if this works. Update: 12/7/15
Continue to love.....BUT after 6 months of intermittent use, and less than 10 successes (only because I am not home) the trap no longer will stay open. I tried cleaning it to be sure nothing was caught causing it to trip or not fully open to set. Nothing is in the way, so assume after this period of time the spring has sprung. Have contacted the company to see if they can pass on some insight to help.

reviewText: It was fine...until  I went to replace it, at which time the magnetic pull was too strong and snapped a fin off of it.  My mistake...

I have a townhouse with a typical small front and backyard to mow. I've been using a manual push mower and was ready for an upgrade. It was relatively easy to put together although I think the directions could be much improved.

I used it for the first time today on seriously overgrown grass. It was at weed wacking height and a bit wet. I set the wheel height at the tallest (3.5"), left the bag off and hoped for the best. It did a great job and I actually enjoyed mowing the lawn for a change.

I was pleasantly surprised by how quiet this is, even when it's set to "power" mode. It's light enough to operate with one hand and I like that you can use either hand to hold the lever to keep it turned on. This really helps with discomfort from gripping and vibration. It's a breeze to turn on and off. No crazy long cord to yank.

It took less than an hour for the battery to be at full charge out of the box and there was no indication of the battery running low after at least 30 minutes of run time. Removing and replacing the battery is really easy...literally lift in and out. It will fall out if you tip the mower over, which I discovered when I was wiping off the underside after mowing.

The cutting path is narrow as other reviewers have mentioned (picture cutting a foot wide strip of your lawn at a time), which is fine for my purposes, but would be insufficient for larger lawns I think.

I'm kind of excited to mow the lawn again soon :)
summary: Great, quiet little mower for small lawns

My tomato garden is on my patio so space is at a premium. To expand my gardening space last year I added a Topsy Turvy planter. I grew cherry tomatos in it, because they tend to stay more compact and produce a lot of small sweet tomatos. The main down fall of tomatos growing in the topsy turvy planter can be the lack of water because the dirt dries out much quicker than the dirt around tomatoes planted in the ground. To solve this problem I used a drip irrigation system on a timer which released a small amount of water into the plant several times a day. This kept my tomatos very happy and healthy. A drip irrigation system may sound expensive but you can buy a kit for around $20 dollars Rain Bird Patio Watering Kit PATIO-KIT. Since everything in containers gets dry fast, I have my entire patio garden watered by a drip irrigation system. After buying a small drip irrigation set up 3 years ago, it has been functioning great each summer and all my vegetables, strawberries, and herbs have been much more productive.
summary: I use it in combination with a drip irrigation system

I have no complaints about the quality of this waterer. It does exactly what it's supposed to do and works well. However, after using this for a few weeks, I noticed my chickens were barely drinking from it. The water would sit there for days and hardly go down. I had to clean it often because it would develop little brown things in the water from being closed in. My chickens would drink out of the duck's water or out of mud  puddles instead. So I switched back to my old waterer with an open bottom tray for them to drink out of and immediately we started going through a lot more water. I put the waterer on an upside down plastic bin so the ducks can't reach it and muddy up the water. That solution has worked for me and it's what I'm sticking with. If you can get your chickens to like drinking out of this then that's great! Maybe if you introduced them to it from a young age they would take to it more.
summary: Good Product But My Chickens Don't Like It

The package had everything it said it should and nothing looked unusual until I got to the very last step building it and realized that the top of the grill was not correct and I had no way to install the thermometer or cook properly because the spot where it is supposed to be screwed in is a gaping 2 inch hole that the thermometer just falls through rather than the screw in hole shown in the last step.

Not sure if there is a special piece that should have been welded on or if someone just cut the hole about 2000% too big but it makes the entire grill unusable without something ghetto to plug the hole.  One way or the other, it arrived "defective" because it is clear that this was not the intended state.

Had an earlier Lacrosse remote thermometer that died after 5 years or so.  This one has smaller digits, harder to see from a distance, but on the positive side it was much quicker to establish the wireless link than the old one, which often took half a dozen tries.

Added on 21 Jun 2015:  This unit has proven to be wildly inaccurate at high and low temps, as compared with my mercury bulb lab thermometer.  It correlates within 1 degree only in the range from 50 to 60 degrees F.  At 85 on the lab  thermometer the La Crosse displays 94 degrees!  Laid the sensor unit in a foam cooler with some ice packs and the lab thermometer, and found that at 30 F. the LaCrosse reads 27 degrees.  In service the sender is mounted on a window frame IN SHADE,  next to an old alcohol bulb thermometer which correlates much better.  Metrology was my career - we'd say that this unit is highly non-linear.
summary: Better than their earlier units, but wildly inaccurate at high and low termps.

I almost pulled the trigger on another camp grill here on Amazon, but then I ran across this one and I'm very glad I did. Obviously the reviews were important in making the decision because we wanted something that we wouldn't be disappointed in. Now that I have it I can say that this grill is perfect for camping! We actually have a RV, but like to cook outside as much as possible. Before having this grill we would buy charcoal and travel with a small BBQ. It was a hassle having to both start a campfire and grill, now we only do one. The property we stay at most of the time we have built a 3 foot wide fire pit that is surrounded by landscaping stones. The legs of this grill sit perfectly on the stones and give us about 12-18 inches above our fire. So far we've heated up our coffee percolator, cooked breakfast in a cast iron pan and grilled burgers and hot dogs directly on the grill. The best part? It cleans up easy by just letting any food burn off over the fire and then it stores flat! This is a heavy duty grill and I HIGHLY recommend it to anyone looking for one. I expect it will last many years! If you need a smaller size Texsport does sell a couple others here on Amazon. Texsport Heavy Duty Camp 24" X 16" Grill Texsport Heavy Duty Camp 16" x 12" Grill
summary: It's everything it claims to be!

I wasn't sure I wanted this when I chose it.  I'm glad I did.  Black+Decker was thinking ahead of themselves when they designed this.  It reminds me of a vacuum that is multi-functional in that you can use it as an upright and as a handheld when needed.

If you work at all on your yard when it comes to landscaping, I highly recommend this.  I cannot express the convenience this piece of machinery offers and it isn't back-breaking heavy.  Need to reach up high into some trees?  This will do the job.  Have some bushes or shrubs that are a little unruly but you need more control while trimming them?  The 4-N-1 Multi-Trimmer can be taken apart and be held by your hands.

As you can read, there are four extensions you can work with and they all do a good job.  I actually enjoyed pruning my hedges and doing a little artwork with them.  They turned out rather nice (if I do say so myself).

The only caveat that some people may have is that it is a corded item, not gas powered.  I wouldn't worry too much about that as you can use an extension cord if you need to.  You may also find most of your trimming around your home as well.

A great idea and a great invention.

You can't expect much from a $25 flag. This one does get high points for colorfastness. After four months constant exposure on a pole in Texas, winter to summer, colors are still vibrant. Getting pretty ragged, but if you want a flag that lasts without fraying, be prepared to spend more, and still don't expect too much. I'd say it's going to be able to finish the summer before it reaches a state of being so frayed that it's improper to keep flying it.  I'll probably buy another, because I doubt that you get that much more wear from an expensive flag, and this one will probably still have good color when it's retired.
summary: Colorfast. Wear... Eh. About as expected.

I was surprised that Apollo had all the features of the best tents for a much lower price. I didn't need gorilla strength so I went with this and it's been perfect so far! Dimensions are exact and the tent is pretty simple to put together. The crossbars are currently supporting 50 pounds no problem.

My only gripe is that the zippers often got stuck when I was trying to zip it all together. The zippers and material themselves are high quality and durable, but there is a seam very close to the teeth of the zipper that gets caught. It's a tiny excess of fabric, had to go around with my fingernail loosening every inch in order to finally get it to zip. This took me no joke 45 minutes to zip up the first time. I thought it would be a constant problem, but the more progress I made the easier it got. I've zipped it up about 20 times now and it's already wearing in to the point that I can zip it shut very easily with no catches. So it's really not a big deal and I urge anyone having similar problems to just patiently work the thread-line and it'll start smoothing out.

The only other complaint I have is there are minor pinhole light leaks around the seams. Not eye catching unless you're already looking at it. I may spray paint or smear black silicone over them eventually to make it 100% lightproof. For the value, I'm very satisfied.
summary: ... surprised that Apollo had all the features of the best tents for a much lower price

reviewText:
Pros:
- Compact, sturdy, easy to setup

Cons:
- Expensive
- Very hard to clean the peanut butter out of the unit
- Given the above, actual reusability and longevity is in question

My major gripe on this product is how hard it is to clean. The peanut butter can't sit in there forever, eventually it gets a little rotten and you don't want that smell in your house so it has to be cleaned. The peanut butter, once smeared to the back wall, is imbedded into the vent holes and into the cracks and corners of the inside compartment. I bought 2 units and each unit took me 20 minutes to clean with a bunch of toothpicks, qtips anda bottle of rubbing alcohol. Not well designed with this in mind at all and at this price point, I expect more. Perhaps the sellers are just hoping you'll give up and throw it out so you can buy another one from them? It's cynical to think so but go ahead and try cleaning one and you'll likely agree with me.
summary: Decent trap, albeit too expensive, nearly impossible to clean

I have an inflatable spa. I actually call it my "super classy inflatable hot tub", because hey, if I say it out loud enough times that'll make it true, right? (right?!)

Anyway, the thing about super classy inflatable hot tubs is that they do not have skimmers. Instead, the filters are underwater, and after a failed attempt at using a pool skimmer to clean it up (in the most classy way possible, of course), I needed something better. Enter Scumbug. I throw a couple of these bad boys in, run the bubbles, and they collect the gunk like crazy ... and I'm talking "change colors to an icky brown at the water line" crazy. Rinse 'em out in the wash tub & repeat. Now this is an excellent product, but given the way that they look when I'm done ... well, I'm going to have to double-down on the "call it classy to make it classy" approach to my doubleplusclassy luxury inflatable spa. Nothing so gross should ever come out of such a classy tub.

A tip - Regularly take this out & clean it, don't let it get super scummy in between washes. I accidentally had one flip over on me after it had collected a lot of gunk, and by the time I realized it had happened, all of the gunk had washed back off into the water. Washing gunk back *into* the water will definitely erode the classiness of your tub :).
summary: Doubleplus'd the classiness of my inflatable hot tub!

It's a small cylindrical propane-fired oven.  Not a fryer.  Frying by definition uses oil.  This doesn't use oil so it is NOT a fryer.  They can call it a baker or a cooker or an oven or pretty much anything except a fryer, which it is not.  I rate it a ZERO because they're liars.  It is entirely different than a deep-fried turkey.  I've been doing those for 20 years.  They're great.  Just don't try it with a frozen turkey or burn your garage down.  Note that their non-fryer will only do a turkey or whole bird.  Can't do french fries, fried chicken, onion rings, fish, or any of the other delicious cholesterol-laden and possibly-fatal-but-delicious things you can do with a turkey fryer. I'll bet these things are illegal in Texas or Louisiana unless you have a special sissy-boy certificate.

Tips:1)  Before installation, "unwind" the hose and lay it in the sun. They can easily puncture the hose (this can be fixed, though, as the kit comes with "goof plugs".

I highly recommend this sprinkler system. The bid I got to install professionally was over $2,000, which 4 of these kits covers ($130), and, in my opinion, is just as effective.

reviewText:
The La Crosse Technology 308-1451 Atomic Forecast Station is a handy way to see the indoor and outdoor temperature at a glance. We had the La Crosse Technology WS-9611U for years. It was less expensive and really provided everything we want. The 308-1451 is overkill but still a good gadget to have.

I'm really only looking for the time, temperature, and humidity. It's easy to see all of them on the 308-1451. It's nice that the time is sync'd with an official clock over the airwaves, so there is never a concern about the accuracy. I like that it is very easy to find the button to turn on the light in the middle of the night. It is a big button on the top of the display.

Like the old station, this one occasionally loses connection with the probe outside and won't show the outdoor status for several minutes. We can't find any source of interference, but it always recovers without us doing anything.

Unlike the old station, the 308-1451 gets hot with just the slightest direct sunlight and continues to read an overly high temperature for hours afterwards. Maybe, it is because of the white case of the probe, or possibly where the thermometer is in the probe. It's important to keep it in the shade at all times.

The fisherman is just silly and takes up about a quarter of the screen. I don't know why the average person would really want to see the barometric pressure or moon phases on a regular basis. I'd rather have a smaller screen and skip the extra information.
summary: Handy weather gadget with more info than you need

reviewText:
Succulents arrived a day early planted "the right way" in coco coir and perlite mixture. Sometimes you get these little succulents and they are in potting soil which isn't good for drainage. Packed extremely well, double boxed with finely shredded paper over the plant tops and a heating pack underneath. Included instruction sheet.

I bought these on a Lightning Deal to make arrangements for gifts. These usually cost about two dollars individually so it was a no-brainer. They are good beginners succulents. If your household is dry remember to water more often because this is not potting soil and does not become waterlogged like potting soil. In other words, the medium is more likely to dry much quicker. This can be remedied by either putting a piece of oasis or sponge underneath at the bottom of the soil to retain water or using glazed pots instead of glass, terracotta or plastic, or by keeping them in a humidity dome or covered terrarium.

I am satisfied with my purchase and being a person who ships many items on a daily basis, I was highly impressed by the packaging.

Edit: updated rating to reflect that plants have fungus gnats, which I have isolated to these plants. Still a good value. To fix, let soil dry out COMPLETELY to kill larvae. Put out a flytrap of apple cider vinegar or wine to catch living flies. Done.

I just recently received this gas can and couldn't wait to test it so I filled it with water instead of gasoline to confirm that the mfr claims are true.

It does work as shown in the mfr video -- for the most part.  Initially, the push button mechanism was sticking.  When I released it to stop the flow, water continued to pour out.  Once I operated the push button a few times it began to retract all the way and the valve sealed tightly.

Then I tested the auto shut-off feature.  It works, but the flow of water did not stop immediately.  As another reviewer pointed out, vacuum must build up inside the can first.  I was filling a 16 oz. jar and the level ended up being about 3/4" above the level of the end of the nozzle.  I had to hold the nozzle down at least 1" below the top of the jar so it wouldn't overflow.  As long as the user holds the can so that the nozzle is well inside the tank it should work well.

Finally, I had to try a tall shot glass, like they did in the video.  The push button shuts off the flow quickly enough to accurately fill the shot glass, but the auto shut-off isn't fast enough.  Water poured over the top of the glass for 2-3 seconds before the flow stopped.  It may not work for small fuel tanks (leaf blowers, chain saws, etc).

Bottom line -- it doesn't leak, the cap has an o-ring to seal it, the push button valve works well (after the initial sticking problem cleared up), and the auto shut-off feature is useful for larger tanks where it doesn't need to work instantly.  The plastic is thicker than most and the molding is high quality.  The threads are clean and smooth and the surface where the o-ring seals is finished well.

I'm giving it 4 stars because of the sticking push button assembly.  It is working now, but it feels cheap and doesn't fill me with confidence.  The rest of the can appears to be solid.

We use our backyard grill a lot! We even use it for our Thanksgiving turkey. And now that the weather is so nice, we'll be using it a lot more. Sometimes we don't get started as early as we would like so my husband ends up in the backyard with a flashlight to finish our meal. So when I told him that we would be testing & reviewing this Grillumintor BBQ Grill Light, he was happy to try it.
This grill light is very easy to set up & very easy to use. It comes with the 3 AA batteries needed for it to work which is a big plus in my book. When a company provides everything you need to use their product straight out of the box, I really appreciate that. You just need a tiny screwdriver to take the battery cover off so you can install the batteries. Now you're ready to use your new grill light.
This grill light can easily be attached to so many different things & be used so many different ways, not just for grilling. We do use it on the handle of our grill when we need it, but we've also attached it to the pipes under the sink when we had a plumbing problem that needed to be fixed. My husband has used it in his backyard work shed when he needs more direct light than the overhead fixture provides. I even used it to find our flashlights when we lost power during a storm a couple of weeks ago. So don't think this is a single-use product because you'll be surprised how much you use it!
We'll definitely be taking this durable grill light with us on camping trips this season. It will come in handy in so many ways. And it is weather resistant so we won't have to worry if we get caught in the rain while we're camping.
summary: Great for grilling but so many more ways to use this light!

Just like everyone else, I loved my Jora when I first got it (except for the difficult assembly). There's so much hype out there that I'd like to warn others. Don't be fooled by the claim that it is galvanized. This makes you think it will last for decades. After mine rusted, Joraform told me I wasn't using it correctly. However, I followed their instructions to the T. Every time I put material into the unit I put in a ratio of 1 part wood chips to 10 parts composting material. They said my compost was too wet and that wasn't enough. But the instructions are still the same. They said the problem is that liquid from the kitchen scraps turns too acidic and when it seeps out of the unit through the seams between the panels, it will rust the unit. The liquid will always seep out through the seams between the panels because they are not sealed. Mine started to rust in year 2 and is now completely unusable in year 6. There is only a 1-yr warranty. Check out the photos. This unit is way too expensive to be usable for only 5 years! Get one that's plastic. That's what I'm going to do. And I'm thinking about starting to vermacompost as well.
summary: This will rust within 6 years and no longer be usable

They were out of the Ames and since it had a fold down door figured this would be better choice. Got some good advice for hanging the Ames which I'm sure applies to this, here it is,

"Hanging wall mount hose reels, our engineers are telling me: For the Ames 2382561, I would recommend at least four (4) #8 x 1-5/8 long: drywall, flooring, or wood screws, and flat washers with a minimum  O.D., I.D. sized to match the screws usedand anchored into wall studs, NOT just directly to drywall. If brick or concrete, the proper fastener systems must be used or the hanger could fall and the wall could be damaged. As for the hose hanger, the flat washers are very important.  They serve to distribute the force of the fasteners across a broader portion of the plastic, improving longevity.  It is also important that the fasteners are not over-tightened or they could pull through the plastic"
