reviewText: Who doesn't love a hibachi.

This is a large patio set that comfortably sits 4, perhaps 7 cozy friends (assuming 2 sit on the included ottomans).  The seating position is low to the ground and lets you have a relaxed, reclined position.  The center table is sturdy and large enough that it doesn't shake too much if you bump it.

The wicker is coated and has an almost plastic-like quality.  I think this will help it survive out in the sun.  Despite being labeled "brown/tan", the color of the wicker is sort of brownish/dark grayish.

The cushion fabric is not soft, but it does appear quite sturdy. The cushions are fluffy and wick away water...to a point.  After a heavy soaking rain, the cushions retain some water and the fastest way to dry them is to squeeze out the water.  Without some help, the cushions will be wet all day after an overnight rain.  This is similar to other cushions I have so it's not a big surprise.  The cushions do not have a zipper so you can't replace the internals.

None of the pieces are stackable so if you plan to store them indoors in the winter, you'll have to get creative with how to save space.

I like that each piece feels sturdy and yet doesn't weigh a ton.  The wicker exterior wraps a black steel frame.  The base of the love seat is supported by a wicker weave and, to my eye, looks like the part that might fail first if someone too heavy sits on it or a kid started jumping on it.  We'll see how it holds up.

DELIVERY
-----------------------------
This set is delivered by a freight company.  I got it a few days after placing my order.  About two days before the delivery I got a call from the freight company specifying a day and a delivery window.  I told them that their delivery window (1-5pm) didn't work for me so they agreed to move it until after 5pm.  The day of the delivery, at 12:30pm, I got a call from the driver telling me "I'll be at your house in 30 minutes".  So much for rescheduling!  Fortunately, I was home for lunch and just waited around until he showed up.  The driver was very helpful and courageously hoisted the entire setup up my fairly steep driveway and into my garage.  He even carried away the pallet that it came on.

Despite the scheduling issue, I was pleased with the delivery experience.  I'm pretty sure that if I hadn't been home, the driver would have just turned around and come back during the proper delivery window after 5pm..

ASSEMBLY
-----------------------------
Believe it or not, everything you see here comes in one huge box.  For this reason, a small amount of assembly is required.  It took me almost as long to get things lifted out of the box as it did to assemble the love seat and the table.  The love seat bench seating is fastened to the back by way of metal brackets and 7 screws.  Happily, all 7 screws lined up perfectly with their brackets so it was simply a matter of inserting the screws and tightening.  The kit includes a wrench but I'd go dig out a 10mm socket wrench to greatly speed up the process.

The table is the hardest part to assemble.  You have to attach the four legs to the base and top with 12 screws.  Until you get the first group of screws in, getting things lined up is a bit of a chore.  The 10mm socket wrench was a lifesaver here.  Just for grins, I tried using their included throw-away wrench: not good.  I'd only use that if you are stranded on a desert island.

Summary
-----------------------------
So far, this seems like a great patio set that will serve my family well as we head into Spring.  I plan on spending a lot of time outside lounging around.  If anything turns negative, I'll update my review.

This item was sent to a person undergoing serious surgery and she said that she has a very musical family and they all really love it. Last I heard about it they were looking for a good place to hang it for the best effect. The surgery did not sound like it went well so hopefully this chime will help or at least add some joy. Fast ship, well packed, sounds great.

I ordered one for me but have not heard it yet (love it, see update). Will update as I use it but the receiver of the gift was very happy with it and the sound so it gets 5 stars. I have three Woodstock chimes from Amazon (the three pack of alto, tenor, and bass) and they are wonderful and very high quality. I highly recommend Woodstock chimes, and through Amazon; best price and fast ship. I hang them all in the garage over winter snowy and windy times.

Update 8-13-13:
Great sound. I mounted it near our kitchen window but it ws too loud for my wife so I moved it near our sitting room and it is great!! Highly recommended. I would give again as a gift and buy for myself.

First off, this is no flimsy wicker chair. This thing is solid and well-balanced. My wife and I tried sitting on it at the same time (probably around 300 pounds together) and it feels completely stable, which is rare for a wicker chair (or maybe I'm just used to weaker wicker chairs). The description says to bring it inside during "inclement weather" and I can see why. Although it's "weather-resistant" I can't see this thing holding up to too much rain and sun exposure. This seems like the perfect chair for a screened in porch, though. We put it in our sun-room (not technically outside but definitely separate from the rest of the house). The high back and arms make it extremely comfortable for sitting and talking or even just sitting and reading. The cushion material is the one thing I'm not sure about - it seems a little flimsy for such a serious chair.

reviewText: This thing is a monster. It's very sturdy and surprisingly heavy, and when it is fully extended it's difficult to control when water is blasting out of the nozzle. If you are petite or not in reasonably good physical condition, it may just be too much to handle. That's not a fault of the product, it's just leverage. The telescoping sections are pretty easy to extend and retract, although the flip levers are a bit awkward. Not a big deal unless you are constantly adjusting the length. The trigger is oriented on the top of the wand, which doesn't make sense to me, but it works. It just feels a bit weird. I used it today for about an hour, and there were no leaks, no issues at all. I was able to clean the gutters on my 2-story house and unclog the drain pipes, for far less money than a one-time "professional" cleaning. I also used it to clean the outside of my gutters and my siding. Being able to get the nozzle much closer to the surface cleans far better than just aiming my short wand from below. That shouldn't have surprised me, but it did.

reviewText: I ordered two packages, and nada, zilch, zero!  Can't even give it one star as not even a hint of green/growth. I bought good quality organic potting soil and nothing
I must have smart rodents, they've avoided it so far. I'll add a heavier portion of peanut butter to see if that does the trick.

When I discovered Mr. Mouse had taken up in my garage - I searched for an effective solution to eliminate his stay. In my efforts, I purchased a electronic device by Viktor (thinking it would be more humane - a quick zap and it's over), the Cube and the J.T. Eaton Repeator. I read the directions carefully and baited the Viktor electronic device with a dab (rice size) of peanut butter. The next morning, the green light was flashing (indicating a kill) but when I opened the unit - the peanut butter was gone and just some pee stains remained. No mouse! Worse off, the mouse probably got a decent zap, but not enough of a zap to kill it - stumbled off somewhere and is most likely suffering a bit too - something I DID NOT WANT! So I tried another device - the "Cube" which advertises as a "No kill, humane" device. While it DID catch a mouse - the mouse died from lack of oxygen. Unless you can check the trap every hour or so and don't care about your sleep - the mouse will die as there are no oxygen holes in the trap! Lastly, I purchased the "J.T. 421CL Repeater Multiple Catch Mouse Trap". (Viktor makes a similar one to this if you can't get the J.T.version). I baited the J.T. with a tiny amount of peanut butter for scent and the trap worked GREAT. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND it - It is a no kill trap (it has plenty of air holes and a clear plastic/metal lid for easy viewing and release). I have since "relocated" Mr. Mouse #2 to the forest. I'm sure he's happy and so am I!  The J.T. Repeater is the clear WINNER in my opinion!
summary: The Better Humane Choice and it Works!  Explore your options!

reviewText: Repair Clinic and E-Replacement Parts have parts. E Replacement Parts has exploded views of equipment. Stens has a FULL-LINE catalog for ALL kinds of 2 and 4 cycle equipment. It is a VERY good catalog! It has parts in bulk. Amazon has parts in bulk. Amazon has a Oregon tach which you touch the spark plug wire to set the idle.  It is for single cyl. 2 and 4 cycle equipment. You might want to install Inserts in spindle untapped bolt holes. Amazon has CTA insert kits with a drill bit. Put a drill bit in the hole to check the size. Select a insert kit to fit it. You can choose standard or metric. Inserts are stronger than self-tapping screws. Use loc-tite high strength on the threads. Keep backing off the tap often to prevent clogging. Use tap oil on the tap. Get several spindles to have spare on hand. Get brand name belts rather than cheap ones.

WEED B GON used to list crabgrass as a controlled weed, but the "new" WEED B GON Max dropped crabgrass. However, they then changed that to just WEED B GON and the NEW WEED B GON MAX lists crabgrass. Problem: The newest "Max" isn't sold anywhere near me and the only solutions available were said to be "RoundUp" (kills everything) or "Elbow Grease" (aka.. hand-weeding.)

I bought Drive XLR8 from a seller here at Amazon and sprayed extensive, well-established crabgrass in Bermudagrass with the recommended dose/coverage a few weeks ago. The first application was about 85% effective. There was very little browning/injury to the established grass. Just spot-sprayed crabgrass areas the are showing some re-growth, but expect the results to be near 100% control/elimination.

Most of the other lawn weeds, including broadleaf varieties didn't seem to be affected much or at all, but they can be controlled with other selective herbicides such as WEED B GON.

Bottom line: I am totally satisfied and even impressed with Drive XLR8 Herbicide. I recommend it highly, but as with any chemical: READ AND FOLLOW THE LABEL DIRECTIONS CAREFULLY.
summary: Works really well even on well-established crabgrass

At 61 years of age, it seems impossible to have been so naive about "grilling" as I have been. After several Weber charcoal units, after a couple old electric and propane Char-broilers that used Lava Rock, after so many tedious to use, hard to operate, just plain nasty grill & BBQ'S, It looks like we finally found what has been missing all along. This grill is so fast, so effortless to operate, and about my fear of grilling with only propane with no lava rock or charcoal meant no "flavor"? BOY was I wrong!
  I light this and close the lid. 10 minutes later, throw on a steak of burgers or both along with something our cats (Lucy & Ethel) will like (NO, not mice...). 10-12 minutes later, it's all finished and perfect. Of course I turn over each item 1/2 way through. It has more flavor than ANY grill or BBQ owned in my 61 years, period. It is a beautiful grill to look at, it has so many clever design elements everywhere I look, I am still kind of dazzled. There are already a hundred reviews in great detail by those who know far more than myself about grilling so this is just to point out, that it is a truly wonderful grill, easy to operate, easy to clean, a joy to look at, food tastes amazing. The BEST part? It is MADE IN THE U.S.A.
  It is such a joy to find something that offers so much, is rewarding every time you use it, and then goes further to make you feel the pride of owning something USA made. I just don't know how it could get any better? I found a website that shows a nice video that makes assembly take just 30 minutes or less providing you don't do what I did (remember, I am an IDIOT on things mechanical. I noted this video was a NON American product so wonder what differences I would find other than the propane connector? Well after putting it together and tearing it all down again, and then back together the 4th time (successfully finally!) I can direct you to the website for help but know BEFOREHAND, what differences to look for. The differences are:
-Our USA model has a front and back side that IS different, it matters that the side with 2 inside screw holes be on the back. Reason? It's because our version comes with a heavy metal bracket NOT shown in the video assembly.
-The other mistake I made was on the bottom bracket, there is a difference as to which way is front versus back. Again, the video is for a foreign model that doesn't NOT have yet another missing part, the propane tank "holder" or resting platform.

  Nonetheless, this video is an amazing help to aid in assembly. I also have no regrets as to all my build & tear-down fun, I now KNOW this grill! And everything is simply amazing in it's design to all flow together. I also had never even opened the instruction book to look beforehand since I am no good with instructions! If I had however, I would have instantly seen there were these 2 parts included that the darn video never showed. Oh well, now I am a master Grill Assembler....

  The great video to aid in assembly is at: [...]WHY don't they want you to know of a video that helps to assemble?????

  If this URL is censored out, contact me for the link. Or got to youtube at search for:
Barbecue a gas Weber Q300: istruzioni per il montaggio

6/21/2010 update:

  My BBQ was always lit by using an old fashioned fireplace lighter. Since I had used charcoal for 40+ years it was just habit. I finally decided to try my red button auto light. It didn't work. I tried everything per the book, no luck. I called Weber tech support. Oh the shock! An American company still using REAL Americans? Yep. After I regained consciousness, The very nice woman insisted she send me a whole new button and igniter assy. I told her I didn't need it as I was completely happy using my old fashioned lighter. She still insisted so I said fine. FEDEX brings it a couple days later & I check it out. Hooked up the wires to test it and immediately get a cute little ZAP (don't try this at home...) I learned where to hold it and where NOT to hold it! But it sparked perfectly every time so I installed it. About a 5 minute piece of cake. Put it all back together & it still doesn't work. So I take the old unit out & test it while in my hand. It also works perfectly so now I am confused. I pull out the burners again to look and this time pay attention. The problem is so simple....the instruction book says to turn on the OUTSIDE burner to ignite. CAN'T happen! The ignitor is directly at the small INNER burner.....So, I turn on the inner burner 1st & it lights 1st click, every single time since and that's now about 15 BBQ's later. If you have this or it's sister model 320 series, try reversing the lighting instructions. Light using the INNER burner, then turn on the outer, just opposite the directions.

  I called the very nice & helpful customer service to inform them and they agreed the book is wrong after testing my discovery. I told them I would gladly pay myself to send back their NOT defective parts and they refused & just told me thanks for the info & to enjoy my extra parts. So....when you wonder if buying American is worth the extra cost, if buying a Weber is worth the extra cost, don't wonder! It's not only worth it, it's actually priceless.
Mike
summary: FINALLY, A Clean, Quick & Easy Way To Cook

This "fireman's style nozzle"  principally  of the imported variety that  many U.S. dealers and merchandisers sell are basically complete junk.  I am on my seventh nozzle of this type. Neccessity is the progenitor of the stupiid.  I usually buy what is available at the local Walmart or Home Depot stores near Los Angeles. Invariably, each of these types of nozzles fail within two to three months. Usually, the gasket seals blow out and there is no way to repair them and of course the sellers don't guarantee anything and you cannot find the manufacturer importer to return the junk. Sadly, that's the current marketing distribution system that is sucking the US economy dry. The only way to stop this sham is to simply not buy the product.  But, if you really want or need this type of water distribution tool, you pays the price and takes the fall. Actually, a nozzle of this general design is a knockoff of the professional nozzle used by all fire departments in the U.S. today are all brass beasts that last 50 years or more, but cost upwards of $1,500.
summary: Why Waste Your Money on Imported Junk

Used to live a nightmare hearing mice chew on the walls  and studs while I was trying to sleep. Busted my fingers too many times trying to set snap traps. Have owned this product for over 5 years and it has killed dozens of field mice every year and two chipmunks :) Put peanut butter on one saltine cracker, break it in half and stick them together. Then drop it into the trap so it falls past the electric plate. Also rub a tiny bit of peanut butter on the outside grill for the mice to sample. They see there is no danger and run inside for the main course and in seconds they are in mouse heaven. Also have the accessory remote mouse that blinks its eyes back and forth to let me know that we got another dead mouse. I use some long tongs that's hung on a nail near the trap to grab the corpse, place it in a zip lock type bag, seal it and toss in the trash can outside the house.

Some days a few mice will get into the house together. Within a day or two all of them are back outside in the trash can:) Don't waste your money on other junk. This is one of the best products I have ever bought.
summary: Compared to this product, everything else is obsolete

reviewText:
We built our home in a rural area 14 years ago, and are lucky to have hummingbirds in our back yard.  So getting them to come to a feeder has been a breeze.  They're highly entertaining, and making nectar is a lot easier than messing with bird seed!

From the start, I put a hanging feeder in the front yard on a shepherd's hook. On the patio window, I placed a Perky Pet Window Mount feeder.  From the living room, I can see both feeders.  There's almost always someone at one or the other, sometimes both.  Hummer fans will surely understand how special this is.

The reason I bought Perky Pet is because locally, that's what every store carries.  This is the only window mount feeder available in the brick and mortar stores.  It's a frustrating product though.  I've never had a problem with the suction cup.  I've had petals blow off, but the hummers don't mind that.  The problem is the prongs on the back of the reservoir.  Sometime, they're going to break.  I've had them break on first filling and fiftieth filling, and even if I can get the well to stay on the reservoir for awhile, eventually it slides off.  I only mount one of these at a time, and have bought as many as 3 in a season.  I've also had them last more than one season but never more than two.  The hummers get frustrated if the food disappears.  They chase us around!

I've emailed Perky Pet about this issue, which they acknowledge.  That's been a couple years ago, and I bought a new one this spring, because last year's broke.  Well, two weeks ago, a prong broke off, and I know I'm on borrowed time.  I will not buy another of these, since the problem hasn't been resolved.  I'll look for a window feeder by another manufacturer.  This is the only Perky Pet feeder I've had a problem with, and I would not recommend it.  I know I've bought at least 20 of these, and every single one has broken.  I've only bought two for the shepherd's hook!
Heh, heh, heh, no more moles..........

The Filter Pump I got with the iPool was (as many reviewers have said)a joke.
You could barley feel any water flow in the inlet and outlets of the pool.
But thanks to upgrading to the Intex 56637EG, the water flow is more like a real
filter pump should be and is very strong.
I am a bit confused as to why someone would buy the 56637E without a fault breaker for
more money, but to each his/her own.
This is a very strong pump, but I have ordered a second as back up.

Oh yeah, one more thing, when cleaning the (A) filter, you can actually remove the filter with
the pump running, but not with the pump off because when the pump is running, water will only
enter at the bottom of the filter well; when the pump is off, pressure from the pool, forces
the filter well to fill up. Also, when cleaning the filter, it may look clean (white) but don't
let that fool you, as most of the sediment is trapped in the inside folds of the filter where
you can't see it; just spray off the filter and out comes brown stuff you would never see by
just looking at the filter.
Addendum:
After running this pump/filter for two seasons (my seasons are about 8 months long as I live in the desert) for an average of 6 to 8 hours a day, I can say this is a very strong pump and I have had no problems with it.
Something else I have learned about the filters, is that you don't need a bunch of them, as I have been running off the same filter for the two years, I just unscrew the top as the unit is running, spray off the filter, put it back in, close the lid (not to tight), turn off the power, unscrew the air vent and let all the trapped air out, and then start up the pump again.
Addendum 1: I have been using this Pump/Filter for over three years now with NO PROBLEMS.
Intex has a new number for this Pump/Filter; it is: 28637EG
Addendum 2:  This is the start of the 4th year on this pump.  I ran the pump for a few days, and I noticed the GFI was tripping, after four or five restarts, the pump impeller started to make an uneven sound, and then it just stopped. I will use the back up pump I have, and have ordered another back up.  At $45.00,  three years of service is acceptable.
I disassembled the bad unit, and the impeller had no damage, so the motor windings (potted) went out. I pulled the impeller and plastic coated magnet (all one unit) out, and anything else I could use for spare parts, and installed the new pump.
Also, at minimum before you toss the old unit, clip the extension cord and GFI plug, as the 25ft cord and plug are worth about half what you are spending on the whole pump!
summary: Replaced iPool Pump/Filter. What a difference

So far, this seems to be working.  This summer has been worse than usual for fruit flies -- maybe because I'm keeping more fruit in the house.  However, they were seeking out and attacking "sweetened" beverages (like my lemonade and coffee), and I really wanted to corral them in one location.

Enter the Terro Fruit Fly Trap.  It was smaller than I expected, but that's OK.  As long as it works, I don't care how large it is.  Set it up near the primary "swarming" location, and waited.  Within a couple of hours, the opening was covered with the little buggers.  OK -- this looks promising.

Next morning, not much action, and I noticed a couple of errant flies making a bee-line for my coffee.  But that was way fewer than normal.  Later, I noticed that again the opening was populated by several dozen flies.  So it's still working.

It's now been 4 days, and I've seen maybe 2 flies today.  That's all.  I'll leave it out for the duration (30 days), and then see what's left.

Bottom line: it has been effective against my fruit fly infestation, hasn't involved spraying a bunch of chemicals around, and is virtually effortless once it's set up.  WIll purchase again if necessary.

Just some things to keep in mind --- the first hassle, believe it or not, is getting the PWS [Personal Weather Station] out of the box as it has two VERY TINY phillips screws attached to a disk and then attached to the PWS itself. I can well understand the frustration another reviewer had getting those tiny screws out of there as a normal or even mid-size phillips head screwdriver simply won't work and you just about need those eyeglasses kit tools and/or specialized very small phillips head screwdriver to get those seemingly welded [! -- they are screwed into the PWS very tight!] screws out of there. Mercifully, I had to dig around my electronic toolkit downstairs and dig up a small phillips head to do the job. My guess is that these are so-termed "security screws" but it's a hassle. Anyway, BE SURE to have your hand UNDER the PWS after you're working on the last screw to prevent the PWS from then falling out of its carrier. Chuckle time! Note the directions which say to remove the hugh advertisement stick-on on the face of the PWS in order to use the PWS!  Duhhhh! Ya' gotta' love it!

Meanwhile, when you're waiting [and waiting!] for the so-termed "atomic clock" [** Even NIST itself rebels against such wordage as "atomic clock" and state that virtually all of these commercially advertised "atomic clocks" are in actuality, and I quote, "radio controlled clocks" from a radio received signal [60KhZ] coming from Fort Collins, CO, AKA, WWBV] to click in, you may have a long wait! It takes time! Until that "code" is received and much depends on your geographical location, the receiver itself and where the PWS is located, you could wait up to 10 hours or more before you get the signal. You'll know when you have it as the satellite icon [with NO blinking] stays continually ON just to the right of the time. Note too, you MUST go through the time setting user selected 10 steps [set WWVB time to ON, set time zone where you are, DST (if wanted so that AZ and HI folks can skip it since those states don't use it ---why we don't chuck DST escapes me but that's another forum ...], 12/24 hour clock , hour, minute, year, month, date, F/C temps] or you'll wind up spinning your wheels. The "instructions", such as they are, are virtually useless so, roughly, find the "TIME SET" button on the right side of the PWS  and ==HOLD IT IN== until you see the word "ON", at this point ==release== the TIME SET button and go down to the PWS right side UP and DOWN button arrows, the PWS will cycle through =10= mentioned settings and on ==EACH ONE== of them you then confirm EACH individual setting by pressing the TIME SET button ONCE, then go back to the down arrow for the next user setting, confirm with the TIME SET button and basically repeat the process and "set" each setting. For example, the LAST setting will be Fahrenheit/Celsius [it is set to FAHRENHEIT by default] so press the TIME SET button to "confirm" that and the PWS will be "set" to read the degrees in Fahrenheit. The process is tricky and can be a bit frustrating so take your time! Of note, I set the clock MANUALLY [using the arrow keys] figuring the WWBV signal and "sync" will eventually pop in by itself at around 2AM [I was working late doing some research on one Harry "Chippy" McNish and my anticipated defense of Chippy getting the Polar Medal posthumously -- long story, that one], anyway, around 2AM, the satellite icon suddenly popped in and the PWS automatically set itself up with the WWBV time, day of the week and the correct date. The satellite icon then then stayed on permanently.

I like the idea that the PWS uses BOTH an included AC plug-in 5 volt AC to DC plug-in adapter ==AND== a battery back-up [Note! NO batteries are included! The PWS takes ==3== AAA's in the PWS  unit itself and then ==2== AA's for the remote and, mind you, there is only ==ONE== remote with no provision in this PWS for any more than ONE remote which explains why I have other PWS's in the house that offer more readings and the use of multiple remote sensors [on other models] but 'not' this one  which only offers a single remote sensor.  The PWS has a pleasing and colorful look about it [although I could do without the cheesy flower pot and daisy icon] and I'm quite satisfied with the indoor/outdoor readings in terms of accuracy.

As for the remote and the first rule of giving it time to reach the outside temperature AND the blue bar graph signal connection icon [if you're getting nothing, press the side mounted HEAT/DEW button which will help in the remote 'finding' the main unit and vice versa, if still nothing, reinstall the batteries], anyway, nothing can mess up a remote more than poor placement of the remote sensor unit in terms of poor, inaccurate or, indeed, no reading whatsoever!  If you live in the north with very cold temps, I strongly recommend using two AA LITHIUM batteries for the outside sensor. Last week we had temps at night of MINUS 23 [!] degrees up this way [in the upstate NY Adirondack mountains area] and last night was minus 18 degrees with a wind-chill estimate [with the wind] of minus 42 degrees. Lithium batteries [over alkaline batteries] deal very well and sustained very cold weather. So too, even during the day, keep the remote in a totally SHADED area for the most accurate readings! It surprizes some folks on a very cold yet bright sunny day, the outside remote suddenly starts 'rising' [!] but this is often caused by the sun reflecting off snow and affecting the sensor so that while your local weather folks are reporting let's say 15 degrees, your outdoor sensor that is =not= in the shade, may be showing 25 to 30 degrees [!] but ONLY because of the effect of the very bright sun on the outside snow being reflected upward and which duly throws the sensor out of whack. Look for a totally shaded area [on a roof protected outside porch would be idea] and preferably do ==not== have the sensor in the face of any wind [or whirling snow for that matter] for the most accurate DAY TIME readings. Fresh batteries [NONE of which are included in this PWS] are a must and, as I said, lithium is highly recommended for the outside sensor. They last a long time and do very well in very cold weather. And yes, the PWS WILL work without any batteries in the main unit via the AC adapter but the 3 batteries in the main unit serve as a back-up in the event of power loss. As for the outside remote, those two AA batteries are obviously required.

I use three PWS devices but they do different jobs although some things are obviously duplicated. For example, because winters up here can often be extremely cold, I use one PWS that is 'dedicated' to checking the temp in my downstairs basement back utility room where the house 50 gallon water heater is located and outside submerged water pump piping enter the house from the outside and the big fear in sustained minus weather is cracked pipes so I monitor the temperature of the utility room [with an alarm] where the water heater and assorted house piping is located. The second sensor goes in my attached but unheated garage. Another PWS offers digital pressure readings with pressure reading tracking  so that the pressure "rising or falling" can be both visualized and recorded. Ditto the dew point, heat index and read-off CO2 because to supplement all electric heating [which can get mighty expensive!], I use propane ==in conjunction== with a total electric heated and powered house or else the electric bill [for a two level house] would, be staggering. I even have a temp sensor in the attic for summer monitoring as circulated air in an attic is important in extreme heat situations during the summer. Enjoy!

Doc Tony

This new Troy-Bilt Gas blower works Great! First thing I wanted to cover is the starting, one reviewer complained of starting issues so I purposely added gas I knew was sitting in my garage for a number of months, 2 cycle mix of course, anyway I followed the Troy-bilt starting directions and it started and ran on the second pull! It also ran fine with plenty of power. The mixed-flow fan design pulls in and pressurizes a high volume of air, then creates a powerful 650 Cubic feet per minute  that clearly is the most powerful hand held Gas Blower I've ever used! The multiple side air intake holes don't get clogged like my old blower, I'd have leaves or my jacket stuck to the air intake, not a problem with this Troy-Bilt blower.  Flip and Go Starting is an option if your rotate cuff is acting up or you have other issues that make using a pull starter difficult, Its a AC powered electric starter that simply engages on the side of the engine and press the starter button, Flip and Go works on other Troy-Bilt products, including string trimmers, lawn edgers, leaf blowers and cultivators. Sadly Amazon doesn't offer it at the moment but is available at retail dealers for $39.95.
summary: Easy to start powerful Hand Held Blower!

My house is located midway down the side of a hill, and the deer like to congregate around the front door area, which puts all my plants at risk. I ordered this incubator to hatch some chicks as a hobby. Last year I tried hatching for the first time with a similar incubator of a different brand but for a handful of reasons it didn't go so well. This year I learned from my mistakes and I'm hoping for a better hatch rate. Like I said, I'm just doing this for kicks but if you are really serious about a high hatch rate you probably want to go with a more advanced incubator.

PROS:
I really like that this model is a combo with the fan and turner instead of having to buy everything separately. I also like that the styrofoam has a plastic covering to protect and possibly make more efficient. With PATIENCE and careful tweaking you CAN get this machine to hold a fairly constant temp (fluctuates about 2 degrees at most).

CONS:
Fan and turner are loud and vibrate. The built in thermometer and hygrometer are basically useless INVEST IN A GOOD ALTERNATE METER! The built in therm is off by about 5 degrees and the hygro is off by about 20%. The water wells are hard to see and hard to fill - I've gotten it wrong a couple times and it leaks all over the place.

Conclusion --> This is not a plug in and forget machine. Take the time to get the machine up to temp and then monitor for at least 24hrs before putting eggs in. If you change the temp, just twist knob a tiny hair at a time and wait for results. Remember - it may take several minutes for the machine to adjust and for your meter to detect the change. Once you do this it IS a stable machine. Do not trust the thermometer included - get a really good one that you know you can trust.

reviewText: fit and works

Update: For even better performance and non-stickability, season the bad boy. Preheat your oven to 325 degrees, wash your 6558 griddle with detergent; I recommend using a chain mail scrubber if you have baked-on crust. Since the griddle is technically cast iron, you may see rust spots as you'd do with a regular cast iron skillet. Just scour the rust off with a scrubber (or steel wool if you need to). Rinse and thoroughly dry the griddle. Pour 1/2 tsp of vegetable oil on the top of the griddle and rub the oil in with a paper or cloth towel. Cover as much surface area as you can. Flip the griddle over, apply another 1/2 tsp of vegetable oil and repeat. Be sure to rub the sides too. Once rubbed with oil, bake in the pre-heated oven on the center rack for an hour. Clean-up is now a lot easier than ever.

I've read a few reviews that claim that this griddle is heavy. I placed it on our bathroom scale and it weighs a back breaking 4.8 lbs. In all fairness, it weighs just about the same as the right half grate it replaces on the Q. With that out of the way, I like to say that this griddle is the perfect companion to the Weber Q (we have the green Q 1200). It cooks unconventional grill items that are otherwise impossible or difficult to cook on the standard grates, such as fish, scallops, shrimps and just about any breakfast items (hash browns, eggs, bacon strips, links, etc.). It also acts as mini flattop great for flipping burgers, French toasts and pancakes.

Ever since we acquired this griddle, we've done all of our breakfast cooking outside of the kitchen and on the Q 1200 in our balcony - easy clean up and don't need to run the vent fan or deal with cooking fumes permeating throughout the home. For an awesome pancake recipe, look up "Instant pancake" by Alton Brown, easy to make and cooks exceptionally well on this griddle. We also took the Q 1200 with us on our July 4th weekend road trip and made scrumptious breakfast with it.

If you cook your steak sous vide style, such as an Anova Precision Cooker, the Weber 6558 griddle will create a gorgeous seared crust in 30 seconds at 500 degrees (see photos).

Pro-tip: Grab a can of Weber non-stick spray for use with this griddle, it's the only non-stick spray you'll ever need. While many users mistaken the porcelain-coated surface as a non-stick coating, it is not non-stick. If you toss your food onto the griddle without greasing it up first thinking it's non-stick, you'll have a very rude awakening.
summary: Great Weber Q accessory to have, when you need it!

reviewText: Come spring and summer every year, we have ants in the house.  I've tried the Terro and Raid liquid ant baits, and while they worked ants kept coming back.  With the mentioned baits, I would see a lot of ants feeding on the bait (on the Terro, hardly see any surrounding the Raid ones) and also a bunch of dead ones inside the bait.  The ants would disappear, but after a while they would be back.  I had a particular bad ant problem this year where I constanly see ants in my kitchen floor.  I placed the Maxforce bait in their path, after finding the bait, they fed and apparently brought food back to the colony as I did not see a single dead ant inside the bait receptacle.  Up to now I have not sees any more ants in my kitchen.  The product itself is a gel, and the included receptacles have 4 sections.  I would squeeze a small gel bead into each section and set it.  I have place a few around the areas where I saw ants, so far the one in the kitchen keeps getting eaten (as the bait beads are gone) but I don't see any ants - so I am hoping that it keeps killing the colonies.  Even though the tube cost more than the other brands, it is well worth it as it will last a very long time, since only a small amount are used.  So far for it it worked better than all others I've tried.
summary: It works! No more (at least I don't see them) freeloading ants!

reviewText:
We have a vole problem in our yard every year. Voles are about the size of a field mouse and look similar but they run through the grass eating the grass and roots leaving brown lines in your yard.

The best way I have found to get rid of voles is to use a mouse trap at the beginning of the runs. I can usually find them holes in my mulched beds and I just place them with the opening over the hole. I have tried other mouse traps and they are worthless. With these I have caught the little critters in sometimes just a few minutes after placing them.

The traps are a little gruesome but they do kill the voles instantly which I feel is way more humane than a sticky trap. It is also safer than using poison because other animals can get into the poison or eat the poisoned animals.

The traps work like a classic mouse trap but covered. A spring loaded metal bar is pulled back and held in place in a notched area. When the mouse or vole enters the trap, it steps on a floating piece of plastic. The weight of the animal releases the bar from the notch and the mouse is crushed instantly by the force of the bar.

These little covered traps will generally not cause a problem with catching other unwanted animals although one time I did catch a snake who was going through looking for rodents.

The traps are relatively easy to set especially the first time. They are meant to be for individual use but I can usually get 5 or more uses from each trap. I use a mouse attractant gel in mine but you could use peanut butter or bird seeds etc. Once you have caught a mouse or vole, you can pick the trap up without coming into contact with the animal and press the lever in the back which can release the dead animal from the trap. I usually go out back and drop them in the field because we have lots of hawks looking for food and they are always gone in a few hours. If you prefer you can release the dead mouse/vole into a trash bag.

I paid $24.43 for this set of five traps and feel that was a pretty good value at less than $5 each.

Thanks for reading my review, if you have questions let me know in the comments

:-)

Becky Brooks
summary: D-Con Mouse Trap Review - Awespme for Voles too!

I received this item to test and review. This is my opinion: The construction of this light is very solid. The solid magnetic base is heavy enough to offset the 24" gooseneck light so that it doesn't fall over. The magnets are strong and will hold the light upright and even extended out fully from a flat surface and up to about a 45 degree angle. The light is bright and a bit on the bluish side of the spectrum as you can see in the pictures. The orange light in the background is actually a normal tungsten bulb, so the camera has reduced the blue in the picture to make the BBQ light look more "white". You can see the light attached both with the magnets on the right side and with the clamp on the left. One problem I ran into was that with the long neck of the light, you have to bend the light away from the grill to be able to close and open the cover. The best place on my grill to mount it was simply with the magnets on the right side. I tried mounting to the grill cover handle, but it was just too awkward when opening and closing the cover with the 24" light whipping around. The light color makes the items on the grill look pale, so it's not easy to see how "done" it is just by sight. I would prefer a more tungsten, or at least closer to about 4500K, colored light when looking at food. That said, this light is probably more useful around the house than on the BBQ. I agree with another reviewer that it makes a good work light in the garage or workshop. It could also be clamped to a desk for direct lighting in your craft or other workspace. I did review another BBQ light which is OK -- I like how it attaches though: HOMEAN Super Bright 10 LED BBQ Grill Light
summary: Advertised as BBQ Light, but better for general Task Lighting

reviewText:
Late this summer our 2,200 gallon goldfish water garden developed a large "muck" build up that no amount of beneficial bacteria would resolve & it was too large a job to vacuum out. I realized that the answer was more circulation/air in the water. After lots of online research I chose the Airmax KoiAir .

I installed it a few days ago and here are my initial thoughts:

Pump> appears to be very good quality; is heavy and has 4 rubber feet on the base and a carry handle @ the back; easy replacement/maintenance namely a filter and the diaphrams [they do wear out after a while]
Weighted airline> love it! as soon as it hits the water its sitting on the bottom and out of sight
Diffusers/plate> plate is weighted so it sinks immediately; diffusers have a rubber sleeve that appears to be replaceable
Spring Clamps> I don't trust so I used two screw clamps [found in plumbing supply stores] to make sure the airline stayed attached.
Surprise Included> discovered that the connector for the diffuser plate is a "check valve" ;was very pleasantly surprised at this [if your unfamiliar with check valves, they are a back-flow prevention devices i.e. they only allow flow in one direction, this protects the air-pump].
Price> after researching several brands of aeration kits for water-gardens I found the KoiAir not the cheapest or highest but the "best bang for your buck"
Installation> was a snap and took all of about 10 mins [took me longer to decide where to put the pump!]

The air-pump is bigger than it appears in images! Measuring about 8 1/2" front to back x 6" wide x 6 1/2" height; Airmax recommends that you place pump on something to keep water out [i.e. heavy rains], I used a 1 1/2" thick stone block. It is also recommended that you cover the pump for protection from sun/rain, etc. I ended up buying a Airmax True Rock cover. It hasn't arrived yet so will do a review on it when it comes.

NOTE: this kit is designed for use in "decorative" backyard Koi/goldfish/water-gardens. It is NOT for a farm [fishing] pond or lake which holds a much larger volume of water than backyard/decorative ponds and thus require a much larger aeration system than the KoiAir1 or 2.

UPDATE 3/2017
With Spring here [well almost] I removed the leaf net from my pond and I am amazed! The pond hasn't been that clear for years! If you have problems with muck / leaf build up in your decorative ponds I highly recommend the Airmax KoiAir it does the job!!
summary: GOOD QUALITY AT A GOOD PRICE

reviewText: I started out using chlorine products.  Prefer Bromine in the hot tub and these do the job.

Up front, I want to note that this "portable fire pit" will do what it says it will do. However, it could have been designed infinitely better.

After having spent a lifetime at camping in the outdoors all over the country, and having earned my college degree in Parks and Recreation (which includes maintenance and design), and serving for 25 years as a park ranger/park manager, I can honestly say that I actually know a great deal about every sort of fire device which has ever been contrived. In fact, I have designed several myself.

Here we have a solid copper bowl, a steel three-legged support, a wire cover/screen, and a vinyl rain cover for when the unit is cool and not in use. The idea here is to build a fire in the bowl so that folks can sit around it, roast a few marshmallows or hot dogs on a stick, and enjoy the evening. You can do that. The company recommends that you put sand in the bottom of the bowl and I wholly agree with that. Here are my issues:

1. The copper is too thin. A really hot fire could potentially weaken the walls and possibly melt through over time (hence the sand in the bowl helps to alleviate this problem but I still would much limit the size/heat of the fire.)

2. The feet on the tripod support are entirely too small at the base. If you have the weight of sand and firewood in the bowl and the ground is soft, this thing is going to sink. If it sinks on one side only, this could cause some difficulties, depending upon how you are using the unit. I think it's also too flimsy. So you're probably going to need to set this up on some thin bricks if you plan to use this in your yard, (especially if you plan to use the same spot all the time.)

3. There are no air vents in the bowl. (This may have been an intentional design feature to keep the fire from getting too hot.)

4. Cleaning out the ashes, (without taking your sand with it), is somewhat of a hassle, a very slow and dirty project. This, I might add, is a problem with almost all campfire rings and fire pits. You MUST remove ashes after use because they are caustic and, (especially if water gets in the bowl), the bowl will deteriorate.

There are other minor issues but those are the four chief drawbacks as I see them. I would characterize the unit overall, as "a looker" rather than a highly functional unit. Given the materials used, I would have made it half the diameter that it is, thus making the copper twice as thick. The same goes for the tripod supports and I would also have added round foot pads which were at least six inches across. A few air holes low on the sides to enhance combustion would be nice too.

Using this unit for cooking, (such as a pot of beans, or laying a grill across the top) would definitely not be recommended.

I really liked the idea of the copper bowl in terms of quality materials but I think the designer got pretty far afield in terms of utility. I wish they would have called me (or another outdoor recreation professional) -- I would have steered them in a superior direction.

In summary, if you want a small campfire, two or three evenings during the summer just to enjoy the night and entertain the kids a bit, then this will probably work for you. However, if I tried to use this unit as I do use my own portable fire pits, (I currently have two, both home-made), it would be in the junk-pile in about a week.

reviewText: Originally bought one of these units a few months ago to target bats in my storage shed that I store many items useful for my rental houses. It is a metal shed [about 2000 Sq Ft] with only 1 small window. Perfect place for bats to shack up. I have a motion sensor alarm that alerts my house if ANY intruder moves & after no false alarms for 5 years suddenly it became obvious that bats had moved in. MANY people have bats without knowing it. Bats are almost helpless if anything interupts their sonar sound system & this unit stopped my false alarms almost instantly. After I saw how nice it worked I moved it under my house that I live in. Most houses in Kentucky have no basement but a crawl space to sevice plumbing,wiring ect. My crawl space is about 3-4 feet tall with plastic on the ground neat & clean. Suddenly had some rodent move in [maybe a squirrel] that started tearing up some insulation. After no success in trapping it I went to my shed & got my ET pest unit & the varmint moved out as suddenly as it had come in. This unit is so versital in repelling so MANY different kind of pests & uses NO harmful chemicals or poisons. I am ordering more of these units to put under my other rental houses because it is trouble free,not noticable,works 24-7 & I calculate electric cost at about 25 cents per month. To control almost all pests just set the pitch to "Variable" & it will drive em all out with it`s inconspicuous squalling sounds. It has a test button you can push to hear the sound at YOUR ear level & that will convince you that it will drive the pests crazy when they hear it at THEIR ear level. Nice product,easy & clean to use & a whole lot cheaper than an exterminator. Trapping gets only the dumb ones. This things cleans house.

Not sure where Amazon was aiming their 'recommendations' regarding this wonder. They know everything about me and my cooking habits and I wish they had alerted me to this very clever (and easy) appliance.
I turned on a home shopping network a few days ago and this was a special value for that day. Fifteen minutes after they introduced this after watching their demo this was ordered with a cookbook and some accessories.
I followed the instruction and roasted a 16 lb turkey (the max capacity for this "fryer"). The cool thing is you can cook it stuffed, unstuffed, whatever. The end result was perfection. Crisp skin, moist fully cooked meat. Later, I cooked a brisket because it was cool and the perfect beef brisket day. This is a versatile appliance that can be used to cook a lot of dishes, but for the turkey alone I am delighted. I am no cook and holidays are always dreaded because my convection oven is large but won't accommodate a turkey and everything else. Right now I have boneless prime rib cooking away.
This is fairly easy to clean, can handle plenty, and makes me look like I know what I'm doing. It's a space saver, too. Attach a propane tank, power up, and let it cook away on the patio out of everyone's way. Monitor the cooking and when it's ready, start slicing. Before I forget, it is very similar to my Phillips oil free fryer except for its huge capacity and it has a convenient dripping collector so you can even make beautiful mahogany gravy.
So 4*? I'd go with 5* except I haven't had it long enough to see if it has anything I don't like. Tune in after Thanksgiving.
summary: Wonderful Appliance That I Think Will Make A Huge Difference

I've had this model for one year and the factory paint is flaking off even though I'm running it at normal temps. I have added a second analog thermometer so I can keep an eye on the temps across the chamber. Out of the box it can be 50-75 F difference between the one near the firebox and the one near the chimney. I ended up buying a tuning plate from BBQSmokerMods (dot) com, for $80 which has helped even out the temp quite a bit.

My main complaint about this unit is that it's made from very thin steel. Probably 14 or 16 gauge? Whereas, a quality made smoker would be constructed with something like 1/4" steel. It doesn't seem like much of a difference, but trust me, it makes all the difference! The thicker steel allows the unit to retain heat longer and slows down heat fluctuations.

Just to give some background, Oklahoma Joe's used to manufacture their smokers from steel pipe right here in Oklahoma using real oilfield grade pipe line material; heavy stuff. The Oklahoma Joe's brand was sold to Char-Broil and it was downhill from there. They moved manufacturing the to China.

If you still want one built like the original Oklahoma Joe's, check craigslist. Usually someone will have one sitting in their backyard that they do not use anymore. If you have the cash to spend, check out Horizon Smokers. They took over where Oklahoma Joe's left off as far as manufacturing quality smokers here in Oklahoma. They're not cheap, but they are QUALITY.

As for this unit, I will be selling mine before next summer and upgrading to an Old Country Pecos model which are made here in the USA with thick steel.
summary: Ok for a beginner, but not a seasoned pitmaster

reviewText: Excellent...

I've purchased the Silky PocketBoy 170 (mm) in coarse (Red), medium (Black), and fine (Yellow).  All are very well built, very durable, and very effective saws.  Further, the PocketBoy 170's come with a smooth, close-fitting, clear plastic case that protects the rest of your gear if in your backpack, waist pack or back pocket. Finally, replacement blades for all 3 are readily available on Amazon (from Japan), and do arrive quite quickly; replacement blades mean field replacement is possible, while with competitive product you might as well just buy another saw instead.
I have compared the medium (Black) and coarse (Red) PocketBoys with competitive saws from Corona, Ace Hardware, and Coghlan's, and found that the PocketBoy Red (coarse) does outperform the others in a "number of strokes" test to cut through a 4" hardwood branch. (Corona a close second), PocketBoy Black (medium) ties with the others - but the cut is much cleaner and effort 'smoother' with the PocketBoy.
If you're looking for a good backpacking saw, give the PocketBoy 170 Red (coarse) or Black (medium) a serious consideration.
summary: PocketBoy 170 (Black or Red) plus Case makes a great backpacking saw or landscaping tool

The purpose of this device is to provide a true cold smoking environment. Unmodified, the Bradley smokers will provide a semi-cold smoke by turning the main heating element off. Unfortunately, the "biscuette burner" remains in the smoking chamber, and heat soon builds up to temperatures that will melt fat and cook your product. That's undesirable when making foods intended to stay raw during the smoking process, such as bacon, cheese, and many sausages.

This device provides a simple solution by putting distance between the smoke generator and the smoking chamber. The heat stays in the adapter box, while the smoke cools as it travels upward to the main unit. Assembly is simple (no tools needed, just lift the biscuette burner off the main unit and place it on the adapter, then attach the adapter plate where the burner was) and the steel adapter is a safer alternative to home-fabricated solutions made out of cardboard boxes, which have the risk of catching fire. The unit was surprisingly sturdy and the door offers easy access to the water pan and discarded biscuettes.

All in all, this is a worthy accessory for the Bradley owner who wants to cold smoke foods with no risk of overheating the product.

Update: I had the 30" and it was a little tight for some of my cooking needs. I upgraded to the 40" and have not needed more. A rack of ribs fits whole, unlike the 30th". A brisket will still need to be cut in half, but this is better as the flat is usually done before the point.

I've cooked two briskets and 2 pork butts and they fit with ease, also one brisket, 4 racks of baby backs, 4 sausage rings and 12 chicken legs.

Stands up to Texas bbq critics! Cooks just as good or better briskets than pellet smokers.  I have cooked 10 briskets and 6 pork shoulders since I bought this and numerous racks of ribs. Soooooo easy! You can sleep during that 12 hour cook time (after you put the smoke on the meat) and know that the heat will remain low and steady and use the built in probe to check the temp without constantly going outside to check. Won't go back to a regular pit ever!!!

Brisket, chicken legs, pork shoulder, ribs, and  wings all get the thumbs up from family and friends.

There isn't a smoke ring, but don't let that fool you. The flavor is there and some research as to what causes the ring will reassure you that you aren't missing anything.

reviewText:
This is my second hummingbird feeder ever.  My first unit was a $10 unit from Walmart made of plastic.  I had it throughout the summer, and what I didn't know was that the plastic bottle that holds the feed had a small crack, so every time I would refill it, air would come in, so the feed would all leak out.

This unit has a glass bottle, very thick like a mason jar, so I don't think that will ever be a problem.  It has good weight to it, and the bottom flowery piece is a very sturdy hard plastic, whereas my WalMart model was a light plastic with cheap feel... the kind that those cheap toys from the dollar store feel like.  The top piece is removable and has a reservoir for holding water to keep ants from climbing down to the feed.  The top also screws off to help when you're refilling the bottle -- it allows the jar to stand straight up and is sturdy.  It comes with a small S hook, but I used a carabiner that i bought from the dollar store instead.  I went to Lowe's to pick up a $2 hook to hang it on my fence.
As expected.

Nice - so much better than the cheap, flexy handles I've been using. The extension wedge clamp really keeps the extension from sliding. My only nitpick is in the finishing - at the tool end, there was no attempt made to chamfer, bevel or round the edges. The end of the extension, where the tools slide in was a straight, sharp-edged cut, and so where the drilled holes for the little pop buttons that lock the tools in was also drilled and not finished. The result is really annoying when soft plastic meets sharp aluminum edges and catches. A few seconds with a dremel to round those edges and the tool buttons insert and release much better. One of those annoying details that really should have been done at manufacture.
Very nice.
This came right after the 4th of July. And works like it should. No tares of any kind.

This unit is mediocre. I think it's overpriced when one considers it's really just a two-breaker panel with two breakers - a 60 AMP and a 100 AMP.

The most irritating part of this is the lack of an isolated ground bar. There is a single bus bar for ground/common, but this should almost never be done because the NEC rules apparently say that common and ground should only be connected at the main service panel.

Therefore, to install this properly, one needs to buy an additional bus bar. The most affordable option is to purchase a new GROUND bar that can screw right to the back of the box, then use the existing bar for common since it appears to be insulated from the box. However, don't take my advice on any of this but seek a professional, licensed electrician to evaluate your situation.

A small irritant I found is that if one reverses the position of the breakers, the cover doesn't fit. You can either flip the whole box upside down if you need/want a breaker on a given side, or you have to carefully pull the labels off the sides and switch them . I suppose that indicates that the positioning within the box isn't exactly symmetrical. It was more of an annoyance. Another irritant for persnickety persons like myself was the color of this box which deviates from the gray color used in many other panels. Silly, I know, but I'd prefer a gray panel. Perhaps this is intentional so that it's not confused for a sub-panel?

Aside from the above, there was at least adequate space for wiring - all of which I did with #4 and #6 AWG wire which is very think and inflexible.
summary: Overpriced but adequate for the job

Very effective tool so you don't have to check your grill so often.
It has two probes that are individually programmable with a target temp.
I use one to measure grill temp at the cook surface, and the other for the meat temp.
It takes a bit of effort to learn how to program it.  Instructions could be a bit more clear. But once you learn it, it's effective.
I think they outsmarted themselves with the firmware, but then again, you don't have to look up cooking temps for various meats in a chart to set your target temperatures....it's built into the receiving unit.
The alarm goes off ten degrees before target. You can silence it and it will go off at target.
I've enjoyed using this tool.

The Jumbo Outdoor Grill Basket has become my favorite item to use on the grill. It has a deep basket and a shallow skillet that doubles as a lid. Both pieces can be used separately or as a unit. I use both pieces to grill vegetables. I coat my vegetables with oil, salt, pepper, and put them in the preheated basket on the grill, give them a shake and put the skillet/lid on. After a few minutes, I flip the basket over and let the vegetables cook until they are crisp tender. I usually use the basket over direct heat, but sometimes, if necessary, I will finish cooking the vegetables or other items with indirect heat. The basket is huge, and it holds a lot of food. I like to use the skillet for shrimp, salmon, and stir fry type dishes. It's a sturdy set, and I haven't experienced any sticking. I let it cool down a bit and hand wash it. This is a worthwhile grilling accessory.

reviewText:
Great Machine! I bought it from Home Depot (get it same day and I get a 10% military discount).
I have three relatively minor complaints about this sweeper:
1. The assembly instructions are in the wordless picture format. It was a little difficult to figure it out (& I am mechanically inclined). If they would include an English description for it drawing, it would be helpful. During assembly, I only had one minor problem with one drawing and - to be fair - the drawing was complete but I missed a small item fly out picture.
2. The dump procedure is difficult using a zero turn (dump arm is not long enough to reach from the seat). So, I have to park the mower and dump the sweeper. However, this is not a biggie either.
3. The sweeper should have a "neutral" drive position. I have to cross a gravel driveway and the sweeper continues picking up everything in its path - including rocks.
Otherwise, I have nothing but praise for it! None of the above issues is even close to causing me to reconsider the purchase. Rather, I am very pleased with it. It will reduce the leaf blower use by at least 3-4 hours each job.
First, the main body is made with reasonably thick steel. (Compare the overall shipping weight with competitive devices - the heavier item probably has more "real" steel).
I put the machine together and connected it to my zero turn with the wheel setting in the default position and started to work. We have a *LOT* of trees and there was about 3" of leaves in most of the yard. It cleaned up everything! Leaves, twigs, and small branches. The only problem I experienced was where the ground was very wet and the leaves were very thick. At that, the wheels stop turning and start dragging on the grass.
summary: Picks up everything but fails traction if ground is wet

Bought the 4 nite guard set and installed on poles in garden as cited in directions.  I also rotated the location and direction of the units to prevent deer getting accustomed to a single location.  Although the units charge and work from dusk to dawn...............they seem to do nothing to deter deer or raccoons in our NC location.  I am tempted to give the units 2 stars simply because they flash as advertised..........but they do nothing to repel deer which is why I bought these pricy flashing boxes.
  Save your money and install a fence which is what I should have done and will now have to do.

ADDITION:  Gotta admit that these lights are built well and still flashing........but still absolutely no effect on deer which have gotten used to using them as a beacon........However, now my 7 foot deer fence has allowed me to garden once again in a region where we regularly have 10-14 deer roaming by the back of our acre lot

I got them at Lowe's.  I've since ordered (2) different traps from Amazon and I am looking forward to using them as soon as I can locate the run.  I  am sure the mole is running in this direction bc this is where it spilled the soil out of my compost bin onto the ground.  If these were such a success we would not need to be further discussing this.  The problem would be fixed!  I have now put (4) No Mol snap traps into my compost bin with the hopes that this will work.  I think I found a run in the compost bin.  Precious worms are being eaten while I am waiting to catch and kill this mole.

reviewText:
The fire pit is great. It looks very nice on our patio, and it feels like it will last a long while. I like the possibility (although I'm not sure how easy it would be) to replace the pan in the middle if it ever wears out.

The thing that we didn't like was that of the four legs, only three had the little metal feet that you see. One leg came pre-assembled (contrary to the included directions) but without the little metal foot.

So I contacted Amazon to get a replacement foot, but they could not send just the foot, or even the leg. They offered to send me an entire new fire pit, exchange the part I needed and then let me send it back to them with a prepaid label. This is a fairly heavy item shipped, and so I jsust couldn't imagine dong that.

I also tried to take off the feet from the remaining three legs, but one of the three simply would not come off - it's stuck.

So basically I had a problem with two out of four of the legs that came with this. And it's just enough to be annoying.

So - aside from the little feet that have been a huge pain in the rear, the fire pit itself is very nice and well worth the price. No other issues even remotely identified yet. I would buy one again for our next place, but hoping that it would come fully assembled.
summary: Great Fire Pit - Assuming they ship you a complete unit

reviewText:
Well, since it's been freezing here I've only used the griddle once when we got a break from snow and super cold temps--but my review is due so here it goes.

The griddle is definitely sturdy and well made, but I know that the shiny finish won't last long when the griddle gets used more. I was surprised by how small the griddle is, and expect this to be good for cooking veggies for no more than 2 people--which is what I did this time.  I grilled chunks of sweet peppers, onions, and cherry tomatoes and it was definitely easier than anything else I've tried.  I brushed the griddle with some refined coconut oil, seasoned the veggies and cooked until tender crisp.  It's not the same as directly on the grill; I didn't get a char on the food but it tasted great. As for bacon, I would need something twice this size for us.

I'll update this review when the Spring thaw arrives and we start grilling regularly again.
summary: Small griddle but a handy tool

reviewText: Not bad

I wasn't expecting much when opening the box this set came in and wasn't really sure what to expect even upon accepting it for review. The pictures on Amazon just do not really do this bistro type table and chairs justice - they are actually really nice.

The idea was for this set to look like wood resin, although it is made out of a weather resistant PE resin wicker. The resin looks very good and even has some coloring difference so it really resembles a real wood wicker table. In fact there is a big benefit here as the resin wicker will not be destroyed by rain and dampness like a wood one and overall it should possess a very long life factoring that in.

It comes all pre assembled so there is nothing for you to put together! The set sure feels sturdy, and the chairs say they can support up to 280 pounds but Im nowhere near that so I cant test it to be sure but it feels great to sit on and relax.

The table and chair all fold up well so they can easily be stored in a closet or garage but I will just be leaving mine on the patio. It's a breeze to open them and this would make a nice little card or puzzle table. The surfaces usable space is approximately 24" X 24" and although that is not tremendous, I think it's perfect for sitting and having my first cup of joe outside while staring at the mountains and trees and wondering what bark is made out of.

For the price at $128 this Bistro set is pretty good deal - It isn't going to be for everyone but I really like the style and really can't find fault with it. Again, much nicer than the product images portray it.

Product provided for review - its just my opinion

This is a large very pretty gazing ball, I especially like the fact that it will not break if dropped (yes, the dog smacked into me and I dropped it, watched it bounce on the grass a few times and picked it up.  No scratches and still in one piece, If you drop it on a harder surface it will probably get scratched, I would recommend a light coat of poly urethane to protect it from branches scratching the pretty rainbow coating off.  The poly should also keep it from fading.

I keep going back to this tool, after trying the various power trimmers (string or plastic blade) on the market.

This tool has remained sharp enough to cut.
I did have to use fine metal sand paper after allowing the blades to rust, but that restored it to good working condition.
summary: Mine has held up well for more than a few years.  This works better than any power trimmer I have tried

This is the BEST product for the home aquarium hobbyist.  No more using chemicals to remove the chemicals in city water before doing water changes.  I got a kitchen faucet adapter that has hose thread, a short feeder hose, this filter, a paper dip test kit and a 25' curly hose.  I keep the adapter on the kitchen faucet.  When I want to add water to one of my tanks, I first adjust the water temp to match the tank and attach the 4' hose between the faucet adapter and the filter.  Then I attach the curly hose to the filter.  I test the water coming out to ensure that the filter is working correctly and just fill the tank.
summary: This is the BEST product for the home aquarium hobbyist.

reviewText:
This is a really excellent outdoor cast iron grill that will work well with either charcoal briquettes or firewood (or in a pinch, anything that will burn).

This is a great grill/stove to have, whether for Emergency Preparedness or just grilling in the backyard.
It's a perfect compromise between being stable (solid cast iron) and portable. You can pick this up by the attached bail handle and carry it to the beach, to a fixed campsite, or wherever. Check the measurements, it's more compact than it looks in most photos. It's about the size of a standard fishing tackle box ( a little bigger than a shoebox).

The oval grill on top can flip over to adjust its height. The hinged front 'door' allows you to feed in additional wood, sticks or other fuel after the fire has started and allows you to rearrange the coals with a poker as needed. There's another air intake opening below the door with a detachable cover that you can slide to control air flow. The more air, the hotter the flame.

This is 100% solid cast iron. These have been around since the 1930s when they were first introduced by the Birmingham Stove company in Alabama as the 'Sportsman's Grill' and marketed to hunters and fishermen. That family-owned company went under around 1990 and Lodge cast iron company acquired the patents, the molds etc and ever since 1990 has been producing this current version of the original Sportsman's Grill.

This current Lodge version is actually stronger and better, with several design improvements, than the Original. It's great to see a company acquire an existing product and actually improve its design and build quality, rather than cheapen it. I salute Lodge for actually improving the Original design. The current grills are stronger, are cast thicker, have side carry handles, are more stable and all around improved over earlier versions.

There's a really well done youTube video in which the 1940 Birmingham version and a modern Lodge version are compared side by side. Lodge has really done a great job maintaining and improving an already excellent design.

This works great outdoors, but it's also handy if you want a controlled wood fire in your home fireplace, or if you want to be able to actually cook (pots, pans) in your fireplace for Emergency Preparedness. And it's small enough to fit in any working fireplace I can imagine.

This comes 'pre-seasoned' out of the box, and ready to cook. Like all cast iron it will rust if you leave it out exposed to weather; hygienically the main component you really need to care about is the grill top itself. This is small and easy to move under cover or wrap in a tarp or plastic bag. Lodge sells a custom cover but you can accomplish the same thing with any decent trash bag.

It's not clear in some photos but this has three legs, because a tripod is stable and can't wobble. The bail is attached, but the front door, the sliding air-intake grate and both the upper and lower grill plates are detachable; just something to remember when moving it around. When I'm going to carry it I put the front door-hatch and sliding air intake cover inside the grill under the lid to prevent losing them. Then I double-bag everything to keep ash inside, with just the bail handle protruding. Easy to do. (The grill still works fine without those doors if you lose them, it just burns hotter without the hatches).

This is just a great grill. These are available at most big box sports store and discount chains. The older versions are sought after by some collectors. I found a 1940s version at a garage sale recently and it cleaned up beautifully with a wire brush and a little vegetable oil (there are tons of instructions online for restoring old cast iron, and also fan forums).
If you have an older pre-1990 version, the modern replacement parts fit perfectly with the vintage versions, which is another nice gesture from Lodge. These really are so solid you can pass them down to the next generation.

Just a great grill in every way. I see these in stores from $70 to $120, and they go on Sale seasonally. This one is #1 in cast iron grills, and it deserves to be. It's just a pleasure to have around.

I hope this review is helpful. Happy grilling!
summary: A Great Performing Cast Iron Grill With Vintage Nostalgia: 'Sportsman's Grill' by LODGE

reviewText:
I settled on this particular hose reel after reading lots of Amazon reviews for various reels.  This one seemed to have the best reviews, and I suppose I was also swayed by the fact that I've owned a Rapid Reel hose reel for my air compressor hose for a number of years that has proved extremely durable and handy.

It comes in a remarkably small box given the size of the assembled unit, they did a pretty darn good job on the packaging.  I got mine assembled in about 15-20 minutes, despite my toddler trying to haul off the wheels.  The design is such that the handle always has a bit of flex to it even if you torque down the bolts pretty tight.  I wish that it ended up a bit more rigid, as the flex makes it feel odd.  But otherwise this thing ends up like the tank that I expect from Rapid Reel.  The section of feed hose is very high quality Goodyear hose, the zip tie for holding your hose in the right spot on the reel is very beefy and has a tab so you can loosen/remove it if needed.

The unit has a friction brake on it so that gravity doesn't unspool your hose for you.  The friction level is adjustable, but seemed fine with my hose out of the box.  It rolls easily, and doesn't seem to be in any danger of tipping over even if you pull on the hose to get it to unspool.  I pulled at a 90 degree angle from the spool from about 20 feet and the handle conveniently helped align the hose and it unspooled just fine.
good quality.  have two pairs

reviewText:
Well, since the allotted time for a review doesn't begin to cover a growing season, even if I could plant this out-of-doors right now  (my garden is still under a foot of snow and ice), I can only tell you what I think about this sort of product.  First off, I think it's clever.  Marketing from-seed crops like this in a plantable starter pod is pretty smart.  You've got everything you need to grow a cherry tomato plant in this pod, seeds, of course, growing medium, fertilizer, and a bio-degradable pot which will allow the seedling's roots to spread out.  All you really need to do is take off the cover, plant the pod and keep it moist.

I like the minimal packaging.  Too many things are over-packaged these days.  This gives you exactly what you need.  The instructions included on the cover, are simple but adequate.  I don't honestly see how you could go wrong.  The only thing I'd say is this:  I'm not crazy about Miracle-Gro products.  I prefer organic fertilizers for my garden for a great many reasons -- you can go look up all the information, it's out there.  However I don't see that using these pods would be a huge problem for anyone who isn't a committed organic gardener.
