This 1Byone 2 Wires Audio Door Phone Intercom System with Phone Handset works well, is good quality, and is also a fairly good value. We own a small business that keeps odd hours and we often don't open to the public until late in the day. This intercom system is useful to screen people from the back-office and "buzz in" the delivery drivers without significantly interrupting us by having to walk to the front just to turn someone away. Here are my observations:

Includes: Indoor Unit with Phone Style Handset (it is an intercom, not an actually phone), Outdoor Unit, Mounting Hardware, and Instructions

Not Included:
* Connection Wire, I used phone wire that we picked up at a local "Big Box" store. You will need two wires (1 Pair) for the intercom and another two wires if you want to use the unlocking function (you can get "2-Pair" in one cable spool, which is what we used).
* Optional Electric Door Lock, we already had one on our door but they are sold on Amazon

Installation:
* Main Unit - This is desktop or wall mountable, connect the wires to the terminals in the back, one pair for the intercom and (optional) one pair for the lock
* Outdoor Unit - Mount bracket on wall (ours is well protected from the elements), connect intercom wires to the unit and place in bracket (power is provided from the handset unit)
* Optional Electric Lock - connect 2nd pair of wires to the lock

Use: This is very straight forward, pressing the button on the outdoor unit alerts the main handset unit and you can clearly hear, and be heard, on both sides of the  conversation. If you have the optional electric door lock, you can press the button on the handset unit and it will allow the door to be opened by the visitor.

This is a fairly basic unit that works well and is very cost effective.

Highly Recommended!

This was posted when the umbrella was two weeks old:
The umbrella is nice and thick with "thatch" but it suffers from a major nuisance. Every time you lower the umbrella at least six of the eight caps that attach to the ribs come off the ribs. (Sometimes all eight of them.) So each time you raise the umbrella you have to re-attach the plastic caps onto the ribs. But that's not the only thing. You can only re-attach the caps with the umbrella in the "half-way up" position. (All the way down they fall off. All the way up, it's too tight and you'll rip or break something.) Picture this. One hand holds the umbrella half-way up while the other hand single-handedly tries to re-attach the caps.
If you don't mind going through that ritual each time you lower it, it's a very nice "thatch-look" umbrella with plenty of "hair."

This is at the end of the first season:
After four months this summer (May 15 - Sept 15, 2018) the umbrella thatch has deteriorated in the Connecticut sun. (Umbrellas are supposed to be in the sun, aren't they?) With each breeze and/or rain little strands of the plastic "thatch" blow off the umbrella and on to my deck and yard. It has also turned color from tan to neutral taupe. By now, September, I'm very disappointed in this product. It looked good when it arrived (see above paragraph) but now it doesn't. It would probably would work in a covered environment like a screened in porch or a sun room. But who needs an umbrella in a location with a roof over it?

Wish there was an improved material or process this company would use.

This is a good buy if you know what you're getting into and have a particular purpose in mind. It isn't going to be a good substitute for a regular garden hose unless you live in a condo or downstairs apartment and are just watering a small flower bed or pots by hand. The good part is the very light weight, especially if you are disabled, arthritic, or both. The bad news is that it has to be babied along, and won't take the kind of treatment a heavy rubber garden hose will.

I have a small yard inside the city. Most of my yard is reachable by soaker hoses, but I have potted plants on my front porch and a small bed nearby that aren't reached by my soaker hoses. Every day in summer I step out, turn on my little 50 foot hose (mine is royal blue), and I water my pots and the little pansies and petunias beside my porch. When I am done, I turn off the hose, hold about half of it upside down to drain it, and then I coil it carefully on top of a plastic crate on the porch (and out of the sun), where it waits for me to do the same thing the next day. Lather, rinse, repeat, right?

I really like the fact that it is so lightweight. The only thing I feel is causing any weight at all on my sore joints is the water inside the hose, and that goes with the territory. We have had temperatures close to 100 degrees, unseasonably hot, and the hose has been fine.

So the bottom line is to follow the rules:

* drain it every single time
* don't leave it where it can be stepped on by someone
* don't drag it across anything prickly like rose bushes with thorns, or pine needles
*don't put it on a hose hanger

If all of those are too limited for your purposes, this is not the product you want. I like mine fine, though.
summary: Perfect for Gentle, Limited Use; Light Weight Great for Disabled and Elderly

I ordered two bales of this a couple of weeks ago and when  arrived a lot of it was in the box itself and in the plastic bag that encloses the bales. Something was clearly wrong so I returned it.  The people at Red Earth sent me a new shipment and this one is perfect.  I've had it in my koi pond for close to a week and it's almost completely submerged now. I like that the product is organic, and seems to be an excellent quality. I also like that the company really cares about whether or not the customer is satisfied and if not,  will make it right.
By the way for those of you who are giving it one star and complaining that it's not cleaning up the algae in your pond,  you must be aware that barley bales are meant to PREVENT STRING ALGAE ONLY and not meant to clear up blanket algae That type requires a UV light on your filter or an algaecide to take care of the problem. You cannot clear up string algae that's already formed either.  Completely remove the string algae  and then start with a clean barley bale  and see what happens.  It is always important to learn about the product you are using and what they're intended to do. I would highly recommend this brand - RED EARTH- being organic and a company that really cares.

We live in South East Texas where mosquitos carry off small children. My kids play outdoor sports all year. They keep a can of 3M Ultrathon in their gear bags next to their sports equipment. It works great!

I have read a few reviews where people were having trouble with the spray nozzle. ***There is nothing wrong with the lid.*** In fact the spray nozzle is the ***BEST*** part of the product. The repellent has a locking feature. When you purchase a can of Ultrathon it will come in the locked position. if you press down on the sprayer it will not spray. If you want to use the product, simply twist the lid and click it out of the locked position. Then it will spray like any other aerosol sprayer. When done, twist the lid back into the locked setting. With the can locked my kids just toss it back into their gear bags and don't have to worry about getting repellent all over their bag and sports equipment.
summary: Best Repellent and a Locking Lids Bonus!

I'm a 62 year old female, and I put 90% of this shed together by myself. I had a little difficulty putting the walls into the floor slots because weighing only 140lbs and being 5"4" tall made it a little difficult because I just didn't have the weight or force required. Other than this I found it easy to assemble and it's quite roomy on the inside. I store all my garden equipment (including a push lawnmower), tools, seasonal decorations, and I have room for more stuff. I reused 2 shelving units, and a Rubbermaid triangular garden tool organizer that I had in my previous shed (which was eaten up by termites and had to be torn down). It comes with 1 wall to wall shelf, 2 smaller shelves plus, 2 small corner shelves, and 2 strips that hold clips? for somewhat smaller tools. I hang my weed eater and the 100ft electrical cord on these, along with some hand tools/garden tools. It does now have any electrical outlets in it, so I put up a Mr. Beams battery operated motion detector light on one of the sides of the roof and this seems to be ample enough for finding something at night. It is water tight, that is, I have found no leaks after a heavy rain, and it rains a lot here in Louisiana. I chose to use a base of pea gravel under the flooring, rather than a wooden or cement base, just because it was easier for me and this seems to be working out just fine-I feel it offers a lot of support under the flooring. It has a neat and attractive appearance, although I think the colors are rather drab-like beige walls and dark gray roof and doors. If you need a larger shed, they sell an expansion kit. So far, I love the shed and find it roomy enough for my needs. I would recommend it for anyone who likes "do-it-yourself" projects. And even a women can do it. Amazon quotes the shipping weight as 220lbs, but a freight company delivered the shed and they put in on their scales prior to delivery and it weighed 573lb. I mention this because the weight of the delivery determines how many men they send out for delivery of the product. So one man was sent out with the delivery and he struggled a little. Although they weighed the 2 large boxes, they have to go by what the seller tells them-the 220lbs. That's the only glitch in the process-Amazon needs to change their shipping weight to a more accurate account, because the delivery person could have hurt himself, while struggling with the 2 large boxes. Overall, I'm very pleased with the product and would do it all over again, knowing the end results.
summary: Attractive, almost indestructible shed for a "do-it-youselfer!

The trap comes apart easily, so you can activate it.  This also allows a child to get to the poison easily, which is liquid!

The tape flaps in the breeze scaring off the birds and they no longer bother my deck and are no longer making a mess.  I can't tell you how happy I am I don't have to hose my deck off every day anymore.  It's nice being able to save time and money on our water bill and to be able to go right outside to sit down without having to clean a mess up first.

While these traps are a bit lightweight and one of two did leak until glued, they do catch the yellowjackets that formerly were visiting the hummer feeder.  We also tried the Rescue trap, bought locally by a housemate, and it works equally well, at first, but who wants to buy more "attractant"?  When I put my recipe (below) in the little cup and added a piece of fried chicken skin/coating on a 'meat prong', the wasps didn't die.  Apparently, once trapped in the upper portion, they crawl back down to feed on the chicken and take some back to the rest? so I think a trap with liquid in the entire bottom, like the Aspectek, is quicker and more humane.

The recipe enclosed in the Aspectek traps used "shot glasses" for some unfathomable reason so I had to do some math to make a usable recipe.  In the U.S. (only) a shot glass is usually 1 oz.  This feeder holds  cup at most. What works for me is:  2 T sugar, 1 T cranberry juice, 3 T water, 1 T cider vinegar.  You can also add 1-2 drops dish soap.

reviewText: This seedling heat mat works perfectly for me. It comes with an insulation mat that should be placed underneath the heating mat as a buffer to help prevent heat loss downward. Also has a 6' cord and the dimensions are 10"x20 3/4". Couple things I feel I should point out. According to the item description here on Amazon, it says it's waterproof but in the manual that comes with the mat it says water resistant. Since we're dealing with electricity and water I'd say that's a huge difference. I err on the side of caution and do my best to not get it wet. The next thing is, this mat gets pretty hot when plugged directly into the outlet. I'm talking roughly 110 F degrees hot. If you plan on using this for seed starting and seedlings you're definitely going to want a thermostat to decrease and regulate the heat cause otherwise you'll cook the roots of your young plants. I use a thermostat set at 75F degrees and that works well for me. Since I have had no problems with this mat for two growing seasons yes, I would buy this again. I hope this helps.
summary: Good product. Best used with a thermostat for seedlings.

I have a Masterbuilt 30" electric smoker and this fits great inside along one of the sides of the smoker. The 12" version is perfect so you can just put it on the far right (or left) and then make sure your meats don't drip fat onto the tube to prevent the fire from going out. It produces quite a bit of smoke and makes the meats taste great.

Tips if you have a Masterbuilt electric smoker
1. If you want to get a lot of smoke for 4-5 hours, remove the tray loader and the wood chip tray from the smoker. You'll have a hole on the bottom right from the tray loader but that gives you better airflow and will help burn the pellets, thus producing more smoke.
2. If you want to get less smoke for 6-7 hours, keep the tray loader inside to prevent more airflow. Since you're limiting the oxygen in the smoker, the pellets will burn at a slower rate since they are producing less smoke.
3. Don't start this fire inside the smoker; start it outside first and then move it in
4. Make sure there's no meat placed directly above the tube, otherwise the fire will go out. If you spritz or mop your meat, be careful so it doesn't drip onto the tube.
5. Don't place the tube directly beneath the heating element. This area is too hot and the pellets will expand and not burn correctly.
summary: 12" perfect for a Masterbuilt electric smoker.

Long Form: I have purchased sever Claber hose reels fro around my home. One finally gave out after 5 years of heavy use. Since I've been having trouble with the Claber hose nozzles leaking, I thought I'd give the Gardena system a try. A few things for comparison.

 The Gardena hose was terribly packed  no spam, paper or protection and the plastic piece knocking around in the box marred the otherwise new reel. Cosmetic, but a bummer

 The Claber is a bit longer for a bit less...

reviewText: Awesome!

I actually bought this from Wal**t.com on sale under $400 with free shipping.  Arrived in less than 4 days.  Very happy with that part of purchase. Set it all up in no time by myself....less than an hour.  I used a pool cover pump to transfer water from my nearby pool into the spa.  The pool water is already chemically treated and substantially warmer than water from the hose.  It was filled in about 3 hours.  Turned on the control panel and everything worked!  I was thrilled.  Now I just had to wait for the water temp to get up to 98 or so....which would take overnight.  (2 degress per hour is accurate). Next morning the spa was 98 degrees.  Perfect.  Put on the bubbles......it looked great.  Appeared very impressive on my deck by the pool.  My 8 year old daughter was anxious and wanted to go in....so I let her go in for a little while.  She went back and forth from the pool to the spa...numerous times.  She got out, I turned off the bubbles and put the cover back on.  A little while later I came back outside and heard the control panel beeping.  I went over and the entire control panel was lit up.  No buttons worked.  I reset the panel (basically unplugged it and plugged it back in) and the same thing happened.  All icons on panel lit up, beeping, and buttons unresponsive. My wife and 2 other children wanted to go in.....and here I am all bummed out that the thing is broken.  I called the Intex customer service....and like others who wrote reviews.....was talking with someone who's primary language was not English.  At least I wasn't on hold for more than 5 minutes....and the phone call was over pretty quickly.  She just took my contact info, what the problem was, and told me I would receive an email to file my claim.  I opted to go through Intex first....as I could always return the entire thing to Wal**rt in the future if I have to.  Within 10 minutes I was online and uploaded my receipt an filled out the claim form.  The next day I received an email that I would be shipped a new control panel.  Later in the day...I got a shipment notification and a FedEx tracking number.  VERY impressed with the customer service so far.  The only downfall is that the "estimated" delivery date is over a week away.....now I have to decide to drain the spa or not until it arrives.  As for the overall experience......if it eventually works as well as it looks....this will have been, even with this hiccup, a great purchase.  I have purchased Intex products before....having 2 Intex pools and related intex filter pumps....and have been very happy with their products.  Intex is based in California and Canada.....but evidently some, if not all, of their products are imported.  If you read the negative reviews....perhaps the people did not properly follow the instructions when filing a claim, or perhaps Intex knows that Wal**rt is a huge retailer of their products compared to smaller vendors on Amazon...and expedites claims.  Who knows....but there hasn't been any issues with customer service delaying anything for me.  In fact......it only took 1 day to get a FexEx tracking number from my initial claim.  We will see....and I will keep posting to this review as things progress.

UPDATE: a week passed and I got my replacement control unit.  I had drained the spa....so before I replaced the new control unit...I filled it with my pool water as mentioned earlier.  After a few hours it was filled.  I replaced the control unit, plugged it in, pushed the power button and presto!  A loud beeping noise, all the icons lit up, and nothing working.  Reset the control unit numerous times....nothing.  Another call to INTEX customer service...phone call answered promptly, and was over in 5 minutes.  They will be shipping me a control BASE this time as they think the power supply unit or something electrical in the base is causing the issue.  This was yesterday...and I got an email confirmation that my base unit was approved and will be shipped.  If all goes well, I will be getting a shipping confirmation today or tomorrow.  But then the week wait again...and deciding to empty the spa or not once again.  Third time's a charm?  We'll see.  I have a 90-day return policy with WALM**T...so I will play the game for now and keep my fingers crossed.

UPDATE:  been another week and the BASE unit is scheduled to arrive today.  Weird thing is that for some reason I decided to reset the spa last night (I kept the water in it)...and the control panel beeped once and started working!  I "gently" pushed the heater control up to 100 degrees...and the filter pump turned on.  I pushed the bubble button and the thing started bubbling!!  I turned off the bubbles and left the thing, checking from my window if it was still lit up every so often.  I went outside before bedtime and the temp said 80 degrees.  It was still going.  This morning I got up, and it had died over the night.  Control panel all lit up and unresponsive.  What a roller coaster....up and down.  I am so anxious for this thing to work.  I will hook up the new BASE tonight and give a final do or die update in the next few days.  Thumbs up....or back to Walm**t. No more chances with Intex customer support.

UPDATE: BASE unit arrived yesterday and I immediately switched it out with the old one. I also attached the new control panel I received last week.  Plugged it in, switched it on and.....everything seems to be working!!  The hum from the base is not as loud as the old one, so maybe that's an indication in a positive direction. Water was at 76 degrees...and I set it to 100....which it was this morning when I checked it.  Still going. Good.  Hopefully this will be my last post.  We will give it a try later today.

UPDATE:  5 days later, and everything working well.  Tub is great, and it looks as good as it feels.  Everyone who sees it wants one. I am keeping my fingers crossed that this will last a few seasons or more.

UPDATE:  Been 3 weeks since I hooked up the replacement BASE unit. Everything working fine. Had to clean the filters about 5 days ago, because of an error code indicating the filters needed cleaning/replacement. Last night I had my window open and I heard the spa bubbling.  I went outside and sure enough, under the cover, the bubbles were going.  Pushed the "bubbles" button numerous times....still going.  Pushed the heat button and they stopped.  Pushed the heat button again and the bubbles turned on. Now the bubbles go on every time the heat is on.  NO GOOD!!!  I reset the breaker, etc., and the same problem.  I have the original control panel and will hook it up later today, but THREE STRIKES YER OUT!!!.  It's only a matter of time this thing will crap out again.  GREAT CONCEPT....but poor quality concerning the electronics on this thing.  Still have over a month to return to WALM**T....but it looks like when I emtpy it for the winter (or the old control unit doesn't work)...it will be making that "RETURN" trip.  COLEMAN just started advertising a spa on Amazon.....I may look into that.

FINAL UPDATE: Hooked up the old original control unit and the same thing.  Turn on the heater and the bubbles turn on too. I am so bummed that I am one of the few that isn't having luck with this.....but in the long run, it is probable that the lack of quality concerning the electronics will eventually catch up with a lot of these 5 star reviewers. My spa will be going back to the local Walxxxt in the next few days. Thank heaven for their 90 day return policy. Can't deal with Intex customer service again...even though they will send me new parts....they just crap out.

Ok,  Its summer 2015 and Walxxt has it on sale for $329 and free shipping.  I must be crazy...but I ordered another one.  It is sitting boxed in my garage waiting to be set up. Maybe I will be lucky this time around.  It will be set up this weekend and I will post the results. Worst case scenario....another return back to the store.  That's the good thing about purchasing it online from Walmxxt....if there is a problem (within return policy), you just bring it back to your local store,,,,no hassle concerning shipping it back to somewhere.

8/10/15:  Set up new spa with no problem.  (Have had much past experience).  Filled with water from hose.  Was up to temperature (100 degrees) by the next morning.  Been going about 4 days now.  Had a BIG pool birthday party for my daughter 2 days ago....kids in and out....many, many people commenting on how cool it is, etc.  So far so good.  I kept my eye on the kids making sure they didn't push buttons too many times, etc., and was yelling at them if they got too rough.  I'm making sure it's babied for a while.  Hopefully my over reaction will diminish the longer it keeps going without issues.  You would think that Intex would beef up their products since there are so many returns.  It costs them an arm and a leg to manufacture and ship out free replacement parts.  Using thicker wire or bigger blower/heater would help cut back on most of the problems (In my case its all been electronics).  Even if they upped the price $100.

8/27/15:  Been going over 3 weeks without issue.  Drained it once and refilled with fresh water as the developed a strange smell. Noted in other posts that the rubber/laytex sides will leach out a bit since the product is new.  This will go away with time.  New water has been in it for 2 weeks and it is still clear without smell.  Washed filters out last week and will again soon.  Keep a small 1" tab of clorine in the little floatie and test water every 3/4 days.  If clorine tests high, i take out floatie for a few days and keep in glass dish by spa.  So far so good on this one.

9/21/15:  Still working without issue.  Did note that those who complained about the sides getting slimey were correct.  Even with the chemicals balanced correctly, there is a slight film (rubs off easily) that developes after a period of non-use.  Especially on the bottom of the cover pillow that makes contact with the water.  Not sure how to correct that problem....but can live with it for now......a quick brushing and its gone.

10/15/15:  The spa is still working fine.  Getting colder outside, and my pool is covered for the season, so I guess this is a wrap for now.  Time to empty it and put it away.  Will report back next spring.

February, 2017:  Sorry for not getting back sooner!  Spa got set up in late Spring of 2016.  After inflating and filling with water, turned on the unit and everything lit up correctly.  After I pushed the circulation button....nothing.  After a few seconds got that familiar beeping noise with the code that indicated pump was not working.  Tried a few times.....still nothing.  I decided not to panic...and let it sit.  After a day or two, I turned on the unit, pushed the circulation button and to my surprise....the pump started working!!  Turned on the heater and had no problems at all for the rest of the season.  I'm thinking that slight corrosion over the winter prevented the impellers from moving and caused the problem. After sitting for a few days, the water loosened up the impeller.  I think.  Who knows. At any rate, the spa worked flawlessly for almost 4 months until I packed it away in September.  Keeping fingers crossed for next season.

Finale' 8/5/2017:  Got it out for 2017 season....everything prepared to inflate it.  Control unit turned on and inflated the tub to the correct pressure. Didn't start filling it with water as I didn't have time.  Returned later in the day and the damn thing was deflated.  Checked everything, hooked back pump and reinflated it. A few hours pass and its soft again.  It's out to the curb. Good riddance.
summary: Made in China.  Decide accordingly.  Ongoing review......

Since I don't get to actually see the gopher eating the bait, nor do I see a dead gopher, I didn't rated it 5 stars.  This is what I did and know.  After trying different traps, repellents, noise solar stake and even took a shot at it with a pellet gun (at which the activity resume after 6 days) nothing worked.  I bought this as a last resort before calling a professional.  I used a stick about 1/2x1/2"x5' and tapered the tip (not sharp) just enough to penetrate the ground,  Where ever I felt soft ground under my feet, I use the stick to see if its a tunnel.  If you have mounds (I removed the mounds daily to monitor activity and not kill the grass that got buried,) try between mounds.  If your stick drops suddenly around 2" after penetrating the top soil, you hit a tunnel. As desperate as I was, whether active or inactive, I poured a teaspoon of the Moletox through the hole made by the stick. I did the same for the next two days.  The activity stopped on the fourth day and had been for more than 3 weeks as of this review.

If you read as much as I did on gopher (pocket,)  you'll read that they won't eat bait because they taste first prior to eating, they gather food in their pocket (their cheeks thus the name pocket gopher) and put it in their food storage and lastly, poison takes 4 to 5 days to take effect and steady consumption.  So this is why I use this product last, because it shouldn't work.  I did however got result, because of it or not I don't know since I have no proof.

If you don't have a stick laying around, you can spend $30 for the Yard Butler bait applicator.
summary: Haven't seen any gopher activity in 3 weeks after application.

I purchased this from Amazon in August 2013 - yes, summer!  (Hey, off-season price was $35 less!)  I contacted the seller because upon testing I could smell a funny burning odor.  They assured me this was normal and due to the friction around the rubberized blades.  Well this morning we had a sufficient amount of snow here in MD for me to try it out.  The handle folded out easily and I was ready to go within  a couple of minutes.  The thrower worked without any trouble with snow as little as 1 inch and as much as 6 inches including some wetter snow with bits of ice.
My only complaints: The mechanism for turning this on is a pain.  I have to press a button WHILE moving the bar against the handlebar.  Hmm, yeah I'll be modifying this at some point.  Second complaint: the power cord on the thrower has a BIG circular cup over it making it impossible for me to use a cord mating device to cover and keep the extension cord connected.  I had to hold the extension cord for tension relief instead of being able to use a cord cover.  I may trim it down or zip-tie it to the frame.
Overall this thrower worked very well for it's first real-world test.

Update 2/15/2014
I simply had to post an update about this snow thrower.  I have been truly impressed with this little snow beast, and have been able to amaze others to where at least one is going to buy one of their own!  I've given this thing HEAVY use over the past few days attacking powdery snow, wet snow, slush, and clumps of packed snow/sleet.  Other than tripping the circuit breaker a couple of times (solely my error) this Power Smart snow thrower has performed wonderfully!  I used it this morning to help clear snow/slush/packed snow from a 150x45' parking area for a local church and kept up VERY well with a two-stage gas-powered snow blower.  This snow thrower is in my top-ten list of good purchased for 2013!  My only tip to everyone - check and tighten the blades after every 2-3 hours of use especially if you've attacked any packed snow.

reviewText:
Strathwood - a product by Amazon.com

The Strathwood Griffen All-Weather Wicker Chair is comfortable & roomy. It looks much nicer in person than in the photo.
Its simple, casual design will withstand changing trends in furniture styles.

A note concerning all-weather, resin wicker: It is  meant to look like natural wicker, but is made of a synthetic material that  requires little maintenance. It is  durable, strong, resistant to humidity, water & UV radiation, & somewhat elastic which adds to the chair's comfort. It's easy to clean & can be hosed down (remove the cushions first). The color is part of the fiber & shouldn't fade.

The chair arrives carefully packaged in a large box with no assembly required.

The Griffen Chair appears to be well-made, with attention to detail. Constructed with an aluminum frame & feet, the chair is lightweight & strong. The aluminum frame & feet are neatly finished with a dark-brown powder coating. The cushions & throw pillow have zippered, 100% polyester, fabric covers; all of them have piping. The back & seat cushions consist of a  2" block of foam covered by polyester fiber which brings the total width of each cushion to 4".  In addition to under-seat webbing which allows the seat to move comfortably,  there's a curved piece of aluminum for additional strength & safety. (see the photo I uploaded)

The back has a slight slope to it so you're not sitting straight up & down.  The included throw pillow can be arranged to give your back  lumbar support if you need it. I'm 5' 3" and need to use the pillow so that I don't sit so far back in the chair. My feet even touch the floor when I use the pillow. Because there's a lot of seat depth, I'm assuming a taller person can sit comfortably in this chair too. I will be sure to update my review when one of our taller friends tries it out.

Approximate seat measurements:
Seat cushion: 25" long (front to back) x 23.5" wide (side to side) x 4" thick.
Back cushion: 17" long (up & down) x 23.5" wide (side to side) x 4" thick.
Pillow: 17" square
Seating area using both seat cushion & back cushion: 23 1/2" wide x 22" - 21" deep or less depending on how you place the back cushion.

Amazon's product description covers cushion care & cleaning so I won't go into that. However, I will remind you that during inclement weather it's recommended  to bring both the chair and the cushions indoors or securely cover them,  and to store them in a dry place when not in use.

This is the most comfortable wicker chair I've ever sat in.  It's roomy,  doesn't cut the circulation off in my legs (at the back of my knees), the cushions aren't lumpy, they're comfortable. The chair arms are smooth & not scratchy. I can rest my arms or my elbow on them without causing myself any discomfort.

I will update my review if the Strathwood Griffen chair fails to perform as expected.

A product guarantee isn't mentioned. However, you may return this item sold by Amazon.com within 30 days of delivery for a full refund. Amazon.com will pay the return shipping cost if the return is a result of their error.

UPDATE:
I've been using this chair indoors on a protected porch so I can't comment on how it withstands the weather.

reviewText: It still looks like new and it has been through AZ summer and a few dust storms. Crank is a little flimsy when you grab it but it is plastic and make it light for easy movement. It works great, recommended buy.

Dear Sir/Madam,

After two weeks of using your products, I must say I am extremely dissatisfied. We have one or two mice in our apartment, and I have used four of your products, all to no avail.

First we used the no-kill traps, baiting them with peanut butter. The mice were able to eat the bait without being trapped.

Then we tried to trap them using good old-fashioned snap traps. Well, neither so good nor so old-fashioned, it seems.

Your weird improvements (the faux-cheese "tray" that serves no discernible purpose, the adjustable sensitivity) do not help at all. Again, the pests are able to eat the bait right off of the trap without triggering the trap. That is, they're eating the peanut butter I've placed there. The Tom Cat Brand bait, that which comes in the small white plastic bottle, doesn't attract them at all, and they've left it to grow hard and stuck to the trap.

And as far as sticking goes, my sister-in-law, visiting from overseas, had the pleasure of seeing a mouse (there has only ever been one, maybe two, with scant droppings found) step onto one of your glue traps. Her scream alerted me and I came running, only to watch the pest easily extricate itself from the glue (!) and run away to hide.

I am beyond disappointed. We now feel we have no choice but to hire a professional exterminator, only because, for some strange reason, your traps are not effective. It is really maddening, frustrating, and just plain disappointing that a simple thing like a mouse trap has been rendered ineffectual by your tinkering.

The lack of sufficient tack on the glue trap is also severely disappointing, but I suppose most maddening of all is the fact your "specially formulated" attractant does anything but attract mice. I thought by using it I was pulling out all the stops for what I perceived to be a rather minor issue. In the end it was probably the most egregious waste of money among those listed herein (even at under three bucks).

These products are all non-returnable, thus my only recourse is write you this note. I'll also be sure to post this same review to your Amazon product pages.

I do hope you take this complaint seriously.

Sincerely,

G Adair
summary: Open letter to Tomcat regarding their poor quality products.

Many people talk about glue traps as being a less than humane way to get rid of mice, while watching a creature struggle for its life is not my favorite thing to do, these traps DO take care of any mice that you may have in your home.  I have heard horror stories of the snap traps not killing the mice instantly and the creature struggling in agony until finally it dies.  I guess it comes down to do you REALLY want to get rid of an infestation of mice in your home.  This product will help you do it and quickly!  The old snap traps where you have to bait the trap and wait for the little guy to come and feed has been laughable sometimes.  You work hard to put the peanut butter or cheese or whatever concoction on the little 'table' and set the trap up and wait.  Late into the night, the little guy comes by for a snack, carefully eats the food you have left him and goes on his way.  How many times do you feed the mice before you actually catch them?

With the Tomcat glue traps that doesn't happen.  You sit the glue trap tray in a location where you have seen or heard evidence of the creatures and you wait.  As soon as the mouse or to be honest, any other pest crawls across the surface it is trapped.  The sticky firm glue keeps the creature from moving off of the trap and you have them.  These traps can be easily removed and disposed of once you have captured your mouse.

Last fall, I bought a bag of bird seed and put it in the garage.  I forgot to put it in the storage bin and before I knew it, I had provided a buffet for all of the field mice that could get into our garage.  After laying out Tomcat glue traps we were quickly able to catch the mice.  Now, I keep a few of the traps in the garage just in case one of the little guys tries to enter the garage looking for a warm place to sleep on a cool night or a place to get out of the rain.

I would recommend these traps to anyone that has heard little scurrying feet in the middle of the night and wants to deal with the issue.

As far as water test kits go this one is pretty simple.  There is only one mixing step and no need to count out droplets.  The instructions are fairly good, it is just the color comparison step that is not all that clear (see my notes below).

What's included
===============
Two bottles, each bottle includes: instructions, 20 packets of test powder, 1 clear test bottle with cap.

Usage
=====
1. Take the cap off the test bottle, rinse it in the pool, then fill with water up to the marked line.
2. Take one small pouch, open it and pour into the test bottle that you filled with pool water.  Take some care opening the pouch and pouring into the bottle so as to not spill.
3. Place lid on bottle, shake for 1 min.
4. Set the test color chart on a flat surface, place the bottle on top of the outlined circle.  Look down through the bottle and compare the result with the color chart listed.

Results
=======
The results I saw are very comparable to what I received from Leslie pools.  I find it much better to quickly test at home before and after treating the pool.  By using this kit and PhosFree I was able to lower my phosphate levels quickly.
summary: Easy to use (for a water test kit)

reviewText:
I've sprayed this around areas where neighbors let their dogs relieve themselves on our lawn, and where rabbits and squirrels get annoying. It seems to work pretty well. Most of the ingredients are natural irritants, like cinnamon oil, garlic, and white pepper. You could almost cook with it... except for the "dried blood" and "putrescent whole egg solids". It's essentially a soup of things that make animals go "Yuck!" It also contains a detergent agent that I assume is included to make it "stick" to whatever you spray it on.

The only disadvantage is that it can't be used on food crops, so you can't spray your vegetable garden. We do some container gardening, and I've used a paintbrush to apply it around the edge of the containers. We'll see if that keeps the squirrels out of the tomatoes.

Absolutely delightful sculpture, very pretty.  That being said, there are a couple of things you need to know.  The wings on the fairy slide on and therein lies the rub; the area on the wings where they slid into place cracked after a couple of months.  To keep the wings on, I had to use superglue.  I had my fairy outside and she did just fine sitting on a fountain, looked great.  When I got a new fountain, she didn't fit on it and I set her down closer to the ground on a box.  Came home one day and she had fallen over, breaking into several (irreparable) pieces.  If you're going to put her outside, just know you may be taking your chances.  I also sprayed her with sealant, which I read was recommended, and it ruined the finish of the fairy.  My advice is to keep her inside or someplace where she isn't going to blow over or fall over.

This is one of the best products I have ever used for bug protection. It protect you from Ticks, Biting Flies, Mosquitoes, Gnats and more. I like how you use it or at least the way I do. I take my clothing, tents, outdoor gear out into the yard and give it a coating. They recommend 3 oz per outfit, but I just dampen the outside of the material I use. I was raised in the Florida Everglades area and now live in the Adirondack Mountains I went from a lot of mosquitoes to a lot of mosquitoes and flies from hell. Until I found SAWYER Permethrin; nothing (100% DEET) did not work on these blood thirsty little boogers. With your clothes and outdoor items properly treated with Sawyer Permethrin, they go WAY around you.
I have used SAWYER and nothing else; it works and there might be something cheaper, but if it works and it is affordable....enough said
I also checked out the safety of Permethrin and found it is from Chrysanthemums and is non-toxic to humans, dogs, cows unless you swim in it. Cats CAN NOT be around the wet/damp/liquid. After it dries it said their should be no problems.

reviewText:
I've only been using this rodent zapper for a week now but after 24 hours I caught a pack rat and then caught a second the next day! My shed is completely taken over by pack rats and I'm disgusted by it...  one of my clients has a water proof rat zapper that she keeps outside by her house to prevent the rats from entering her external cooling system and I'm shocked at how many she's caught! From mice to pack rats and even a couple squirrels! ( Kinda sad about the squirrels, but  amazed they fit in there and we're quickly killed) So i decided to look into one for my shed... Need to eliminate these pests before I clean up there huge mess! This rat zapper only requires four AA batteries where hers takes four D batteries. Four AA batteries packs a good punch! Plus they are cheaper than D so i decided to order this one.
Pro's
Easy to use
AA batteries are cheaper than D batteries
Easy on/off switch with light indicator
Easy to dump out

Con's
Not waterproof
Unit does not come apart for easy cleaning
Metal tray lines the whole unit with no bait section
Dry bait only

Overall I am completely satisfied with my purchase! Yes, there are things i would change about it but it's working to eliminate those pesky rats and that is all I want it for. I was fortunate enough to receive this item at a discounted rate in exchange for my honest review but that doesn't change my true opinion in any way, just an extra bonus!!!!
summary: Works great so far! 2 kills in a week!!!

Not zinc sulfate.  At least not all zinc sulfate, maybe there's some zinc sulfate in there, hard to tell.
Zinc Sulfate, according to the literature is soluble in water at 57.7g per 100 mL of water.  Pretty freely soluble.  This material does not fully dissolve at substantially lower concentrations.  Watching closely is does appear that it is a mixture of at least two components.  When you add it to water it clumps together at the bottom.  A gentle swirling does show diffraction line, a clear indication that something is going into solution.  However there is also a flocculent white material that is completely insoluble, even upon boiling.  It looks a little like silica gel to me but it's hard to tell without sending it out to a lab.

I have been using this product for more than two weeks now. In that time, I've had an opportunity to evaluate both the quality of the product and the overall usability. In creating this review I've considered both the type of material used in making the product as well as the overall fit and finish. I've also considered how well the product meets my needs and whether there are any shortcomings or particular advantages in using this product.

For this particular product, the type of material used in the manufacture and creation of the product seems to be of very good quality. One must consider that for any product of this type there is a balance between the type of material used and the cost that is to be passed on to the consumer. I think for this product that balance has been met fairly well and I believe that the product will meet the expectations of most buyers.

With regard to the fit and finish of this particular product, I believe it to be about average for the products of similar make or style. That is to say that it is not of poor or moderate craftsmanship/finish nor is it something that I would rate as outstanding. The quality of the piece is such that I feel it is a good value for the money.

Finally, as with many products of this type, the value that a consumer sees is dependent on the expectation. When I ordered this product my expectations were moderate, especially because of the price. In an age where we demand low price but often want high quality, it is often best if we expect moderate to good quality instead. I did that with this product as was pleasantly surprised to find that the quality was at least good, if not just a tad bit better than good. For that reason, and those set out above, I'd make a recommendation to buy this product.

NOTE: I received this product at a reduced cost in exchange for the promise to file an honest and unbiased review. To meet that obligation, I typically use the product for an extended period, no less than two weeks, and under the typical conditions that one might use for a product of this type.
summary: I love this product. It does the job so well that I have ordered a second set.

First, the product is working fine.  However, the instruction booklet describes all sorts of restrictions not mentioned in Amazon's product descriptions:
1) You must provide your own batteries (no biggie); 2) Maximum pressure is 60 psi; 3) not for use on outlet end of 'Y' connections or other hose accessories.

I am violating both #2 (60 psi is pretty low) and #3.  So far so good, but folks should be informed of these "restrictions".

The pros:
- nice kit using standard 1/4" tubing
- inline drippers have an adjustable throughput from 0 to 6l/h (about 2.5gal/hour)

The cons:
- hose adapter and pressure reducer are in plastic
- 60 feet of tubing is not that long
- timer has 15 preset programs as follows:
1. 2 min every 6h
2. 5 min every 6h
3. 2 min every 12h
4. 5 min every 12h
5. 10 min every 12h
6. 5 min every 24h
7. 15 min every 24h
8. 30 min every 24h
9. 60 min every 24h
10. 90 min every 24h
11. 30 min every 48h
12. 60 min every 48h
13. 60 min every 72h
14. 90 min every 72h
15. 120 min every week
If you need any other setting, you have to get another timer.

Summary:
Get the Claber Logica Basic Drip Kit (90764) that is the same kit but without the timer and goes for around $35 (not sold yet on Amazon, Google for it). Get a separate timer for your needs.

I have ordered extra basic kits to expand the watering to the rest of my landscaping. Note that you can find 100ft 1/4" tubing for $6.95 at home depot.
summary: Get the basic kit instead without the timer

This was not my first choice for a tow behind dethatcher.  I was look at these three brands Craftsman, Agri-Fab, and Brinly Hardy 48-inch Dethachers.  The Agri-fab and Craftsman dethatcher need to add weight(two cement blocks) to work proper and for that reason I chose not go with those two brands.  The Brinly DT-48H Tow Behind Dethatcher(built in the USA!!!!!) was the only Tow Dethatcher where no added weight is needed to work properly.  The assembly was not too bad but if you have no experience with assembling large mechanical items I would not recommend this product( for a novice, the assembly can be challenge).  After the assembly, the DT-48H is solidly built it will not fall apart( make sure to tighten all those nuts)and will last a long time.  Before you take this lawn dethatcher on your lawn you must place the dethatcher(connected to lawn tractor) on a flat surface to perform a towing arm level check.  Once that is done you are really to begin dethatching your lawn.  I could not believe the amount of dead grass, moss, and other organic material that was coming up.  My grass looks a lot better for it.  If you are in the market for an excellent tow behind dethatcher look no further and get the Brinly DT-48H.  What a great buy!!!!!!  One last thing, watch the package of this item.  My box was open the three plastic ring to keep the box together were to big and did not do their job.  I was missing a total of four parts.  I called Brinly customer service(do not call Amazon for missing parts) told the operate what parts was  missing and two days later my missing parts were at my door(Fedex delivery).

Great feeder. Had a couple of wooden feeders that got chewed up. (Not by squirrels. Raccoons ate one.) Squirrels figure it out soon enough, but stellar jays can't. Bought some copper mesh to replace the plastic window if it broke (after reading other reviews). So far, 3 months in, the plastic has held up to multiple attacks from jays and slow-learning squirrels. I did have to do a few modifications: 1)I put some heavy stick-on felt under the lid in spots so it didn't slam down so loudly. It frightened the squirrels and woke me up on days the critters were having breakfast before I got up. I also taped a stick in it to hold the lid up an inch or so to help the smaller squirrels lift it up. I've mounted the feeder on a railing, so the squirrels have something to stand on when they open it. This may be why it's held up better than other reviews indicated. I'd recommend you put a little platform for the squirrels to stand on when they lift the lid. This thing holds about 2+ pounds of peanuts in the shell, so the supply lasts longer than other feeders I've had.
summary: Great feeder. The metal holds up better than wood feeders.

The product arrived as expected and in good condition. This is a real plus to add to the anchors on my 8x8 cantilever umbrella. It was easy to fill with 100 lbs of play sand, about 6 bucks at local home depot. The velcro opening on the top was perfect for adding sand. I put 50 lb bag  on my out building floor about 1 1/2 ft off the ground. I used a funnel with large opening at top and cut the bottom of funnel off to make length and opening fit my purpose. I situated the premier bad under the corner of the sand bag and then cut off the corner of bad and let sand drain into the bag. I could move funnel side to side to help distribute and also easily controlled flow of sand. I put about 75 lbs in the premier bag. I put umbrella base in its position then fitted it through the center hole of the premier sand anchor. I used stakes to anchor base to the ground and the used a large measuring cup and hand filled the remaining sand into the premier sand anchor. It has so far worked extremely well and I don't anticipate any problems with normal use.

It's OK.  That's about all I can say about this product for a couple of reasons. First, I followed all the directions with two remotes and everything linked up correctly.  I laid them flat on the counter so they could calibrate their temperatures.  The two remotes both read 70.5 whereas the main unit read 71.8.  I let them sit for about 30-45 mintues but the wall unit never quite seemed to match what the other two units were reading.  I can only assume the other two remotes were accurate because they did match up correctly/  The wall unit is not accurate, it seems to be hot by 1-3 degrees depending on the day.  The remote functions seem to be accurate, and I honestly care most about this feature.  I have one remote down in my chicken coop and one on my house on the north side under the eave.  The chicken coop is a good 100 feet away from the unit.  They appear to still be accurate, but I have yet to compare with a mercury tube. The battery cover is poorly designed and cheap.  It feels as if it could just slip off the back of the remotes from gravity alone.  Overall I am happy with what I got as it helps me monitor the two outside temps, but I did buy this with the intentions of having three accurate readings not just 2.  So I guess they are firing at 66% for me.

reviewText:
Will cover a 29" table and 32" high chairs to a diameter of 6' with about a foot of chair leg showing.

Just the way a good backpack will have all the straps and buckles and openings you need, this cover will provide you with what you need to cover up outdoor items and keep them dry and secure in the wind and rain.

This is a quality cover. It has thick fabric, 4 vents, and one zippered opening from the center down to the hem. The hole for the umbrella has a velcro-secured cover when not in use. The hem can be drawn taut  by pulling the elastic cord taut with the the friction-lock tabs. There are snap-buckle straps to hook around chair legs for additional wind resistance.  The fabric sheds water in big beads. the light tan color might will show dirt more than a patterned design, but is attractive. Rather than undo the zipper I just throw the cover over the furniture and tug this way and that to adjust. But the zippered opening gives you the option of taking a little more time and a lot less effort for covering awkward arrangements of furniture.

How it will hold up to a summer of sun remains to be seen. Made in China but obviously to good specificartions. This is a well made cover.

We have areas that are supposed to be plant free. I'm sure you  have them too. In the past I've used long term herbicides that get into the soil and prevent any plant growth in the area. While great in that respect, they also "bleed" into the lawn and I find dead patches adjacent to the cleared area. I decided to try the Spectracide weed and grass killer because the manufacturer claims it doesn't work in the soil. It is supposed to kill only those plants that the spray hits.

So, I added 7 oz.of the concentrate to a gallon of water in my sprayer and went to work. The product claims to show visible results in as little as 3 hours. Three hours went by and no results. The next morning was a different story. Plants in the sprayed area were obviously dying. Excellent! Hopefully within the next week or so the undesired plant life will be gone.

I think they'll take the place of all the twisty wire pieces in the garden and be fairly reuseable.  They should not be confused or substituted for workshop clamps as they're light and plastic. I live in Florida where growing plants is generally pretty easy, but I have still been running into problems with my outside and inside potted plants regularly losing their vibrant appearance soon after bringing them home from the nursery. I had been trying various plant foods (feeding sticks, pellets, etc.) but getting pretty limited and unsatisfactory results with most of them. I could keep the plants going, but they just never recovered their original gorgeous appearance. I had also used the non-concentrate version of Miracle-Gro with better results, but one very quickly goes through a bottle and the cost goes up considerably. Finally, this season I decided to give the All Purpose concentrate a try and I have been amazed. For the first week or two I saw little difference and was becoming disappointed, but after that the changes started appearing. All the plants are thriving, blooming as they did when first purchased and looking gorgeous, all for very little cost. You simply have to be willing to periodically mix a third of a capfull in a couple gallons of water and you are off to the races. I have since purchased several more bottles and will be using this from now on. The cost is very reasonable and the benefits and results are terrific. I even tried this on an orchid that had not bloomed in months (I did not have any specific orchid food), and even that is looking fantastic. Count me as one more very satisfied customer.
summary: Never thought my plants could look so great

I received this as a birthday present on 12/12/11 and right away this is one of those products that I wish I had though of! Assembly is easy, it takes about 5 minutes requiring only a Philips screwdriver. Initially, you have to charge the battery for 5 hours, then 4 hours each subsequent time. On my first charge I got about 30 minutes of run time, which was enough to skim the pool twice, two days apart. I'm used to only getting about 10 minutes run time out of an r/c car so I thought the run time was pretty good. The net does a good job of catching most everything floating on the surface and it is easy to remove and empty, just don't reverse both motors with the net in because it will quickly blast everything you picked up back into the pool!

One thing I noticed is when running full forward or backward the props create a whirlpool that makes them cavitate; I'm not sure if that's bad for these little motors or not. It is especially noticeable if you are running the boat without the net installed. I think a little bit of extra weight on the motors would solve this problem, I'll try it and report back.

Overall I am very pleased with this product, it is a lot of fun to use and serves a purpose at the same time! Now if they would just make an r/c submarine to clean up the crap on the bottom of the pool...
summary: Skimming the pool is fun now!!

I too, like Duffer "Bo" have had my feeder up for a while with no woodpeckers visiting. I have a fly through feeder and the pileated woodpeckers visit that to get whole peanuts every day. I also have a pole mount cup that they use daily to get peanuts. All of these are on the same feeding station, but alas this one remains untouched. I gave this five stars because it is extremely well made. My review is based on the product and not whether or not it is visited. I will leave it up and see what happens. I have a Brome Squirrel Buster Peanut Plus feeder Squirrel Buster Peanut Plus Wild Bird Feederwith shelled peanuts and they seem to like that a lot. That one is hanging on a tree, close to the bark. As birdwatchers, we need to be patient. It took the woodpeckers about three weeks to find and visit the feeder with shelled peanuts. I am sure that this will be visited; in the meantime, I'll be patient and keep checking. Update 5/2/12 This feeder has been used for the past month by both woodpeckers and blue jays. It is great that it can fit two cakes so that I don't have to refill as often. The woodpeckers and blue jays love it and I love looking at them. I am truly happy with this purchase and would definitely recommend this to anyone looking for a great feeder. Another fine product from Birds Choice!

reviewText: Nothing wrong with this.  Use indoors for a great look

Awesome stuff. For those not familiar with this product here is a quick lesson: You put chlorine or Baquacil in your pool to kill algae and other "stuff". Algae eats phosphates which are naturally occurring from dead skin cells from your body, junk from the air, and more. This product removes those phosphates from your pool thus leaving no food for the algae. If algae has no food, it can't live, thus reducing the amount of chlorine or Baquacil needed and leaving you with a sparkling easy maintenance pool.

If you have never used this product before here is a quick step by step process:
1. Ensure all chemicals are in balance (PH, Hardness, Alkalinity, etc)
2. Vacuum the pool like you have never cleaned it before. Trust me, take your time and get the whole pool clean.
3. Add product as described.
4. Run the pump for 24 hours min

After 24 hours you may notice a cloud fog to show up in the bottom of the pool. No worries, this is a bunch of dead phosphates and they just need time to get cleared out by the filter. I tried to vacuum them out but they are so small they went straight through my sand filter.  I added earth to the filter (yes you can add earth to a sand filter) and this caught a lot of the cloud, but it also immediately plugged the filter and I had to change the earth 4-5 times. If you stay on a regular basis and add this product about 2 times a year you won't have the cloud problem.

I highly recommend this product. After year of owning a pool this is one that definitely is worth the cost.
summary: Definitely worth the price and has everlasting benefits

The description on Amazon does not say so, but the Nia boots feature soft, warm furry wool blend linings throughout.  The insole is sheepskin, the uppers are leather, including the shaft (I contacted Bearpaw to verify this).  They are cozy and soft inside, and you don't have to wear them with socks to stay warm.  The strap across the back top of the boot is just a design element - it does not have a snap or Velcro, it is sewn in place.  There are also outer boot pulls but not inner ones, though you don't really need either since the boots have an inside side nylon zipper.  The design is on trend and the slight curve to the back of the boot with the upper strap is flattering to the leg.  It's nice to have a boot that is both stylish enough to wear out, and warm enough to wear outside  :)  Please note that these are warm, fall/winter boots - because of the plush linings and the thicker sole, they have a heavier profile than standard leather dress boots but they are not snow boots, either.  There is texture to the soles for some grip, but the soles are not lug style or overly thick.  I wouldn't stand in snow or on ice with them for very long.

Bearpaw sizing can be iffy sometimes but the Nia's run true to size and are completely comfortable right out of the box.  They're not a very stiff leather boot and won't require a breaking in period.  The toe cap is raised slightly and rounded so your toes aren't cramped.  Bearpaw seems to have taken the plush linings and the sheepskin insole into consideration when doing the sizing on the Nia boot so that you can order your regular size and still have room for thin socks or tights without having to size up.  As for the boot shafts I have average calves, maybe a tad on the heavier side of average, and these fit comfortably with my (not so skinny) jeggings tucked inside.

The Nia's are really nice looking "in person", though I would have liked a better finish to the leather.

UPDATE:  I originally ordered these in Chocolate and when I received them, they had some black spotting (dye?) on the inside side of one boot.  I really loved the fit/feel of them and since it wasn't extremely noticeable when wearing, decided to keep them.  As a matter of fact, I even ordered a 2nd pair in Black.  But when I received the black ones, they had white-ish marks on the boots, almost like bleach stains.  After having ordered 2 pair and receiving both defective, I am sending the black ones back.  This is not an Amazon problem, it is a quality control problem within Bearpaw because the stains on the black ones were so bad they could not have been missed if they had been inspected before packaging.  I would still rate the boots themselves as 5 star, but I am very disappointed in Bearpaw and their lack of quality control.

My husband and I live on wooded acreage in the Pacific Northwest. We experience all four seasons and our summers can be quite hot at times.  Last summer we purchased a 300-gallon cattle trough that we affectionately named our Red Neck Hot Tub. Instead of packing up and heading to the lake when the temperature gets unbearable we cool down by sitting in the tub.  When we are not using our tub, we keep it covered to keep out the pine needles and bugs.  In the past we used a tarp and bungie cords which is a big challenge if you are by yourself.  After putting the tub away for winter, we decided we needed to find another option to keep the water clean when not in use.  I had purchased other covers from this seller to protect my outside furniture and have been very pleased.  I decided to see if they had anything that would work for our needs.  I found this cover and it is exactly what we were looking for! The heavy material will last for years, and there is a handy pull cord on the bottom to keep the cover in place.
This cover is designed to cover a large patio table and chairs, but it is perfect for so many other uses.  If you calculate the price of a decent tarp this product is a real bargain.

I purchased 2, 10 lb pails of these and have used about a 1/4 bucket on one. I put them in some water and then added some Miracle Grow Miracle-Gro 3001192 All Purpose Plant Food - 10 Pound. Once they swell up to about a nickle size, I integrated them into the soil of my container garden. Well a few days later, we had about 3-4 days of heavy rain. Next thing I know, I see the monster-sized gooey things on the ground and at the top of the container. The containers have plenty of drain holes, but I guess all of the heavy rain just super charged the crystals' sizes. I mean they push straight up through several 5 gallon buckets. I put the crystals about midway in the buckets about where I thought the roots may grow. After a couple of very hot days, the ones on the ground and on the top of the buckets just lost all of their form and liquidized into this plasma-looking flat blob. I used my hand and pulled out as much of it as I could from the rest of my buckets. As they were pushing their way up through the soil, they know out a whole lot soil. So, I just did not wish to go through that again during the next heavy rain. Also after seeing the gooey blog that they turned in to when exposed to the sun, I just decided I did not wish for that gunk to be in with food I was going to eat!!! For a cool-looking project to do with kids, I would likely give this item about a 4-star rating; however, for my purposes, it just did not fit the bill. I can't say that these crystal won't help the soil hold or put moisture into the soil. However, I can't say that they will either. I will say that (1) based on the size that these crystals can get, a 10 lb bucket will go a very long way in terms of relative size. (2) I originally was going to put these into a raised bed but decided not to tackle that this year...so maybe they would work better in a larger area (3) If you do use them for gardening, remember a little goes a long way...or at least don't let their tiny initial size fool you to how big they can potentially get when exposed to a lot of moisture like rainstorms, especially for a container garden. Because I have so much of the stuff (almost 18 lbs) left, I am thinking about trying a very small amount in some containers and plants some flowers. If they pan-out in that application, I will certainly update this review and be fair!!!
summary: Crystals Hold Water But Not Sure If It Keeps Soil Moist

reviewText:
This is a very sturdy cover for patio chairs and it is a hickory color that blends in well with the surroundings. Although this particular cover was meant for Adirondack chairs so it is a little wider and higher than the regular patio chair. But that made it perfect for covering up some stacked patio chairs.

It drapes over the chairs nicely and gives protection from the elements. Especially in the Pacific Northwest where it rains often and the moist chairs can get a little moldy and weathered. There are vents in the cover that keep it from lofting in the wind, and also keep it mildew free if it does get damp inside. The handle in front makes it easy to lift it off the chairs when needed. It also works in the garage of course to keep your chairs dust free if they're not being used often.

The click lock strap and the elasticized hem ensure it gives a good fit around the chair(s). It can get weathered in a couple of seasons, especially on an uncovered deck but if it's not exposed to direct sunlight all the time it will last longer.
summary: Sturdy cover for wide patio chairs and Adirondack chair.

reviewText:
I have lusted after the AeroGarden since I first spied one here on Amazon.  I looked at them in stores, online and read websites dedicated to getting the most out of one.  This not the biggest one in the lot but it provides six spaces to grow herbs, lettuce, small tomatoes or even flowers!  You can even buy plug kits to grow your own whatever.  It is a hydroponic system that you add clean water (I used purified) and a few capfuls of liquid fertilizer.  Everything snapped together quite easily and I had it set up and running in about 15 minutes.  I have it sitting on my counter underneath a cabinet.  I have no other place to put, but luckily I can shut off the light that is directly above it.

Right now, I am currently growing the herb pods that came with the kit and most sprouted in one week.  Be sure to put the taller ones in the center.  Everything runs on an automatic timer and it couldn't be any quicker or easier.  I tried growing some of these herbs  outdoors but I have a huge problem with critters eating everything that is not fenced.  My lettuce was the first to be devoured.  I really want to try the lettuce kit next and to see if I can experiment with starting seed for transplant later.
Nice flag, well made, reasonably priced, and proudly flying now

Pretty impressive performance from this lithium powered trimmer.  Assembly was quick and easy and I was out the door giving it a trial run with one of my LBXR20 lithium batteries from my Black & Decker hedge trimmer or blower.

The device was used primarily on the extended run-time setting which gave more than enough opportunity to clear the concrete walk, two driveways and some weedy overgrowth on the front and back yards.  I still had power left on the battery when I was done and put it back in the charger after somewhere in the 20 to 30 minute range. (I didn't wear a watch so I can't be precise.)  If I got this much from the less powerful battery, I'm sure I'll be impressed with the run-time of the supplied double power battery.

As far as I could tell, the feeder and line both did their job admirably but since I don't know how to judge how much time or work I'll get out of the original spool I went ahead last night and ordered up a two pack of replacements for future use.

All in all I must say that I have been very impressed with the three B&D products I have from this line...string trimmer, blower / sweeper and hedge trimmer.
At some point I may consider the quick charger but am not having any issues with the supplied chargers as I usually have a spare battery ready to go.

reviewText:
The Mpow Soar Powered Wireless LED Motion Sensor Light is just what I needed. We live in the country and have no big yard lights, we don't like them. But... the deck area is in three levels and there have been times when coming back to the deck from a dark yard became a problem. The Mpow has a very dim, unobtrusive glow which slightly lights part of the deck all night. When someone comes onto the deck area, it gets bright and stays on for a couple of minutes. If motion continues to be detected it continues to stay bright. It worked the first night I installed it after getting sun for about 2 hours. I just attached the unit to the south wall of house with one screw. It has a place for two screws.
 I have no idea how long it will last, though, it states that it has a 5 year warranty. Only time will tell. I did have three sensor lights on the back sheds, from another company, which used batteries and one light died in a year, even before the batteries died. I like the idea of no batteries, and hope this unit will last.
Works to specs/.

As to concept and design this is a four-star product.  The bar and chain are of comparable quality to the ones on my gas-driven 'ranch size' chain saws.  The low-kickback design features are important to safe use of chain saws.  I like the window for seeing bar oil level. With my big saws there is no way to do that conveniently.  Weight is reasonable at eight pounds or so but the unit will 'feel' heavier the farther the pole is extended from the handle.  Short persons with short arms who are not normally physically active will not find the physics of this unit to be comfortable for long periods of sawing.  The younger and stronger an adult you are, the more you will like working with this unit.

Early reviews of this saw are good on information.  Some conclusions depend on point of view.  The oval extender profile is good in comparison to a hypothetical round pole but I prefer the 'stirrup' type of 'u' shaped bar attachment, such as the ones on my gas-powered trimmers, for better leverage and control.  It is also very important not to over-extend the pole and equally important to really twist down on the extension locking ring to prevent rotation of the cutting head during use.

As to the 'electric' part of this system:  6.5 amps seems to be fine for light trimming and pruning.  An electric saw can be as dangerous as a gas model.  Maybe this tip comes more from the 'Legal Department' at Black and Decker but they recommend using a circuit with a Ground Fault Interrupter built in.  This is not a commonly found feature of outside electrical outlets.  Care must be taken not to overload a circuit and heavy duty, double insulated extension cords will also be necessary.  Those are just a few of the points raised in the owner/operator's manual that comes with the unit and it is a manual that should be read carefully and followed closely.

The 'crunch' in rating this power tool is how often it will get used and how far out your extension cords will reach and how much higher it will reach.  My experience is that the saw will only reach four-to-five feet over your shoulder height.  The manual cautions that the control switch should stay below shoulder level during operation.  Stringing 'endless' power cords out into the yard costs power as distance increases and not every home has as many perimeter power outlets as mine does.  This is not the tool to use for 'felling' even saplings.  It is for shaping by working on unwanted branches or for removing dead or damaged lower limbs on young trees or shrubs.  Soon enough the typical home owner will have done all that is needed in that line to every reachable tree or shrub in the yard.  Then the tool will sit around until a neighbour asks to borrow it.
summary: Four Stars for Design; Execution.  Three Stars for Long-term Need

I am seriously regretting buying from beyondnice.  They shipped my spa cover through some third rate company call YRC shipping, and it was delayed by nearly a week, did not return my calls until days later, and then when they finally called me to schedule a delivery, they said that they could only deliver M-F, from 11am-2pm.  I said "really there's no other way?  So I have to take a day off of work for a stupid delivery."  Their delivery terminal said "yes that's correct."  No explanation, no apology.  The only way they would deliver it without me missing an entire day to receive a box was if I signed a piece of paper releasing the right to get my money back if it were damaged, missing parts, or not even the right item.

And by the way, when you originally purchase the item from beyondnice, their instructions emphasize that if you do not reject the shipment by inspecting it at the delivery time, then beyondnice will not refund or build you a spa cover if it is built wrong or damaged.

So it's a nice little racket they've put together.  There's no way for them to be responsible for mistakes as long as the people purchasing these products need to work.

UPDATE:  It's now going on 4 weeks since I made my order, and the shipper has lost the package, and beyondnice is still going back and forth with me deciding whether to make another one.  Sometimes, ESPECIALLY when it comes to custom, made-to-order products, it's all about the customer experience.  In this case, an awful customer experience.
summary: Do not order from this company:  Buyer beware

Before you buy one, perform this simple test.

Lay a tomato seedling on its side.
Water and fertilize normally
See how the plant grows up, at a right angle, towards the sun?

That's what happens when you plant anything upside down. My plants exhausted themselves trying to grow in a 'U' shape and ended up with all sorts of problems; unlike the SAME SEEDLINGS PLANTED IN A GARDEN JUST 20 FEET AWAY!

Scotts continues to innovate and bring products, like this EZSeed, that appeal to the home gardener who does not have a lot of time to fix their lawns (or like me are lazy). And, of course, the container is designed to easily dispense this mixture from waist height or close to the ground.  You get a good spread and it comes out evenly.

reviewText:
Beware...this is the heavily flowering cultivar of Comfrey. Taller and more invasive than the Bocking 4 or Bocking 14 cultivars.

The positive side is that they are excellent pollinator attractors; superb for composting; and deep root nourishment taps for your other nearby surface plants.  That being said, they will self seed and overtake a garden if not effectively controlled.

This also not the most used for medicinal purposes, and what we call "Knitbone".  The Bocking cultivars are better for that, as well as for using as mulch which will break down very quickly. The Bocking varieties are also better for making comfrey tea for you garden. (Very smelly though!!)

Nonetheless, we grow this variety and control it in order to primarily have the flowers which bring the bees....and they in turn pollinate the rest of our garden.
summary: Great if this is specifically what you are looking for. This is NOT Bocking 4 or 14 cultivar. Can be VERY invasive....CAUTION!

Power to burn! Supper mulcher. Not too heavy for power. Solid feeling and smooth running. Every attachment you will probably ever need. Not very noisy for power produced. I bought this as a back up for my gas blower. I underestimated this thing big time! Overall it out performs my gas leaf blower so I will be retiring it as of today. This is the second time I have bought a electric powered lawn maitainence device and it worked so well I retired the gas powered equivalent I had been using. Both products were Torros. Is it perfect? Nope. To get the best out of it I ended up using a good quality 12 gauge extension cord even at distances of 50'. Naturally dragging a heavy 100' extension cord around is a real drag at times but then I remember how temperamental the gas equivalent was and it really doesn't seem so bad and it sure starts easier. Then I also remember no more gas and oil mixing and plug changing etc. Yep, that cord gets easier and easier to handle now that I think about it with proper perspective. Did I mention how easy it starts and how long it runs on one plug in? I love this thing! Get ya' one.
summary: Hard to find fault with this bad boy!

reviewText: I ordered this Hula-Ho weeder because of all the great reviews.  However it didn't work in my garden when I tried to use it to get ride of the weeds.  This rake's blade is completely dull, the edge of the blade is about 1 mm thick,  smooth and round.  Because of that, if your garden bed has not been turned well recently or  the soil is dry and clay and there are a few weeds grow together this rake will not work. It will not cut through the weeds or cut into the  dry soil.  You will be using the dull edge to scrape the top surface of the soil.  A few reviewers suggested that sharpen it will make it work better.  Since I don't have the right tool to sharpen this brand new rake,  it still sits in my garage, completely useless.
