reviewText:
These traps helped me get rid of a nasty little whitefly problem on my houseplants. I did use these traps indoors, so I'm not sure how effective they are when used outdoors.
The traps were great for trapping the adult whiteflies, thereby keeping them from multiplying further, but I also took some advice I found online and washed each of the infested plants with plenty of soapy water to get rid of eggs and larva that were stuck to the underside of the leaves. You have to really get in there and rub each leaf individually with soapy water and then rinse well, because the eggs that they lay are very sticky and you want to remove all of that stuff before they hatch. I used dishwashing detergent and even though it was a pain, I was able to get rid of those nasty bugs that were killing my plants.

So the traps didn't singlehandedly solve my problem, but they absolutely helped. They do what they're supposed to do, but I recommend a good washing of the plants if you're serious about getting rid of these pests.

This package of 15 was a really good value. I assumed I would get 15 strips or whatever, but I got 15 large sticky traps that were more than enough to spread throughout the apartment around all of my plants, and I still have some left over, which hopefully I will not have to use. It was a really good deal for the price, and the traps arrived within a few days of ordering. Very satisfied.

reviewText: I will never go back to the old fashion metal snake!!  This way is so much better!  Instead of going thru the clean-out Y, and making a mess under the sink,  I went through the roof vent.  With 100'  I was able to get well into the main sewer line.  The jetter's plastic coating makes it slippery and easy to push through the sewer line and it is light in weight.  Instead of turning on my pressure washer at the start I turned it on after I had pushed the jetter hose all the way in.  Then I turned on the pressure washer and slowly pulled out the jetter.  Worked like a charm!!  Unlike a metal snake the clean-up of the jetter hose was a breeze.  To be fair, a couple of days before I used the jetter I put in two bottles of lye based sewer line cleaner, thru the vent line, to turn the oil and grease into soap.  I'm sure this helped the cleaning of the sewer line.  The hose is now sitting in my tool shed waiting for it's next job.
summary: Never go back to the old fashion metal snake!

reviewText: I used it two or three times this year and apples were abundant and nice size without problems.

I've been watching the ants in my yard for quite a while. I've seen their well-worn trails around the base of my foundation, along my fence posts, and under my wood pile. I've also learned (through the internet) that they really like to live in rotten wood, and they are more active at dusk. One evening, I went out at dusk and sprinkled some of this stuff all along those trails and put a little extra near the places where I suspected their colonies to be. I came back to check on them a few minutes later and discovered that they had immediately swarmed the bait and had started carrying it back home. It was amazing to watch the ants go after this stuff - they were quite enthusiastic about it! In fact, their swarming action helped me identify several more potential colonies and I was able to put down even more bait to target those specifically. When I went out to look again the next morning, the bait was pretty much all gone except for a few straggler ants pulling in the last few crumbs. Haven't seen much in the way of ant activity since then! Great product.

Lucky for me that I had some 1/4" gas copper coil and a flare tool,  I replaced that line.  When replacing, I found that the aluminum line was easy to break.  A slight twist and the other end of the line broke at the opposite fitting.

You'd thing for $2500+ dollars, Weber would use use better materials than aluminum for gas lines,  The copper line I used will now last as long as the grill.  It amazes me that manufacturers will save pennies by using the cheapest materials for critical components that can create a real danger for consumers.  Think of GM's ignition switch that will cost them billions.

This is a great little grill. I like the 4 vents for regulating heat. The cheaper competition often does not have much (if any) heat regulation options. My issue with this grill is it is very pricey for what you get, considering many big box hardware stores brands are 1/3 the price with more features and a larger size.  It would be nice if the base clamped to the body and had side handles like some of the competition. The built in thermometer is nearly useless. It reads 75 to as much as 150 off reality. In looking on the internet, it seems the grilling world is well aware of the poor quality of that part. For what this unit costs,  an even moderately reliable thermometer does not seem like too much to ask for.  It would be nice to have a hinge or hanging hook for the hood as well. 3rd party kits are available, but I would rather not hack up the unit right out of the box.

My history with Weber grills has been exceptional, so it 'might' well be worth the extra $, only time will tell.  Would I buy this again; yes, for what I paid - I got a store display at a big discount, but I am not sure I would pay $200+ for it.
summary: I love it, but have reservations.

We've been experimenting with fly ribbons for many years (home, work, warehouse, etc).

Pic has always been, and remains, the most effective. It's because they add something like linseed oil to the ribbon, which acts as an attractant (has kindof a sour smell). But it appears they recently changed their formula to have less smell (and less attractant), probably due to customer complaints about smell. Argh.

I found an old box of Pic ribbons, and hung an old one next to a newer one - the old one caught twice as much. Regardless, even the new Pic catches more than any of the others we've tested (Raid, Victor, Catchmaster, etc etc).

This 30-pack is a great deal, currently $6 Prime. I hung one in the kitchen last night because we've had fuit flies hanging around, and the Raid strip I hung there hadn't caught anything. Overnight, it caught 14 fruit flies (didn't even know I had that many), AND a moth AND a mosquito!

I can't vouch for different insects in different parts of the country (I'm writing in the midwest). But in my experience, the Pic catches anything that flies - moths, flies, gnats, fruit flies, mosquitos, even wasps.

For price... Walmart used to carry these at $2.88 per 10-pack. So I consider anything under 30 each a good price. I haven't seen Pic in stores for a long time, not even the local hardware stores, so I'm glad I found a good deal on Amazon.
summary: This new formula less effective, but still better than any other brand

I received a sample of this product for evaluation and review and give it a nice 4 stars. I regularly use the gloves and claws when cooking (not just BBQ). The flexible grilling skewers, grilling mat and injector are nice, but I don't know that I will use them often.

I really like the silicone gloves - I've been using cloth Cuisinart mitts forever, but they are horrible - you can't hold hot things for too long, can't get the fingers wet, and they get dirty easily. Silicone gloves are awesome!! I picked up a steak with the gloves to turn them over on the BBQ grill! When I roasted a chicken in my oven, I didn't have to worry about getting the thumb into the juices in the pan. What a relief. The gloves fit awkwardly though, the fit isn't anything like normal gloves. I'm guessing this makes it easier for all sized hands to wear? I don't really know. But they fit me fine, and I usually wear Large for Women's gloves.

The claws are handy: I used them for carving a huge slab of meat, as well as a chicken.

The injector unfortunately comes sealed in that crappy plastic case so I haven't bothered to open it yet because I already have a plastic one that I use. If you have never used a syringe before for your turkey.. DO IT!! I normally hate turkey at Thanksgiving and think its bland and boring, but using a syringe full of fresh herbs and juice will make your turkey MOUTHWATERING DELICIOUS. I could eat that everyday!

I also have not used the black thin mats because I like to have grill marks on my food. I will probably never use them, but they are nice a large.

The flexible metal grilling skewers are neat, but I don't know if I will ever cook enough to use them (I usually only cook for 2 people). If I ever entertain a large party for BBQ, I will definitely use them to marinate and grill large amounts of food. How convenient they must be to marinate and easily fold into a large tupperware for marination!

Hope my review helps and happy shopping.
summary: Nice BBQ set - gloves & claws useable for everyday cooking too

summary: This direct spray is more effective than the bottle to hose attachment version. Dandelions are dead.

reviewText: Handy tool to have for RV's. Wand makes it very convenient flush out toilet and any other plumbing.

I ordered the Generac 6596 2,800 pressure washer and when it arrived, I couldn't wait to start using it to clean my driveway.  Setup was very easy, taking about 20 minutes to get the pieces out of the box, get the handle onto the frame, screwing on some hoses, and adding oil and fuel.  No tools were required, so even the most unskilled person could get this thing working easily.

The instructions remind you in multiple places never to start without having your water hooked up and turned on, so as long as you follow the setup instructions, it shouldn't be a problem getting the washer working.  Mine started on the first pull, which is pretty impressive.

This model of Generac comes with 4 wand tips, ranging from a cleaning solution tip to a 0 degree "blast" tip.  I paired mine up with a Karcher T350 surface cleaner (rated at 2650 psi, so use at your own risk), and it worked great cleaning my driveway.  It made a normally 2 to 4 hour job a 45 minute job, plus it didn't leave streaks or areas where I missed.

The large wheels and upright orientation make the pressure washer easy to move around, and the placement of the hose connectors made it easy NOT to accidentally get the hose up against the hot engine (a cause of failure in other models).  This Generac also comes with a detergent reservoir, although since I didn't use it, I can't say how well it works.

Bottom-line for me:  this is an affordable power washer that does the job.  It cost me less than what I would have paid a professional, it accepted an inexpensive surface cleaner attachment, and it's powerful enough to get a dirt and moss encrusted driveway clean.  I can't speak to long-term reliability, but I will update if there are any significant changes in performance.
summary: Easy to use and very powerful

This is a generic version of Round up, highly concentrated.  It's mixed 3 tablespoons to the gallon, although I use more than that.  I also add a cup of salt to each gallon of mixture, to help poison the roots of the weeds between the stones in my patio.  We treat the weeds less than once a month in the spring and summer, trying to get to them when they first appear.  This is a good bargain for something we use a lot.

I'd say so. I can see absolutely zero difference in plants treated with Golden Tree as compared to a placebo group. Foliage, roots, etc, are all the same in the Golden Tree group. Harvest figures showed no discernible improvement. Quality of the treated plants over three runs was about equal to what I find, grow after grow; Again, no discernible difference with Golden Tree.

I am always hopeful when I pop the cap on a new bottle of a highly rated sup or nute. I am ever in pursuit of surpassing genetic potential. The ability to do so doesn't seem to be in this bottle. It's not in Humbolts Secret Enzymes either and while I have no evidence to any ill effect using Golden Tree, I did with their enzyme. If you are considering their enzyme product, run away. Plants dosed with their enzyme at 1/4, 1/2, and bottle recommended strength all showed stunted growth and I was chasing deficiencies the entire run.

I grow healthy plants. I've been doing so for just shy of 25 years. Though I keep looking for one, I have yet to find a magic elixir. Like most, the ease of an all in one is appealing for simplicity sake. Does that mean that someone won't find benefit from using Golden tree? Absolutely not. It very well might have a place. I just find the efficacy with healthy plants to leave a lot to be desired.
summary: Are the reviews for Golden Tree all hype like most of the reviews on Amazon???

As another reviewer Time2Buy mentioned, she's using it as a cover for a round patio table.  It might be used to cover a birdbath or the upper part of an outdoor fountain during winter months, for example.  I bought the 60-inch round cover.
What I like about it:
1.  It's a basic beige color, and the fire pit stays unnoticed off to the side until it's wanted.
2,  It is waterproof.  Dew and rain bead up and roll off it.
Note: It is NOT fireproof or fire resistant, so of course you need to be sure the fire is completely out and the ashes are cold before you cover the fire pit.
3.  It's lightweight and easy to adjust; because it is lightweight, it folds neatly into a small package to set aside when not in use.  However, lightweight does not mean it is not strong and durable.  The cover that came with our Weber charcoal grill is nearly the same weight and thickness of fabric, and it's seen constant use for 3 years. I expect the Leader Accessories cover to have the same durability.
4.  The bottom of the fabric is elasticized, and there are two toggle buttons at the end of the elastic on opposite side.  Pull on the elastic end, slide the toggle button down to tighten the cover around the fire pit, and it locks in place.  Push the side of the toggle button in to slide the toggle button back up and loosen the elastic.
5.  There are tiedown straps on opposite sides of the cover to securely tie the cover to the legs of the fire pit, especially important for us since we currently have a small firepit and this is a large cover.
6.  There are fabric handles, one on each side of the cover, so it is easy to lift the cover off after you undo the tiedown straps and loosen the elastic bottom.
7.  The cover comes with a large piece of the same fabric for repair if needed. The repair fabric has adhesive on one side; just cut to size, peel off the backing, and apply to cover.
I will update this review in the spring after the cover has been in use through one winter. Our 29.92 inch black steel wood-burning fire pit sits outside on an uncovered back porch, and protection from all types of weather is critical so we don't have to buy a new one every couple of years.
I received this item at a discounted price in exchange for my honest review.  I depend on other reviewers to provide solid information about the product and truthful reviews, and I do the same after testing thoroughly.  If you have any questions, please feel free to leave a comment, and I will get back to you as soon as possible.  If you look at my reviews, you'll see I review items I bought without a discount too. (smile)
summary: Easy on, easy off; effective protection for more than just fire pits

It finally dawned on me that my water pressure was too high for the sprayer (100 psi), and, upon disassembling one of the units, I discovered that a small O-ring in the valve had been displaced by the pressure. reviewText:
I received this as a free review sample. I own a number of grow lights in various sizes and from different brands. What they all have in common is they are truly effective. I mainly grow basil and cilantro, and prefer to grow mine inside because weeds have always been an issue in my outdoors herb gardens.  Suffice to say that I am a fan of any grow light, regardless of which brand.

What I particularly like about this one is the size. Many of my grow lights are much smaller and are better suited for getting a seedling started. This one is good for a fairly large pot (up to five gallons if you suspend this light a meter from the top of your herb or plant.) The suspension means that you will need a socket that can be raised or lowered so that when your plant grows the light can be raised to maintain a meter above height. You can be a little loser, but I have found that a meter is perfect for lights this size.

This light runs cool, so if you are using it in an enclosed space and you have more than one the thermal build-up should not be an issue. Some lights from other brands do tend to get hot and can (and will) change the room temperature in ventilated spaces that may hamper growth.

One factor that you need to take into account is this is a heavy light that weights in around a pound. It needs a sturdy suspension, and must be suspended vertically.
summary: Effective light that is larger and heavier than many, but runs cool

This means that when you're throwing on the side of the drive next to your neighbor's house, you can make it throw right next to the drive, and not on their windows... but when you're pointing it towards someplace where you want the snow thrown further, it will throw up to 12'.

It is a white powder (must stay dry) that when bugs walk through it, the acid later on eats them. Kills all kinds of bugs, not just roaches. I actually like this product and would have given it five stars but mine has broken after only a few times of use. It's also out of warranty as I bought it early last year. I have a possible solution that might prevent his from happening to others.

When this product worked for me it worked VERY well. It put fertilizer right where I needed it and this year my wife's roses look great.

The weakest part of this unit is where the garden hose connects. I am a stickler for making sure the connections are not cross threaded and I had this one on tight when all at once the hose just popped out of the connector. I put it back on making sure that it was tight but not overtightened. Again the hose popped out. When I attempted to reattach the hose the third time the connector would not accept the hose fittings. It cannot be used at all now.

I think part of what caused my problem was me carrying the unit around with the garden hose attached. Be sure and disconnect the hose after use.

If I were to purchase another I will attach a garden hose shut-off valve on it. That way I will not ruin the threads on the unit by constantly attaching and removing a garden hose from the unit itself I would be attaching it to the shut off valve instead.

If you are tempted to carry the unit around anyway with a garden hose attached I might have a solution for that too. I'd attach shut-off valve to the unit and reinforce it with duct tape. Maybe even wrap the tape around a couple of wooden dowels. It certainly will not look pretty but if it saves the unit from breaking it might be worth trying.
summary: Be careful with the hose connection

It doubles a s a seat for several people and guests. You can lock it but lets face it, one can easily cut the plastic and your in. The lock is to keep kids out at best. It doesn't offer much theft deterrence. Adding your own lock system might make it more theft resistant if you concern is security. The back could fold away when not in use. There are products like that but they were way to small for my storage needs so I chose this box. Wheels would be nice too. reviewText: good sh-t

I highly recommend this vacuum if you have an Intex pool.  Not withstanding any bad reviews you might have read, this is a good product.  I have an 18' round by 52" deep pool and this vacuum works extremely well.  I was looking at much more expensive products but this one works just as well and, because it's from Intex, it had a better chance or working with my Intex pool.  I had tried another, very expensive, item and had to return it because my pump didn't have the power it needed when my filter got clogged with debris.  I have a sand filter and that other model was hooked up to the intake line so the debris was sent straight to the sand filter.  This model is hooked up to the return line so the dirt doesn't get to the sand filter directly.  The dirt and debris gets caught in a catch basin inside the vacuum and it has a fine mesh screen that keeps the dirt from going back into the pool.  At first it doesn't seem to be working but as you watch it going about the pool, you start to see it picking up the debris and dirt from the floor.  It has an erratic pattern but it does cover the entire pool bottom. I cleaned the vacuum after the first day of cleaning (6 hours) and I was surprised at the amount of dirt the vacuum had in the catch basin.  I have put away my manual vacuum hose and attachments because this vacuum seems to be working just fine.  It's been running for a few days now and I hope to keep it going for a few seasons. I read many bad reviews from people who stated it doesn't work.  I gave it a try because I'm very mechanically inclined and can fix pretty much anything.  I sometimes wonder what people do to install the item when items don't work for them.  Either way, for every bad review, there are probably 100+ satisfied customers.  The good reviews were very informative and, now that I have used this product, I feel that those good reviews were right on point.

I will say that the hoses need to be installed in their specified manner.  There are two types of hoses (labed B and C) and they have to be installed in alternating fashion because only one of those hoses has a swivel joint.  I read that someone had to keep untangling his hose; I haven't had that issue and my vacuum is running with a solar cover on the top of the water.  The hose untangles itself if you install the hoses correctly.

One reviewer stated that they put their pump on recirculate and that's a good idea if your pump doesn't have the power to run the vacuum. I like to have any debris that gets kicked up by the vacuum picked up by the intake and filtered by the sand.  My pump pressure does go into the yellow/green area but the vacuum still zips around the pool doing it's job.

UPDATE: Here we are a few months later and this vacuum is working perfectly.

2nd UPDATE: We are in our second season with this vacuum and it's still working perfectly. I would also recommend replacing the metal hose clamps with plastic hose clamps. We have a salt pool and the clamps started rusting by the middle of the first season
summary: I rarely give five stars to a product.

reviewText: Top quality shovel; you get what you pay for.
Excellent product thanks!

There are many options out there for capturing the dreaded Japanese Beetle.

Many of them include bags, which you have to purchase in quantity and it's expensive aside from being wasteful.  My dog has chewed through the bags of other systems.

The Tangle Foot trap is re-usable and saves money and waste in the long run.  The traps are well designed, can handle high wind conditions (bags often tear and lose their contents).  The expandable traps are well made and easy to wash out, have drainage holes so the beetles once trapped, do not rot in the summer heat in their own juices.

I made a video where I review the merit of these well designed traps, you may view it on YouTube at [...]
I don't sell them, nor have an interested in marketing them.  My goal is to educate people as to the best and least wasteful methods of capture.

Don't buy bags, that's just silly....  capture and compost or recycle the beetles by giving them to chickens or other birds (kill them in soapy water first).

This is hands down, the most effective method of attracting and capturing Japanese Beetles.

Some will say that drawing beetles to a trap, also brings them to your yard/property from other yards?  This may be true, however, you are indeed removing them from the breeding cycle and over years to come, if you are consistent, the numbers will be reduced greatly.

Without these traps, I would have lost all of my plumb trees to defoliating beetles.

The only thing you have to replace with this system is the bait.  That is very inexpensive in the long run.

Happy Beetle Trapping!
summary: Most cost effective method for trapping and disposing of beatles

I have found that this is one of the best products to kill weeds on my lawn.  I use it to spot treat weeds when it is dry out and rain is not expected within the next two or three days.  Weeds usually start to wilt quickly but take a day or two to die completely.  This is a systemic weed killer so keep it away from desirable plants.

The included spray wand is great because it is an electric pump that runs off the included batteries. I have found this to be the most convenient way to apply the weed killer (hate the ones that need to be pumped).  I have found that Ortho Weed B Gon kills just about all of the weeds I get on my lawn.  It will kill crabgrass but it takes several applications so I just buy Ortho crabgrass killer and use that instead.  Just be sure to follow the instructions and spray when rain is not expected for a few days and this stuff will snuff out those pesky weeds.

I understand why there are soo many negative reviews complaining about the solar charging capability. Don't count on this thing to be a solar charger, more like a decent battery bank with emergency solar capability. I put it to an honest test and have concluded that it performs well for such a small cell. Most people don't fully understand that getting useable power for charging out of a single solar cell is no small task. These cells put out maybe a watt and a half on a good day. I tested by putting in direct sun(angled toward the sun) at a point where the sun would clear an obstruction at exactly the same time every day and hit the panel with full sun. total sun time per day was approx 6hrs. After 4 days, I was up to the second power bar. I was originally unimpressed by this. Then I began depleting back down to 0 power and the point that it would not turn on and charge anything unless pointed directly at the sun. It took over 3 hrs from the second power level, charging a Samsung Galaxy S5 and an Earson BT Speaker both connected streaming netflix. I further tested by trying to power a phone that would not turn on with the charger that would not stay on unless pointed directly at the sun. I was actually able to make a phone call. As Far as the Weather Proofness; it is not. While there are rubber flaps to shed water, they don't seal completely and there are large holed behind the rubber bumpers. See video for more details. So the conclusion is: This thing is worth taking on a backpacking trip for light daily or emergency use and works well as a Battery Bank, but is not a full blown solar charger. If you want full charging capability you want one of these: http://smile.amazon.com/dp/B00HQ5UIFY/?tag=solarbank-20 Watch the full resolution version and commentary on YouTube @GadgetClass Be Sure to use an Amazon Smile Link When you Buy it to Give a Slice to Charity: http://smile.amazon.com/dp/B00KV6GL8I/?tag=solarbank-20
summary: Impressive For a Tiny Solar Cell But Not a Solar Charger & Not WeatherProof

reviewText: I received this yesterday and had it assembled in about 15 minutes including the kickstand. I used it today for about 1 hour to mix peat moss and manure into a bed that had already been tilled using a large tiller. The Mantis did an excellent job of blending all this together and it also found all the rocks (and one full brick) in the ground. The small rocks were all kicked up to the top where I could pick them up. It bounced on the brick and i used a shovel to dig it up. The other bed was a long strip along a fence with no grass. It did a great job of tilling this up and I was very happy with the results. I used a fifty foot 12 gauge extension cord and had no overheating problems and the breaker never tripped as some have reported. I used all three speeds to see how they differed and really couldn't tell much difference. It is a workout to use so keep the painkillers handy for sore muscles but the results are worth it!

I am trying to grow vegetables and herbs on my back porch this year.  I have used Miracle Gro potting soil in the past with good results, but I was feeling too lazy to drive to the home improvement store to buy it, so I ordered on Amazon.

The quality of the soil I received was excellent.  There were very few large pieces and no gnats.  It was easy to scoop out with a pot or a trowel and it holds moisture very well (so make sure your pots have adequate drainage and don't water your plants too often).  The seedlings I transplanted into this soil are thriving thus far.  My past experience with this soil has been that the fertilizers it already contains are good enough for one growing season, at least, so you don't need to add more fertilizer.  Also, if you don't use it all up, it will usually last more than a year in the bag, although opened bags may dry out a bit.

I would caution you to be careful what you're ordering when it comes to package size, since there are many package sizes with many different measurement units available on this page.  I had no idea what the sizes of the bags I had bought in previous years were, so I ordered what I thought was the biggest bag (2.5 cubic feet).  Indeed, that is a big bag -- it had a 55-lb shipping weight per bag!  And now I have three of them.  The good news is that this stuff is inexpensive, lasts a long time, and I've already used half a bag and have lots of planting left to go.  But if you don't have a lot of storage space, you may want to opt for a smaller size.
summary: good soil for potted vegetable plants

I bought two of these feeders about 18 months ago.  I was looking for a couple of the best feeders I could find.  These were very well-reviewed, and they were made of glass.

The bottles are heavy-grade quality glass with screw-on hanger tops.  The bottlenecks are very narrow, which makes cleaning difficult, particularly if any mold has developed inside the bottle.  Also, these are almost impossible to fill  without a funnel.

The feeder base is red plastic with snap-in flower feeders, and they are prone to leak.  Worse, quite a variety of flying bugs and ants are able to get inside the feeder.  The feeder base does not come apart, so you can only keep rinsing until the dead bugs stop floating out.  You can't see the inside edges of the feeder to see if it's clean enough.  After about a year, the plastic flowers started breaking, so I gave up and tossed both feeders.

Curiously, when I first ordered these and was waiting for them to arrive, I picked up a cheap little plastic feeder at a local store.  Not only am I still using it, I just bought four more.  They're made by First Nature, and they come apart completely for cleaning.  Bugs don't seem to get inside these, either.  They were less than half the price of this model, and the hummingbirds like them a lot.
summary: Hard to fill, hard to clean, leaky, and buggy

reviewText: I have a solid safety cover so I need a pump that comes on whenever water accumulates to prevent too much weight from accumulating and damaging the cover.  Unfortunately my experience so far with pumps like those is they have a short life (if they turn on intermittently) or the trigger to turn them on when the water level rises is unreliable.  As a result I use an intermittent pump and they frequently fail - typically once to twice per year!! (They have a 3 year warranty though and the manufacture just sends me a new one for free each time to their credit)  Anyway, I use this pump as a back up when my main intermittent pump fails and I'm waiting for a replacement in the mail.  This pump worked great.  The biggest problem for me, of course, is that I have to turn it on and off manually.  It failed after I left it on too long while draining my cover.  That was my fault but it was on for only 30-60 seconds after water was drained.  That killed the pump which is disappointing.  That is the only reason for 4 four stars.

This mousetrap works a lot like the classic wooden-board-and-spring kind, with a lever that will come crashing down on poor mousie's head. reviewText:
Along with what others said, its good overall, but needs practice.  Don't whip it out to impress your friends without a few test runs.

Its a tad irritating that the front door flops open when lifted by the handle (talking to you lodge).  When you lift it you must be VERY slow and careful or hold the front door shut or it will clank open further unbalancing the grill, making it lean more.  Don't try picking it up with hot dogs on there, they'll all be on the floor.

Its far deeper than it needs to be.  Thinking of putting in a grate to save charcoal.  One layer should be all one needs in a hibachi, this, being similar design should be no different, but unless you flip the grill over, its too far away for one layer of charcoal.  It takes something like 35 briquettes to cook a burger that comes out more BBQ than electric broiler.  If you've looked at the videos some have done on youtube.  Their levels are more along 45-60 briquettes to "fill" the fire pit.  I can get similar results from my full scale webber using similar amounts of coal ( the webber takes up too much patio and shed space btw).  Not to say you couldn't cook something with one layer of coals, but it will be dry and or take forever.

Having no sides at all to the cooking surface make it a poor device to cook thick things.  the radiant heat cooks from the bottom, but any breeze blows the heat right away.  I've cooked a couple thick burgers/steaks where the top and bottom were well seared and leeward side was cooked through, and the windward side was raw.

Completely surprised by this deck box.  I have used many deck boxes over the years, but this Keter deck box is truly a real piece of patio furniture.  Quality shock type hinges, not plastic hinges, has a bracket for a masterlock, absolute sturdiness you could dance on it. Closes easily, no slamming down, very easy to lift the lid.  Adds an area on your patio for up to three or four people to sit.  Gorgeous deep chocolate color. (I hate that my deck looks so bad against this box in my pictures, but starting that stain project again soon.)
I am undecided on what I want to put in this box so buying another one.  I plan to use one in the horse barn tack room to store washed folded winter horse blankets.  Actually this would be nice to use indoors to store human winter blankets too, or even use for a toy box. Or even a dorm room to virtually store most belongings and use for seating. Also could use for folded pool towels, and pool maintenance equipment.  Once you get one of these you are going to start wanting to use them for other uses than on the deck.

reviewText:
Got it for deadheading and it's doing the job comfortably. I've always used pruners for clipping back the flowers, but sometime accidentally clipped off whole stems I didn't want removed. The narrow point on these snips allows more precision. I should have used something like this in the last few decades of gardening.  These aren't for woody pruning, seem best for softer stems.  They are sharp, and the lever that holds the blades closed does the job, although I haven't been able to operate that one-handed.

These are working well on my geraniums and zinnias, and very useful for snipping off what I need from my parsley, cilantro, and basil plants. Since these are the first such snips I've ever tried, I offer no comparison. Only other comment is that these are small in the hand so I wonder if they are comfortable for men's hands.

edit:  backyardgardenpros has an interesting and somewhat amusing website with tips on these snips as well as other gardening issues. I'm enjoying my visit. You might want to take a peek.

I previously used an electric Troy-Bilt model cultivator.  Frankly, I loved it.  With the small size and the power that it had, I was able to till up lawn and create garden space.  I wrote a glowing review here on Amazon.  But after about six or seven years it died on me.  I was going to have it repaired, but instead saw a refurbished model of the Sun Joe here on Amazon.  I figured the total price would be less than the repairs on my old one, so I gave it a shot.  This thing is a little monster!  For starters, it's 50% wider than the Troy-Bilt was, so it gets the job done a lot faster, and all with no less digging power (despite using two extra tines by comparison).  I like the wider handles as compared to my old ones narrow grasp. I've dug up all kinds of beds and garden spaces, plowed into my huge compost pile and spare dirt pile and it just keeps churning and breaking down everything.  No rock jams at all after using it last fall and this spring.  One minor inconvenience is that the tines don't come off easily for cleaning/clearing, but I've been able to unwrap roots by hand to clear it out with them still mounted.  I'd say it's a fair price at the normal rate, but the deal I got on the refurbished model was an absolute steal.

reviewText: I have received SO many compliments on this terrace board and it is much cheaper online than in stores. Other users had recommended the need to unroll it and leave it in the sun. They are spot on. It makes it so much easier to work with. It does get slight waves in it if the day is very hot, but as I have mulch right up to the edge and flowers that will fill the space, I do not feel that detracted from the quality of the product at all. I feel it looks much better than the black borders I had used before. I did use the Terrace Board stakes that are recommended for it and I couldn't imagine putting the board down without it. It is incredibly hard and can be difficult to cut. I used both a little saw and Kitchen shears to see which would work better. If you know exactly how much you need and can saw it, that would be best. I sawed and then lightly sanded to smooth the edges. There were some areas that I was adding curves to and wasn't sure of the exact length I would need in the end but was able to use the shears. The shears were fortunately strong enough even though my hand begged me to stop. It does create a smoother line in my opinion, but you need really strong shears.
summary: My go to product for borders

reviewText:
I have an older Weber Genesis Silver B from around 2002 (with a thermometer that is mounted on the right side of the lid, rather than in the center of the lid).  Its original thermometer stopped functioning after about 8 years.  I then went for several years without a working thermometer.  Finally, I decided to replace it.

In case you have the same older Weber Genesis Silver B...yes, this is the correct thermometer.  And it works great.  It appears that this part is discontinued.  So, grab one while you can!
summary: Perfect for Genesis Silver B from around 2002
